aadd.summary: Add a new element to the end of an array.
aadd.param: The array to add a new element to.

The value assigned to the new element. If <uNewElement> is another array, the new element in the target array will contain a reference to the array specified by <uNewElement>, rather than the array itself.
aadd.remarks: AAdd() increases the actual length of the target array by one. The newly created array element is assigned the value specified by <uNewElement>. AAdd() is used to dynamically increase the size of an array. It is useful for building dynamic lists or queues. A good example of this is the GetList array used to hold Get objects. AAdd() is similar to ASize() but only adds one element at a time; ASize() can change an array to a specified size. AAdd(), however, has the advantage that it can assign a value to the new element, while ASize() cannot. AAdd() seems similar to AIns(), but they are different: AIns() moves elements within an array, but it does not change the array's length.

abs.summary: Return the absolute value of a numeric expression, regardless of its sign.
abs.remarks: Absolute value is the same as <nValue> if <nValue> is greater than or equal to 0. It is the negation of <nValue> if <nValue> is less than 0. Abs() lets you get the difference between the magnitude of two numbers, where magnitude is the distance from the origin or zero.
abs.example:
These examples show typical results from Abs():
nNum1 := 100 nNum2 := 150 ? nNum1 - nNum2 // -50 ? ABS(nNum1 - nNum2) // 50 ? ABS(nNum2 - nNum1) // 50 ? ABS(-12) // 12 ? ABS(0) // 0 nSouth := -5 nNorth := 4 ? ABS(nSouth) - ABS(nNorth) // 1 ? ABS(nSouth) > ABS(nNorth) // TRUE ? nSouth > nNorth // FALSE

absfloat.summary: Return the absolute value of a strongly typed numeric expression, regardless of its sign.
absfloat.param: The floating point number to evaluate.
absfloat.remarks: AbsFloat() is the same as Abs() except that it is strongly typed. For more information, see Abs().
absfloat.example:
These examples show typical results from AbsFloat():
LOCAL fNum1 := 99.99 AS FLOAT LOCAL fNum2 := 149.99 AS FLOAT ? fNum1 - fNum2 // -50.00 ? AbsFloat(fNum1 - fNum2) // 50.00 ? AbsFloat(fNum2 - fNum1) // 50.00 ? AbsFloat(-12) // 12 ? AbsFloat(0) // 0

absint.summary: Return the absolute value of a strongly typed numeric expression, regardless of its sign.
absint.remarks: AbsInt() is the same as Abs() except that it is strongly typed. For more information, see Abs().
absint.example:
These examples show typical results from AbsInt():
LOCAL iNum1 := 100 AS INT LOCAL iNum2 := 150 AS INT ? iNum1 - iNum2 // -50 ? AbsInt(iNum1 - iNum2) // 50 ? AbsInt(iNum2 - iNum1) // 50 ? AbsInt(-12) // 12 ? AbsInt(0) // 0

abslong.summary: Return the absolute value of a strongly typed numeric expression, regardless of its sign.
abslong.remarks: AbsLong() is the same as Abs() except that it is strongly typed. For more information, see Abs().
abslong.example:
These examples show typical results from AbsLong():
LOCAL liNum1 := 100 AS LONGINT LOCAL liNum2 := 150 AS LONGINT ? liNum1 - liNum2 // -50 ? AbsLong(liNum1 - liNum2) // 50 ? AbsLong(liNum2 - liNum1) // 50 ? AbsLong(-12) // 12 ? AbsLong(0) // 0

absreal4.summary: Return the absolute value of a strongly typed numeric expression, regardless of its sign.
absreal4.param: The 32-bit floating point number to evaluate.
absreal4.remarks: AbsReal4() is the same as Abs() except that it is strongly typed. For more information, see Abs().
absreal4.example:
These examples show typical results from AbsReal4():
LOCAL r4Num1 := 99.99 AS REAL4 LOCAL r4Num2 := 149.99 AS REAL4 ? r4Num1 - r4Num2 // -50.00 ? AbsReal4(r4Num1 - r4Num2) // 50.00 ? AbsReal4(r4Num2 - r4Num1) // 50.00 ? AbsReal4(-12) // 12 ? AbsReal4(0) // 0

absreal8.summary: Return the absolute value of a strongly typed numeric expression, regardless of its sign.
absreal8.param: The 64-bit floating point number to evaluate.
absreal8.remarks: AbsReal8() is the same as Abs() except that it is strongly typed. For more information, see Abs().
absreal8.example:
These examples show typical results from AbsReal8():
LOCAL r8Num1 := 99.99 AS REAL8 LOCAL r8Num2 := 149.99 AS REAL8 ? r8Num1 - r8Num2 // -50.00 ? AbsReal8(r8Num1 - r8Num2) // 50.00 ? AbsReal8(r8Num2 - r8Num1) // 50 ? AbsReal8(-12) // 12 ? AbsReal8(0) // 0

absshort.summary: Return the absolute value of a strongly typed numeric expression, regardless of its sign.
absshort.remarks: AbsShort() is the same as Abs() except that it is strongly typed. For more information, see Abs().
absshort.example:
These examples show typical results from AbsShort():
LOCAL siNum1 := 100 AS SHORTINT LOCAL siNum2 := 150 AS SHORTINT ? siNum1 - siNum2 // -50 ? AbsShort(siNum1 - siNum2) // 50 ? AbsShort(siNum2 - siNum1) // 50 ? AbsShort(-12) // 12 ? AbsShort(0) // 0

aclone.remarks: AClone() creates a complete duplicate of <aSource>. If <aSource> contains subarrays, AClone() creates matching subarrays and fills them with copies of the values in the <aSource> subarrays. To copy subarrays by reference instead of creating new ones, use ACloneShallow().

acloneshallow.summary: Duplicate an array without its subarrays.
acloneshallow.returns: A duplicate of <aSource> without its subarrays.
acloneshallow.remarks: ACloneShallow() creates a duplicate of <aSource>. Unlike AClone(), ACloneShallow() does not check to see if <aSource> contains subarrays and does not copy them if they exist. ACloneShallow() also works differently from AClone() in that AClone() duplicates by recursively traversing the source array. ACloneShallow() first builds the target array structure from information derived directly from the source array, then copies the first-dimension values to the target. If an element of the source array is a subarray, the target array will contain a reference to the subarray.

acopy.summary: Copy elements from one array to another.
acopy.param: The array to copy elements from.
The array to copy elements to.

The starting element position in <aSource>. A negative value starts from the end. If <nCount> is positive, the default value is 1; if <nCount> is negative, the default value is the length of the array.

The number of elements to copy from <aSource>, beginning at <nStart>. A negative value starts from the end. If <nCount> is not specified, all elements in <aSource> beginning with the starting element are copied.
The starting element position in <aTarget> to receive elements from <aSource>. The default value is 1.
acopy.remarks: ACopy() copies elements from <aSource> to <aTarget>. <aTarget> must already exist and be large enough to hold the copied elements. If <aSource> has more elements, some elements will not be copied. ACopy() copies values of all data types. If an element of <aSource> is a subarray, the corresponding element in <aTarget> will contain only a reference to the subarray. Thus, ACopy() will not create a complete duplicate of a multidimensional array. To do this, use the AClone() function.

acot.summary: Calculate the arc cotangent of a number.
acot.returns: A number between -PI/2 and PI/2, representing the angle, in radians, whose cotangent is equal to <nNum>.
acot.example: This examples uses ACot() to find the angle whose cotangent is 20: ? ACot(20) // .05 radians

adel.param: The array to delete an element from.
The position of the element to delete.
adel.remarks: When an element is deleted from an array, its content is lost, and all elements from that position to the end of the array are shifted up one element. The last element in the array becomes NIL.

adir.summary: Fill a series of arrays with directory information. Note: ADir() is a compatibility function and therefore not recommended. It is superseded by the Directory() function, which returns all file information in a multidimensional array.
adir.param: The file specification for the directory search. Besides a file name, this specification may include an optional drive, directory, and extension. The file name and extension may include the standard wildcard characters (* and ?). If you do not specify a drive and directory, this function uses the SetDefault() setting.
The array to fill with the file names matching <cFileSpec>. Each element will contain the file name and extension as a string, in all uppercase letters.
The array to fill with the sizes of the corresponding files in <acFileNames>.
The array to fill with the dates of the corresponding files in <acFileNames>.
The array to fill with the times of the corresponding files in <acFileNames>, in the form hh:mm:ss.

The array to fill with attributes of the corresponding files in <acFileNames>. If <acAttributes> is specified, hidden, system, and directory files are included as well as normal files. If <acAttributes> is not specified, only normal files are included.
adir.returns: The number of files matching the directory skeleton described in <cFileSpec>.
adir.remarks:
ADir() performs two basic operations. First, it returns the number of files matching the file specification. Second, it fills a series of arrays with file names, sizes, dates, times, and attributes. Note that all of the array arguments must exist prior to calling this function and must be of a large enough size to hold the function results.
If you specify <acAttributes>, and <cFileSpec> contains a pattern, such as "*.*" or "*.", that matches directory names, directories are included in <acFileNames>. They are indicated with an attribute value of "D." If ADir() is executed within a subdirectory, the first two entries of <acFileNames> are "." and "..", the parent and current directory aliases. The date and time of last update are reported for directories, but the size of a directory is always 0.
adir.example:
This example creates an array to hold the names of all .TXT files in the current default directory, then uses AEval() to list them to the console:
LOCAL aFiles AS ARRAY aFiles := ArrayCreate(ADir("*.txt")) ADir("*.txt", aFiles) AEval(aFiles, {|element| QOut(element)})

adjustfname.summary: Remove spaces from a file name specified as a string.
adjustfname.param: The file name you want to adjust.
adjustfname.example:
This example shows how AdjustFName() removes the spaces from a file name without affecting the original file name:
cFile := " BadFileName .DBF" ? AdjustFName(cFile) // "BadFileName.DBF" ? cFile // " BadFileName .DBF"

adjustfnamea.summary: Remove spaces from a file name specified as a string, changing the contents of the original file name as well as the returned file name.
adjustfnamea.param: The file name you want to adjust.
adjustfnamea.remarks: AdjustFNameA() is the same as AdjustFName(), except that AdjustFNameA() removes the spaces from the original file name as well as those in the return value.
adjustfnamea.example:
This example shows how AdjustFNameA() returns a new file name with spaces removed and adjusts the original file name as well:
cFile := " BadFileName .DBF" ? AdjustFNameA(cFile) // "BadFileName.DBF" ? cFile // "BadFileName.DBF"

adjustfnamepsz.summary: Remove spaces from a file name specified as a PSZ, changing the contents of the original file name as well as the returned file name.
adjustfnamepsz.param: The file name you want to adjust, specified as a null-terminated string.
adjustfnamepsz.remarks: AdjustFNamePsz() is the same as AdjustFNameA(), except that its argument and return value are type PSZ instead of string.

aeval.summary: Execute a code block for each element in an array.
aeval.param: The starting element. A negative value starts from the end. If <nCount> is positive, the default value is 1; if <nCount> is negative, the default value is the length of the array.
The number of elements to process from <nStart>. A negative value starts from the end. The default is all elements to the end of the array.
aeval.returns: A reference to <aArray>. The return value of the code block or is ignored — to assign the return value to each element in the array, use the AEvalA() function.
aeval.remarks:
AEval() passes the element value and the element index as arguments. AEval() makes no assumptions about the contents of the array elements it is passing. It is assumed that the supplied code block knows what type of data will be in each element. AEval() is similar to DBEval() which executes code for each record of a database file. Like DBEval(), AEval() can be used as a primitive for the construction of iteration commands for both simple and complex array structures.
In Visual Objects and Vulcan.Net 2 different functions were introduced: AEval() and AEvalOld(). The difference between these functions was that AEval() was only calling the codeblock with one parameter (the element in the array), where AEvalOld() was also passing in a second parameter (the array index). Inside X# this difference no longer exists. So AEval() and AEvalOld() are doing the same thing in X#.
aeval.example:
This example displays the contents of a one-dimensional array:
LOCAL aArray[6] AFill(aArray, "Hi All!") // Fill up all elements AEval(aArray, {|Element| QOut(Element)})
This example uses AEval() to display an array of file names and file sizes returned from the Directory() function:
LOCAL aFiles := Directory("*.dbf") LOCAL nTotal := 0 AEval(aFiles, {|aDBFFile | QOut(PadR(aDBFFile[F_NAME], 10), ; aDBFFile[F_SIZE], nTotal += aDBFFile[F_SIZE]}) ? "Total bytes:", nTotal

aevala.summary: Execute a code block for each element in an array and assign the return value to each element in the array.
aevala.param: The starting element. A negative value starts from the end. If <nCount> is positive, the default value is 1; if <nCount> is negative, the default value is the length of the array.
The number of elements to process from <nStart>. A negative value starts from the end. The default is all elements to the end of the array.
aevala.remarks: AEvalA() is similar to AEval() in that they both evaluate a code block once for each element of an array, passing the element value as an argument. The difference is that while AEval() ignores the return value of the code block, AEvalA() assigns the return value to the array element. See AEval() for details.
aevala.example:
This example uses AEvalA() to create an array of file names in lowercase:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL aFiles := Directory("*.dbf") LOCAL nTotal AS SHORTINT AEvalA(aFiles,{|aDBFFile| LOWER(PadR(aDBFFile[F_NAME], 10))})

aevalold.summary: Execute a code block for each element in an array.
aevalold.param: The starting element. A negative value starts from the end. If <nCount> is positive, the default value is 1; if <nCount> is negative, the default value is the length of the array.
The number of elements to process from <nStart>. A negative value starts from the end. The default is all elements to the end of the array.
aevalold.returns: A reference to <aArray>. The return value of the code block is ignored. To assign the return value of the code block to each element in the array, use the AEvalA() function.
aevalold.remarks:
AEvalOld() passes the element value and the element index as arguments. AEvalOld() makes no assumptions about the contents of the array elements it is passing. It is assumed that the supplied code block knows what type of data will be in each element. AEvalOld() is similar to DBEval() which executes code for each record of a database file. Like DBEval(), AEvalOld() can be used as a primitive for the construction of iteration commands for both simple and complex array structures.
In Visual Objects and Vulcan.Net 2 different functions were introduced: AEval() and AEvalOld(). The difference between these functions was that AEval() was only calling the codeblock with one parameter (the element in the array), where AEvalOld() was also passing in a second parameter (the array index). Inside X# this difference no longer exists. So AEval() and AEvalOld() are doing the same thing in X#.
aevalold.example:
This example uses AEvalOld() to display an array of file names and file sizes returned from the Directory() function:
LOCAL aFiles := Directory("*.dbf") LOCAL nTotal := 0 AEvalOld(aFiles, {| aDBFFile | QOut(PadR(aDBFFile[F_NAME], 10), ; aDBFFile[F_SIZE]), aDBFFile[F_SIZE]), nTotal += aDBFFile[F_SIZE]}) ? "Total Bytes:", nTotal
This next example changes the contents of the array element depending on a condition. If the condition is false, array elements are merely displayed. Notice the use of the code block arguments:
LOCAL aArray[6] AFill (aArray, "old") AEvalOld (aArray, {|cValue, nIndex| IF(cValue == "old",; ArrayPut (aArray, nIndex,"new"),QOut(cValue))})

afields.summary: Fill arrays with the structure of the current database file. Note: AFields() is a compatibility function and therefore not recommended. It is superseded by DBStruct(), which does not require the existence of any arrays prior to invocation and returns a multidimensional array containing the current database file structure.
afields.param: The array to fill with field names.
The array to fill with the type of fields in <acFieldNames>.
The array to fill with the widths of fields in <acFieldNames>.
The array to fill with the number of decimals defined for fields in <acFieldNames>. If the field type is not numeric, the system assigns 0 to <anDecimals>.
afields.returns: The number of fields or the length of the shortest array argument, whichever is less. If no arguments are specified, or if there is no file in use in the current work area, AFields() returns 0.
afields.remarks: AFields() fills a series of arrays (structure attribute arrays) with the structure of the database file currently open, one element in each array per field. AFields() works like ADir(), filling a series of existing arrays with information. To use AFields(), you must first create the arrays to hold the database structure information, each with the same number of elements as the number of fields (that is, FCount()). Once the structure attribute arrays exist, you can then invoke AFields() to fill them with information about each field.
afields.example:
This example uses AFields() with an aliased expression to fill arrays with the structure of SALES.DBF, open in an unselected work area:
PROCEDURE Start() LOCAL acFieldNames, aTypes, aWidths, ; aDecimals AS ARRAY USE sales NEW USE customer NEW acFieldNames := Sales->(ArrayNew(FCount())) acTypes := Sales->(ArrayNew(FCount())) anWidths := Sales->(ArrayNew(FCount())) anDecimals := Sales->(ArrayNew(FCount())) Sales->(AFields(acFieldNames, acTypes, anWidths, anDecimals))

afill.summary: Fill array elements with a specified value.
afill.param: The value to place in each array element.
The starting element. A negative value starts from the end. If <nCount> is positive, the default value is 1; if <nCount> is negative, the default value is the length of the array.
The number of elements to process from <nStart>. A negative value starts from the end. The default is all elements to the end of the array.
afill.remarks: AFill() fills the specified array with a single value of any data type by assigning <uValue> to each array element in the specified range. Using AFill with a multidimensional array could overwrite subarrays used for the other dimensions of the array.

ains.summary: Insert an element into an array and assign it a NIL value.
ains.param: The array into which the element will be inserted.
The position at which the element will be inserted.
ains.remarks: AIns() inserts a new element into a specified array. The newly inserted element is NIL until a new value is assigned to it. After the insertion, the last element in the array is discarded, and all elements after the new element are shifted down one position. AIns() must be used carefully with multidimensional arrays. Using AIns() in a multidimensional array discards the last element in the specified target array which, if it is an array element, will cause one or more dimensions to be lost. To insert a new dimension into an array, first add a new element to the end of the array using AAdd() or ASize() before using AIns().

alen.summary: Return the number of elements in an array.
alen.returns: The number of elements in the array. If the array is empty, ALen() returns 0.
alen.remarks: If the array is multidimensional, subarrays count as one element. This means that the ALen() of a multidimensional array simply returns the length of the first dimension. To determine the number of elements in other dimensions, use ALen() on the subarrays, as shown in the example below. (Note that multidimensional arrays in X# need not have uniform dimensions.)
alen.example:
This example creates a literal 2-dimensional array, then returns the array and the number of elements in the subarray that is contained in the first element of the array:
LOCAL aArray := {{1, 2}, {1, 2}, {1, 2}} ? ALen(aArray) // 3 ? ALen(aArray[1]) // 2
This example navigates a multidimensional array using ALen():
LOCAL aArray := {{1, 2}, {1, 2}, {1, 2}} LOCAL nRow, nColumn AS SHORTINT LOCAL nRowCount, nColumnCount AS SHORTINT nRowCount = ALen(aArray) FOR nRow := 1 UPTO nRowCount nColumnCount = ALen(aArray[nRow]) FOR nColumn := 1 UPTO nColumnCount ? nRow, nColumn, aArray[nRow][nColumn] NEXT NEXT
In this example, a function returns an array of numeric values that describe the dimensions of a multidimensional array. The function assumes that the array has uniform dimensions:
FUNCTION Dimensions(aArray) LOCAL aDims := {} DO WHILE IsArray(aArray) AADD(aDims, ALen(aArray)) aArray := aArray[1] ENDDO RETURN (aDims)

alias.summary: Return the alias of a specified work area as a string.
alias.param: Any work area name or number. If not specified, the alias of the current work area is returned.
alias.returns: If there is no database file in use, Alias() returns a NULL_STRING.
alias.remarks: Alias() is the inverse of Select(). Alias() returns the alias name given the work area number, while Select() returns the work area number given the alias name.
alias.example:
This example returns the name of the previously selected work area:
USE file1 NEW ALIAS Test1 nOldArea := Select() USE file2 NEW ALIAS Test2 QOut(Alias(nOldArea)) // Returns: Test1

alias0.summary: Return the alias of the current work area as a string.
alias0.returns: If there is no database file in use, Alias0() returns a NULL_STRING.
alias0.remarks:
Alias0() is the same as Alias() except that Alias0() accepts no arguments. (This is indicated by the "0" in the function name.) Therefore, when no argument is required, Alias0() should be used instead of Alias() to increase program efficiency.
This example returns the name of the current work area:
USE file1 NEW ALIAS Test1 QOut(Alias0()) // Returns: Test1

alias0sym.summary: Return the alias of the current work area as a symbol.
alias0sym.returns: If there is no database file in use for the current work area, Alias0Sym() returns a NULL_SYMBOL.
alias0sym.remarks:
Alias0Sym() is the same as Alias0() except that it returns the alias as a symbol.
This example returns the name of the current work area:
USE mydbf QOut(Alias0Sym()) // Returns: "MYDBF" QOut(Alias0Sym() = #MYDBF) // Returns: TRUE

alltrim.summary: Remove leading and trailing spaces from a string.
alltrim.returns: A trimmed string, with leading and trailing spaces removed.
alltrim.remarks: AllTrim() is related to LTrim() and RTrim(), which remove leading and trailing spaces, respectively. The inverse of AllTrim(), LTrim(), and RTrim() are the PadC(), PadL(), and PadR() functions, which center, left-justify, and right-justify strings by padding them with fill characters.
alltrim.example:
This example creates a string with both leading and trailing spaces, then trims them with AllTrim():
LOCAL cString AS STRING cString := SPACE(10) + "string" + SPACE(10) ? SLen(cString) // 26 ? SLen(ALLTRIM(cString)) // 6

altd.summary: Either determine whether the Debugger can be invoked manually or programmatically define a breakpoint in an application.
altd.param: Enables or disables your ability to invoke the Debugger manually, as defined in the table below:
Disables the ability to invoke the Debugger manually with Ctrl+Alt+SysRq
Enables the ability to invoke the Debugger manually with Ctrl+Alt+SysRq (this is the default)
altd.remarks: AltD() is operational only if the application is being executed by the Debugger (that is, using the Trace Expression toolbar button or Debug Run menu command). See "Debugging Your Applications" in the IDE User Guide for more information on using the Debugger. Note: AltD(0) has no effect on breakpoints set from within the Debugger or programmatic breakpoints set with AltD(). Breakpoints will always return control to the Debugger, regardless of the status of Ctrl+Alt+SysRq.
altd.example:
This example shows how to temporarily disable Ctrl+Alt+SysRq for one function:
DEFINE ALTD_ENABLE := 1 DEFINE ALTD_DISABLE := 0 FUNCTION Good() ... AltD(ALTD_DISABLE) ... AltD(ALTD_ENABLE) RETURN Value
This example shows how to define a breakpoint in a function using AltD():
FUNCTION Bad() ... AltD() // Programmatic breakpoint ... RETURN Value

ampm.summary: Convert a 24-hour military time to a 12-hour clock time.
ampm.param: A valid military time in the form hh:mm:ss, where hh is hours in 24-hour format, mm is minutes, and ss is seconds.
ampm.returns: An 11-character string in 12-hour format with either "am" or "pm." If <cTime> does not represent a valid military time, a NULL_STRING is returned.
ampm.example:
These examples use AmPm():
? AmPm("10:45:23") // 10:45:23 am ? AmPm("22:45:23") // 10:45:23 pm ? AmPm("10:45:23Hello") // NULL_STRING ? AmPm("1045") // NULL_STRING ? AmPm("10:45") // NULL_STRING

ansi2oem.summary: Convert a string of ANSI characters to OEM characters.
ansi2oem.param: A source string of ANSI characters.
ansi2oem.returns: A converted string of OEM characters.
ansi2oem.remarks: Ansi2Oem() changes the individual characters in the source string to matching characters from the OEM character set. This may need to be done because certain symbols, such as ä, have different code values in the ANSI and OEM character sets. DOS applications creating a file with ä as part of the file name use the OEM code values and place 132 into the directory entry. But Windows applications with ANSI code values use 228 for ä and thus cannot find the file. To get around this problem, you can use Ansi2Oem() to convert ANSI file names to the OEM character set. Also, if characters written to files by Windows applications are in the ANSI character set, the same character conversion problem might arise when DOS applications read the file.
ansi2oem.example: This example writes the string "aá.TXT" to a DOS file. Note that á has the code value 225 in the ANSI character set, while in the OEM character set, code value 225 corresponds to the ß character. The FWrite() functions assume raw binary data and thus does not automatically convert ANSI to OEM. (If desired, you could do the conversion yourself or use other functions such as FWriteText().) FWrite(ptrFileHandle, Ansi2Oem("aá.txt"))

ansi2oema.summary: Convert a string of ANSI characters to OEM characters, changing the contents of the original string as well as the returned string.
ansi2oema.param: A source string of ANSI characters.
ansi2oema.returns: A converted string of OEM characters.
ansi2oema.remarks: Ansi2OemA() is the same as Ansi2Oem(), except that Ansi2OemA() also replaces the contents of the original string with OEM characters.
ansi2oema.example:
This example converts the contents of a string containing the characters ßä from ANSI to OEM.
LOCAL cString AS STRING cString := "ßä" Ansi2OEMA(cString) // Converts ßä to OEM

ansi2oembuff.summary: Convert a specified number of ANSI characters in a source buffer to a buffer of corresponding OEM characters.
ansi2oembuff.param: A pointer to the buffer that will contain the converted string.
A pointer to the buffer that contains the string to convert.
The number of characters to convert.
ansi2oembuff.returns: A pointer to the buffer that contains the converted string.
ansi2oembuff.remarks:
Ansi2OemBuff() is similar to Ansi2Oem(), except that the resulting string is stored in the buffer pointed to by <pszTarget>. Also, the <dwCount> argument lets you specify the number of characters to be converted.
You are responsible for allocating space for the buffer pointed to by <pszTarget>. Using an unallocated buffer pointer can have adverse results.
ansi2oembuff.example:
This example uses Ansi2OemBuff() to convert the contents of the ANSI string "ßä" to the OEM character set. Note that the source string is also used as a target string:
LOCAL cStr := "ßä" Ansi2OemBuff(PSZ(_CAST, cStr), PSZ(_CAST, cStr), SLen(cStr))

areplicate.summary: To create an array and fill its elements with a default value.
areplicate.param: The value with which to fill the array.
areplicate.returns: An array <nElements> elements long, each element containing <xFill>.
areplicate.example: This example creates an array of 10 elements and fills it with zeros: aNewArray := AReplicate(0, 10) This example creates an array of 5 elements and fills it with "Empty" strings: aEmptyArray := AReplicate("Empty", 5)

arraybuild.remarks: ArrayBuild() creates an empty array. It is the functional form of an empty array assignment like this: aMyArray := {} Note, however, that within the generic {} you are allowed to list other values while ArrayBuild() does not take any arguments. To create uninitialized arrays of specified length, see ArrayCreate() and ArrayNew(). To create initialized arrays, see ArrayInit().

arraycreate.param: The number of elements in the array.
arraycreate.remarks: ArrayCreate() returns an uninitialized array with only one dimension. To create uninitialized multidimensional arrays, see ArrayNew().
arraycreate.example:
This example creates a one-dimensional array of five elements using ArrayCreate(), then shows the equivalent action by assigning a literal array of NIL values:
LOCAL aArray AS ARRAY aArray := ArrayCreate(5) aArray := {NIL, NIL, NIL, NIL, NIL}
This example creates an array of numbers and puts values in the elements:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL aArray AS ARRAY aArray := ArrayCreate(3) ArrayPut(aArray, 1, 1) ArrayPut(aArray, 2, 10) ArrayPut(aArray, 3, 100)

arraydeprotect.summary: Removes write protection from an entire array.
arraydeprotect.returns: TRUE if the array was successfully deprotected; otherwise, FALSE.
arraydeprotect.remarks: ArrayDeprotect() removes the protection placed on an array by the ArrayProtect() function, allowing their values to be changed.
arraydeprotect.example:
This example stores values to array elements, protects the elements, then removes the protection so they can be changed:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL aWriteProtect AS ARRAY aWriteProtect := ArrayCreate(2) ArrayPut(aWriteProtect, 1, "Origin") ArrayPut(aWriteProtect, 2, "Origin") ArrayProtect(aWriteProtect) // Write allowed in calling function ArrayPut(aWriteProtect, 1, "Main Function") // Write not allowed in called function TryChange(aWriteProtect) ArrayDeprotect(aWriteProtect) // Write allowed (no protection) TryChange(aWriteProtect) FUNCTION TryChange(aPassed) ArrayPut(aPassed, 1, "Sub Function")

arrayget.param: The number of the element to read.
arrayget.returns: The value held by the element.
arrayget.remarks: ArrayGet() reads and returns an array element's value.
arrayget.example:
This example creates an array and prints the values:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL aStates[3] LOCAL i AS SHORTINT ArrayPut(aStates, 1, "Montana") ArrayPut(aStates, 2, "Wyoming") ArrayPut(aStates, 3, "Idaho") FOR i := 1 UPTO ALen(aStates) QOut(ArrayGet(aStates, i)) NEXT // Below we print the same array in two different // ways from the above: // Functional equivalent of FOR...NEXT AEval(aStates, {|Element| QOut(Element)}) // Using [] to get an array element FOR i := 1 UPTO ALen(aStates) QOut(aStates[i]) NEXT

arrayinit.returns: An initialized array with the specified number of elements and referenced values in each element.
arrayinit.remarks: ArrayInit() builds an array with the specified number of elements and initializes the elements with the pointer contents. At least <wElements> data of type USUAL must be at the location referenced by <>. To create an uninitialized array, see ArrayNew().
arrayinit.example:
This example creates and initializes a 2-element array. An existing DIM array serves as the pointer to the initialized data:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL aOffsets AS ARRAY LOCAL DIM aDimPoint[2] AS USUAL aDimPoint[1] := "Hello" aDimPoint[2] := "World!" aOffsets := ArrayInit(2, @aDimPoint)

arraynew.summary: Create an uninitialized array with the specified number of elements and dimensions.
arraynew.param: A comma-separated list representing the number of elements in each dimension. If more than one element number is specified, a multidimensional array is created with the number of dimensions equal to the number of arguments in <wElementList>.
arraynew.remarks: In X#, there are several ways to create an array: Declare an array using a declaration statement such as LOCAL or STATIC. Create an array using a PRIVATE or PUBLIC statement. Assign a literal array to an existing variable. Use the ArrayNew() function. ArrayNew() has the advantage that it can create arrays within expressions or code blocks. You can also use the ArrayBuild() function to create empty arrays, the ArrayCreate() function to create one-dimensional arrays, or ArrayInit() to create initialized arrays.

arrayprotect.summary: Protect an array from change in all functions except the one in which it was declared.
arrayprotect.returns: TRUE if the array was successfully protected; otherwise, FALSE.
arrayprotect.remarks: ArrayProtect() protects array values from change once you assign values to them. The function in which the array is declared can still write to the array.
arrayprotect.example:
This example stores values to array elements, protects the elements, then removes the protection so they can be changed by sub-functions:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL aWriteProtect AS ARRAY aWriteProtect := ArrayCreate(2) ArrayPut(aWriteProtect, 1, "Origin") ArrayPut(aWriteProtect, 2, "Origin") ArrayProtect(aWriteProtect) // Write allowed in calling function ArrayPut(aWriteProtect, 1, "Main Function") // Write not allowed in called function TryChange(aWriteProtect) ArrayDeprotect(aWriteProtect) // Write allowed (no protection) TryChange(aWriteProtect) FUNCTION TryChange(aPassed) ArrayPut(aPassed, 1, "Sub Function")

arrayput.summary: Write a value to an array element.
arrayput.param: The number of the array element to receive the value.
The value to write to the array element.
arrayput.remarks: ArrayPut() writes values to specified array elements. If a value is already there, it is overwritten.
arrayput.example:
This example writes values to array elements:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL aStates[2] ArrayPut(aStates, 1, "Montana") ArrayPut(aStates, 2, "Wyoming") // Below we get the same result by using [] aStates[1] := "Montana" aStates[2] := "Wyoming"

arraystore.summary: Store an array to a buffer.
arraystore.param: The array to be stored to a buffer.
arraystore.returns: The number of bytes stored to the buffer.
arraystore.remarks: Stores the contents of an array into the buffer pointed by <Buff>. You should insure that the buffer is allocated and is large enough before writing to it.
arraystore.example:
This example writes an array's elemental values to a buffer. A DIM array serves as the destination pointer:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL DIM aDestination[4] AS USUAL LOCAL aList[4] ArrayPut(aList, 1, 1) ArrayPut(aList, 2, 3) ArrayPut(aList, 3, 5) ArrayPut(aList, 4, 7) ArrayStore(aList, @aDestination, 4*6) ? aDestination[1] // Result: 1 ? aDestination[2] // Result: 3 ? aDestination[3] // Result: 5 ? aDestination[4] // Result: 7

arrayswap.summary: Replace an array element with a new value and return the old value.
arrayswap.param: The array whose element will be replaced with a new value.
The number of the element to be replaced.
arrayswap.returns: The value that was replaced by <uNewValue>.
arrayswap.remarks: ArraySwap() replaces the element specified with a new value.
arrayswap.example:
This example swaps the second and third elements of an array:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL aList[4] ArrayPut(aList, 1, "First") ArrayPut(aList, 2, "Second") ArrayPut(aList, 3, "Third") ArrayPut(aList, 4, "Fourth") aList[3] := ArraySwap(aList, 2, aList[3])

asc.summary: Convert a character to its ASCII value.
asc.param: The character to convert to a number.
asc.returns: A number from 0 to 255, representing the ASCII code of < cString >.
asc.remarks: Asc() is a character conversion function that returns the ASCII value of the leftmost character in a string. Asc() is used primarily on expressions requiring numeric calculations on the ASCII value of a character. Chr() and Asc() are inverse functions.
asc.example:
These examples illustrate various results of Asc():
? Asc("A") // 65 ? Asc("Apple") // 65 ? Asc("a") // 97 ? Asc("Z") - Asc("A") // 25 ? Asc(NULL_STRING) // 0 ? Asc(Chr(0)) // 0

ascan.summary: Scan an array until a value is found or a code block returns TRUE.
ascan.param: The value to scan for. Unless this argument is a code block, it must match the data type of the elements in <aTarget>.
The starting element. A negative value starts from the end. If <nCount> is positive, the default value is 1; if <nCount> is negative, the default value is the length of the array.
The number of elements to process from <nStart>. A negative value starts from the end. The default is all elements to the end of the array.
ascan.returns: If <uSearch> is a code block, AScan() returns the position of the first element for which the code block returns TRUE. Otherwise, AScan() returns the position of the first matching element. AScan() returns 0 if no match is found.
ascan.remarks: If <uSearch> is not a code block, its value is compared to the first target element. If there is no match, AScan() proceeds to the next element in the array. This process continues until either a match is found or the range of elements to scan is exhausted. If <uSearch> is a code block, AScan() scans <aTarget>, executing the code block for each element accessed. As each element is encountered, AScan() passes the element's value as an argument to the code block, then performs an Eval() on the code block. The scanning operation stops when the code block returns TRUE or when the range of elements to scan is exhausted. Note: Values are compared using the = operator. For exact matching (that is, using the == operator), use AScanExact().
ascan.example:
This example demonstrates scanning a 3-element array, using both a string and a code block as search criteria. The code block criteria shows how to perform a case-insensitive search:
aArray := {"Tom", "Mary", "Sue"} ? AScan(aArray, "Mary") // 2 ? AScan(aArray, "mary") // 0 ? AScan(aArray, ; {|x| Upper(x) = "MARY"}) // 2
This example demonstrates scanning for multiple instances of a search argument after a match is found:
LOCAL aArray := {"Tom", "Mary", "Sue", "Mary"} LOCAL nStart := 1 LOCAL iAtEnd, iPos AS INT // Get last array element position iAtEnd := 4 DO WHILE (iPos := AScan(aArray, "Mary", nStart)) > 0 ? iPos, aArray[iPos] // Get new starting position and test boundary condition IF (nStart += iPos) > iAtEnd EXIT ENDIF ENDDO
This example scans a 2-dimensional array using a code block. Note that the argument aVal in the code block is an array:
LOCAL aArr := {} AAdd(aArr,{"one", "two"}) AAdd(aArr,{"three", "four"}) AAdd(aArr,{"five", "six"}) ? AScan(aArr, {|aVal| aVal[2] = "four"}) // 2

ascanbin.summary: Scan a sorted array until a value is found or a code block returns 0.
ascanbin.param: The value to scan for. Unless this argument is a code block, it must match the data type of the elements in <aTarget>. If <uSearch> is a code block, it should return a numeric value that indicates the outcome of the comparison: a positive value indicates that <uSearch> is greater than the current array element, a 0 stands for equality, and a negative value indicates that <uSearch> is less than the current array element.
ascanbin.returns: If <uSearch> is a code block, AScanBin() returns the position of the element if the code block returned a value of zero. Otherwise, AScanBin() returns the position of a matching element. If multiple occurrences of the same element exist, the returned match is not necessarily the lowest numbered element since AScanBin() uses a binary search algorithm. AScanBin() returns 0 if no match is found.
ascanbin.remarks: AScanBin() scans an array for a specified value. If <uSearch> is a code block, AScanBin() scans <aTarget>, by using a binary search algorithm and executes the code block for each element accessed. As each element is encountered, AScanBin() passes the element's value as an argument to the code block, then performs an Eval() on the code block. The scanning operation stops when the code block returns a value of zero or when the range of elements to scan is exhausted. Note: Values are compared using the = operator. For exact matching (that is, using the == operator), use AScanBinExact().
ascanbin.example:
This example demonstrates scanning a 3-element array, using both a string and a code block as search criteria. The code block criteria shows how to perform a case-insensitive search:
aArray := {"Tom", "Mary", "Sue"} ASort(aArray) ? AScanBin(aArray, "Mary") // 1 ? AScanBin(aArray, "mary") // 0 ? AScanBin(aArray, ; {|x| MyCompare(x, "MARY")}) // 1 FUNCTION MyCompare(cElement, cSearch) AS SHORTINT LOCAL siRet := 0 AS SHORTINT cElement := Upper(cElement) IF cSearch > cElement siRet := 1 ELSEIF cSearch < cElement siRet := -1 // ELSE defaults to the initial value of 0 ENDIF RETURN siRet

ascanbinexact.summary: Scan a sorted array until there is an exact match or a code block returns 0.
ascanbinexact.param: The value to scan for. Unless this argument is a code block, it must match the data type of the elements in <aTarget>. If <uSearch> is a code block, it should return a numeric value that indicates the outcome of the comparison: a positive value indicates that <uSearch> is greater than the current array element, a 0 stands for equality, and a negative value indicates that <uSearch> is less than the current array element.
ascanbinexact.returns: If <uSearch> is a code block, AScanBinExact() returns the position of the element if the code block returned 0. Otherwise, AScanBinExact() returns the position of an exact-matching element. If multiple occurrences of the same element exist, the returned exact match is not necessarily the lowest numbered element since AScanBinExact() uses a binary search algorithm. AScanBinExact() returns 0 if no exact match is found.
ascanbinexact.remarks: AScanBinExact() is the same as AScanBin() except that == is used for matching instead of =. See the "Operators and Expressions" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on how these operators work.
ascanbinexact.example:
This example shows the difference between AScanBinExact() and AScanBin():
aArray := {"Larger", "Largest"} // Already sorted ? "Larger" = "Large" // TRUE ? "Larger" == "Large" // FALSE ? AScanBin(aArray, "Large") // 1 ? AScanBinExact(aArray, "Large") // 0

ascanexact.summary: Scan an array until there is an exact match or a code block returns TRUE.
ascanexact.param: The value to scan for. Unless this argument is a code block, it must match the data type of the elements in <aTarget>.
The starting element. A negative value starts from the end. If <nCount> is positive, the default value is 1; if <nCount> is negative, the default value is the length of the array.
The number of elements to process from <nStart>. A negative value starts from the end. The default is all elements to the end of the array.
ascanexact.returns: If <uSearch> is a code block, AScanExact() returns the position of the element if the code block returned TRUE. Otherwise, AScanExact() returns the position of the first exact-matching element. AScanExact() returns 0 if no exact match is found.
ascanexact.remarks: AScanExact() is the same as AScan() except that == is used for matching instead of =. See the "Operators and Expressions" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on how these operators work.
ascanexact.example:
This example shows the difference between AScanExact() and AScan():
aArray := {"Larger", "Large"} ? "Larger" = "Large" // TRUE ? "Larger" == "Large" // FALSE ? AScan(aArray, "Large") // 1 ? AScanExact(aArray, "Large") // 2

asend.summary: Invoke a method for every element in an array of objects.
asend.param: The method name, specified without parentheses.
A comma-separated list of arguments to pass to <symMethod>.

asendclass.summary: Invoke a method of a specific class for every element in an array of objects.
asendclass.param: The method name, specified without parentheses.
A comma-separated list of arguments to pass to <symMethod>.

ashexstring.summary: Convert a value to a hexadecimal string.
ashexstring.example:
This example uses AsHexString() to display the hexadecimal dumps of different expressions:
LOCAL cAlpha AS STRING LOCAL siSum AS SHORTINT cAlpha := "ABCDEF" siSum := 100 ? AsHexString(cAlpha) // 41 42 43 44 45 46 ? AsHexString(siSum) // 00000064 ? AsHexString("abcdef") // 61 62 63 64 65 66

asize.param: The array to grow or shrink.
The new size of the array.
asize.remarks: ASize() changes the actual length of <aTarget>. The array is shortened or lengthened to match the specified length. If the array is shortened, elements at the end of the array are lost. If the array is lengthened, new elements are added to the end of the array and assigned NIL. ASize() is similar to AAdd(), which adds a single new element to the end of an array and optionally assigns a new value at the same time. Note that ASize() is different from AIns() and ADel(), which do not actually change the array's length.

asort.param: The starting element. The default value is 1.
The number of elements to process from <nStart>. The default is all elements to the end of the array.

A code block used to determine the sort order. This argument is used to change the sorting order to descending or dictionary order. Each time it is evaluated, two elements from the target array are passed as arguments. The code block returns TRUE if the elements are in sorted order. See the examples below.
The default sorting order is ascending:
Elements with low values are sorted toward the beginning of the array (the first element).
Elements with high values are sorted toward the end of the array (the last element)
asort.remarks: ASort() sorts all or part of an array. The array may contains USUALs of mixed types. Data types that can be sorted include character, date, logical, and numeric. Strings are sorted in ASCII sequence; logical values are sorted with FALSE as the low value; date values are sorted chronologically; and numeric values are sorted by magnitude. ASort() will not directly sort a multidimensional array. To sort a multidimensional array, you must supply a code block which properly handles the subarrays.

aspadr.summary: Convert a value to a right-padded string.
aspadr.param: The length of the padded string.
aspadr.returns: A right-padded string of length <wLen> containing the converted value.
aspadr.example: This example uses AsPadR() to compare a number with the contents of a character field: ? _FIELD->cRegion == AsPadR(2048, 10)

aspsz.summary: Convert a value to a static PSZ.
aspsz.returns: A PSZ to the static buffer containing the value in string form.
aspsz.remarks: AsPsz() is similar to AsString() except that AsPsz() does not use dynamic allocation. Another runtime function may overwrite the statically allocated buffer afterwards.
aspsz.example:
These examples show how to use AsPsz():
LOCAL pszNum AS PSZ LOCAL pszA AS PSZ pszNum := AsPsz(123456) pszA := AsPsz("hey" + Chr(0)+ "you")

asstring.summary: Convert a value to a string.
asstring.returns: A string containing the converted value. The converted string is dynamically allocated.
asstring.example:
These examples show how to use AsString():
LOCAL cNum AS STRING LOCAL cDate AS STRING cNum := AsString(123456) // Convert an empty date cDate := AsString(0.0.0)

assymbol.summary: Convert a string or a PSZ to a symbol.
assymbol.param: The value to be converted. Possible data types for <uValue> are STRING, PSZ, or SYMBOL.
assymbol.returns: The converted value as a symbol.
assymbol.example:
This example converts a string to a symbol. One reason for doing this is to boost performance, since symbol comparisons are faster than string comparisons.
symFind := AsSymbol("ALongPassword!") // Do a faster search AScan(aSymList, symFind)

at.summary: Return the position of the first occurrence of a substring within a string.
at.param: The string in which to search. (To start at a specific offset, use At3().)
at.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cSearch> within <cTarget>. If <cSearch> is not found, At() returns 0.
at.remarks: If you only need to know whether a substring exists within another string, use the InStr() function or the $ operator. To find the last occurrence of a substring within a string, use RAt(). Both the At() and RAt() functions are used with Substr(), Left(), and Right() to extract substrings.
at.example:
These examples show typical uses of At():
? At("a", "abcde") // 1 ? At("bcd", "abcde") // 2 ? At("a", "bcde") // 0
This example uses strong typing to split a string based on the position of a comma within the target string:
LOCAL cTarget AS STRING cTarget := "Langtree, Lilly" ? Substr(cTarget, 1, At(",", cTarget) - 1) // Langtree ? Substr(cTarget, At(",", cTarget) + 2) // Lilly

at2.summary: Return the position of the first occurrence of a substring within a string.
at2.param: The substring for which to search.
The string in which to search. (To start at a specific offset, use At3().)
at2.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cSearch> within <cTarget>. If <cSearch> is not found, At2() returns 0.
at2.remarks: At2() is like At() except that it returns a WORD. See At() for more information.

at3.summary: Return the position of the first occurrence of a substring within a string, starting at a specified position.
at3.param: The string in which to search.
The position in the string at which to start searching. A value of zero corresponds to the first byte.
at3.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cSearch> within <cTarget>. If <cSearch> is not found, At3() returns 0.
at3.remarks: At3() is the same as At(), except that you can specify an offset that tells where to start searching.
at3.example:
These examples show typical uses of At3():
? At3("a", "abcdeabc", 2) // 6 ? At3("a", "bcde", 1) // 0
This example displays the position of every occurrence of a string within the source:
LOCAL dwOffset AS DWORD LOCAL dwFound := 1 AS DWORD LOCAL cSource AS STRING LOCAL cSearch AS STRING cSource := "Now know-how is valued" cSearch := "ow" DO WHILE dwFound != 0 ? dwFound := At3(cSearch, cSource, wOffset) dwOffset := dwFound + SLen(cSearch) END

atail.summary: Return the highest numbered element of an array.
atail.returns: The contents of the last array element.
atail.remarks: ATail() returns the highest numbered element of an array. It can be used in applications as shorthand for <aArray>[ALen(<aArray>)] when you need to obtain the last element of an array.

atan.summary: Calculate the arc tangent of a number.
atan.returns: A number between -PI/2 and PI/2, representing the angle, in radians, whose tangent is equal to <nNum>.

remarks.note: The result only spans half a circle (from -PI/2 to PI/2). This implies that Tan() and ATan() are not inverse functions for values that do not lie between -PI/2 and PI/2. In other words, ATan(Tan(<n>)) does not always return <n>. See the example below.

atan.example:
This example shows that, for a value of -1+PI, ATan() is not the inverse of Tan() but, for a value of -1, ATan() is the inverse of Tan(). This is because the tangent of -1+PI is equal to Tan(-1+PI) or -1.56. The tangent of -1 is also equal to Tan(-1) or -1.56. The ATan() of -1.56 is ATan(-1.56) or -1. Thus ATan(Tan(-1)) equals -1. But ATan(Tan(-1+PI)) equals -1 which is not equal to -1+PI.
? ATan(Tan(-1+PI)) <> -1+PI // TRUE ? ATan(Tan(-1)) = -1 // TRUE

atc.summary: Return the position of the first occurrence of a substring within a string, without regard for case.
atc.param: The string in which to search.
atc.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cSearch> within <cTarget>. If <cSearch> is not found, AtC() returns 0.
atc.remarks: If you only need to know whether a substring exists within another string, use the InStr() function or the $ operator. To find the last occurrence of a substring within a string, use RAt().
atc.example:
These examples show typical use of AtC():
? AtC("bcd", "ABCDE") // 2 ? AtC("a", "bcde") // 0 ? AtC("a", "AbCdE") // 1
This example uses strong typing to do the same thing more efficiently:
LOCAL cSearch AS STRING LOCAL cTarget AS STRING cSearch := "a" cTarget := "AbCdE" ? AtC(cSearch, cTarget) // 1

atc2.summary: Return the position of the first occurrence of a substring within a string, without regard for case.
atc2.param: The substring for which to search.
The string in which to search.
atc2.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cSearch> within <cTarget>. If <cSearch> is not found, AtC2() returns 0.
atc2.remarks: AtC2() is like AtC() except that it returns a WORD. See AtC() for more information.

atcline.summary: Return the line number of the first occurrence of a substring within a multiple line string, without regard for case.
atcline.param: The string in which to search.
atcline.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cSearch> within <cTarget>. If <cSearch> is not found, AtCLine() returns 0.
atcline.remarks: If you only need to know whether a substring exists within another string, use the InStr() function or the $ operator.

atcline2.summary: Return the line number of the first occurrence of a substring within a multiple line string, without regard for case.
atcline2.param: The substring for which to search.
The string in which to search.
atcline2.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cSearch> within <cTarget>. If <cSearch> is not found, AtCLine2() returns 0.
atcline2.remarks: AtCLine2() is like AtCLine() except that it returns a WORD. See AtCLine() for more information.

atline.summary: Return the line number of the first occurrence of a substring within a multiple line string.
atline.param: The string in which to search.
atline.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cSearch> within <cTarget>. If <cSearch> is not found, AtLine() returns 0.
atline.remarks: If you only need to know whether a substring exists within another string, use the InStr() function or the $ operator.

atline2.summary: Return the line number of the first occurrence of a substring within a multiple line string.
atline2.param: The substring for which to search.
The string in which to search.
atline2.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cSearch> within <cTarget>. If <cSearch> is not found, AtLine2() returns 0.
atline2.remarks: AtLine2() is like AtLine() except that it returns a WORD. See AtLine() for more information.

atranslate.summary: Translate a value to another value, using a two-dimensional array as a lookup table. The shape of the array matches that returned by DBServer:GetLookupTable.
atranslate.param: A rectangular array dimensioned n by 2. A lookup table has two elements, each of which is a single-dimensioned array, and the two arrays have the same length. (This is the type of array returned by DBServer:GetLookupTable.) The first linear array is used to look up the value, and the second is used to get the translated value.
A value to be translated. The value should match the types of the values in the first column of the <aLookupTable> array.

Indicates whether soft seeking should be used. If TRUE, the first value greater than <uValue> is used to yield the return value; if FALSE, only exact matches yield a return value. This argument is optional; if omitted, FALSE is assumed. (This default does not depend on SetSoftSeek().)
atranslate.returns: The looked-up value from the second column of the array, of whatever data type the array contains. If no match is found (with soft seeking off), or if <uValue> is greater than all the elements in the lookup table (with soft seeking on), it returns NIL.

between.summary: Determine if a value is between two other values.
between.param: A value of any type to compare to <uMin> and <uMax>.
The point at which to start comparing. This must be of the same type as <uValue> except that numerics of different types are allowed.
The point at which to stop comparing. This must be of the same type as <uValue> except that numerics of different types are allowed.
between.returns: TRUE if <uValue> is greater than or equal to <uMin> and less than or equal to <uMax>; otherwise, FALSE.
between.remarks:
Between() can be used to do advanced searching on polymorphic data types. For example, it can determine whether A character falls between 2 other characters, either in the alphabet or the ASCII chart A date falls between 2 other dates A number falls between 2 other numbers
String comparisons: String comparisons are nation-dependent. Be aware that a character can fall between 2 other characters in the ANSI character set but not in the OEM character set. Thus, when passing strings you may often need to specify whether the ANSI or the OEM character set should be used. Floating point comparisons: SetFloatDelta() affects the outcome of Between().
between.example:
These examples show what would happen if you use Between() to search for the letters "cd" in a list of the alphabet:
? Between("cd", "ab", "ef") // TRUE ? Between("cd", "gh", "kl") // FALSE
This example determines whether today's date is between 12/12/93 and 12/12/94:
// Return value depends on today's date ? Between(Today(), 93.12.12, 94.12.12)
This example does comparisons based on numbers: ? Between(2, 1, 3) // TRUE

bin2date.summary: Convert a string containing a 32-bit binary date to a date data type.
bin2date.param: A 32-bit binary date represented as a string — least significant byte first. Only the first 4 bytes are used by the function; all others are ignored.
bin2date.returns: A date value that corresponds to the date specified in <cString>. If <cString> is not a valid binary date, Bin2Date() returns a NULL_DATE.
bin2date.remarks: Bin2Date() is a conversion function that converts the first 4 bytes of a string to a date. Typical applications include reading foreign file types in their native format then saving, reading, decrypting, and transmitting date types in their compressed binary form instead of in strings. Its inverse is Date2Bin().
bin2date.example: This example illustrate Bin2Date(): ? Bin2Date("!$%" + Chr(0)) // 03/09/52 This example shows the inverse relationship of Bin2Date() and Date2Bin(): ? Bin2Date(Date2Bin(Today())) // Today's date

bin2dw.summary: Convert a string containing a 32-bit unsigned integer to a double word.
bin2dw.param: A 32-bit unsigned integer represented as a string — least significant byte first. Only the first 4 bytes are used by the function; all others are ignored.
bin2dw.remarks: Bin2DW() is a conversion function that converts the first 4 bytes of a string to a double word. Typical applications include reading foreign file types in their native format then saving, reading, decrypting, and transmitting numeric data in their compressed binary form instead of in strings. Its inverse is DW2Bin().
bin2dw.example: This example is passed 4 ASCII characters and returns a number that is 10 digits long: ? Bin2DW("abcd") // 1684234849

bin2f.summary: Convert a string containing a 80-bit floating point number to a float value.
bin2f.param: An 80-bit floating point number represented as a string — least significant byte first.
bin2f.remarks: Bin2F() is a conversion function that converts a binary string into a floating point number. Typical applications include reading foreign file types in their native format then saving, reading, decrypting, and transmitting numeric data in their compressed binary form instead of in strings. Its inverse is F2Bin().
bin2f.example:
This example decrypts a converted floating point numeric back to its original format:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL cEncrypt AS STRING LOCAL fDecrypt AS FLOAT cEncrypt := F2Bin(12365789.96587) // Encrypting fDecrypt := Bin2F(cEncrypt) // Decrypting ? fDecrypt // 12365789.96587 RETURN TRUE

bin2i.summary: Convert a string containing a 16-bit signed integer to a short integer.
bin2i.param: A 16-bit signed integer represented as a string — least significant byte first. Only the first 2 bytes are used by the function; all others are ignored.
bin2i.remarks: Bin2I() is a conversion function that converts the first 2 bytes of a string to a short integer. Typical applications include reading foreign file types in their native format then saving, reading, decrypting, and transmitting long numeric data in their compressed binary form instead of in strings. Positive numbers with 2 digits or less will not save disk space when converted. For numbers that fall between 0 and 255, you can use Chr() or _Chr(). The inverse of Bin2I() is I2Bin().
bin2i.example:
This example opens a database file using file functions and reads the date of last update (bytes 1-3). The result is the same as LUpdate():
ptrHandle := FOpen2("sales.dbf", FO_READ) // Point to byte 1 in the file FSeek(ptrHandle, 1, FS_SET) // Read date of last update siYear := Bin2I(FReadStr(ptrHandle, 1) + _Chr(0)) siMonth := Bin2I(FReadStr(ptrHandle, 1) + _Chr(0)) siDay := Bin2I(FReadStr(ptrHandle, 1) + _Chr(0)) ? NTrim(siMonth), NTrim(siDay), NTrim(siYear) FClose(ptrHandle)

bin2l.summary: Convert a string containing a 32-bit signed integer to a long integer.
bin2l.param: A 32-bit signed integer represented as a string — least significant byte first. Only the first 4 bytes are used by the function; all others are ignored.
bin2l.remarks: Bin2L() is a conversion function that converts the first 4 bytes of a string to a long integer. Typical applications include reading foreign file types in their native format then saving, reading, decrypting, and transmitting numeric data in their compressed binary form instead of in strings. Its inverse is L2Bin().
bin2l.example:
This example opens a database file using file functions and reads the number of records (bytes 4-7). The result is the same as LastRec():
ptrHandle := FOpen2("sales.dbf", FO_READ) // Sales.dbf contains 84 records FSeek(ptrHandle, 4, FS_SET) // Point to byte 4 cRecords := Space(4) FRead(ptrHandle, @cRecords, 4) // Read the number of records ? LTrim(Str(Bin2L(cRecords))) // 84 FClose(ptrHandle)

bin2logic.summary: Convert a string containing an 8-bit logical into a logical value.
bin2logic.param: An 8-bit logical represented as a string.
bin2logic.remarks: Bin2Logic() is a conversion function that converts the first byte of a string to a logical. Typical applications include saving data in their native format, data decryption, and transmitting logical data in their binary form. Its inverse is Logic2Bin().
bin2logic.example:
This example opens a file using file functions, reads the first byte as a binary logical, then converts it into a logical value:
ptrHandle := FOpen("sales.txt", FO_READ) cByte := Space(1) FRead(ptrHandle, @cByte, 1) ? Bin2Logic(cByte))) // Returns either TRUE or FALSE FClose(ptrHandle)

bin2real4.summary: Convert a string containing a 32-bit floating point number to a Real4 value.
bin2real4.param: A 32-bit floating point number represented as a string — least significant byte first. Only the first 4 bytes are used by the function; all others are ignored.
bin2real4.remarks: Bin2Real4() is a conversion function that converts the first 4 bytes of a string to a 32-bit floating point number. Typical applications include reading foreign file types in their native format then saving, reading, decrypting, and transmitting numeric data in their compressed binary form instead of in strings. Its inverse is Real42Bin().
bin2real4.example:
This example shows that Real42Bin() is the inverse of Bin2Real4():
cString := Real42Bin(1245633.25) ? cString // 4-byte string ? Bin2Real4(cString) // 1245633.25

bin2real8.summary: Convert a string containing a 32-bit floating point number to a Real8 value.
bin2real8.param: A 32-bit floating point number represented as a string — least significant byte first. Only the first 8 bytes are used by the function; all others are ignored.
bin2real8.remarks: Bin2Real8() is a conversion function that converts the first 8 bytes of a string to a 32-bit floating point number. Typical applications include reading foreign file types in their native format then saving, reading, decrypting, and transmitting numeric data in their compressed binary form instead of in strings. Its inverse is Real82Bin().
bin2real8.example:
This example shows that Real82Bin() is the inverse of Bin2Real8():
cString := Real82Bin(1245633.25) ? cString // 8-byte string ? Bin2Real8(cString) // 1245633.25

bin2w.summary: Convert a string containing a 16-bit unsigned integer to a word.
bin2w.param: A 16-bit unsigned integer represented as a string — least significant byte first. Only the first 2 bytes are used by the function; all others are ignored.
bin2w.remarks: Bin2W() is a conversion function that converts the first 2 bytes of a string to a word. Typical applications include reading foreign file types in their native format then saving, reading, decrypting, and transmitting numeric data in their compressed binary form instead of in strings. Its inverse is W2Bin().
bin2w.example:
This example opens a database file using file functions and reads the number of bytes per record (bytes 10-11). The result is the same as RecSize():
ptrHandle := FOpen2("sales.dbf", FO_READ) // Note: The length of a record in sales.dbf is 124 // Point to byte 10, the first record size byte FSeek(ptrHandle, 10, FS_SET) cRecSize := Space(2) // Read record size FRead(ptrHandle, @cRecSize, 2) ? NTrim(Bin2W(cRecSize))) // 124 FClose(ptrHandle)

blobdirectexport.summary: Export the contents of a binary large object (BLOB) pointer to a file. Note: A BLOB file (.DBV or .FPT) is used for storing memo field information, as an alternative to the standard .DBT file mechanism supported by some RDDs. It is a more powerful and efficient mechanism for storing and retrieving large amounts of data than using .DBT files. X# supplies the DBFCDX driver, which uses the BLOB file storage mechanism by default, and the DBFBLOB driver, which you can use as an inherited driver with other RDDs. Refer to the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide for further information on using this driver.
blobdirectexport.param: A pointer to the BLOB data. This pointer can be obtained using BLOBDirectPut(), BLOBDirectExport(), or DBFieldInfo(DBS_BLOB_POINTER, <nFieldPos>).

The name of the target file where the BLOB data will be written, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. No default extension is assumed.
If <cTargetFile> does not exist, it is created. If it exists, this function attempts to open the file in exclusive mode and, if successful, the file is written to without warning or error. If access is denied because, for example, another process is using the file, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.

A constant defining the copy mode, as shown in the table below:
Constant Description
BLOB_EXPORT_APPEND Appends to the file
BLOB_EXPORT_OVERWRITE Overwrites the file — this is the default

blobdirectget.summary: Retrieve data stored in a BLOB file without referencing a specific field.
blobdirectget.param: A pointer to the BLOB data. This pointer can be obtained using BLOBDirectPut(), BLOBDirectImport(), or DBFieldInfo(DBS_BLOB_POINTER, <nFieldPos>).

The starting position in <nPointer>. If <nStart> is positive, the starting position is relative to the leftmost character in <nPointer>. If <nStart> is negative, it is relative to the rightmost character in <nPointer>. If <nStart> is omitted, it is assumed to be 1.

The number of bytes of data to retrieve, beginning at <nStart>. If <nCount> is larger than the amount of data stored, excess data is ignored. If omitted, BLOBDirectGet() retrieves to the end of the data.
blobdirectget.returns: The data retrieved from the BLOB file. The data type of the return value depends on the actual data stored. Use ValType() or UsualType() to determine the data type.
blobdirectget.remarks: BLOBDirectGet() retrieves data stored in a BLOB file without the need to reference a particular field in the database file. It is particularly useful when accessing data that is larger than 64 KB, (such as memo fields created with the BLOBImport() function).
blobdirectget.example:
This example illustrates storing setup information in a BLOB file, then selectively retrieving the stored information:
FUNCTION PutSettings(aColors AS ARRAY,; aPaths AS ARRAY, aPassWords AS ARRAY) AS VOID LOCAL aSettings AS ARRAY USE setup NEW VIA DBFBLOB aSettings := {} AADD(aSettings, BLOBDirectPut(0, aColors)) AADD(aSettings, BLOBDirectPut(0, aPaths)) AADD(aSettings, BLOBDirectPut(0, aPassWords)) BLOBRootPut(aSettings) CLOSE FUNCTION GetColors() AS ARRAY LOCAL aSettings AS ARRAY LOCAL aColors AS ARRAY USE setup NEW VIA DBFBLOB aSettings := BLOBRootGet() aColors := BLOBDirectGet(aSettings[1]) CLOSE RETURN aColors

blobdirectimport.summary: Import a file into a BLOB file and return a pointer to the data.
blobdirectimport.param:
A pointer to the BLOB data which will be released after the import. This pointer can be obtained using BLOBDirectPut(), BLOBDirectImport(), or DBFieldInfo(DBS_BLOB_POINTER, <nFieldPos>). Passing 0 disables the release of data.
If specified, BLOBDirectImport() releases the space associated with <nOldPointer> for reuse by other data. Therefore, it is illegal to use <nOldPointer> with any of the BLOB functions after passing it as an argument to this function. Use the function's return value to refer to the newly stored data.

The name of the file from which to read the BLOB data, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. No default extension is assumed.
This function attempts to open <cSourceFile> in shared mode. If the file does not exist, a runtime error is raised. If the file is successfully opened, the operation proceeds. If access is denied because, for example, another process has exclusive use of the file, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.
blobdirectimport.returns: A numeric pointer to the BLOB image stored in <cSourceFile>.
blobdirectimport.remarks:
BLOBDirectImport() provides a mechanism for copying the contents of a file into a BLOB file.
BLOBDirectImport() is used in conjunction with BLOBDirectExport() to transfer data back and forth between external files and BLOB files. You can use BLOBDirectImport() with a variety of file types, including graphics images, word processor files, and printer fonts. These two functions are excellent for creating databases of documents, graphics, sounds, and so on. After importing a file with BLOBDirectImport(), nNewPointer, the return value, is the only way to access the data from the BLOB file. It is up to you, the developer, to provide permanent storage for this reference (see example below) Note: DBFieldInfo(DBS_BLOB_TYPE, <nFieldPos>) will return "C" (string) for any memo field created using BLOBDirectImport().

blobdirectput.summary: Put data in a BLOB file without referencing a specific field.
blobdirectput.param:
A reference to previously stored BLOB data. This reference can be obtained using BLOBDirectPut(), BLOBDirectImport(), or DBFieldInfo(DBS_BLOB_POINTER, <nFieldPos>). If other than 0, the data referenced by <nOldPointer> is replaced by <uBLOB>; otherwise, <uBLOB> is added to the current contents of the BLOB file.
Important! If specified, BLOBDirectPut() releases the space associated with <nOldPointer> for reuse by other data. Therefore, it is illegal to use <nOldPointer> with any of the BLOB functions after passing it as an argument to this function. Use the function's return value to refer to the newly stored data.
The data you want to put into the BLOB file. <uBLOB> can be any X# usual data type, except code block and object.
blobdirectput.returns: A numeric pointer to the <uBLOB> data.
blobdirectput.remarks: BLOBDirectPut() stores variable length BLOB data without creating a link with a particular memo field in a database file. After adding data to a BLOB file using BLOBDirectPut(), you should store the function's return value, as this is the only way to access the data from the BLOB file. It is up to you, the developer, to provide permanent storage for this reference (see BLOBRootPut()).
blobdirectput.example:
This example illustrates storing setup information in a BLOB file, then selectively retrieving the stored information:
FUNCTION PutSettings(aColors AS ARRAY,; aPaths AS ARRAY, aPassWords AS ARRAY) AS VOID LOCAL aSettings AS ARRAY USE setup NEW VIA DBFBLOB aSettings := {} AADD(aSettings, BLOBDirectPut(0, aColors)) AADD(aSettings, BLOBDirectPut(0, aPaths)) AADD(aSettings, BLOBDirectPut(0, aPassWords)) BLOBRootPut(aSettings) CLOSE FUNCTION GetColors() AS ARRAY LOCAL aSettings AS ARRAY LOCAL aColors AS ARRAY USE setup NEW VIA DBFBLOB aSettings := BLOBRootGet() aColors := BLOBDirectGet(aSettings[1]) CLOSE RETURN aColors

blobexport.summary: Copy the contents of a BLOB, identified by its memo field number, to a file.
blobexport.param: The position of the field in the database file structure.

The name of the target file where the BLOB data will be written, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. No default extension is assumed.
If <cTargetFile> does not exist, it is created. If it exists, this function attempts to open the file in exclusive mode and, if successful, the file is written to without warning or error. If access is denied because, for example, another process is using the file, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.

A constant defining the copy mode, as shown in the table below:
Constant Description
BLOB_EXPORT_APPEND Appends to the file
BLOB_EXPORT_OVERWRITE Overwrites the file — this is the default

blobget.summary: Get the contents of a BLOB, identified by its memo field number.
blobget.param: The position of the field in the database file structure.

The starting position in the memo field of the BLOB data. If <nStart> is positive, the starting position is relative to the leftmost character in <nFieldPos>. If <nStart> is negative, it is relative to the rightmost character in <nFieldPos>. If <nStart> is omitted, it is assumed to be 1.
The number of bytes of data to retrieve, beginning at <nStart>. If <nCount> is larger than the amount of data stored, excess data is ignored. If omitted, BLOBGet() retrieves to the end of the data.
blobget.returns: The BLOB data retrieved from the memo field. The data type of the return value depends on the actual data stored. Use ValType() or UsualType() to determine the data type. If the indicated field is not a memo field, BLOBGet() returns NIL.
blobget.remarks:
BLOBGet() is very similar to FieldGet(). However, because string type variables cannot be larger than 64 KB, FieldGet() will raise a runtime error when attempting to retrieve memo fields of this magnitude or greater. BLOBGet() will also raise an error if you attempt to retrieve a field greater than this magnitude; however, you can retrieve any subset of the BLOB data by using an <nCount> less than 64 KB.
Note: BLOB data less than 64 KB can be retrieved from a memo field using standard means (for example, referring to the field by name in an expression or using the FieldGet() function).

blobimport.summary: Read the contents of a file as a BLOB, identified by a memo field number.
blobimport.param: The position of the field in the database file structure.

The name of the file from which to read the BLOB data, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. No default extension is assumed.
This function attempts to open <cSourceFile> in shared mode. If the file does not exist, a runtime error is raised. If the file is successfully opened, the operation proceeds. If access is denied because, for example, another process has exclusive use of the file, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.
blobimport.remarks:
BLOBImport() provides a mechanism for copying the contents of a file into a memo field as BLOB data.
BLOBImport() is used in conjunction with BLOBExport() to transfer BLOB data back and forth between files and memo fields. You can use BLOBImport() with a variety of file types, including graphics images, word processor files, and printer fonts. These two functions are excellent for creating databases of documents, graphics, sounds, and so on. Note: DBFieldInfo(DBS_BLOB_TYPE, <nFieldPos>) will return "C" (string) for any memo field created using BLOBImport().
blobimport.example:
This example imports information from a word processing document into a field, then uses BLOBGet() to extract the first 25 characters of the field:
FUNCTION Populate() USE customer NEW INHERIT FROM {"DBFBLOB"} // Construct unique file name based on last // name and id DO WHILE .NOT. EOF() GetPix("Pix", SUBSTR(LastName, 1, 4) + CustID) Customer->DBSkip() ENDDO FUNCTION GetPix(cPixField, cPixFile) LOCAL nPos nPos := FIELDPOS(cPixField) // Import the picture file into indicated field IF !BLOBImport(nPos, cPixFile) Alert("Import of picture " + cPixFile + "; failed!") ENDIF

blobrootget.summary: Retrieve the data from the root area of a BLOB file.
blobrootget.returns: The data retrieved from the root of the BLOB file. The data type of the return value depends on the actual data stored. Use ValType() or UsualType() to determine the data type. Note that BLOBRootGet() returns NIL if the root reference has never been written to with BLOBRootPut().
blobrootget.remarks:
BLOBRootGet() allows the retrieval of a BLOB from the root of a BLOB file in a work area.
Note: Because the root data does not reference a particular record in the database file, the DBRLock() will not protect this root storage reference. Therefore, if the database file is opened in shared mode, you should use BLOBRootLock() before calling BLOBRootGet().

blobrootlock.summary: Obtain a lock on the root area of a BLOB file.
blobrootlock.remarks: Use BLOBRootLock() when accessing the database file in shared mode to obtain a lock on the root area of a BLOB file for reading from or writing to the root area.
blobrootlock.example:
This example illustrates how to properly lock and unlock the root area of a BLOB file for a database file opened in shared mode.
FUNCTION GetSettings() LOCAL aCustSettings AS ARRAY // Open a customer file in shared mode USE customer NEW SHARED INHERIT FROM {"DBFBLOB"} IF BLOBRootLock() aCustSettings := BLOBRootGet() BLOBRootUnlock() ELSE Alert("Could not obtain root lock of Customer; file") ENDIF CLOSE RETURN aCustSettings
