blobrootput.summary: Store data in the root area of a BLOB file.
blobrootput.param: The data you want to put into the BLOB file's root area. <uBLOB> can be any X# usual data type, except code block and object.
blobrootput.remarks:
BLOBRootPut() allows the storage of one — and only one — piece of data to a BLOB file's root area (there is no size limitation on this one piece of data). After storing the new data, BLOBRootPut() releases the space associated with any data previously stored in the BLOB file's root area.
Note: Because the root data does not reference a particular record in the database file, the DBRLock() will not protect this root storage reference. Therefore, if the database file is opened in shared mode, you should use BLOBRootLock() before calling BLOBRootPut().

blobrootunlock.summary: Release the lock on a BLOB file's root area.
blobrootunlock.remarks:
Use BLOBRootUnlock() to release a lock previously obtained using BLOBRootLock().
Note: The only functions that require the use of BLOBRootLock() or BLOBRootUnlock() are BLOBRootGet() and BLOBRootPut().
blobrootunlock.example:
This example illustrates how to properly lock and unlock the root area of a BLOB file for a database file opened in shared mode.
FUNCTION GetSettings() LOCAL aCustSettings AS ARRAY // Open a customer file in shared mode USE customer NEW SHARED INHERIT FROM {"DBFBLOB"} IF BLOBRootLock() aCustSettings := BLOBRootGet() BLOBRootUnlock() ELSE Alert("Could not obtain root lock of Customer; file") ENDIF CLOSE RETURN aCustSettings

bof.returns: TRUE after an attempt to skip backward beyond the first logical record in a database file or if the database file contains no records; otherwise, FALSE. If there is no database file open in the work area, BOF() returns TRUE.
bof.remarks:
BOF() is a database function used to test for a boundary condition when you are moving the record pointer backward through a database file using the DBSkip() function. An example is a screen paging routine that pages forward or backward through the database file based on a user key stroke. When the user attempts to page backward, you would use BOF() to test for a beginning-of-file condition before using DBSkip() to move the record pointer and repaint the screen.
DBSkip(), VODBSkip(), and the SKIP command are the only record movement operations that can set BOF() to TRUE. Once BOF() is set to TRUE, it retains its value until there is another attempt to move the record pointer.
bof.example:
This example demonstrates BOF() by attempting to move the record pointer before the first record:
USE sales NEW QOut(RECNO(), BOF()) // Result: 1 FALSE DBSkip(-1) QOut(RECNO(), BOF()) // Result: 1 TRUE
This example uses aliased expressions to query the value of BOF() in unselected work areas:
USE sales NEW USE customer NEW USE invoices NEW QOut(sales->BOF(), customer->BOF())
This example uses a parameter to the BOF() function to eveluate the value of BOF() in unselected work areas:
USE sales NEW USE customer NEW USE invoices NEW QOut(BOF("sales"), BOF("customer"))

break.summary: Branch out of a BEGIN SEQUENCE...END construct.
break.param: The value passed to the RECOVER clause. Note that <uValue> is not optional; however, NIL can be specified if there is no break value.
break.returns: The value passed to the RECOVER clause.
break.remarks: _Break() is identical in functionality to the BREAK statement and the LabelJump() function.

buffer.summary: Return an uninitialized string of a specified size.
buffer.param: The number of bytes to return.
buffer.returns: A string of <dwSize> bytes. If <dwSize> is 0, Buffer() returns a NULL_STRING.
buffer.remarks: Buffer() is similar to Space() but with random contents. You should use it, instead of Space(), in cases where an initialization character is not needed.
buffer.example:
This example uses Buffer() to allocate a string then fills it in with the data read from FRead3():
cBuff := Buffer(8) FRead3(ptrHandle, Ptr(_CAST, cBuff), 8)

canbreak.summary: Check whether a break occurs within the BEGIN SEQUENCE...END construct.
canbreak.remarks: If the code is not within a BEGIN SEQUENCE...END construct, the break behaves like the QUIT command. Note that the break can be invoked by either the _Break() function or the BREAK statement executing within the BEGIN SEQUENCE...END construct.
canbreak.example:
This example shows the two possible results of CanBreak():
BEGIN SEQUENCE ? CanBreak() // TRUE END SEQUENCE? CanBreak() // FALSE

cast2psz.summary: Check a strongly typed string for NULL_STRING and return a valid (non-zero) PSZ.
cast2psz.returns: A non-zero PSZ if successful; otherwise, NULL_PSZ.
cast2psz.remarks: Cast2Psz() is useful for many Windows or DLL functions that require a PSZ in their argument list. It checks whether <cString> is a NULL_STRING. If this is the case, String2Psz() returns a static pointer to a byte containing 0x00. Otherwise, it returns the <cString> argument as a PSZ. Do use Cast2Psz() to initialize your own PSZ variable, because it remains the same dynamic string and its location will be changed by the next call to the "garbage collector."

cdow.summary: Extract the name of the day of the week from a date.
cdow.param: The date from which to extract the day of the week.
cdow.returns: The name of the day of the week, where the first letter is uppercase and the rest of the string is lowercase. For an invalid or NULL_DATE, CDoW() returns a NULL_STRING.
cdow.remarks: CDoW() is a date conversion function used in formatting date displays for reports, labels, screens, and so on. This function is nation-dependent.
cdow.example:
These examples illustrate CDoW():
? Today() // 06/05/93 ? CDoW(Today()) // Tuesday ? CDoW(Today() + 7) // Tuesday ? CDoW(CToD("06/12/93")) // Sunday

ceil.summary: Round a number up to the next highest integer.
ceil.returns: The integer part (no decimals) of the nearest number that is greater than or equal to <nNumber>. Since both <nNumber> and the return value are data type USUAL, you are not limited to the size of an integer.
ceil.remarks: Ceil() rounds a positive number with a fractional portion up to the next highest integer and returns the integer portion of a negative number.
ceil.example:
These examples illustrate Ceil() on a positive and a negative value:
? Ceil(1.6) // 2 ? Ceil(-1.6) // -1 (since -1 > -2)

chareven.summary: Return the even-numbered characters in a string.
chareven.param: The string whose even-numbered characters you want to return.
chareven.returns: Every other character in the string, starting from the second character.
chareven.example:
These examples display every even character in a string:
? CharEven("A1B2C3") // 123 ? CharEven("1234567890") // 24680

charmix.summary: Return a string whose odd-numbered characters and even-numbered characters are from 2 different strings.
charmix.param: The string whose characters will constitute the odd-numbered characters in the returned string.
The string whose characters will constitute the even-numbered characters in the returned string.
charmix.returns: A string in which characters from <cOdd> and <cEven> appear alternately. The length of <cOdd> determines the length of the returned string: the length is twice the length of <cOdd>, assuming that <cEven> contains at least one character: A longer <cEven> string is cut down to the length of <cOdd>. A shorter <cEven> is processed from beginning to end, wrapping to the beginning again until there are no more characters in <cOdd>. If <cEven> contains less than one character, a NULL_STRING is returned.
charmix.remarks: CharMix() provides a convenient way to recombine strings extracted from CharOdd() and CharEven().

charodd.summary: Return the odd-numbered characters in a string.
charodd.param: The string whose odd-numbered characters you want to return.
charodd.returns: Every other character in the string, starting from the first character.
charodd.example:
The SaveScreenOld() function, whose return value maintains compatibility with the CA-Clipper SaveScreen() function, stores the screen contents in a buffer such that the odd bytes contain the actual screen characters and the even bytes contain the corresponding screen attributes. CharOdd() is useful in extracting the screen contents from such a buffer. This example saves the screen contents of the first row and redisplays it in many different colors on the next row:
Function Start() LOCAL i AS SHORTINT LOCAL cBuffer AS STRING LOCAL cCharacters, cAttributes AS STRING LOCAL cSong AS STRING cSong := "Show me your true colors!" ?? cSong cBuffer := SaveScreenOld(0, 0, 0, 79) cCharacters := CharOdd(cBuffer) cAttributes := CharEven(cBuffer) // Change the attributes SEvalA(cAttributes, {|| Chr(i++)}, 1,; SLen(cSong)) // Redisplay with new attributes RestScreenOld(1, 0, 1, 79,; CharMix(cCharacters, cAttributes)) RETURN TRUE

charpos.summary: Return a character based on its position in a string.
charpos.param: The string that you want to extract a character from.
The position of the character within <cString>.
charpos.returns: The character located at the specified position.
charpos.remarks:
CharPos(<cString>, <wPosition>) extracts a substring from the specified string for a length of one character. Functionally, it is the same as Substr(<cString>, <wPosition>, 1).
This example extracts single letters from a name and displays them individually:
FUNCTION SayName() LOCAL siCount AS SHORTINT LOCAL cName := "Biff Styvesent" FOR siCount := 1 UPTO Len(cName) ?? CharPos(cName, siCount) NEXT

checkinstanceof.summary: Determine if an object is an instance of a particular class.
checkinstanceof.param: The class that <oObject> may be an instance of.
checkinstanceof.returns: TRUE if <oObject> is an instance of <symClassName>; otherwise, an error is generated. FALSE is returned if you choose to ignore the error. If <oObject> is a NULL_OBJECT, a FALSE is returned but no error is generated.
checkinstanceof.remarks: An instance of an inherited class is also an instance of the original (super) class. However, an instance of a super class is not an instance of any of its inherited classes. CheckInstanceOf() is similar to IsInstanceOf(), except that it also generates an error message if the specified object is not an instance of the specified class.
checkinstanceof.example:
These examples illustrate CheckInstanceOf() on inherited classes:
CLASS Person EXPORT name, sign METHOD Init(tName, tSign) CLASS Person name := tName sign := tSign CLASS Male INHERIT Person EXPORT prefers FUNCTION CheckArgument() LOCAL x, y AS OBJECT x := Person{"Dude", "president"} y := Male{"Charlie", "VP"} ? CheckInstanceOf(x, #Person) // TRUE ? CheckInstanceOf(x, #Male) // FALSE ? CheckInstanceOf(y, #Person) // TRUE ? CheckInstanceOf(y, #Male) // TRUE

chr.summary: Convert an ASCII code to a character value.
chr.returns: A single character that corresponds to <dwCode>.
chr.remarks:
Chr() is the inverse of Asc(). Chr() serves a number of common tasks including: Sending control codes and graphics characters to the screen or printer Ringing the bell Converting InKey() return values to characters Stuffing the keyboard buffer Chr(0) has a length of 1 and is treated like any other character; this lets you send it to any device or file, including a database file.
_Chr() is an operator that does the same thing as the Chr() function. As an operator, it is evaluated at compile time and can be used in DEFINE, GLOBAL, or STATIC LOCAL statements to specify initial values. Because it does not incur the overhead of a function call, it is more efficient. Here is an example: DEFINE CRLF := _Chr(ASC_CR) + _Chr(ASC_LF)
chr.example:
These examples illustrate Chr() with various arguments:
? Chr(Asc("A") + 32) // a ? Chr(7) // Bell sounds ? Chr(72) // H

classcount.summary: Return the number of classes available to your application.
classcount.example:
This example illustrates ClassCount():
FUNCTION Start() ? ClassCount(), "classes are available." // 5 classes are available.

classlist.summary: Return an array of symbols corresponding to the classes available to your application.
classlist.returns: An array of all class names as a symbol.
classlist.example:
This example illustrates ClassList():
CLASS MyClass ... FUNCTION PrintClass() LOCAL aClass AS ARRAY aClass := ClassList() // Predefined system classes are listed first. FOR i := 1 UPTO ALen(aClass) QOut(aClass[i]) NEXT

classname.summary: Get the class name of an object.
classname.param: An object whose class name you want to get.
classname.returns: The class to which <oObject> belongs. If <oObject> is not an instance of a class, a NULL_SYMBOL is returned.
classname.example:
These examples illustrate ClassName():
CLASS Person EXPORT cName, cSign METHOD Init(tName, tSign) CLASS Person cName := tName cSign := tSign CLASS Female INHERIT Person EXPORT prefers FUNCTION CheckClass() LOCAL oY AS OBJECT oY := Female{"Ms.", "Wonderful"} IF ClassName(oY) = #Female ? "The woman belongs to the Female class." ENDIF

classtree.summary: Get the class hierarchy of an object.
classtree.param: An object whose class hierarchy you want to get.
classtree.returns: An array of class names from which <oObject> has been derived. The last element of the array contains the root class from which subsequent classes in the array inherit.
classtree.remarks: ClassTree() shows what other classes, if any, the class of the object inherits from.
classtree.example:
These examples illustrate ClassTree() with multiple inheritances:
CLASS Person EXPORT name, sign METHOD Init(tName, tSign) CLASS Person name := tName sign := tSign CLASS Male INHERIT Person EXPORT prefers CLASS OldMale INHERIT Male EXPORT age FUNCTION InheritanceTree() LOCAL y AS OBJECT LOCAL a AS ARRAY y := OldMale{"Charlie", "dude"} a := ClassTree(y) ? ArrayGet(a, 1) // OLDMALE ? ArrayGet(a, 2) // MALE ? ArrayGet(a, 3) // PERSON

classtreeclass.summary: Get the class hierarchy of a class.
classtreeclass.param: A symbol representing the class name whose class hierarchy you want to get.
classtreeclass.returns: An array of class names from which <oObject> has been derived. The last element of the array contains the root class from which subsequent classes in the array inherit.
classtreeclass.remarks: ClassTreeClass() shows what other classes, if any, the specified class inherits from.
classtreeclass.example:
These examples illustrate ClassTreeClass() with multiple inheritances:
CLASS Person EXPORT name, sign METHOD Init(tName, tSign) CLASS Person name := tName sign := tSign CLASS Male INHERIT Person EXPORT prefers CLASS OldMale INHERIT Male EXPORT age FUNCTION InheritanceTree() LOCAL a AS ARRAY
a := ClassTreeClass(#OldMale) ? ArrayGet(a, 1) // OLDMALE ? ArrayGet(a, 2) // MALE ? ArrayGet(a, 3) // PERSON

cls.summary: Clear the terminal window and position the cursor at row and column 0.
cls.example:
These examples illustrate CLS():
FUNCTION Start() QOut("Clear the screen.") WAIT CLS() RETURN

cmonth.summary: Extract the name of the month from a date.
cmonth.param: The date from which to extract the month of the date.
cmonth.returns: The name of the month, where the first letter is uppercase and the rest of the string is lowercase. For an invalid or NULL_DATE, CMonth() returns a NULL_STRING.
cmonth.remarks: CMonth() is a date conversion function useful for creating formatted date strings that can be used in reports, labels, screens, and so on. This function is nation-dependent.
cmonth.example:
These examples illustrate CMonth():
? CMonth(Today()) // September ? CMonth(Today() + 45) // October ? Substr3(CMonth(Today()), 1, 3) +; Str(Day(Today())) // Sep 1

col.summary: Return the current column position of the cursor in the terminal window.
col.returns: The column in which the cursor is currently located. This value can range from 0 to MaxCol().
col.remarks: The value returned by Col() changes whenever the cursor position changes in the terminal window; for example, both console and full-screen commands can change the cursor position. In addition, Col() is automatically set to 0 whenever a CLEAR, CLEAR SCREEN, or CLS() is executed.
col.example:
This example displays a file name at a specified row and column:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL cErrorMessage AS STRING LOCAL cFileName AS STRING cErrorMessage := "File not found." cFileName := "customer.dbf" SetPos(1, 10) QQout(cFileName) SetPos(Row(), Col() + 2) QQOut(cErrorMessage)

collect.summary: Call the garbage collector if a watermark is reached.
collect.remarks: Collect() calls the garbage collector if a watermark is reached. A watermark is a point at which garbage collection is appropriate as determined by the system. Literal or hard-coded strings are static and cannot be collected. Strings which are dynamic can be collected. For example, in MyFunc("hello"), the literal string "hello" is not collectable, while in MyFunc(Time()), the string returned from Time() is collectable. Strings, floats, arrays, and object are dynamic and collectable objects unless they are literals or have been moved into the static memory via functions such as DynToOldSpace().

collectcount.summary: Count the number of garbage collections performed by the system.
collectcount.remarks: CollectCount() determines how many times garbage collection was performed in your application. This tells you how much of your system resources are being devoted to garbage collection. If the garbage collector is being called too frequently, memory might be low, resulting in a degradation in performance. CollectCount() is the same as Memory(MEMORY_COLLECT).
collectcount.example:
These examples show that after every call to CollectForced(), the return value of CollectCount() is increased by 1:
? CollectCount() // 1 CollectForced() ? CollectCount() // 2 CollectForced() ? CollectCount() // 3

collectforced.remarks: CollectForced() calls the garbage collector regardless of whether a watermark has been reached. Literal or hard-coded strings are static and cannot be collected. Strings which are dynamic can be collected. For example, in MyFunc("hello") the literal string "hello" is not collectable, while in MyFunc(Time()) the string returned from Time() is collectable. Strings, floats, arrays, and object are dynamic and collectable objects unless they are literals or have been moved into the static memory via functions such as DynToOldSpace().
collectforced.example:
These examples illustrate CollectForced():
? CollectCount() // 1 CollectForced() ? CollectCount() // 2 CollectForced() ? CollectCount() // 3

concatatom.returns: The concatenated symbol. This symbol is added to the atom table if it is not already there.
concatatom.remarks: ConcatAtom() lets you concatenate 2 symbols, the same way you concatenate strings with the "+" operator. To perform more complicated string operations, convert symbols to strings (using Symbol2String()); then use the string operators described in "Operators and Expressions" in the Programmer's Guide.
concatatom.example:
These examples illustrate ConcatAtom():
? ConcatAtom(#HEL, #LO) // #HELLO ? ConcatAtom(#GOOD,#BYE) = #GOODBYE // TRUE

concatatom3.returns: The concatenated symbol. This symbol is added to the atom table if it is not already there.
concatatom3.remarks: ConcatAtom3() lets you concatenate 3 symbols, the same way you concatenate strings with the "+" operator. To perform more complicated string operations, convert symbols to strings (using Symbol2String()); then use the string operators described in "Operators and Expressions" in the Programmer's Guide.

condate.summary: Format a set of numbers representing a year, month, and day as a date.
condate.param: A valid year. If the century digits are not specified, the century is determined by the rules of SetEpoch().
A number from 1 through 12 representing a valid month.
A number representing a valid day of <dwMonth>.
condate.returns: The date that corresponds to the passed arguments. If any of the arguments specified do not represent a valid year, month, or day, a NULL_DATE is returned.
condate.remarks: ConDate() converts the given numbers to a date. The display of dates is controlled by SetCentury().
condate.example:
These examples illustrate ConDate():
? ConDate(93, 10, 25) // 10/25/93 ? ConDate(2093, 10, 25) // 10/25/93 ? SetCentury(TRUE) ? ConDate(2093, 10, 25) // 10/25/2093

contime.summary: Format a set of numbers representing an hour, minute, and second as a time string.
contime.param: The number of hours, up to 23.
The number of minutes, up to 59.
The number of minutes, up to 59.
contime.returns: A time that corresponds to the passed arguments.
contime.example:
These examples illustrate ConTime():
? ConTime(10, 59, 59) // 10:59:59 ? ConTime(22, 59, 59) // 22:59:59

cos.summary: Calculate the cosine of a number.
cos.returns: The cosine of the specified angle.
cos.example:
This example uses Cos() to calculate the cosine of 0 and PI:
? Cos(0) // 1.00 ? Cos(PI) // -1.00
This example finds the cosine of a 60-degree angle. The first step is to convert 60 degrees to radians. This is done by dividing the angle by 180/PI: ? Cos(60/(180/PI)) // 0.50

cot.summary: Calculate the cotangent of a value.
cot.returns: The cotangent of the specified angle.
cot.example:
This example uses Cot() to show that cotangent is the same as cosine over sine:
? Cot(1.5) // 0.07 ? Cos(1.5) // 0.07 ? Sin(1.5) // 1.00 ? Cos(1.5) / Sin(1.5) // 0.07

cparamcount.summary: Return the number of arguments that a code block is expecting.
cparamcount.returns: The number of arguments that <cbBlock> is expecting.
cparamcount.remarks: When printing a code block (via functions like QOut()) the number of arguments is displayed in hexadecimal notation within the code block's | | pair
cparamcount.example:
This example uses CParamCount() to determine what calculation to perform:
DEFINE N_LENGTH := 10 DEFINE N_WIDTH := 5 DEFINE N_HEIGHT := 2 Function Start() LOCAL cbRectangle AS CODEBLOCK cbRectangle := {|x, y| x * y} ? Size(cbRectangle) // 50 RETURN TRUE FUNCTION Size(cbArea) AS LONGINT LOCAL siDimensions AS SHORTINT LOCAL liArea AS LONGINT siDimensions := CParamCount(cbArea) DO CASE CASE siDimensions = 1 // Length liArea := Eval(cbArea, N_LENGTH) CASE siDimensions = 2 // Area liArea := Eval(cbArea, N_LENGTH, N_WIDTH) CASE siDimensions = 3 // Volume liArea := Eval(cbArea, N_LENGTH, N_WIDTH,; N_HEIGHT) ENDCASE RETURN liArea

creategcdump.summary: Retrieve information about the current dynamic memory status (garbage collector entries).
creategcdump.param: Pointer to a _GCDUMP structure containing the resulting values.
Polymorphic value type for the garbage collector entries. Valid values are:
creategcdump.returns: The number of references found or the maximum number of references allowed.
creategcdump.remarks: This function retrieves information about garbage collector entries currently held in dynamic memory. Information is stored in a _GCDUMP structure, the first parameter to the function. The first member of this structure, nEntryCount, indicates how many entries can be stored by the function CreateGCDump. The user is responsible for allocating sufficient memory for this structure. If the number of garbage collector entries exceeds the number specified by the user, the function CreateGCDump() finishes execution and returns the current maximum.
creategcdump.example:
This example dumps all types of references into the _GCDUMP structure (maximum 100):
nAlloc := SIZEOF(DWORD) + 100 * _SIZEOF(_GCENTRY) pDump := MemAlloc(nAlloc) pDump.nEntryCount := 100 nEntries := CreateGCDump(pDump,0)
You can modify this to dump all valid STRING references into the _GCENTRY(maximum 100): nEntries := CreateGCDump(pDump, STRING) This example creates a function that can be used to display the desired types of references (maximum 100): NOTE - This function must be compiled with Range Checking disabled, otherwise it will cause a bound error.
FUNCTION MyGCDump(nType) LOCAL pDump AS _GCDUMP LOCAL pEntry AS _GCENTRY LOCAL nAlloc AS INT LOCAL nEntries, dwCount AS DWORD LOCAL aTypeStr AS ARRAY
// If you don't pass a value, default to all references Default(@nType, 0 ) aTypeStr := {"*","**","FLOAT","****","ARRAY","OBJECT",; "STRING"} // GC entry types IF !InCollect() CollectForced() ENDIF nAlloc := _SIZEOF(DWORD) + 100 * _SIZEOF(_GCENTRY) pDump := MemAlloc(nAlloc) IF pDump != NULL_PTR pDump.nEntryCount := 100 nEntries := CreateGCDump(pDump, nType) ? "Number of Active References: " + Ntrim(nEntries) ? FOR dwCount := 1 UPTO nEntries pEntry := @pDump.GCE[dwCount] ? nTrim(dwCount) + ":" ? "Created by : " + IIF(pEntry.nGCType ; == GC_TYPE_STACK, "Compiler", "RegisterKid()") ? "Var. Type : " + aTypeStr[pEntry.nVarType] ? "Dyn. Addr. : " + AsString(pEntry.pDynMem) ? "Size (bytes): " + Ntrim(pEntry.nSize) ? "Ref. Addr. : " + AsString(pEntry.ppRefDynMem) ? "Value : " + Psz2String(@pEntry.abValue[1]) NEXT dwCount ENDIF RETURN

createinstance.param: The name of the class for which you want to create an object.
A comma-separated list of arguments to pass to the Init() method of <symClassName> (see example below).
createinstance.remarks: CreateInstance() is the functional way to create an object of a particular class. It is essentially the same as creating an object through an invocation of {}, but is useful in situations where a functional form is needed.
createinstance.example:
This example shows how an object is created using CreateInstance():
CLASS Person EXPORT name, sign METHOD Init(tName, tSign) CLASS Person name := tName sign := tSign FUNCTION Start() LOCAL x AS OBJECT // Pass the class name as symbol and also // specify all Init() method arguments. x := CreateInstance(#PERSON, "Odile", "H") ? x:name // Odile

createinstancestatic.param: The name of the class for which you want to create a static object.
A comma-separated list of arguments to pass to the Init() method of <symClassName> (see example below).
createinstancestatic.returns: An instance of the desired static object.
createinstancestatic.remarks: CreateInstanceStatic() is the functional way to create an object of a particular class. It is essentially the same as creating an object through an invocation of {}, but it is more useful in situations where a functional form is needed.
createinstancestatic.example:
This example shows how an object is created using CreateInstanceStatic():
CLASS Person EXPORT Name, Sign METHOD Init(tName, tSign) CLASS Person Name := tName Sign := tSign FUNCTION Start() STATIC LOCAL x AS OBJECT // Pass the class name as symbol and also specify all // Init() method arguments. x := CreateInstanceStatic(#PERSON, "Odile", "H") ? x:name //Odile ? x:sign //H

createvothread.param: Pointer to a _WINSECURITY_ATTRIBUTES structure that determines whether the returned handle can be inherited by child processes. If lpThreadAttributes is NULL, the handle cannot be inherited. For more information, see the WIN32 function, CreateThread().
Stack size in bytes for the new thread. If this argument is 0, the stack size defaults to the same size as that of the primary thread of the process.
Entry point of the new thread, typically the address of a function declared with the PASCAL calling convention. Its prototype is: ThreadFunc( pArguments AS PTR ) AS DWORD PASCAL.
Pointer or any other 32-bit parameter passed to the thread entry point <pFunc> as the argument.

Additional flags to control the thread creation.
Note: Consult your Microsoft Win32 Software Development Kit documentation for detailed information about the WIN32 function, CreateThread().
Pointer to a DWORD that receives the thread identifier.
createvothread.returns: Handle of the new thread, if successful; otherwise, NULL_PTR.
createvothread.remarks: CreateVOThread() is a wrapper function for the Win32 function, CreateThread(). All arguments are passed to that function after notifying the runtime that a new thread is created by a X# process.
createvothread.example:
The following sample features three different threads:
STRUCT _THREADDATA MEMBER nThread AS INT // MEMBER xy AS ... FUNC Start LOCAL DIM adw[3] AS PTR LOCAL DIM pData[3] AS PTR LOCAL pTData AS _THREADDATA LOCAL i AS DWORD LOCAL nID AS DWORD
FOR i := 1 TO 3 pTData := MemAlloc(_SIZEOF(_THREADDATA)) IF pTData != NULL_PTR pTData.nThread := i pData[i] := pTData ENDIF adw[i] := CreateVOThread( NULL_PTR, 0,; @__ThreadFunc(),; pTData, 0,; @nID ) NEXT WaitForMultipleObjects( 3, @adw, TRUE, INFINITE ) FOR i := 1 TO 3 IF pData[i] != NULL_PTR MemFree(pData[i]) ENDIF NEXT WAIT "DONE" RETURN NIL STATIC FUNC __ThreadFunc ( pTData AS _THREADDATA ) AS DWORD PASCAL LOCAL i AS DWORD LOCAL n AS DWORD n := pTData.nThread FOR i := 1 TO 100 _DebOut32("Thread " + NTrim(n) ) Sleep(1) NEXT ExitVOThread(0)

crypt.param: The string that will be encrypted or decrypted.
The encryption/decryption key to be used.
crypt.remarks: This function can be used to encrypt or decrypt any string. Note that the encryption key is very important for decrypting the string later on. Without the proper key (i.e., the same key used to encrypt the string), the data will be unusable.
crypt.example:
This sample will encrypt a string and then decrypt the string:
LOCAL a, b, c AS STRING LOCAL cKey as STRING a := "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog." cKey := "CAT" b := Crypt(a, cKey) c := Crypt(b, cKey) ? a // The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog. ? b // ú¿C_6g[‡N%ì*„k ÙYñƒ---à-øÃFé†ÈbÓÈã_ø´Ù¢ù½Ÿ ? c // The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.

crypta.summary: Encrypt or decrypt a string, changing the contents of the original string as well as returning the encrypted string.
crypta.param: The string that will be encrypted or decrypted.
The encryption/decryption key to be used.
crypta.remarks: This function is identical to Crypt() except that it also changes the original string <cSource>. Note that the encryption key is very important for decrypting the string later on. Without the proper key (i.e., the same key used to encrypt the string), the data will be unusable.
crypta.example:
This sample will encrypt a string and then decrypt the string:
LOCAL a AS STRING LOCAL cKey as STRING a := "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog." cKey := "CAT" ? a // The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog. ? CryptA(a, cKey) // ú¿C_6g[‡N%ì*„k ÙYñƒ---à-øÃFé†ÈbÓÈã_ø´Ù¢ù½Ÿ ? a // ú¿C_6g[‡N%ì*„k ÙYñƒ---à- øÃFé†ÈbÓÈã_ø´Ù¢ù½Ÿ CryptA(a, cKey) ? a // The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.

ctod.summary: Convert a date string to date format.
ctod.param: A string of numbers representing the month, day, and year, separated by any character other than a number. The month, day, and year digits must be in the format set by SetDateFormat() or SetDateCountry(). If the century digits are not specified, the century is determined by the rules of SetEpoch().
ctod.returns: The date value that corresponds to the numbers specified in <cDate>. If <cDate> is not a valid date, CToD() returns a NULL_DATE.
ctod.remarks: CToD() is a character conversion function that converts a date value originally formatted as a string to a date data type. To initialize a NULL_DATE, specify <cDate> as a NULL_STRING. Keep in mind, however, that you can obtain empty date (or even non-empty dates), without incurring a function call overhead, by just specifying a date literal such as 92.07.22. Moreover , when a strongly typed variable is declared as having the DATE type, it is automatically initialized to an empty date. CToD() is the inverse of DToC(), which converts a date value to a string. DToS() also converts a date value to a string, and, since it is in the form of yyyymmdd, it is usually the preferred form for indexing a date in combination with a string.
ctod.example:
This example simply applies CToD() to a string: ? CToD("05/15/64") // 05/15/64 This example compares the return value of CToD() with a hard-coded date: ? CToD("05/15/64") = 64.05.15 // .T. This example shows that a declared strongly typed DATE variable is initialized to an empty date:
LOCAL dInit AS DATE ? CToD(NULL_STRING) = dInit // .T. ? CToD(NULL_STRING) = NULL_DATE // .T.
This example demonstrates the inverse relationship between CToD() and DToC(): ? CToD(DToC(Today())) = Today() // .T.

ctodansi.summary: Convert an ANSI date string to date format.
ctodansi.param:
A string in the ANSI form yyyy.mm.dd, where yy, mm, and dd represent year, month, and day respectively. The year, month, and day can be separated by any character other than a number.
<cDate> is always interpreted as an ANSI string and is not dependent on SetDateFormat() or SetDateCountry(). If the century digits are not specified, the century is determined by the rules of SetEpoch().
ctodansi.returns: The date value that corresponds to the numbers specified in <cDate>. If <cDate> is not a valid ANSI date, CToDAnsi() returns a NULL_DATE.
ctodansi.remarks: CToDAnsi() is a character conversion function that converts an ANSI date string to a date data type.
ctodansi.example:
This examples simply applies CToDAnsi() to a string: ? CToDAnsi("84/10/23") // 10/23/84 This example shows the effect of SetCentury():
SetCentury(TRUE) ? CToDAnsi("2084/10/23") // 10/23/2084 ? CToDAnsi("90$05$14") // 05/14/1990
This example shows that CToDAnsi() is not nation-dependent:
SetDateCountry(GERMAN) ? CToDAnsi("84/10/23") // 23.10.1984

curdir.param: The letter of the disk drive to query. SetDefault() is ignored; the Windows default is used unless you specify a drive.
curdir.returns: The current directory of the drive specified by <cDrive>, without either leading or trailing backslash (\) characters. If an error occurs, or the current directory of the specified drive is the root directory, CurDir() returns a NULL_STRING. Please note that another Windows task might change the current directory of a non-default drive, thereby affecting the return value of CurDir() when it is used to query non-default drives.
curdir.example:
These examples illustrate various CurDir() results:
? CurDir("e:") // NULL_STRING, root directory ? CurDir("c") // vo\source ? CurDir("c:") // vo\source ? CurDir() // NULL_STRING, root directory ? CurDir("a") // NULL_STRING, drive not ready
This example changes the current Windows directory to a new value if it does not match a specified directory:
IF CurDir("c:") != "vo\source" DirChange("\vo\source") ENDIF

curdrive.returns: The letter of the current drive, without a trailing colon.
curdrive.example:
This example illustrates the relationship between CurDrive() and DiskChange() and shows that CurDrive() is unaffected by SetDefault():
FUNCTION DriveTest() ? CurDrive() // C SetDefault("A") ? CurDrive() // C DiskChange("A") ? CurDrive() // A DiskChange("C") ? CurDrive() // C

date2bin.summary: Convert a date to a 32-bit binary date string.
date2bin.remarks: Date2Bin() is a conversion function that converts a date data type into a 4-byte string. Typical applications include reading foreign file types in their native format and then saving, reading, decrypting, and transmitting date types in their compressed binary form instead of in strings. Its inverse is Bin2Date().
date2bin.example:
This example uses Date2Bin() to record today's date to a debugging file:
FUNCTION RecordDate() AS LOGIC LOCAL nh LOCAL lSuccess := FALSE AS LOGIC nh := FOpen2("debug.doc", FO_READWRITE) // Assumes that file debug.doc already exists IF nh != F_ERROR FWrite(nh, Date2Bin(Today())) FClose(nh) lSuccess := TRUE ELSE ? "An error occurred when opening debug.doc" ? FError() ENDIF RETURN lSuccess

day.summary: Extract the number of the day of the month from a date.
day.returns: The day of the month, as a number in the range 0 to 31. If the day is February 29 and the year is not a leap year, Day() returns 0. For an invalid or NULL_DATE, Day() returns 0.
day.remarks: Day() is a date conversion function that is useful when you require a numeric day value during calculations for such things as periodic reports. Day() is a member of a group of functions that return components of a date value as numbers. The group includes Month() and Year() to return the month and year values as numerics. CDoW() is a related function that allows you to return the name of the day from a date value.
day.example:
These examples show the Day() function used several ways:
? Today() // 09/01/90 ? Day(Today()) // 1 ? Day(Today()) + 1 // 2 ? Day(0.0.0) // 0
This example uses Day() in combination with CMonth() and Year() to format a date value:
? CMonth(Today()) + Str(Day(Today())) + ; "," + Str(Year(Today())) // June 15, 1990

days.summary: Convert a specified number of seconds to days.
days.param: The number of seconds to convert to days.
days.returns: The number of days to the nearest day.
days.remarks: Days() converts a given number of seconds to the whole number of days. The remainder under 24 hours can be obtained by the TString() function (see example below).
days.example:
This example uses Days() and TString() to show that 300,000 is equal to 3 days, 11 hours, and 20 minutes:
? Days(300000) // 3 ? TString(300000) // 11:20:00

dbapp.summary: Import records from a database file.
dbapp.param:
The name of the database file from which to add records, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. The default extension for database files is determined by the RDD (see the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide for details on a particular RDD).
This function attempts to open <cSourceFile> in shared mode. If the file does not exist, a runtime error is raised. If the file is successfully opened, the operation proceeds. If access is denied because, for example, another process has exclusive use of the file, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.

The list of fields to append from <cSourceFile>. The default is all fields.
Only fields with the same names and types in both files are appended. If fields with the same name do not match in data type, a runtime error is raised.
The number of records to append, starting at the first record.
The number of the record to append.
TRUE or FALSE processes all records.
The name of the RDD that will service the work area. If not specified, the default RDD as determined by RDDSetDefault() is used.

A one-dimensional array with the names of RDDs from which the main RDD inherits special functionality. This allows you to use RDDs with special capabilities, like encryption or decryption, in different work areas with different database drivers. These RDDs overlay special functions of the main RDD (specified with the <cDriver> argument). If multiple RDDs (specified with this argument) implement the same function, the function associated with the last RDD in the list takes precedence. If <aRDDs> is omitted, no additional RDDs are assumed.
dbapp.remarks: By default, this function adds record to the database file in the currently selected work area. It can be made to operate on an unselected work area by specifying it within an aliased expression. DBApp() does not require that the database file be used exclusively or locked with FLock() to perform its operation. As each record is added, X# automatically arbitrates contention for the new record. DBApp() is the functional equivalent of the APPEND FROM command, specified without a DELIMITED or SDF clause.
dbapp.example: The following example adds records from the OLD.DBF file: DBApp("old.dbf")

dbappdelim.summary: Import records from a delimited text file.
dbappdelim.param:
The name of the delimited text file from which to add records, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. The default extension is .TXT.
This function attempts to open <cSourceFile> in shared mode. If the file does not exist, a runtime error is raised. If the file is successfully opened, the operation proceeds. If access is denied because, for example, another process has exclusive use of the file, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.
The delimiter used to separate fields in <cSourceFile>. The default delimiter is a double quote mark.
A list of fields to copy from <cSourceFile>. The default is all fields.
The number of records to append, starting at the first record.
The number of the record to append.
TRUE or FALSE processes all records.
dbappdelim.remarks: DBAppDelim() is the functional equivalent of the APPEND FROM DELIMITED command. It is the same as the DBApp() function except that it can be used only with text files. See APPEND FROM and DBApp() for more information.
dbappdelim.example:
The following example appends records from a text file named SRCDELIM.TXT:
USE test NEW DBAppDelim("srcdelim.txt")

dbappend.summary: Add a new record to a database file.
dbappend.param: A logical data type that, if TRUE, clears all pending record locks, then appends the next record. If FALSE, all pending record locks are maintained, and the new record is added to the end of the lock list. The default value is TRUE.
dbappend.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE. If successfully added, each field in the record is set to the empty value for its data type, and the new record becomes the current record.
dbappend.remarks:
By default, this function operates on the database file in the currently selected work area. It can be made to operate on an unselected work area by specifying it within an aliased expression. DBAppend(TRUE) performs the same function as the APPEND BLANK command. For more information, refer to APPEND BLANK.
Logical records: DBAppend() does not respect logical visibility. That is, if the record is successfully added, it becomes the current record, regardless of any order or filter condition. Shared mode: For a shared database, DBAppend() automatically places a record lock on the new record. If the record cannot be locked, NetErr() is set to TRUE, indicating that the record was not added, and execution continues. For more information, refer to "Concurrency Control" in the Programmer's Guide.
dbappend.example:
The following example appends a blank record, checks for a NetErr() condition, and updates the data:
DBUseArea(TRUE, "DBFNTX", "sales", "Sales", ; TRUE) ... <Statements> DBAppend() IF !NetErr() Sales->FirstName := cFirst Sales->LastName := cLast ELSE QOut("Append operation failed") ENDIF
The following example first locks a record and then appends a blank record to the SALES database without releasing the record locks in the current lock list. It also checks for errors:
USE sales NEW DBRLock() // Lock the current record // Add a new record but keep the old lock IF DBAppend(FALSE) .AND. !NetErr() ? "Multiple records are locks" ELSE ? "An error has occurred!" ENDIF

dbappsdf.summary: Import records from an SDF file.
dbappsdf.param:
The name of the SDF file from which to add records, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. The default extension is .TXT.
This function attempts to open <cSourceFile> in shared mode. If the file does not exist, a runtime error is raised. If the file is successfully opened, the operation proceeds. If access is denied because, for example, another process has exclusive use of the file, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.
A list of fields to copy from <cSourceFile>. The default is all records.
The number of records to append, starting at the first record.
The number of the record to append.
TRUE or FALSE processes all records.
dbappsdf.remarks: DBAppSDF() is the functional equivalent of the APPEND FROM SDF command. It is the same as the DBApp() function except that it can be used only with SDF files. See APPEND FROM and DBApp() for more information.
dbappsdf.example:
The following example appends text from an SDF file:
USE test NEW DBAppSDF("srcsdf")

dbclearfilter.remarks:
DBClearFilter() performs the same function as the SET FILTER command with no expression specified. For more information, refer to SET FILTER.
Logical records: DBClearFilter() affects the logical visibility of records in a work area. For more information, refer to DBSetFilter() and the SET FILTER command.
dbclearfilter.example:
The following example sets a filter, lists data as filtered, and then clears the filter:
USE employee NEW DBSetFilter({|| Age < 40}, "Age < 40") GO TOP LIST Employee->Name DBClearFilter()

dbclearindex.summary: Remove orders from the order list in a work area and close associated index files.
dbclearindex.param: The name of the order to clear or a number representing its position in the order list. Using the order name is the preferred method since the position may be difficult to determine using multiple-order index files. If not specified, all orders in the specified index file (or the entire work area, if no index file is specified) are cleared. Invalid values are ignored.

The name of an index file, including an optional drive and directory (no extension should be specified). Use this argument with <uOrder> to remove ambiguity when there are two or more orders with the same name in different index files. Use it alone to close only those orders associated with the specified file.
If <cIndexFile> is not open by the current process, a runtime error is raised.
dbclearindex.remarks: All pending updates are written to disk prior to closing the index files. Once the files are closed and the order list cleared, the database file returns to its natural order.
dbclearindex.example:
The following example closes index files if any are open:
DBUseArea(TRUE, "DBFNTX", "sales", "Sales", ; TRUE) Sales->DBSetIndex("FirstName") Sales->DBSetIndex("LastName") // Are there any open index files? IF Sales->DBOrderInfo(DBOI_NUMBER) > 0 Sales->DBClearIndex() // Close index files ENDIF // Copy to SDF in natural order COPY TO temp SDF

dbclearordercondition.summary: Clear the condition and scope for an order.
dbclearordercondition.remarks: This function calls OrdCondSet() with its default arguments to clear the order condition.

dbclearrelation.remarks: DBClearRelation() performs the same function as the SET RELATION command with no clauses specified. For more information, refer to the SET RELATION command.
dbclearrelation.example:
The following example sets a relation, lists data, and then clears the relation:
USE employee NEW USE department NEW INDEX dept SELECT Employee DBSetRelation("Department", ; {|| Employee->Dept}, "Employee->Dept") LIST Employee->Name, Department->Name DBClearRelation()

dbcloseall.summary: Close all files in all work areas.
dbcloseall.remarks: DBCloseAll() releases all occupied work areas from use. It is equivalent to calling DBCloseArea() on every occupied work area. DBCloseAll() has the same effect as the CLOSE DATABASES command. For more information, refer to the CLOSE command.
dbcloseall.example:
The following example closes all work areas:
cLast := "Winston" DBUseArea(TRUE, "DBFNTX", "sales", "Sales", TRUE) Sales->DBSetIndex("salefnam") Sales->DBSetIndex("salelnam") DBUseArea(TRUE, "DBFNTX", "colls", "Colls", TRUE) Colls->DBSetIndex("collffnam") Colls->DBSetIndex("colllnam") // Select "Sales" work area IF (Sales->DBSeek(cLast)) IF Sales->Deleted() IF Sales->RLock() Sales->DBRecall() QOut("Record deleted: ", Sales->Deleted()) ENDIF ENDIF ELSE QOut("Not found") ENDIF DBCloseAll() // Close all work areas

dbclosearea.summary: Close all files in a work area.
dbclosearea.remarks:
DBCloseArea() releases a work area from use.
DBCloseArea() is equivalent to the CLOSE command or the USE command with no clauses. For more information, refer to the USE and CLOSE commands.
dbclosearea.example:
The following example closes a file via an alias reference:
cLast := "Winston" DBUseArea(TRUE, "DBFNTX", "sales", "Sales", TRUE) Sales->DBSetIndex("salefnam") Sales->DBSetIndex("salelnam") DBUseArea(TRUE, "DBFNTX", "colls", "Colls", TRUE) Colls->DBSetIndex("collfnam") Colls->DBSetIndex("colllnam") // Select "Sales" work area IF Sales->DBSeek(cLast) IF Sales->Deleted() .AND. ; Sales->RLock() QOut("Record deleted: ", Sales->Deleted()) ENDIF ELSE QOut("Not found") Colls->DBCloseArea() ENDIF

dbcommit.summary: Flush all pending updates in one work area.
dbcommit.remarks:
DBCommit() causes all updates to the work area to be written to disk.
All updated database and order buffers are written to DOS, and a DOS Commit request is issued for the database file and any index files associated with the work area. DBCommit() performs the same function as the DBCommitAll() function, except that it operates only on the current or aliased work area.
Shared mode: DBCommit() makes database updates visible to other processes. To insure data integrity, issue DBCommit() before an unlock operation. For more information, refer to "Concurrency Control" in the Programmer's Guide. DBCommit() uses DOS interrupt 21h function 68h to perform the solid-disk write. It is up to the network software to properly implement this request. Check with the network software vendor to see if this is supported.
dbcommit.example:
In this example, DBCommit() is used to force a write to disk after a series of memory variables are assigned to field variables:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL cName, cAmount USE sales EXCLUSIVE NEW cName := Sales->Name cAmount := Sales->Amount @ 10, 10 GET cName @ 11, 10 GET cAmount READ IF Updated() IF DBAppend() REPLACE Sales->Name WITH cName REPLACE Sales->Amount WITH cAmount Sales->DBCommit() ENDIF ENDIF

dbcommitall.summary: Flush all pending updates in all work areas.
dbcommitall.remarks:
DBCommitAll() causes all pending updates to all work areas to be written to disk. It is equivalent to calling DBCommit() for every occupied work area. For more information, refer to DBCommit().
DBCommitAll() uses DOS interrupt 21h function 68h to perform the solid-disk write. It is up to the network software to properly implement this request. Check with the network software vendor to see if this is supported.
dbcommitall.example:
The following example writes all pending updates to disk:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL cLast := "Winston" DBUseArea(TRUE, "DBFNTX", "sales", ; "Sales", TRUE) Sales->DBSetIndex("salefnam") Sales->DBSetIndex("salelnam") DBUseArea(TRUE, "DBFNTX", "colls", "Colls", ; TRUE) Colls->DBSetIndex("collfnam") Colls->DBSetIndex("colllnam") IF Sales->DBSeek(cLast) IF Sales->Deleted() .AND. Sales->RLock() Sales->DBRecall() QOut("Deleted record recalled.") ENDIF ELSE QOut("Not found") ENDIF // Processing done, write updates to disk and // close files DBCommitAll() DBCloseAll()

dbcontinue.remarks: DBContinue() is the functional form of the CONTINUE command. For more information, see the CONTINUE command.
dbcontinue.example:
The following example searches for all occurrences of the name "Winston":
DBUseArea(TRUE, "DBFNTX", "address", "Address",; TRUE) LOCATE FOR UPPER(Address->Name) == "WINSTON" DO WHILE Found() ? RECNO() DBContinue() ENDDO

dbcopy.summary: Export records to a new database file.
dbcopy.param:
The name of the target file, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. The default extension for database files is determined by the RDD (see the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide for details on a particular RDD). For text files, it is .TXT.
If <cTargetFile> does not exist, it is created. If it exists, this function attempts to open the file in exclusive mode and, if successful, the file is overwritten without warning or error. If access is denied because, for example, another process is using the file, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.
DBCreate() creates the specified file in ANSI or OEM character set format, based on the SetAnsi() setting. (For more information, refer to the SetAnsi() function.)
A list of fields to copy to <cTargetFile>. The default is all fields.
The number of records to append, starting at the current record.
The number of the record to append.
TRUE processes only records from the current record to end-of-file. FALSE processes all records.
The name of the RDD that will service the work area. If not specified, the default RDD as determined by RDDSetDefault() is used.

A one-dimensional array with the names of RDDs from which the main RDD inherits special functionality. This allows you to use RDDs with special capabilities, like encryption or decryption, in different work areas with different database drivers. These RDDs overlay special functions of the main RDD (specified with the <cDriver> argument). If multiple RDDs (specified with this argument) implement the same function, the function associated with the last RDD in the list takes precedence. If <aRDDs> is omitted, no additional RDDs are assumed.
dbcopy.remarks: By default, this function copies records from the database file in the currently selected work area to a new file. It can be made to operate on an unselected work area by specifying it within an aliased expression. If SetDeleted() is FALSE, deleted records in the source file are copied to <cTargetFile> where they retain their deleted status. If SetDeleted() is TRUE, however, no deleted records are copied. Similarly, if a filter has been set, invisible records are not copied. DBCopy() is the functional equivalent of the COPY TO command, specified without a DELIMITED or SDF clause.
dbcopy.example:
The following example copies records from the current database file to a new database file:
USE Test NEW DBCopy("newdb.dbf")

dbcopydelim.summary: Export records to a new delimited text file.
dbcopydelim.param:
The name of the target file, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. The default extension for database files is determined by the RDD (see the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide for details on a particular RDD). For text files, it is .TXT.
If <cTargetFile> does not exist, it is created. If it exists, this function attempts to open the file in exclusive mode and, if successful, the file is overwritten without warning or error. If access is denied because, for example, another process is using the file, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.
The delimiter used to separate fields in <cTargetFile>. The default delimiter is a double quote mark.
A list of fields to copy to <cTargetFile>. The default is all fields.
The number of records to append, starting at the current record.
The number of the record to append.
TRUE processes only records from the current record to end-of-file. FALSE processes all records.
dbcopydelim.remarks: DBCopyDelim() is the functional equivalent of the COPY TO DELIMITED command. It is the same as DBCopy() except that it copies records to a delimited text file. See COPY TO and DBCopy() for more information.
dbcopydelim.example:
The following example copies records from the current database file to a delimited text file:
USE Test NEW IF Used() DBCopyDelim("newdelim") ENDIF

dbcopysdf.summary: Export records to a new SDF file.
dbcopysdf.param:
The name of the target file, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. The default extension for database files is determined by the RDD (see the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide for details on a particular RDD). For text files, it is .TXT.
If <cTargetFile> does not exist, it is created. If it exists, this function attempts to open the file in exclusive mode and, if successful, the file is overwritten without warning or error. If access is denied because, for example, another process is using the file, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.
A list of fields to copy to <cTargetFile>. The default is all fields.
The number of records to append, starting at the current record.
The number of the record to append.
TRUE processes only records from the current record to end-of-file. FALSE processes all records.
dbcopysdf.remarks: DBCopySDF() is the functional equivalent of the COPY TO SDF command. It is the same as DBCopy() except that it copies records to an SDF file. See COPY TO and DBCopy() for more information.
dbcopysdf.example:
The following example copies records from the current database file to an SDF file:
USE Test NEW IF Used() DBCopySDF("newsdf") ENDIF

dbcopystruct.summary: Create an empty database file with field definitions from another database file.
dbcopystruct.param:
The name of the target database file, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. The default extension for database files is determined by the RDD (see the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide for details on a particular RDD).
If <cTargetFile> does not exist, it is created. If it exists, this function attempts to open the file in exclusive mode and, if successful, the file is overwritten without warning or error. If access is denied because, for example, another process is using the file, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.
DBCopyStruct() creates the specified file in ANSI or OEM character set format, based on the SetAnsi() setting. (For more information, refer to the SetAnsi() function.)
A one-dimensional array of field names to copy to the new database file. The default is all fields.
dbcopystruct.remarks: DBCopyStruct() is the functional equivalent of the COPY STRUCTURE command.
dbcopystruct.example:
The following example copies the structure of the current database file to a new database file:
USE Test NEW IF Used() DBCopyStruct("c:\savestru\test") ENDIF

dbcopyxstruct.summary: Copy the field definitions in a database file structure to a structure-extended file as data.
dbcopyxstruct.param:
The name of the target structure-extended database file, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. The default extension for database files is determined by the RDD (see the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide for details on a particular RDD).
If <cTargetFile> does not exist, it is created. If it exists, this function attempts to open the file in exclusive mode and, if successful, the file is overwritten without warning or error. If access is denied because, for example, another process is using the file, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.
DBCreate() creates the specified file in ANSI or OEM character set format, based on the SetAnsi() setting. (For more information, refer to the SetAnsi() function.)
dbcopyxstruct.remarks:
DBCopyXStruct() creates a database file whose contents is the structure of the current database file, with a record for the definition of each field.
The structure-extended database file has the following structure: Name Type Length Decimals Field_Name Character 10 Field_Type Character 1 Field_Len Numeric 3 0 Field_Dec Numeric 3 0 Used in application programs, DBCopyXStruct() permits you to create or modify the structure of a database file programmatically. To create a new database file from the structure-extended file, use CREATE FROM. If you need an empty structure-extended file, use CREATE. DBCopyXStruct() is the functional implementation of the COPY STRUCTURE EXTENDED command.
Character field lengths greater than 255: Field lengths greater than 255 are represented as a combination of the Field_Dec and Field_Len fields. After performing DBCopyXStruct(), you can use the following formula to determine the length of any character field:
nFieldLen := If((Field_Type = "C" .AND. ; Field_Dec != 0), Field_Dec * 256 + ; Field_Len, Field_Len)
dbcopyxstruct.example:
The following example creates a new structure-extended file:
USE test IF Used() DBCopyXStruct("stru.dbf") ENDIF

dbcreate.summary: Create a database file from a database structure array.
dbcreate.param:
The name of the new database file, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. The default extension for database files is determined by the RDD (see the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide for details on a particular RDD).
If <cTargetFile> does not exist, it is created. If it exists, this function attempts to open the file in exclusive mode and, if successful, the file is overwritten without warning or error. If access is denied because, for example, another process is using the file, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.
DBCreate() creates the specified file in ANSI or OEM character set format, based on the SetAnsi() setting. (For more information, refer to the SetAnsi() function.)
An array containing field descriptions in the format returned by DBStruct(). This array defines the structure for the new database file.
The name of the RDD that will service the work area. If not specified, the default RDD as determined by RDDSetDefault() is used.
TRUE opens the database file in a new work area (first available). FALSE opens it in the current work area. <lNew> is useful only when <lOpen> has a value of TRUE. The default is FALSE.

The alias to be associated with the work area where the file is opened. Within a single application, X# will not accept duplicate aliases. <cAlias> is useful only when <lOpen> has a value of TRUE. The default alias is the eight-letter database file name .

The delimiter for fields within a delimited database file. If you are using one of the supplied RDDs for processing .DBF files (see the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide for a complete list), the delimiter should be a NULL_STRING, which is the default if the
argument is omitted.

TRUE specifies that an existing database file be opened; FALSE specifies that that a new database file be opened. The default is FALSE. This can be used to open existing SDF and delimited files, which do not have a structure in the header — in which case, <aStruct> should be used.

A one-dimensional array with the names of RDDs from which the main RDD inherits special functionality. This allows you to use RDDs with special capabilities, like encryption or decryption, in different work areas with different database drivers. These RDDs overlay special functions of the main RDD (specified with the <cDriver> argument). If multiple RDDs (specified with this argument) implement the same function, the function associated with the last RDD in the list takes precedence. If <aRDDs> is omitted, no additional RDDs are assumed.
dbcreate.returns: TRUE if the requested actions are successful; otherwise, FALSE.
dbcreate.remarks: DBCreate() creates a database file from an array containing the structure of the file. DBCreate() is similar to the CREATE FROM command, which creates a new database file structure from a structure-extended file. Before using DBCreate(), you must first create the <aStruct> array and fill it with the field definition arrays, according to the structure in the table above. You can create the array programmatically or by using DBStruct(). There are some specific rules for creating a field definition array, including: - Specify all field attributes with a value of the proper data type for the attribute. The decimals attribute must be specified — even for non-numeric fields. If the field does not have a decimals attribute, specify 0. - Specify the type attribute using the first letter of the data type as a minimum. Use longer and more descriptive terms for readability. For example, both "C" and "Character" can be specified as the type attribute for character fields. - Unlike the CREATE FROM command, DBCreate() does not use the decimals attribute to specify the high-order part of the field length. Specify the field length directly, regardless of its magnitude.
dbcreate.example:
The following example demonstrates DBCreate():
USE test IF Used() DBCreate("newdb.dbf", DBStruct(), "",; TRUE,"", "", FALSE) ENDIF
This example creates an empty array and then adds field definition subarrays using the AAdd() function before creating PEOPLE.DBF. You might use this technique to add field definitions to your structure array dynamically:
aDBF := {} AAdd(aDBF, {"Name", "C", 25, 0}) AAdd(aDBF, {"Address", "C", 1024, 0}) AAdd(aDBF, {"Phone", "N", 13, 0}) DBCreate("people", aDBF)
This next example performs the same types of actions as the example above, but it declares the structure array as a two-dimensional array, and then uses subscript addressing to specify the field definitions. The database file is created using the DBFMDX RDD:
LOCAL aDBF[1][4] aDBF[1][DBS_NAME] := "Name" aDBF[1][DBS_TYPE] := "Character" aDBF[1][DBS_LEN] := 25 aDBF[1][DBS_DEC] := 0 DBCreate("Name", aDBF, "DBFMDX")

dbcreateindex.summary: Create an index file and add an order to it.
dbcreateindex.param:
The name of the target index file, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. The default extension is determined by the RDD and can be obtained using DBOrderInfo(DBOI_INDEXEXT).
In RDDs that support production indexes, the production index file is assumed if <cIndexFile> is not specified.
If <cIndexFile> does not exist, it is created.
If <cIndexFile> exists, DBCreateIndex() must first obtain exclusive use of the file. If successful, the file is overwritten without warning or error. If the attempt is unsuccessful because, for example, the file is open by another process, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information.

The order key expression specified as a string. This is the key expression that is stored in the index file and used for such purposes as locating key values and recreating the order.
Although <cKeyValue> is optional, it is highly recommended that you specify this argument. Without it, the order will be properly created using <cbKeyValue>, but the key expression will be stored in the index file as a NULL_STRING, rendering the order unusable for subsequent access.

The order key expression specified as a code block. This code block is used to initially create the order. If you do not supply <cbKeyValue>, it is macro-compiled from <cKeyValue> (for example, {||&<cKeyValue>}).
The data type of the key expression and all other limitations, including the length of the key and the key expression, are determined by the RDD (see the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide for information about RDD limitations.)
TRUE creates a unique order by including only those records with unique key values; FALSE uses all records in the database file. If <lUnique> is omitted, the SetUnique() setting is used.
dbcreateindex.remarks:
By default, this function creates an index file for the database file associated with the currently selected work area. It can be made to operate on an unselected work area by specifying it within an aliased expression. DBCreateIndex() uses the current DBSetOrderCondition() to determine the conditions for the order (for example, its scope, for condition, and while condition). If there are other open index files in the work area, they are closed. After the new index file is created, an order is added to the file using the index file name and the specified key. The index file is opened (in the same mode as its associated database file), the controlling order for the work area is set, and the database file is positioned to the first logical record. Note: If the RDD supports multiple orders per index file, add subsequent orders to the index file using DBCreateOrder(). See the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide if you are unsure about multiple-order support for a particular RDD.
Side effects: DBCreateIndex() is guaranteed to create an order that, when made the controlling order, will impose the specified logical order on the database. The key expression is not necessarily evaluated at any particular time, by any particular means, or on any particular record or series of records. If the key expression relies on information external to the database file or work area, the effect is unpredictable. If the key expression changes the state of the work area (for example, by moving to a different record or changing the contents of a record), the effect is unpredictable. Key evaluation: Before the key expression is evaluated, the associated work area is automatically selected as the current work area; the previously selected work area is automatically restored afterward.
dbcreateindex.example:
This example creates an index file, EMPNAME, indexed on the Name field:
USE employee NEW Employee->DBCreateIndex("EmpName", "Name", ; {|| Employee->Name})

dbcreateorder.summary: Create or replace an order in an index file.
dbcreateorder.param: The name of the order to be created. For single-order index files, the file name without an extension or path, is the default order name. For multiple-order index files, the order name is required.

The name of the target index file, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. The default extension is determined by the RDD and can be obtained using DBOrderInfo(DBOI_INDEXEXT).
In RDDs that support production indexes , the production index file (that is, one with the same name as the database file) is assumed if <cIndexFile> is not specified.
If <cIndexFile> does not exist, it is created.
If <cIndexFile> exists, the INDEX command must first obtain exclusive use of the file. If the attempt is unsuccessful because, for example, the file is open by another process, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information.
If the attempt is successful and the RDD specifies that index files can contain only a single order, the current contents of the file is overwritten with the new order. If the RDD specifies that index files can contain multiple orders, the order is added to <cIndexFile> if it does not already exist; otherwise it is replaced.

The order key expression specified as a string. This is the key expression that is stored in the index file and used for such purposes as locating key values and recreating the order.
Although <cKeyValue> is optional, it is highly recommended that you specify this argument. Without it, the order will be properly created using <cbKeyValue>, but the key expression will be stored in the index file as a NULL_STRING, rendering the order unusable for subsequent access.

The order key expression specified as a code block. This code block is used to initially create the order. If you do not supply <cbKeyValue>, it is macro-compiled from <cKeyValue> (for example, {||&<cKeyValue>}).
The data type of the key expression and all other limitations, including the length of the key and the key expression, are determined by the RDD (see the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide for information about RDD limitations.)

TRUE creates a unique order by including only those records with unique key values; FALSE uses all records in the database file. If <lUnique> is omitted, the SetUnique() setting is used.Note that keys from deleted records are also included in the index, and may hide keys from non-deleted records.
dbcreateorder.remarks:
DBCreateOrder() uses the current DBSetOrderCondition() to determine the conditions for the order (for example, its scope, for condition, and while condition). After it is created (or replaced), the new order is added to the order list for the work area. Other orders already associated with the work area, including the controlling order, are unaffected. Note: Although this function is designed to work with both single-order and multiple-order index files, you may find it is easier to use DBCreateIndex() for creating single-order index files.
Side effects: DBCreateOrder() is guaranteed to create an order that, when made the controlling order, will impose the specified logical order on the database. The key expression is not necessarily evaluated at any particular time, by any particular means, or on any particular record or series of records. If the key expression relies on information external to the database file or work area, the effect is unpredictable. If the key expression changes the state of the work area (for example, by moving to a different record or changing the contents of a record), the effect is unpredictable. Key evaluation: Before the key expression is evaluated, the associated work area is automatically selected as the current work area; the previously selected work area is automatically restored afterward.
dbcreateorder.example:
This example creates the order CUACCT and adds it to the production index file CUSTOMER:
USE customer VIA "DBFMDX" NEW Customer->DBCreateOrder("CuAcct", "Customer", ; "Acct", {|| Customer->Acct})

dbdelete.summary: Mark the current record for deletion.
dbdelete.remarks:
Records marked for deletion can be filtered using SetDeleted() or removed from the file using DBPack().
DBDelete() is the functional equivalent of the DELETE command with a scope of the current record. For more information, refer to DELETE.
Logical records: If SetDeleted() is TRUE, deleted records are not logically visible. That is, database operations which operate on logical records will not consider records marked for deletion. Note, however, that if SetDeleted() is TRUE when the current record is marked for deletion, the record remains visible until it is no longer the current record. Shared mode: For a shared database, DBDelete() requires the current record to be locked. For more information, refer to "Concurrency Control" in the Programmer's Guide.
dbdelete.example:
The following example deletes a record after a successful record lock:
cLast := "Winston" DBUseArea(TRUE, "DBFNTX", "sales", "Sales", TRUE) Sales->DBSetIndex("LastName") IF Sales->DBSeek(cLast) IF Sales->RLock() Sales->DBDelete() QOut("Record deleted: ", Sales->Deleted()) ELSE QOut("Unable to lock record...") ENDIF ELSE QOut("Not found") ENDIF

dbdeleteorder.summary: Remove an order from an open index file.
dbdeleteorder.param: The name of the order to be removed or a number representing its position in the order list. Using the order name is the preferred method since the position may be difficult to determine using multiple-order index files. If the order cannot be found, a runtime error is raised.

The name of an index file, including an optional drive and directory (no extension should be specified). Use this argument with <cOrder> to remove ambiguity when there are two or more orders with the same name in different index files.
If <cIndexFile> is not open by the current process, a runtime error is raised.
dbdeleteorder.remarks:
DBDeleteOrder() requires that the current database be open in exclusive mode. If this condition is not met when DBDeleteOrder() is invoked, a runtime error is raised. DBDeleteOrder() deletes one order from a multiple-order index file and removes the order from the current order list. To delete the entire index file, use a regular file handling function such as Windows DeleteFile().
Note: The RDD determines the order capacity of an index file, and DBDeleteOrder() is supported only by RDDs with multiple-order capabilities. For single-order index files, you must delete the entire file. See the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide for details on a particular RDD.
Third-party RDD suppliers may define specific behaviors for this function.
dbdeleteorder.example:
In this example, since both open index files may contain an order named CUACCT, the DBDeleteOrder() function distinguishes which index file to use:
USE customer VIA "DBFMDX" NEW Customer->DBSetIndex("customer") Customer->DBSetIndex("custtemp") Customer->DBDeleteOrder("cuacct", "customer")

dbdriver.summary: Return the default RDD for the application.
dbdriver.returns: The name of the RDD that will be used to activate and manage applications when no driver is explicitly specified. If this RDD is not available to the application, the call has no effect.
dbdriver.remarks: To set the default RDD, use RDDSetDefault().
dbdriver.example:
The following example checks the default RDD to report the default extension for the index files:
IF DBDriver() == "DBFMDX" QOut(".MDX extension") ENDIF

dbeval.summary: Evaluate a code block for each record that matches a specified scope and/or condition.
dbeval.param: The code block to execute for each record that matches the scope and conditions.
The number of records to process, starting at the current record.
The number of the record to process.
TRUE processes only records from the current record to end-of-file. FALSE processes all records.
dbeval.remarks: On each iteration, DBEval() evaluates the specified code block. All records within the scope or matching the condition are processed until end-of-file is reached. DBEval() is similar to AEval(), which executes code for each element in an array. Like AEval(), DBEval() can be used as a primitive for the construction of commands that process database files. In fact, many of the X# database processing commands are created using DBEval().
dbeval.example:
This example uses DBEval() to enhance the DBList() function:
GLOBAL siFCount FUNCTION MyListAll(cFile AS STRING) AS LOGIC PASCAL LOCAL lRetCode AS LOGIC USE test IF Used() siFCount := FCount() cbDisp := {|| ShowFields()} GO TOP lRetCode := DBEval(cbDisp) ENDIF RETURN lRetCode FUNCTION ShowFields() AS VOID PASCAL LOCAL i AS WORD IF Deleted() QOut("*") ELSE QOut() ENDIF FOR i := 1 UPTO siFCount QQOut(FieldGet(i)) QQOut(" ") NEXT

dbf.summary: Return the name of the alias. Note: DBF() is a compatibility function and is no longer recommended. It is superseded by Alias0(). See Alias0() for more information.
dbf.returns: The alias of the work area as a string. If there is no active database file in the work area, DBF() returns a NULL_STRING.

dbfieldinfo.summary: Return and optionally change information about a field.
dbfieldinfo.param:
Specifies the type of information. The constants are described in the Constants section below. Note, however, that not all constants are supported for all RDDs.
Important! DBS_USER is a constant that returns the minimum value that third-party RDD developers can use for defining new <kInfoType> parameters. Values less than DBS_USER are reserved for Computer Associates development.

The position of the field in the database file structure or a numeric pointer to a BLOB. Only certain <kInfoType> constants designed to work with BLOB fields — all noted in the Constants section below — allow specifying the field using a pointer; all others require specifying the field by its position.

If specified, this parameter is used to change the value of a setting. The data type (and whether <uNewSetting> can be specified), depends on the <kInfoType> constant and is documented in the Constants section below.
