dibdelete.remarks: DIBDelete() destroys a DIB created by DIBCreateFromFile() or DIBCreateFromPtr().

dibgetinfo.summary: Retrieve a pointer to the BITMAPINFO structure of a DIB.
dibgetinfo.returns: Pointer to the BITMAPINFO structure, if successful; otherwise, NULL_PTR.
dibgetinfo.remarks: DIBGetInfo() retrieves a pointer to the BITMAPINFO structure of a DIB.

dibsaveas.summary: Save the DIB to a file.
dibsaveas.param: Name of the new DIB file.
dibsaveas.remarks: DIBSaveAs() saves the DIB as a file.
dibsaveas.example:
The following sample saves the image, test.jpg, as file, test.dib:
FUNC Start() LOCAL pDib AS PTR
pDib := DIBCreateFromFile("c:\test.jpg") IF pDib = NULL_PTR DIBSaveAs(pDib, "c:\test.dib") DIBDelete(pDib) ENDIF WAIT
RETURN

dibshow.summary: Display the DIB within the specified window.
dibshow.remarks: DIBShow() displays the DIB within to the specified window <hWnd>.

dibstretch.summary: Display the DIB within the specified window.
dibstretch.param: Width of the area for displaying the DIB.
Height of the area for displaying the DIB.
The zoom factor of the bitmap. A value of 1.0 would be its normal size.
dibstretch.remarks: DIBStretch() copies a DIB into a destination rectangle of <nWidth> by <nHeight>, stretching or compressing the bitmap by a factor of <r8Zoom> to fit the dimensions of the specified window, <hWnd>. <r8Zoom> can be calculated as <size of the area>/<size of the bitmap>. For example, a value of 2.0 would double the bitmap size, while a value of 0.5 would shrink the DIB to half its normal size.

dirchange.param: The name of the directory to change to, including the drive.
dirchange.returns: 0 if successful; -1 if there is an argument error; otherwise, the DOS error code. For a complete list of DOS error codes and accompanying descriptions, see Appendix A.
dirchange.remarks: DirChange() changes the current subdirectory or determines if a directory exists. Be aware that if, after issuing a DirChange(), you change to another drive (via DiskChange(), for example), another Windows task might change the directory of the disk on which your original DirChange() was issued.
dirchange.example:
This example uses DirChange():
siError := DirChange("c:\dos") IF siError != 0 ? DOSErrString(siError) ENDIF

directory.summary: Create an array of directory and file information.
directory.param: The file specification for the search. Besides a file name, this specification can include an optional drive, directory, and extension. The file name and extension can include the standard wildcard characters (* and ?). If you do not specify a drive and directory, the Windows defaults are used.

Specifies inclusion of files with special attributes in the returned information. <uAttributes> can be a string or a numeric. When specified as a string it can contain one or more of the characters listed in the table below. When specified as a numeric it can contain one or more of the constants listed in the following table:
Character Constant Description
D FA_DIRECTORY Directory
H FC_HIDDEN Hidden
S FC_SYSTEM System
V FA_VOLUME Volume label
To specify more than one constant, you can either add attributes together using the + operator, or use the _Or() operator, as in this example: _Or(FC_SYSTEM, FC_HIDDEN). To specify more than one string, simply concatenate them, as in "SH."
<uAttributes> specifies a criterion to satisfy in addition to any "visible" files that match the <cFileSpec>. Visible files do not include directories, volumes, or hidden or system files — all other files are visible, regardless of the status of their read or archive attributes. To include only visible files, omit this argument.
Note:To specify volume labels only, to the exclusion of all other files, specify FA_VOLUME or "V" as the sole <uAttributes> argument.
directory.returns: An array of subarrays, with each subarray containing information about each file matching <cFileSpec>. The subarray elements are referenced as follows (see example below): Constant Description F_ATTR File attributes (as a string) F_DATE Date of last update (as a date) F_NAME Name of file (as a string) F_SIZE Size of file (as a numeric) F_TIME Time of last update (as a string) If no files are found matching <cFileSpec> or if <cFileSpec> is an illegal path or file specification, Directory() returns an empty array.
directory.remarks: Directory() returns information about files in the current or specified directory. You can use it to perform actions on groups of files. In combination with AEval(), you can define a block that can be applied to all files matching the specified <cFileSpec>.
directory.example:
This example obtains an array of information about all files and directories in the current directory then lists the names of the files using AEval() and QOut():
aDirectory := Directory("*.*", "D") AEval(aDirectory, {|aFile| QOut(aFile[F_NAME])})
This example obtains an array of information about all files in the current directory: aDirectory := Directory("*.*") This example displays the name, size, date, time, and attribute of each file that matches the file specification *.PRG:
Function Start() LOCAL aDir AS ARRAY LOCAL i AS DWORD LOCAL wLen AS DWORD aDir := Directory("*.prg") wLen := ALen(aDir) FOR i := 1 UPTO wLen ? aDir[i][F_NAME], aDir[i][F_SIZE],; aDir[i][F_DATE], aDir[i][F_TIME],; aDir[i][F_ATTR] NEXT // Instead of the above FOR loop, you could // use the AEval() array iterator function as // follows: AEval(aDir, {|aSub| QOut(aSub[F_NAME],; aSub[F_SIZE], aSub[F_DATE], aSub[F_TIME],; aSub[F_ATTR])}) RETURN TRUE

dirmake.param: The name of the directory to create, including an optional drive. If you do not specify a drive, the Windows default is used.
dirmake.returns: 0 if successful; -1 if there is an argument error; otherwise, the DOS error code. For a complete list of DOS error codes and accompanying descriptions, see Appendix A.
dirmake.remarks: DirMake() creates a specified directory. You must have sufficient rights to create a directory. To create nested subdirectories, you must create each subdirectory separately, starting from the top-level directory that you want to create (see example below.)
dirmake.example:
This example assumes that C:\VO exists and uses DirMake() twice to create a nested subdirectory under it:
DirMake("c:\vo\one") // Create top-most one siResult := DirMake("c:\vo\one\two") IF siResult != 0 ? DOSErrString(siResult) // check DOS error ENDIF

dirremove.param: The name of the directory to erase, including an optional drive. If you do not specify a drive, the Windows default is used.
dirremove.returns: 0 if successful; -1 if there is an argument error; otherwise, the DOS error code. For a complete list of DOS error codes and accompanying descriptions, see Appendix A.
dirremove.remarks: DirRemove() removes a specified directory. You must have sufficient rights to delete a directory. A directory must be empty in order to be deleted. So, to delete a directory that contains subdirectories, you must first delete the subdirectories (see example below).
dirremove.example:
This example uses DirRemove() to delete a subdirectory named C:\VO\ONE, which only contains an empty subdirectory named C:\VO\ONE\TWO:
DirRemove("c:\vo\one\two") // First delete lowest dir siResult := DirRemove("c:\vo\one") // Then delete higher dir ? DOSErrString(siResult) // check DOS error if any

diskchange.param: The letter of the disk drive to change.
diskchange.example:
This example uses DiskChange() to change to drive D:
IF DiskChange("D:") ? "Successfully changed" ELSE ? "Not changed" ENDIF
This example builds a string that contains all currently available drives on your system:
FUNCTION AllDrives() LOCAL wI AS DWORD LOCAL cDrives AS STRING cDrives := NULL_STRING FOR wI := 1 UPTO 27 IF DiskChange(Chr(wI +64)) cDrives := cDrives + Chr(wI+64) ENDIF NEXT RETURN cDrives

diskfree.summary: Return the space available on a specified disk.
diskfree.param: The letter of the disk drive to query, for example "C:", "A:". The drive can also be identified by a number, where 1 is drive A, 2 is B, 3 is C, and so on. If you do not specify a drive, the Windows default is used.
diskfree.returns: The number of bytes of empty space on the specified disk drive.
diskfree.remarks: DiskFree() determines the number of available bytes remaining on the specified disk drive. It is useful when copying or sorting to another drive to determine if there is enough space available before initiating the operation.
diskfree.example:
This example is a function that demonstrates the use of DiskFree() to back up a database file to another drive:
FUNCTION BackUp(cTargetFile, cTargetDrive) LOCAL nSpaceNeeded LOCAL lSuccess := FALSE // Calculate the size of the open file nSpaceNeeded := Integer((RecSize() * ; LastRec()) + Header() + 1) IF DiskFree(cTargetDrive) < nSpaceNeeded lSuccess := FALSE ELSE // Close the database file before copying DBCloseArea() FCopy("sales.dbf", cTargetDrive + ":"+ cTargetFile) lSuccess := TRUE ENDIF RETURN lSuccess

diskname.returns: The letter of the current drive, without a trailing colon.
diskname.example:
This example illustrates the relationship between DiskName() and DiskChange() and shows that DiskName() is unaffected by SetDefault():
FUNCTION DriveTest() ? DiskName() // C SetDefault("A") ? DiskName() // C DiskChange("A") ? DiskName() // A DiskChange("C") ? DiskName() // C

diskspace.summary: Return the capacity of the specified disk.
diskspace.param: The number of the disk drive to query, where 1 is drive A, 2 is B, 3 is C, and so on. The drive can also be identified as a string, for example "C:", "A:". If you do not specify a drive, the Windows default is used.
diskspace.returns: The capacity of the specified disk drive in bytes.
diskspace.remarks: DiskSpace() determines the capacity of the specified disk drive in bytes. This function is only accurate for disk drives up to 2 gigabytes in size. For larger drives, please refer to the GetDiskFreeSpaceEx() Windows API function.
diskspace.example:
This example displays the capacity of the C drive in a TextBox:
TextBox{, "C Drive Capacity", AsString( DiskSpace(3) ) }:Show() TextBox{, "C Drive Capacity", AsString( DiskSpace("C:") ) }:Show()

doserror.summary: Return the last DOS error code associated with an activation of the runtime error block.
doserror.param: A DOS error number that changes the value returned by DOSError(). You can use it, for example, to reset the error code when trying to preserve the environment in black-box modules or when trying to counteract the side-effects from other modules.
doserror.returns: The number of the last DOS error. If the failed operation has no associated DOS error, DOSError() returns 0.
doserror.remarks: When a runtime error occurs and the operation has an associated DOS error, DOSError() is set to that error code. This value is retained until another runtime error occurs or until you set the value of DOSError() by specifying the <nNewDosCode> argument. For a complete list of DOS error codes and accompanying descriptions, see Appendix A. With file functions, FError() returns the same value as DOSError().
doserror.example:
The following example displays the DOS error code as a string:
FUNCTION Start() Dir AA: // Bad device QOut(DOSErrString(DOSError())) // Path not found

doserrstring.summary: Return a description string for a DOS error number.
doserrstring.param: The DOS error number that you want a description for.
doserrstring.example:
The following example displays the DOS error code as a string:
FUNCTION Start() Dir AA: // Bad device QOut(DOSErrString(DOSError())) // Path not found

dow.summary: Extract the number of the day of the week from a date.
dow.returns: The day of the week as a number from 1 to 7, where 1 is Sunday, 2 is Monday, and so on. For an invalid or NULL_DATE, DoW() returns 0.
dow.remarks: DoW() is a date conversion function that converts a date value to a number identifying the day of the week. It is useful when you want date calculations on a weekly basis. DoW() is similar to CDoW(), which returns the day of week as a string instead of a number.
dow.example:
These examples illustrate CDoW() and its relationship to DoW():
? TODAY() // 09/01/98 ? DOW(TODAY()) // 3 ? CDOW(TODAY()) // Tuesday ? DOW(TODAY() - 2) // 1 ? CDOW(TODAY() – 2) // Sunday

dtoc.summary: Convert a date to a string.
dtoc.returns: A string representation of <dDate>, formatted in the current date format. A NULL_DATE returns a string of spaces equal in length to the current date format.
dtoc.remarks: DToC() is a date conversion function used for formatting purposes when you want to display the date in the SetDateFormat() or SetDateCountry() format or when a string is required (in a LABEL FORM, for example). If you need a specialized date format, you can use Transform() or a custom expression. Since DToS() is in the form of yyyymmdd, it is usually the preferred form for indexing a date in combination with a string.
dtoc.example:
These examples show general uses of DToC():
? TODAY() // 09/01/98 ? DTOC(TODAY()) // 09/01/98 ? "Today is " + DTOC(TODAY()) // Today is 09/01/98

dtos.summary: Convert a date value to a string formatted as yyyymmdd.
dtos.returns: An 8-character string in the format yyyymmdd. If <dDate> is a NULL_DATE, a string of eight spaces is returned. The return value is not affected by the current date format.
dtos.remarks: DToS() is a date conversion function that is used when creating order keys consisting of a date value and a string. DToS() converts a date value to a string that can be concatenated to any other string. The return value is structured to preserve date order (year, month, and day).
dtos.example:
These examples simply apply DToS() to a date:
? TODAY() // 09/01/98 ? DTOS(TODAY()) // 19980901
This example applies DToS() to a date literal and reports its length: ? SLen(DTOS(0.0.0) // 8 This example demonstrates how to create an order with a compound date and character key using DToS():
USE sales NEW INDEX ON DTOS(SaleDate) + LastName TO datename

dw2bin.summary: Convert a double word to a string containing a 32-bit unsigned integer.
dw2bin.param: The value to convert. Decimal digits are truncated.
dw2bin.returns: A 4-byte string containing a 32-bit unsigned integer.
dw2bin.remarks: DW2Bin() is a conversion function that converts a double word to a 4-byte string. Typical applications include reading foreign file types in their native format and then saving, reading, decrypting, and transmitting numeric data in their compressed binary form instead of in strings. Its inverse is Bin2DW().
dw2bin.example:
This example uses DW2Bin() to record our current memory settings to a debugging file:
FUNCTION RecordMemory() AS LOGIC LOCAL nh LOCAL lSuccess := FALSE AS LOGIC nh := FOpen2("debug.doc", FO_READWRITE) // Assumes that file debug.doc already exists IF nh != F_ERROR FWrite3(nh, DW2Bin(Memory(1)), 4) FWrite3(nh, DW2Bin(Memory(2)), 4) FWrite3(nh, DW2Bin(Memory(3)), 4) FClose(nh) lSuccess := TRUE ELSE ? "An error occurred when opening debug.doc" FError() ENDIF RETURN lSuccess

dyncheckerror.summary: Get a description of the error which was discovered by an internal function that is used by the system to check dynamic memory for consistency.
dyncheckerror.returns: An error code, which is interpreted as follows: Error Code Meaning 0 No error. 1 A STRING is not OK. 2 An OBJECT is not OK. 3 An ARRAY is not OK. 4 A FIXED is not OK. (This is reserved for the future; it is not currently in use.) 5 A FLOAT is not OK. 6 An ARRAY element is not OK. 7 An unknown USUAL was found. 8 A USUAL type does not correspond to the internal DynType (USUAL and TYPED are a mismatch). 9 An unknown DynType (TYPED) was found. 10 A STACK is not OK.
dyncheckerror.example:
This example issues a DynCheckError() after calling the internal checking function:
IF !_DynCheck() ? "Error Code", DynCheckError() ENDIF

dyninfofree.summary: Return the number of bytes available for dynamic memory allocation.
dyninfofree.remarks: DynInfoFree() reports the size of memory currently available for dynamic allocation. Note that the amount reported may not all be in one contiguous block of memory. To find the size of the largest available contiguous block of memory, use the DynInfoMax() function. The dynamic memory system is not designed to replace database processing via external disk space; however, it should keep the programmer from having to allocate and free memory for local, global, and instance variables. The default maximum size available for dynamic memory is 16MB. Some applications need more dynamic memory. In versions of X# before 2.7 the memory was increased by registry settings but in 2.7 and above the memory is increased by the use of the SetMaxDynSize() function. To increase the dynamic memory to 32MB, you would set MaxDynSpace to 33554432. New values can be verified by calling DynInfoFree().

dyninfomax.summary: Return the number of bytes of contiguous memory available for dynamic memory allocation.
dyninfomax.remarks: DynInfoMax() is used to find the size of the largest available contiguous dynamic memory buffer. For memory allocations greater than DynInfoMax(), the garbage collector is first called to possibly create a larger contiguous block first. The largest contiguous block cannot be larger than MAX_ALLOC.
dyninfomax.example:
This example forces a garbage collection if the return of DynInfoMax() is lower than some user-specific value:
DEFINE A_WATERMARK := 4096 ... IF DynInfoMax() < A_WATERMARK CollectForced() ENDIF

dyninfosize.summary: Return the size of dynamic memory in 64 KB segments.
dyninfosize.remarks: Keep in mind when using this function that dynamic memory is always divided into a used and an unused half. DynInfoSize() returns the size of the used half — internally, twice the memory is allocated.

dyninfoused.summary: Return the number of bytes of dynamic memory in use.
dyninfoused.remarks: DynInfoUsed() reports the size of dynamic memory currently in use.

dynlock.summary: Lock dynamic memory and prevent the Garbage Collector from activating.
dynlock.remarks: DynLock() locks dynamic memory by preventing the garbage collector from compacting dynamic memory and releasing space. Without the garbage collector active, as application will continue to consume dynamic memory until it runs out.

dynprotect.summary: Protect dynamic memory that is not currently in use.
dynprotect.param: TRUE protects dynamic memory. FALSE removes the protection from dynamic memory. Specifying TRUE curtails performance.
dynprotect.remarks: DynProtect() determines whether unused collector memory is protected. After a garbage collection, DynProtect() lets you find forbidden references to old dynamic memory that cannot be written into. There is no need to call this function more than once; the system handles the protection and deprotection automatically.
dynprotect.example:
This example uses DynProtect():
LOCAL lSave lSave := DynProtect(TRUE) CollectForced() DynProtect(lSave) // Restore

dynshrink.summary: Shrink the dynamic memory pool to its minimum size.
dynshrink.returns: The new size of the memory pool in 64-KB segments.
dynshrink.remarks: The dynamic memory pool grows if the application needs more memory. For performance reasons, the dynamic memory manager will never try to shrink the dynamic memory pool, even if memory is freed. This function can be used to shrink dynamic memory explicitly to the minimum size. If memory is allocated later, the dynamic memory pool will grow again.
dynshrink.example:
This example demonstrates DynShrink():
? DynInfoSize() // Get size of dynamic memory in segments, e.g., 2 // Allocate dynamic memory a := SPACE(50000) b := SPACE(50000) c := SPACE(50000) ? DynInfoSize() // Dynamic memory has grown, new size e.g., 3 // Free memory again a := b :=c := NIL CollectForced() ? DynInfoSize() // Dynamic memory size is same ? DynShrink() // Dynamic memory back down to 2

dynsize.summary: Resize the dynamic memory pool to a specific number of pages.
dynsize.param: The number of pages that you want to allocate for the dynamic memory pool. Each page is 64 Kb.
dynsize.returns: The new size of the memory pool in pages. The return value will normally be the same as the <dwPages> argument.
dynsize.example: This example doubles the amount of dynamic memory: DynSize(DynInfoSize() * 2)

dyntooldspace.summary: Copy a dynamic object to static allocated memory.
dyntooldspace.param: The dynamic object you want to copy. It can be a string, a float, an object, or an array.
dyntooldspace.returns: The new, copied object in static memory.
dyntooldspace.remarks:
DynToOldSpace() lets you copy objects to static memory so that the garbage collector won't get them. If you pass a string as an argument to a function which directly or indirectly allocates dynamic memory, it can be collected. For example, if you issue Psz2String(Time()), the passed string argument (in this case, the string returned by Time()) can be wiped out by the garbage collector when Psz2String() utilizes dynamic allocation. Static strings, on the other hand, are not collected, so Psz2String("hello") could be issued without a problem. To free up a static buffer, use OldSpaceFree().
When an object is moved to OldSpace, any nested Strings, Floats, Objects and Arrays will also be moved to OldSpace automatically.
dyntooldspace.example:
This example uses DynToOldSpace() on a string:
FUNCTION GarbageProtect() AS VOID LOCAL cV AS STRING cV := TIME() cV := DynToOldSpace(cV) ? cV // Current time
This example ensures that a passed argument does not get wiped out by the garbage collector: Psz2String(DynToOldSpace(TIME()))

dyntooldspacearray.summary: Copy a typed dynamic object to static allocated memory.
dyntooldspacearray.param: The array you want to copy.
dyntooldspacearray.returns: The new, copied object in static memory.
dyntooldspacearray.remarks:
DynToOldSpaceArray() is the same as DynToOldSpace() except that it is strongly typed. For more information, see DynToOldSpace().
When an object is moved to OldSpace, any nested Strings, Floats, Objects and Arrays will also be moved to OldSpace automatically.
dyntooldspacearray.example:
This example uses DynToOldSpaceArray():
FUNCTION AProtect() LOCAL a AS ARRAY a := {1,2,3} a := DynToOldSpaceArray(a) ? a[1] // 1

dyntooldspacefloat.summary: Copy a typed dynamic object to static allocated memory.
dyntooldspacefloat.param: The floating point number you want to copy.
dyntooldspacefloat.returns: The new, copied object in static memory.
dyntooldspacefloat.remarks: DynToOldSpaceFloat() is the same as DynToOldSpace() except that it is strongly typed. For more information, see DynToOldSpace().
dyntooldspacefloat.example:
This example uses DynToOldSpaceFloat():
FUNCTION FProtect() LOCAL f AS FLOAT f := 3.14 f := DynToOldSpaceFloat(f) ? f // 3.14

dyntooldspaceobject.summary: Copy a typed dynamic object to static allocated memory.
dyntooldspaceobject.param: The class object you want to copy.
dyntooldspaceobject.returns: The new, copied object in static memory.
dyntooldspaceobject.remarks:
DynToOldSpaceObject() is the same as DynToOldSpace() except that it is strongly typed. For more information, see DynToOldSpace().
When an object is moved to OldSpace, any nested Strings, Floats, Objects and Arrays will also be moved to OldSpace automatically.
dyntooldspaceobject.example:
This example uses DynToOldSpaceObject():
FUNCTION OProtect() LOCAL o AS OBJECT o := MyClass{} o := DynToOldSpaceObject(o) ? o // Object representation

dyntooldspacestring.summary: Copy a typed dynamic object to static allocated memory.
dyntooldspacestring.param: The string you want to copy.
dyntooldspacestring.returns: The new, copied object in static memory.
dyntooldspacestring.remarks: DynToOldSpaceString() is the same as DynToOldSpace() except that it is strongly typed. For more information, see DynToOldSpace().
dyntooldspacestring.example:
This example uses DynToOldSpaceString():
FUNCTION SProtect() LOCAL s AS STRING s := TIME() s := DynToOldSpaceString(s) ? s // Hello

dynunlock.summary: Unlock dynamic memory and restart the Garbage Collector.
dynunlock.remarks: DynUnlock() unlocks dynamic memory and restarts the garbage collector.

elaptime.summary: Return the difference between two time strings.
elaptime.param: The starting time in the form hh:mm:ss.
The ending time in the form hh:mm:ss.
elaptime.returns: The amount of time that has elapsed from <cStartTime> to <cEndTime> as a time string in the format hh:mm:ss.
elaptime.remarks: ElapTime() calculates the difference between two time strings by subtracting <cStartTime> from <cEndTime>.

empty.summary: Determine if the result of an expression is empty.
empty.param:
An expression of any data type. The criteria for determining whether a value is considered empty depends on the data type of <uValue>, according to the following rules:
Data Type Contents
Array NULL_ARRAY or empty array
Code block NULL_CODEBLOCK
Date NULL_DATE
Logic FALSE
NIL NIL
VOID TRUE
Numeric 0
Object NULL_OBJECT
PSZ NULL_PSZ
PTR NULL_PTR
String Spaces, tabs, carriage return/line feed, or NULL_STRING
Symbol NULL_SYMBOL
empty.returns: TRUE if the expression results in an empty value; otherwise, FALSE.

emptyfield.summary: Determine if field number n in the current workarea is empty.
emptyfield.param: The field number in the current workarea.
emptyfield.returns: TRUE if the field is empty; otherwise FALSE.

emptyrecord.summary: Determine if the current record in the current workarea is empty.
emptyrecord.returns: TRUE if the record is empty; otherwise FALSE.

emptyusual.summary: Return the empty value of a specified data type.
emptyusual.param: The data type whose empty value is desired. The constants defining all X# data types are listed in the table below.
emptyusual.returns: The empty value of the data type specified by <kType>. These values are as follows: <kType> Empty Value ARRAY NULL_ARRAY or empty array BYTE, DWORD 0 FLOAT, INT 0 LONGINT, REAL4 0 REAL8, SHORTINT 0 WORD 0 CODEBLOCK NULL_CODEBLOCK DATE NULL_DATE LOGIC FALSE OBJECT NULL_OBJECT PSZ NULL_PSZ PTR NULL_PTR STRING Spaces, tabs, carriage return/line feed, or NULL_STRING SYMBOL NULL_SYMBOL USUAL NIL VOID NIL
emptyusual.example:
This example shows the result of EmptyUsual() for different data types:
? EmptyUsual(LOGIC) // FALSE ? EmptyUsual(SHORTINT) // 0 ? EmptyUsual(STRING) // NULL_STRING
This example passes the result of the EmptyUsual() function to the Empty() function:
? Empty(EmptyUsual(DATE)) // TRUE ? Empty(EmptyUsual(LONGINT)) // TRUE ? Empty(EmptyUsual(SYMBOL)) // TRUE

enable3dcontrols.summary:
Note - This function has no purpose in 32 bit programs. It is included for backward compatibility with 16 bit applications only.
Determines whether controls on windows created with the GUI classes are displayed using a sculpted, three-dimensional look.
enable3dcontrols.remarks: Controls (such as edit controls) that are displayed on a window are, by default, displayed using a flat, one-dimensional look. You can, however, assign various color attributes to the controls, using, for example, the Control:Background or TextControl:TextColor properties. Invoking Enable3DControls() causes them to be displayed with shading, producing a sculpted, three-dimensional effect, and disables all color attributes. Note: Enable3DControls() affects controls on windows created with the GUI classes (such as data windows) only. It has no effect on the terminal emulation window.
enable3dcontrols.example:
The Standard Application invokes this function in the App:Start() method, as illustrated in the example below. If you prefer the one-dimensional look, simply delete the call to Enable3DControls():
METHOD Start() CLASS App LOCAL oWindow AS Window Enable3DControls() oWindow := StandardShellWindow{SELF} oWindow:Show() SELF:Exec()

enableappvisualtheme.summary:
Note - For Windows XP and later only.
Enable or disable the applications support for visual themes.
enableappvisualtheme.param:
An optional logical value. TRUE sets the support for visual themes on, FALSE sets this off.
The default is TRUE.
enableappvisualtheme.returns: TRUE if visual themes are enabled; otherwise, FALSE.
enableappvisualtheme.remarks: Visual themes are automatically enabled if version 6 of the common controls is loaded by using an application manifest.

encodebase64.summary: Encode a file for e-mail transfer.
encodebase64.param: Handle of the file to encode.
Handle of the file to which the encoded text is to be written.
encodebase64.returns: The number of bytes that were encoded.
encodebase64.remarks: Base64 encoding is used to transmit files attached to messages over the Internet.
encodebase64.example:
hOut := FCreate("C:\MyFiles\MailOut.txt") IF hfOut != F_ERROR hIn := FOpen("C:\MyFiles\Source.txt", FO_READ) IF hIn != F_ERROR nTotalBytes := EncodeBase64(hIn, hOut) TextBox{,"Encode", "Bytes Encoded: " + ; AsString(nTotalBytes)}:Show() ENDIF ENDIF FClose(hfOut) FClose(hf)
For a more complete example of EncodeBase64(), see the Mime Encoding sample application (CAVOxx\SAMPLES\INTERNET\MIME\MENCODE.AEF).

enforcenumeric.summary: Make sure a variable is a numeric.
enforcenumeric.param: The variable to check. If <uVar> is NIL, a value of 0 is assigned to it. If <uVar> is not passed by reference and is not a numeric, the error system aborts the program. If <uVar> is passed by reference but is not a numeric, the error system is called up and a value of 0 is assigned to <uVar>.
enforcenumeric.example:
This example uses EnforceNumeric() to ensure that an argument is a numeric, initialized to 0:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL nOne LOCAL nTwo LOCAL cName CheckNumbers() FUNCTION CheckNumbers(nOne, nTwo) EnforceNumeric(@nOne) // Assigns 0 since NIL Default(@nTwo, 100) // Assigns 100 since NIL

enforcetype.summary: Make sure a variable is of a certain type.
enforcetype.param: The variable to check. If <uVar> is NIL and is passed by reference, the EmptyUsual() of the data type specified by <wType> is assigned to it. If <uVar> is not passed by reference and is not of the data type specified by <wType>, the error system aborts the program. If <uVar> is passed by reference but is not of the data type specified by <wType>, the error system is called up and the EmptyUsual() of the data type specified by <wType> is assigned to <uVar>.
enforcetype.example:
This example uses EnforceType() to ensure all arguments are of the correct type:
FUNCTION CheckArgs(cName, nScore, dDate, nMoney) EnforceType(@cName, STRING) EnforceType(@nScore, SHORTINT) // Assigns 0 if NIL EnforceType(@dDate, DATE) EnforceType(@nMoney, LONGINT) // Assigns 0 if NIL EnforceType(@nOne, SHORTINT) // Assigns 0 if NIL

eof.returns: TRUE when an attempt is made to move the record pointer beyond the last logical record in a database file or if the database file contains no records; otherwise, FALSE. If there is no database file open in the work area, EOF() returns TRUE.
eof.remarks: EOF() is a database function used to test for an end-of-file boundary condition when the record pointer is moving forward through a database file. Any command that can move the record pointer can set EOF(). The most typical application is as a part of the <lCondition> argument of a DO WHILE construct that sequentially processes records in a database file. Here <lCondition> would include a test for .NOT. EOF(), forcing the DO WHILE loop to terminate when EOF() returns TRUE. EOF() and Found() are often used interchangeably to test whether a SEEK, FIND, or LOCATE command failed. With these commands, however, Found() is preferred. When EOF() returns TRUE, the record pointer is positioned at LastRec() + 1 regardless of whether there is an active filter setting or SetDeleted() is TRUE. Further attempts to move the record pointer forward return the same result without error. Once EOF() is set to TRUE, it retains its value until there is another attempt to move the record pointer.
eof.example:
This example demonstrates EOF() by deliberately moving the record pointer beyond the last record:
USE sales DBGoBottom() QOut(EOF()) // Result: FALSE SKIP QOut(EOF()) // Result: TRUE
This example uses aliased expressions to query the value of EOF() in unselected work areas:
USE sales NEW USE customer NEW QOut(Sales->EOF()) QOut(Customer->EOF())
This example illustrates how EOF() can be used as part of a condition for sequential database file operations:
USE sales INDEX custnum NEW DO WHILE !(Sales->EOF()) nOldCust := Sales->CustNum nTotalAmount := 0 DO WHILE nOldCust = Sales->CustNum .AND. ; !(Sales->EOF() QOut(Sales->CustNum, ; Sales->Description, ; Sales->SaleAmount) nTotalAmount += Sales->SaleAmount SKIP ENDDO QOut("Total amount: ", nTotalAmount) ENDDO
You could have written the EOF check in the code above with an alias parameter to EOF() as well:
DO WHILE !EOF("Sales") . . ENDDO

errorblock.summary: Return and optionally change the code block that is executed when a runtime error occurs.
errorblock.param: The code block to execute whenever a runtime error occurs.
errorblock.returns: If <cbNewSetting> is not specified, ErrorBlock() returns the current setting. If <cbNewSetting> is specified, the previous setting is returned.
errorblock.remarks: X# defines a default error handling code block that determines what to do when a runtime error occurs. ErrorBlock() lets you override this default error handling mechanism with one that you define. Specify the error handler as a code block with the following form: {|<oError>| <uList>} where <oError> is an error object containing information about the error and <uList> is a comma-separated list of USUAL expressions that call the function that actually handles the errors. Within the code block, messages can be sent to the error object to obtain information about the error. A return value of TRUE from the error handling code block retries the failed operation, whereas a return value of FALSE resumes processing. The error handling code block can be specified either as a list of expressions or as a call to a function. A call to a function is more useful since you can use X# control statements instead of expressions. This is particularly the case if there is a BEGIN SEQUENCE or LabelPush() pending and you want to BREAK or LabelJump() to the nearest RECOVER statement. As this implies, error handling code blocks can be used in combination with BEGIN SEQUENCE...END and/or LabelPush()...LabelPop() control structures. Within an error handling code block, you handle device, low-level, and common errors that have a general recovery mechanism. If the operation needs specific error handling, define a BEGIN SEQUENCE or LabelPush(), then BREAK or LabelJump() to the RECOVER statement, returning the error object for local processing. See the example below. For more information on the structure and operations of error objects, refer to the Error Class entry and the "Error and Exception Handling" chapter in the Programmer's Guide.
errorblock.example:
This code fragment posts, then calls an error handling code block when there is an error within a BEGIN SEQUENCE construct:
LOCAL cbErrorHandler, cbLastHandler, oError cbErrorHandler := {|oError|MyErrorHandler(oError)} // Save current handler cbLastHandler := ErrorBlock(cbErrorHandler) BEGIN SEQUENCE . . <OperationStatements> . // Receive error object from BREAK RECOVER USING oErrorInfo . . <RecoveryStatements> . END ErrorBlock(cbLastHandler) // Restore handler FUNCTION MyErrorHandler(oError) BREAK oError // Return error object to RECOVER
This example improves on the previous example. Instead of setting up ErrorBlock({|oError| _Break(oError)}) which just does a BREAK without taking advantage of the facilities of the error system (for example, VOERROR.LOG), you could set up an Init method for the Error class as follows:
METHOD Init() CLASS Error SELF:Choice :=EC_BREAK
This way you always get a BREAK after successfully running the error system and also update VOERROR.LOG. EC_BREAK is already defined by the system.

errorbuild.summary: Call the currently installed error function and create a new error object.
errorbuild.param:
A pointer to the ErrInfo structure. ErrInfo is a structure that is used by the error system to contain information about an error. It is defined as follows:
MEMBER pszSubSystem AS PSZ
MEMBER dwSubCode AS DWORD
MEMBER dwGenCode AS DWORD //EG_
MEMBER dwOSCode AS DWORD
MEMBER dwSeverity AS DWORD
MEMBER lCanDefault AS LOGIC
MEMBER lCanRetry AS LOGIC
MEMBER lCanSubstitute AS LOGIC
MEMBER pszOperation AS PSZ
MEMBER pszDescription AS PSZ
MEMBER pszFileName AS PSZ
MEMBER strucArgs AS _ARGS
MEMBER dwTries AS DWORD
MEMBER symFuncSym AS SYMBOL
MEMBER dwFileHandle AS DWORD
MEMBER dwArgNum AS DWORD
MEMBER ptrFuncPtr AS PTR
MEMBER pszSubCodeText AS PSZ
MEMBER pszArg AS PSZ
MEMBER dwArgType AS DWORD
MEMBER dwArgTypeReq AS DWORD
MEMBER dwMaxSize AS DWORD
MEMBER dwSubstituteType AS DWORD
MEMBER dwChoice AS DWORD
MEMBER symCallFuncSym AS SYMBOL
errorbuild.remarks: An error block is installable via ErrorBlock(). An error function is installable via ErrorFunc(). ErrorBuild() may be of use to you if you are programming in C (or some other language besides X#) and want the error information to be available at the system level.
errorbuild.example:
Although ErrorBuild() is intended to be used in non-X# routines, this example is written in X# to convey the concept:
STATIC GLOBAL MystrucErrInfo IS ErrInfo FUNCTION ErrorLocal() MemClear(@MystrucErrInfo, _SizeOf(ErrInfo)) MystrucErrInfo.wGenCode := MYERRORCODE MystrucErrInfo.wSeverity := ES_ERROR MystrucErrInfo.symFuncSym := #MyDefError MystrucErrInfo.pszArg := AsPsz("MyBase") MystrucErrInfo.wArgNum := 1 MYstrucErrInfo.lCanDefault := FALSE oError := ErrorBuild(@MystrucErrInfo)

errorcount.summary: Return the number of errors that have occurred during program execution.
errorcount.param: Resets the error count for the application to the specified value.
errorcount.example:
These example produces an intentional error and shows the return value of ErrorCount():
FUNCTION Start() // Produce an error and get the error count LOCAL oError, nVal BEGIN SEQUENCE oError := ErrorBlock({|| _Break(NIL)}) nVal := 0 ? 1/nVal // Divide by 0 error END ErrorBlock(oError) ? ErrorCount() // 1 ErrorCount(0) // Reset error count to zero

errorexec.summary: Call the currently installed error function and error block.
errorexec.param:
A pointer to the ErrInfo structure. ErrInfo is a structure that is used by the error system to contain information about an error. It is defined as follows:
MEMBER pszSubSystem AS PSZ
MEMBER dwSubCode AS DWORD
MEMBER dwGenCode AS DWORD //EG_
MEMBER dwOSCode AS DWORD
MEMBER dwSeverity AS DWORD
MEMBER lCanDefault AS LOGIC
MEMBER lCanRetry AS LOGIC
MEMBER lCanSubstitute AS LOGIC
MEMBER pszOperation AS PSZ
MEMBER pszDescription AS PSZ
MEMBER pszFileName AS PSZ
MEMBER strucArgs AS _ARGS
MEMBER dwTries AS DWORD
MEMBER symFuncSym AS SYMBOL
MEMBER dwFileHandle AS DWORD
MEMBER dwArgNum AS DWORD
MEMBER ptrFuncPtr AS PTR
MEMBER pszSubCodeText AS PSZ
MEMBER pszArg AS PSZ
MEMBER dwArgType AS DWORD
MEMBER dwArgTypeReq AS DWORD
MEMBER dwMaxSize AS DWORD
MEMBER dwSubstituteType AS DWORD
MEMBER dwChoice AS DWORD
MEMBER symCallFuncSym AS SYMBOL
errorexec.returns: E_RETRY or E_DEFAULT. If, in a dialog box of the default error system, the user selects the retry option, E_RETRY is returned; otherwise E_DEFAULT is returned. Note that for the retry option to be enabled, ptrErrInfo.lCanRetry must be set to TRUE. For the default or ignore option to be enabled, ptrErrnfo.lCanDefault must be set to TRUE. If neither lCanRetry and lCanDefault is enabled, abort is the only user-selectable option.
errorexec.remarks: After the call to the currently installed error function, an error object is created. The current error block is evaluated using the new error object. An error block is installable via ErrorBlock(). An error function is installable via ErrorFunc(). ErrorExec() may be of use to you if you are programming in C (or some other language besides X#) and want the error information to be available at the system level.
errorexec.example:
This example calls ErrorExec() until a file is successfully opened by FRead2():
DEFINE EG_MYGENCODE := 1 FUNCTION Start() LOCAL strucMyErrInfo IS ErrInfo LOCAL ptrHandle AS PTR LOCAL wUserTries AS DWORD DO WHILE (ptrHandle := FOpen2("notexist.txt", FO_READWRITE)) = F_ERROR ? "Open failed. Calling ErrorExec()" WAIT strucMyErrInfo.wGenCode := EG_MYGENCODE strucMyErrInfo.wSeverity := ES_ERROR strucMyErrInfo.symFuncSym := #_MyModule strucMyErrInfo.pszFileName:= "notexist.txt" strucMyErrInfo.wOSCode := FError() strucMyErrInfo.lCanDefault:= TRUE strucMyErrInfo.lCanRetry := TRUE strucMyErrInfo.wTries := wUserTries wUserTries += 1 IF ErrorExec(@strucMyErrInfo) <> E_RETRY QUIT ELSE ? "Make sure that the file exists; and"+" has read-write attributes" ENDIF ENDDO

errorfunc.param: A pointer to a function which uses the CLIPPER calling convention.
errorfunc.returns: A pointer to the previous error function.
errorfunc.remarks: ErrorFunc() is comparable to ErrorBlock(), but, instead of installing a code block which will execute when an error occurs, ErrorFunc() installs a function which contains a pointer to an error structure. On error, the installed function is called by C or other language functions and a pointer to an error structure is passed to it. The installed function returns a new object of the Error class. ErrorFunc() may be of use to you if you are programming in C (or some other language besides X#) and want the error information to be available at the system level.
errorfunc.example:
This example uses ErrorFunc() to install an error function for the current module:
STATIC GLOBAL ptrOldErrorGen AS PTR FUNCTION BrowseDBF(cFile AS STRING) AS VOID PASCAL // Install an error function and save the // pointer to the old error function: ptrOldErrorGen := ErrorFunc(@ErrorGenBrowseDBF()) . . . // Reinstall the old error function: ErrorFunc(ptrOldErrorGen) // Install an error function for the current module: STATIC FUNCTION ErrorGenBrowseDBF(ptrStrucError) AS ERROR LOCAL oError AS ERROR oError := ErrorExec(ptrStrucError) oError:SubSystem := "browseDBF" RETURN oError

errorgen.remarks: The ErrorGen() procedure, because it is declared with the _INIT1 keyword, executes automatically at the startup of every X# application to install the default error handling function, DefErrorGen(). If you choose to install your own error handling function and want to reinstall the default one at any point during your application, simply call ErrorGen().

errorlevel.summary: Retrieve and optionally set the X# return code.
errorlevel.param:
The new return code setting. This can be a value between 0 and 255. The default initial value is 0.
When a X# program terminates, the return code is set to 1 if the process ends with a fatal error. If the process ends normally, the return code is set to 0 (unless ErrorLevel() was set to something else in the program).
Typically, you would set a return code with ErrorLevel() to indicate an error state to the program that invoked the current X# program. In most cases, this is the application batch file. Here you would test the return code using the DOS ErrorLevel command. (Refer to your DOS manual for more information.)
errorlevel.returns: If <dwNewSetting> is not specified, ErrorLevel() returns the current setting. If <dwNewSetting> is specified, the previous setting is returned.

remarks.note: After a RUN command, a return value of less than 32 from ErrorLevel(), indicates an error. (Refer to the Windows API WinExec() function for more information.)

errornew.summary: Create a new error object. Note: ErrorNew() is a compatibility function and is no longer recommended. It is superseded by a direct call to the Error class constructor (Error{}) which creates an error object directly.
errornew.example:
This example uses ErrorNew() to create a new error object:
LOCAL oError AS ERROR oError := ErrorNew()
This example does the same thing as the one above but does it more efficiently by creating the error object directly:
LOCAL oError AS ERROR oError := Error{}

errorstackoptions.param: (Optional) LOGIC: Should the Module name be included in the call stack
(Optional) LONG: Number of levels to include in the call stack of errors
(Optional) LOGIC: Should the level number be included in the call stack
(Optional) LONG: Number of Dispatch(), Eval() or Exec() levels to include in the call stack.

errorsys.remarks: The ErrorSys() procedure, because it is declared with the _INIT1 keyword, executes automatically at the startup of every X# application to install the default error handler. If you choose to install your own error handler (see the "Error and Exception Handling" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information) and want to reinstall the default one at any point during your application, simply call ErrorSys(). The source code for the default error handler is defined in the ERRORSYS.PRG file, located in your X# \SAMPLES directory.

errstring.summary: Return an error message associated with a system-generated error code.
errstring.param: The error code exported by an error object.
errstring.returns: The message string associated with the error code. Error messages are nation-dependent.
errstring.example:
This example displays the error message associated with a protection error:
FUNCTION Start() QOut("EG_PROTECTION:", ErrString(EG_PROTECTION))

eval.summary: Evaluate a code block or an object's Eval() method.
eval.param: The code to execute. If an object is specified, its Eval() method is used.
A list of arguments that can be sent to the code block or the method to be evaluated.
eval.returns: The value of the last expression within the code block.
eval.remarks: The X# compiler usually compiles a code block at compile time. If you need to compile a code block from a string at runtime, use the macro operator (&). Eval() is often used to create iterator functions. These are functions, like AEval(), ASort(), AScan(), and DBEval(), that apply a code block to each member of a data structure. For example, AEval() can be used to apply a code block to each element within an array.
eval.example:
This example creates a code block that increments a number, then evaluates it:
cbBlock := {|nArg| nArg + 1} ? Eval(cbBlock, 1) // 2
This example demonstrates compiling a code block at runtime using the macro operator (&):
// Compile a string to a code block cbBlock := &("{|nArg| nArg + 1}") // Evaluate the code block ? Eval(cbBlock, 1) // 2
This example applies Eval() to an object:
CLASS Greet METHOD Eval(cStr) CLASS Greet ? "hello", cStr FUNCTION Start() LOCAL oHello AS OBJECT oHello := Greet{} // Call the Eval() method of the class: Eval(oHello, "there") // hello there

evaluate.summary: Evaluate an expression contained in a string.
evaluate.param: The string containing the expression to evaluate.
evaluate.remarks: Evaluate() invokes the macro compiler each time it evaluates an expression. Alternatively, you could use MCompile() to compile an expression only once, then use MExec() to execute the compiled form as often as you want.
evaluate.example:
This example shows typical uses of Evaluate():
LOCAL cVar AS STRING cVar := "World" World := "Hello" // World is a PRIVATE variable ? Evaluate(cVar) // Hello ? Evaluate("2+3") // 5 Two := 2 // Two is a PRIVATE variable Evaluate("Two+3") // 5

exp.summary: Calculate the numeric value of a natural logarithm.
exp.param: The power to which e is to be raised.
exp.returns: A floating point number that is equivalent to the value e raised to <nExponent>.
exp.remarks: Exp() calculates the value y (the antilogarithm) of the following equation: e^x = y where e is the base of natural logarithms (2.71828...) and x is <nExponent>. Exp() and Log() are inverse functions.
exp.example:
This example demonstrates several invocations of Exp():
? Exp(1) // 2.72 SetDecimal(10) ? Exp(1) // 2.7182818285 ? Log(Exp(1)) // 1.0000000000

f2bin.summary: Convert a float to a string containing an 80-bit floating point number.
f2bin.returns: A string representing a floating point number.
f2bin.remarks: F2Bin() is a conversion function that converts a string to a floating point number. Typical applications include reading foreign file types in their native format and then saving, reading, decrypting, and transmitting numeric data in their compressed binary form instead of in strings. Its inverse is Bin2F().
f2bin.example:
This example saves the return value from the Seconds() function into a debugging binary file:
FUNCTION StoreData() AS LOGIC LOCAL nh LOCAL lSuccess := FALSE AS LOGIC nh := FOpen2("debug.bin", FO_READWRITE) // Assumes that file debug.doc already exists IF nh != F_ERROR FWrite(nh, F2Bin(Seconds())) FClose(nh) lSuccess := TRUE ELSE ? DOSErrString(FError()) ENDIF RETURN lSuccess

fact.summary: Calculate the factorial of a number.
fact.remarks: The factorial of an integer n is computed as follows: Factorial(n)=n*(n-1)*(n-2) ... 3*2*1 The factorial of 0 is defined to be 1.
fact.example:
This example uses Fact() to compute the factorial of 5, then it verifies the result:
? Fact(5) // 120 // Verify ? 5*4*3*2*1 // 120

fattr2string.summary: Display file attributes as a string.
fattr2string.param:
One or more of the following constants, indicating the file attribute(s) to return (file attributes are returned by FAttrib()):
Constant Returns
FA_DIRECTORY D
FA_VOLUME V
FC_ARCHIVED A
FC_HIDDEN H
FC_NORMAL NULL_STRING
FC_READONLY R
FC_SYSTEM S
fattr2string.returns: One or more of the characters indicated in the table above, depending upon what file attribute constants were specified in <dwAttributes>. If multiple attributes are present, the characters are concatenated as a string. You can use the string search function, At(), to determine if a particular property is set (see example below).
fattr2string.example:
This examples shows the return values from FAttr2String():
? FAttr2String(FC_HIDDEN) // H ? FAttr2String(FC_HIDDEN + FC_SYSTEM) // HS
This example uses FAttr2String() to find out if the file named ABC.DBF is a read-only file:
FFirst("abc.dbf", FC_NORMAL) IF At(FAttr2String(FAttrib()), "R") > 0 // Attribute string contains "R" so file is read-only ENDIF

fattrib.summary: Determine the attributes of the file found after FFCount(), FFirst(), or FNext().
fattrib.returns: A value indicating the attributes of the current file. The constants in the following table can be used individually or added together to determine which attributes are applicable: Constant Description FA_DIRECTORY Directory FA_VOLUME Volume FC_ARCHIVED Archived FC_HIDDEN Hidden FC_NORMAL Read/write FC_READONLY Read-only FC_SYSTEM System Note: It is not uncommon for a file to have more than one attribute. For example, it may be read-only and archived, which would be represented as FC_READONLY + FC_ARCHIVED or _Or(FC_READONLY, FC_ARCHIVED).
fattrib.remarks: Since FFCount() and FFirst() cannot distinguish files based on their read and archive attributes, FAttrib() can be useful in determining these attributes. For example, if FAttrib() returns FC_NORMAL, you know that the current file is read/write and not archived, and if it is FC_ARCHIVED (or FC_NORMAL + FC_ARCHIVED), you know the file is read/write and archived.
fattrib.example:
This example uses FAttrib() in conjunction with FFirst() and FNext():
// Find the first file matching docu*.txt ? FFirst("docu*.txt", FC_NORMAL) ? FAttrib() // 32 (FC_ARCHIVED) ? FNext() // Next file matching docu*.txt ? FAttrib() // 33 // 33 is FC_READONLY + FC_ARCHIVED

fchsize.summary: Change the size of a file opened with a low-level file function.
fchsize.param: The handle of the open file whose size you want to change.
The new length to which the file should be set.
fchsize.returns: The new length of the file if successful; otherwise, F_ERROR. FError() can be used to determine the specific error.
fchsize.remarks: FChSize() truncates or extends a file to a specified length. The file should be open for writing and its handle must be available. If the file size is increased, null characters (Chr(0)) are appended.
fchsize.example:
This example uses FChSize() in conjunction with FOpen2():
LOCAL hFile hFile := FOpen2("docs.txt", F0_READWRITE) IF hFile != F_ERROR IF FChSize(hFile, 100) != F_ERROR ? "Size successfully changed to 100" ELSE ? DOSErrString(FError()) ENDIF ENDIF

fclose.summary: Close an open file and write the buffers to disk.
fclose.param: The handle of the open file you want to close.
fclose.returns: FALSE if an error occurs while writing; otherwise, TRUE.
fclose.remarks: FClose() is a low-level file function that closes files and forces the associated buffers to be written to disk. If the operation fails, FClose() returns FALSE and FError() can be used to determine the specific error. For example, attempting to use FClose() with an invalid handle returns FALSE and FError() returns error 6, invalid handle.
fclose.example:
This example uses FClose() to close a newly created file and displays an error message if the close fails:
ptrHandle := FCreate("testfile", FC_NORMAL) IF !FClose(ptrHandle) ? DOSErrString(FError()) ENDIF

fcommit.param: The handle of the open file you want to flush.
fcommit.remarks: FCommit() writes to a file the contents of its buffers. If files are being shared in a multi-user or multi-tasking environment, FCommit() is helpful in allowing each user to see the latest contents of the file. The disk-write also protects you against possible data loss due to a system crash.
fcommit.example:
This example uses FCommit() to ensure that buffers are written to the disk:
LOCAL ptrFile AS PTR ptrFile := FOpen2("myfile.txt", F0_READWRITE + FO_SHARED) FWrite3(ptrFile, Space(550), 550) // Keep other users/tasks updated FCommit(ptrFile)

fcopy.summary: Copy a file to a new file or to a device.
fcopy.param:
The name of the source file to copy, including an optional drive, directory, and extension.
If <cSourceFile> does not exist, a runtime error is raised. If it exists, this function attempts to open the file in shared mode and, if successful, it proceeds. If access is denied because, for example, another process has exclusive use of the file, NetErr() is set to TRUE.

The name of the target file, including an optional drive, directory, and extension.
If <cTargetFile> does not exist, it is created. If it exists, this function attempts to open the file in exclusive mode and, if successful, the file is overwritten without warning or error. If access is denied because, for example, another process is using the file, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.
See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. This function does not supply a default extension for either file name.
<cTargetFile> can also be the name of the target device specified without a trailing colon. When you specify one of the following device names: PRN, LPT1, LPT2, LPT3, COM1, or COM2, FCopy() searches the Windows registry for a Device entry to use for the printing device. If there is no Device entry, it looks for the Devices entries and presents the user with a list box of devices from which to choose.
fcopy.remarks: FCopy() is the functional form of the COPY FILE command.
fcopy.example: This example copies a file from the default drive and directory into MYDIR directory on the D drive: ? FCopy("thisfile.txt",; "d:\mydir\thisfile.txt")

fcount.summary: Return the number of fields in the current database file.
fcount.returns: If there is no database file open, FCount() returns 0.
fcount.remarks: FCount() is useful in applications containing data-independent programs that can operate on any database file. These include generalized import/export and reporting programs. Typically, you use FCount() to establish the upper limit of a FOR...NEXT or DO WHILE loop that processes a single field at a time.
fcount.example:
This example uses FCount() to return the number of fields in the current and an unselected work area:
USE Sales NEW USE Customer NEW ? FCount() // Result: 5 ? Sales ->(FCount()) // Result: 8
This example uses FCount() to declare an array with field information:
LOCAL aFields := ARRAY(FCount()) AFields(aFields)
This example uses FCount() as the upper boundary of a FOR loop that processes the list of current work area fields:
LOCAL nField USE Sales NEW FOR nField := 1 UPTO FCount() ? FIELDNAME(nField) NEXT

fcreate.summary: Create a file or open and truncate an existing file.
fcreate.param:
The name of the file to create, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. SetDefault() and SetPath() settings are ignored; the Windows default is used unless you specify a drive and directory as part of the file name. No extension is assumed. If the file already exists, its length is truncated to 0 without warning.
This function sets NetErr() in case of a concurrency control conflict.

One of the following constants indicating the attribute to be set when creating the file:
Constant Description
FC_ARCHIVED Archived file
FC_HIDDEN Hidden file
FC_NORMAL Normal read/write file
FC_READONLY Read-only file
FC_SYSTEM System file
fcreate.returns: The DOS file handle number of the new file. If an error occurs, FCreate() returns F_ERROR. FError() can be used to determine the specific error.
fcreate.remarks: FCreate() is a low-level file function that either creates a new file or opens an existing file and truncates it to 0 length. If <cFileName> does not exist, it is created and opened for writing. If it does exist and can be opened for writing, it is truncated to 0 length. When FCreate() successfully creates a new file, the file is left open in compatibility sharing mode and read/write access mode. The file attribute specified by <nAttribute> is applied to the new file when it is closed, allowing you to write to a newly created read-only file. For a list of access modes, see FOpen(). Since a file handle is required in order to identify an open file to other file functions, always assign the return value from FCreate() to a variable for later use.
fcreate.example:
This example creates a file called TESTFILE and opens it for reading and writing:
IF (ptrHandle := FCreate("testfile")) = F_ERROR ? DOSErrString(FError()) ELSE FWrite(ptrHandle, "Hello there") FClose(ptrHandle) ENDIF

fcreate2.summary: Create a file or open and truncate an existing file, specifying two strongly typed arguments.
fcreate2.param:
The name of the file to create, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. SetDefault() and SetPath() settings are ignored; the Windows default is used unless you specify a drive and directory as part of the file name. No extension is assumed. If the file already exists, its length is truncated to 0 without warning.
This function sets NetErr() in case of a concurrency control conflict.

One of the following constants indicating the attribute to be set when creating the file:
Constant Description
FC_ARCHIVED Archived file
FC_HIDDEN Hidden file
FC_NORMAL Normal read/write file
FC_READONLY Read-only file
FC_SYSTEM System file
fcreate2.returns: The DOS file handle number of the new file. If an error occurs, FCreate2() returns F_ERROR. FError() can be used to determine the specific error.
fcreate2.example:
This example creates a file called TESTFILE.TXT and opens it for reading and writing:
ptrHandle := FCreate2("testfile.txt", FC_NORMAL) IF ptrHandle = F_ERROR ? DOSErrString(FError()) ELSE FWrite(ptrHandle, "Hello there") FClose(ptrHandle) ENDIF

fdate.summary: Return the date stamp of the file found by FFCount(), FFirst(), or FNext().
fdate.example:
This example uses FDate() to find out when files were last updated:
// Find the first file matching *.txt IF FFirst("*.txt", FC_NORMAL) ? FDate() // 08/13/98 ENDIF // Next file matching *.txt IF FNext() ? FDate() // 08/21/98 ENDIF

feof.summary: Determine if the file pointer is positioned at the end-of-file.
feof.param: The handle of an open file.
feof.returns: TRUE if the file pointer is at end-of-file; otherwise, FALSE.
feof.example:
This example checks for end-of-file after attempting to move 101 bytes:
LOCAL ptrHandle AS PTR ptrHandle := FOpen("docu.txt") FSeek(ptrHandle, 101) ? FEOF(ptrHandle)
This example reads the entire file, one line at a time, until it reaches the end-of-file:
ptrHandle := FOpen2("docs.txt", FO_READ) IF ptrHandle != F_ERROR DO WHILE !FEOF(ptrHandle) ? FReadLine2(ptrHandle, 80) ENDDO ENDIF FClose(ptrHandle)

ferase.param: The file name, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. SetDefault() and SetPath() settings are ignored; the Windows default is used unless you specify a drive and directory as part of the file name. No extension is assumed.
ferase.returns: TRUE if the operation succeeds; otherwise, FALSE. In the case of a failure, FError() can be used to determine the specific error.
ferase.remarks: FErase() is the same as the ERASE command but returns a value and can be specified within an expression. Warning! Files must be closed before removing them with FErase().
ferase.example:
This example deletes a set of files matching a wildcard pattern:
AEval(Directory("*.bak"), {|aFile|; FErase(aFile[F_NAME])})
This example erases a file and displays a message if the operation fails:
IF .NOT. FErase("afile.txt") ? DOSErrString(FError()) ENDIF

ferror.summary: Get or set the error code for a file operation.
ferror.param: A subsequent error code to set FError() to. All DOS error codes are documented in Appendix A. These are additional error codes used by X#:
EOF was already reached when a read was tried
ferror.returns: The error from the last file operation or the last user-specified setting. If there was no error, FError() returns 0.
ferror.remarks: FError() is a low-level file function that indicates an error after a file function is used. These functions include FClose(), FCreate(), FErase(), FOpen(), FRead(), FReadStr(), and FRename(). FError() retains its value until the next execution of a file function.
ferror.example:
This example tests FError() after the creation of a file and displays an error message if the create fails:
ptrHandle := FCreate("temp.txt", FC_NORMAL) IF ptrHandle == F_ERROR ? FError() ? DOSErrString(FError()) ENDIF

ffcount.summary: Return the number of files that match a given file specification and attribute.
ffcount.param: The names of the files to include, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. The file name and extension can include the standard wildcard characters (* and ?). If the drive and directory are omitted, the Windows default is used.

One or more of the following constants indicating the file attributes to be used with <pszFileSpec> as search criteria:
Constant Description
FA_DIRECTORY Directory
FA_VOLUME Volume
FC_HIDDEN Hidden
FC_NORMAL Visible
FC_SYSTEM System
To specify more than one constant, you can either add attributes together, as in FC_SYSTEM + FC_HIDDEN, or use the _Or() operator, as in _Or(FC_SYSTEM, FC_HIDDEN).
<dwAttributes> specifies a criterion to satisfy in addition to any "visible" files that match the <pszFileSpec>. Visible files do not include directories, volumes, or hidden or system files — all other files are visible, regardless of the status of their read or archive attributes. To include only visible files, use FC_NORMAL as the <dwAttributes> argument.
Note:To specify volume labels only, to the exclusion of all other files, specify FA_VOLUME as the sole <dwAttributes> argument.
ffcount.returns: The number of files matching the specified criteria. If no match is found, it returns zero.
ffcount.remarks: FFCount() also finds the first file matching the specified criteria. Therefore, it is not necessary to call FFirst() immediately after FFCount(). Instead, retrieve the necessary information about the first matching file using other related functions (such as FName(), FSize(), FAttrib(), FTime(), or FDate()), then call FNext() to move on to the next file. This technique is illustrated in the example below.
ffcount.example:
This example uses FFCount() in conjunction with FNext() and FName() to display all files matching "C:\DOCS\*.TXT":
dwMatches := FFCount("c:\docs\*.txt", FC_NORMAL) FOR i:= 1 UPTO dwMatches ? FName() FNext() NEXT
This example illustrates the <dwAttributes> argument, extending the file search to include hidden files and directories, as well as visible files:
dwCnt := FFCount("c:\i*.*", FC_HIDDEN + FA_DIRECTORY) FOR i:= 1 UPTO dwCnt ? FName() FNext() NEXT

ffirst.summary: Find the first file that matches a given file specification or attribute.
ffirst.param: The file specification for the search. Besides a file name, this specification can include an optional drive, directory, and extension. The file name and extension can include the standard wildcard characters (* and ?). If the drive and directory are omitted, the Windows default is used.

One or more of the following constants indicating the file attributes to be used with <pszFileSpec> as search criteria:
Constant Description
FA_DIRECTORY Directory
FA_VOLUME Volume
FC_HIDDEN Hidden
FC_NORMAL Visible
FC_SYSTEM System
To specify more than one constant, you can either add attributes together, as in FC_SYSTEM + FC_HIDDEN, or use the _Or() operator, as in _Or(FC_SYSTEM, FC_HIDDEN).
<kAttributes> specifies a criterion to satisfy in addition to any "visible" files that match the <pszFileSpec>. Visible files do not include directories, volumes, or hidden or system files — all other files are visible, regardless of the status of their read or archive attributes. To include only visible files, use FC_NORMAL as the <kAttributes> argument.
Note:To specify volume labels only, to the exclusion of all other files, specify FA_VOLUME as the sole <kAttributes> argument.
ffirst.returns: TRUE if a match is found; otherwise, FALSE.
ffirst.remarks: FFirst() gets the first matching file; use FNext() to find subsequent matching files. FFCount() returns the number of matches. FAttrib(), FDate(), FName(), FSize(), and FTime() return the attribute, date stamp, name, size, and time stamp of the matching file, respectively.
ffirst.example:
This example uses FFirst() to find a file:
IF FFirst("c:\docs\*.txt", FC_NORMAL) ? "A file was found" ELSE ? "A file was not found" ENDIF
This example illustrates the <kAttributes> argument, extending the file search to include hidden files and directories, as well as visible files:
IF FFirst("c:\i*.*", FC_HIDDEN + FA_DIRECTORY) ? "A file was found" ELSE ? "A file was not found" ENDIF

fflock.summary: Lock a portion of an open file.
fflock.param: The handle of the open file you want to lock.
The file offset at which to start locking. A value of zero corresponds to the first byte of the file.
The number of bytes to lock.
fflock.remarks: FFLock() locks a specified portion of a file. This prevents other processes from accessing that portion. More than one portion of a file can be locked, but the same byte should not be locked more than once. It is also possible to lock past the end of a file. This allows you to append to a file in a multi-user environment.
fflock.example:
This example uses FFLock() to lock 100 bytes of a file starting at offset 300:
ptrHandle := FOpen2("c:\data\myfile.txt", ; FO_READWRITE + FO_SHARED) IF FFLock(ptrHandle, 300, 100) ? "Locked OK" ENDIF
This example implements an FFLock() with an optional retry:
FUNCTION FileLock(ptrHandle AS PTR,; dwOffset AS DWORD, dwLength AS DWORD,; wSeconds AS DWORD) AS LOGIC PASCAL LOCAL lForever AS LOGIC IF FFLock(ptrHandle, dwOffset, dwLength) RETURN TRUE // Locked ENDIF // If wSeconds is zero, retry until successful lForever := (wSeconds = 0) DO WHILE (lForever .OR. wSeconds > 0) IF FFLock(ptrHandle, dwOffset, dwLength) RETURN TRUE // Locked ENDIF InKey(.5) // Wait up nSeconds -= 1 ENDDO RETURN FALSE // Not locked

fflush.summary: Flush to disk a file opened with a low-level file function.
fflush.param: The handle of the open file you want to flush.
fflush.remarks: FFlush() writes buffers to disk, thus releasing the memory used by those buffers. If files are being shared in a multi-user or multi-tasking environment, FFlush() allows each user to see the latest contents of the file. By flushing data from memory, FFlush() can also protect against possible data loss due to a system crash.
fflush.example:
This example uses FFlush() to flush data automatically after waiting for a key press:
ptrHandle := FOpen2("docs.txt", ; FO_READWRITE + FO_SHARED) IF ptrHandle != F_ERROR FWrite(ptrHandle, Space(100)) nKey := Inkey(50) FFlush(ptrHandle) // Save data ENDIF

ffunlock.summary: Unlock a portion of an opened file.
ffunlock.param: The handle of the opened file you want to unlock.
The file offset at which to start unlocking.
The number of bytes to unlock.
ffunlock.remarks: FFUnlock() unlocks a specified portion of a file. This permits other processes to access that portion. The unlocked portion must have been previously locked.
ffunlock.example:
This example uses FFLock() and FFUnlock() to lock and then unlock the first 300 bytes of a file:
ptrHandle := FOpen2("c:\data\myfile.txt", ; FO_READWRITE + FO_SHARED) IF FFLock(ptrHandle, 0, 300) ? "Locked OK" IF FFUnlock(ptrHandle, 0, 300) ? "Unlocked OK" ENDIF ENDIF

fgets.summary: Read a line from an open file.
fgets.param: The handle of the file to read from.

The maximum number of characters to read per line. FGets() will read until a hard carriage return (Chr(13)) is reached, end-of-file is encountered, or <nMax> characters are read. The default value for <nMax> is 256.
fgets.returns: The line read. When the end-of-file is reached, FGets() returns a NULL_STRING and FError() is set to 257.
fgets.remarks: This function is the same as FReadLine(). Both functions are assumed to handle raw binary data and are not dependent upon the status of SetAnsi(). FReadText() and FRead4(), on the other hand, are dependent upon SetAnsi().
fgets.example:
This example uses FGets() to read an entire file without specifying a value for <nMax>:
ptrHandle := FOpen2("docs.txt", FO_READ) IF ptrHandle != F_ERROR DO WHILE !FEOF(ptrHandle) ? FGets(ptrHandle) ENDDO ENDIF FClose(ptrHandle)
The following example provides a utility that displays and counts all occurrences of a string within a file:
FUNCTION Grep(cSearch, cFile AS STRING) ; AS DWORD PASCAL LOCAL handle AS PTR LOCAL Count AS DWORD LOCAL Line AS STRING handle := FOpen2(cFile, FO_READ) cSearch := Upper(cSearch) DO WHILE !FEOF(handle) line := Upper(FGets(handle)) IF InStr(cSearch, line) ? line Count += 1 ENDIF ENDDO RETURN Count

fgets2.summary: Read a line from an open file, specifying two strongly typed arguments.
fgets2.param: The handle of the file to read from.

The maximum number of characters to read per line. FGets2() will read until a hard carriage return (Chr(13)) is reached, end-of-file is encountered, or <dwMax> characters are read. The default value for <dwMax> is 256.
fgets2.returns: The line read. When the end-of-file is reached, FGets2() returns a NULL_STRING and FError() is set to 257.
fgets2.remarks: This function is the same as FReadLine2(). Both functions are assumed to handle raw binary data and are not dependent upon the status of SetAnsi(). FReadText() and FRead4(), on the other hand, are dependent upon SetAnsi().
fgets2.example:
This example uses FGets2() to read an entire file with a maximum of 80 characters per line:
ptrHandle := FOpen2("docs.txt", FO_READ) IF ptrHandle != F_ERROR DO WHILE !FEOF(ptrHandle) ? FGets2(ptrHandle, 80) ENDDO ENDIF FClose(ptrHandle)

fieldblock.summary: Return a set-get code block for a field that is identified by its name.
fieldblock.param: The name of the field to which the set-get block will refer. When executed with an argument, the code block created by this function assigns the value of the argument to <cFieldName>. If omitted, the code block retrieves the value of <cFieldName>.
fieldblock.returns: A runtime code block (implemented as an object) that, when evaluated, sets (assigns) or gets (retrieves) the value of the given field. If <cFieldName> does not exist in the current work area, FieldBlock() returns NULL_OBJECT.
fieldblock.remarks:
Note that the specified field variable does not have to exist when the code block is created but must exist before the code block is executed.
Work area: The code block returned by FieldBlock() sets or gets the value of the specified field in whatever work area is current when the block is run. For example, given work areas 1 and 2, both containing field FName:
DBSetSelect(1) _FIELD->FName := "Kate" DBSetSelect(2) _FIELD->FName := "Cindy" cbFName := FieldBlock("FName") DBSetSelect(1) ? EVAL(cbFName) // "Kate" DBSetSelect(2) ? EVAL(cbFName) // "Cindy"
Use FieldWBlock() to provide a set-get block for a field in a specific work area.

fieldblocksym.summary: Return a set-get code block for a field that is identified by a symbol.
fieldblocksym.param: A symbol that is the name of the field to which the set-get block will refer. When executed with an argument, the code block created by this function assigns the value of the argument to <symFieldName>. If omitted, the code block retrieves the value of <symFieldName>.
fieldblocksym.returns: A runtime code block (implemented as an object) that, when evaluated, sets (assigns) or gets (retrieves) the value of the given field. If <symFieldName> does not exist in the current work area, FieldBlockSym() returns NULL_OBJECT.
fieldblocksym.remarks:
Note that the specified field variable does not have to exist when the code block is created but must exist before the code block is executed.
Work area: The code block returned by FieldBlockSym() sets or gets the value of the specified field in whatever work area is current when the block is run. For example, given work areas 1 and 2, both containing field FName:
DBSetSelect(1) _FIELD->FName := "Kate" DBSetSelect(2) _FIELD->FName := "Cindy" cbFName := FieldBlockSym(#FNAME) DBSetSelect(1) ? EVAL(cbFName) // "Kate" DBSetSelect(2) ? EVAL(cbFName) // "Cindy"
Use FieldWBlock() to provide a set-get block for a field in a specific work area.

fieldget.summary: Get the contents of a field that is identified by its position.
fieldget.param: The position of the field in the database file structure for the current work area.
fieldget.returns: The value of the specified field. If <nFieldPos> does not correspond to the position of any field in the current database file, FieldGet() returns NIL.
fieldget.remarks: FieldGet() retrieves the value of a field using its position within the database file structure rather than its field name. Within generic database service functions this allows, among other things, the retrieval of field values without use of the macro operator. Note: FieldGet() can be used with a BLOB field (that is, a memo field associated with a BLOB file), provided the length of the field does not exceed 64 KB. For BLOB fields longer than 64 KB, use the BLOBGet() function instead.
fieldget.example:
This example compares FieldGet() to functionally equivalent code that uses the macro operator to retrieve the value of a field:
LOCAL nFieldPos := 1, FName, FVal USE customer NEW // Using macro operator FName := FIELDNAME(nFieldPos) // Get field name FVal := &FName // Get field value // Using FieldGet() FVal := FieldGet(nFieldPos) // Get field value

fieldgetalias.summary: Get the contents of a field that is identified by a work area alias and the field name.
fieldgetalias.example:
This example uses FieldGetAlias() to query the contents of fields in two work areas:
USE region1 NEW USE region2 NEW SELECT region1 _FIELD->FName := "Kate" SELECT region2 _FIELD->FName := "Cindy" QOut(FieldGetAlias(#REGION1, #FNAME)) // Kate QOut(FieldGetAlias(#REGION2, #FNAME)) // Cindy

fieldgetarea.summary: Get the contents of a field that is identified by its work area and a symbol.
fieldgetarea.param: The work area in which <symFieldName> is located.
A symbol that corresponds to the field name.
fieldgetarea.example:
This example uses FieldGetArea():
USE region1 NEW nSelect1 := VODBGetSelect() USE region2 NEW nSelect2 := VODBGetSelect() VODBSetSelect(nSelect1) _FIELD->FName := "Kate" VODBSetSelect(nSelect2) _FIELD->FName := "Cindy" // The following line prints Kate ? FieldGetArea(nSelect1, #FNAME) // The following line prints Cindy ? FieldGetArea(nSelect2, #FNAME)

fieldgetsym.summary: Retrieve the contents of a field that is identified by its symbolic name.
fieldgetsym.param: The symbolic name of the field in the database file structure for the current work area.
fieldgetsym.returns: The value of the specified field. If <symField> does not correspond to a field in the current database file, FieldGetSym() returns NIL.
fieldgetsym.remarks: FieldGetSym() retrieves the value of a field using its symbolic field name within the database file structure, rather than the string representation of the field name. Note: FieldGetSym() can be used with a BLOB field (that is, a memo field associated with a BLOB file), provided the length of the field does not exceed 64KB. For BLOB fields longer than 64KB, use the BLOBGet() function instead.
fieldgetsym.example:
This example retrieves the contents of the Lastname field in the TestDBF database:
USE TestDBF NEW DO WHILE !EOF() ? FieldGetSym(#Lastname) // Smith Skip ENDDO USE WAIT

fieldname.summary: Return the name of a field as a string.
fieldname.param: The position of the field in the database file structure.
fieldname.returns: The name of the specified field as a string. If <dwFieldPos> does not correspond to an existing field in the database file or if no database file is open, FieldName() returns a NULL_STRING.
fieldname.remarks: FieldName() returns a field name using an index to the position of the field name in the database structure. Use it in data-independent applications where the field name is unknown. If information for more than one field is required, use DBStruct(). If you need additional database file structure information, use Type() and Len(). For example, to obtain the number of decimal places for a numeric field, use the following expression: Len(Substr(Str(<idField>), RAt(".", Str(<idField>)) + 1))
fieldname.example:
These examples illustrate FieldName() used with several other functions:
USE sales QOut(FIELDNAME(1)) // Result: BRANCH QOut(FCount()) // Result: 5 QOut(LEN(FIELDNAME(0))) // Result: 0 QOut(LEN(FIELDNAME(40))) // Result: 0
This example uses FieldName() to list the name and type of each field in CUSTOMER.DBF:
USE customer NEW FOR nField := 1 UPTO FCount() ? FIELDNAME(nField), DBFieldInfo(DBS_TYPE, nField) NEXT
This example accesses fields in unselected work areas using aliased expressions:
USE sales NEW USE customer NEW USE invoices NEW QOut(Sales->FIELDNAME(1)) // Result: SaleNum QOut(Customer->FIELDNAME(1)) // Result: CustNum

fieldpos.summary: Return the position of a field.
fieldpos.param: Specifies the work area number for the table.
fieldpos.returns: The position of the specified field within the list of fields associated with the work area. If the work area has no field with the specified name, FieldPos() returns 0.
fieldpos.remarks: FieldPos() is the inverse of the FieldName() function. FieldPos() is most often used with the FieldPut() and FieldGet() functions.
fieldpos.example:
This example demonstrates a typical specification of the FieldPos() function:
USE customer NEW QOut(FIELDPOS("Name")) // Result: 1 QOut(FieldGet(FIELDPOS("Name"))) // Result: Kate
This example uses FieldPos() to return the position of a specified field in a unselected work area:
USE customer NEW USE invoices NEW QOut(Customer->FIELDPOS("Name")) // Result: 1 QOut(Customer->FieldGet(FIELDPOS("Name"))) // Result: Kate

fieldpossym.summary: Return the position of a field that is identified by a symbol.
