fieldpossym.param: A symbol that corresponds to the name of the field.
fieldpossym.returns: The position of the specified field within the list of fields associated with the work area. If the work area has no field with the specified name, FieldPosSym() returns 0.
fieldpossym.remarks: FieldPosSym() is the inverse of the FieldName() function. FieldPosSym() is most often used with the FieldPut() and FieldGet() functions.
fieldpossym.example:
This example demonstrates a typical specification of the FieldPosSym() function:
USE customer NEW QOut(FieldPosSym(#Name)) // Result: 1 QOut(FieldGet(FieldPosSym(#NAME))) // Result: Kate
This example uses FieldPosSym() to return the position of a specified field in a unselected work area:
USE customer NEW USE invoices NEW QOut(Customer->FieldPosSym(#Name)) // Result: 1 QOut(Customer->FieldGet(FieldPosSym(#Name))) // Result: Kate

fieldput.summary: Set the value of a field identified by its position.
fieldput.param: The position of the field in the database file structure.
The value to assign to the field. The data type of this expression must match the data type of the field.
fieldput.returns: The value assigned to the field. If <nFieldPos> does not correspond to the position of any field in the database file, FieldPut() returns NIL.
fieldput.remarks:
FieldPut() allows you to set the value of a field using its position within the database file structure rather than its field name. Within generic database service functions this allows, among other things, the setting of field values without use of the macro operator. Note: FieldPut() can be used with a BLOB field (that is, a memo field associated with a BLOB file), provided the length of the field does not exceed 64 KB.
Shared mode: For a shared database, this function requires a record lock. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on locking.

fieldputalias.summary: Set the value of a field identified by its work area alias and field name.
fieldputalias.param: The alias of the work area in which <symField> is located.
The value to assign to the field. The data type of this expression must match the data type of the field.
fieldputalias.returns: The value assigned to the field. If <symField> does not correspond to any field in the work area specified by <symAlias>, FieldPutAlias() returns NIL.
fieldputalias.remarks:
FieldPutAlias() allows you to set the value of a field using a symbol that specifies the field name. Within generic database service functions, this allows the setting of field values without the use of the macro operator, among other things.
Shared mode: For a shared database, this function requires a record lock. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on locking.
fieldputalias.example:
This example uses FieldPutAlias() to set field values in two different work areas:
USE region1 NEW USE region2 NEW FieldPutAlias(#REGION1, #FNAME, "Kate") FieldPutAlias(#REGION2, #FNAME, "Cindy")

fieldputarea.summary: Set the value of a field identified by its work area number and field name.
fieldputarea.param: The work area in which <symField> is located.
The value to assign to the field. The data type of this expression must match the data type of the field.
fieldputarea.returns: The value assigned to the field. If <symField> does not correspond to any field in the work area specified by <dwWorkArea>, FieldPutArea() returns NIL.
fieldputarea.remarks: FieldPutArea() allows you to set the value of a field using a symbol that specifies the field name. Within generic database service functions this allows, among other things, the setting of field values without use of the macro operator. Shared mode: For a shared database, this function requires a record lock. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on locking.
fieldputarea.example:
This example uses FieldPutArea() to set field values:
USE sales NEW USE region1 NEW USE region2 NEW String2Symbol("FName") FieldPutArea(Select("region1"), #FNAME, "Kate") FieldPutArea(Select("region2"), #FNAME, "Cindy")

fieldputsym.summary: Set the value of a field that is identified by its symbolic name.
fieldputsym.param: The symbolic name of the field in the database file structure for the current work area.
The value to assign to the field. The data type of this expression must match the data type of the field.
fieldputsym.returns: The value assigned to the field. If <symField> does not correspond to a field in the current database file, FieldPutSym() returns NIL.
fieldputsym.remarks: FieldPutSym() assigns a new value to a field using its symbolic field name within the database file structure, rather than the string representation of field name. Note: FieldPutSym() can be used with a BLOB field (that is, a memo field associated with a BLOB file), provided the length of the field does not exceed 64KB.
fieldputsym.example:
This example sets a new value for the contents of the Firstname field in the TestDBF database:
USE TestDBF NEW FieldPutSym(#Firstname, "Marijo") ? FieldGetSym(#Firstname) // Marijo USE WAIT

fieldsym.summary: Return the name of a field as a symbol.
fieldsym.param: The position of the field in the database file structure.
fieldsym.returns: The name of the specified field as a symbol. If <dwFieldPos> does not correspond to an existing field in a database file or if no database file is open, FieldSym() returns NULL_SYMBOL.
fieldsym.remarks: FieldSym() returns a field name as a symbol, using an index to the position of the field name in the database structure. Use it in data-independent applications where the field name is unknown. If information for more than one field is required, use DBStruct(). If you need additional database file structure information, use Type() and Len(). For example, to obtain the number of decimal places for a numeric field, use the following expression: Len(Substr(Str(<idField>), RAt(".", Str(<idField>)) + 1))
fieldsym.example:
These examples illustrate FieldSym() used with several other functions:
USE sales QOut(FieldSym(1)) // Result: BRANCH QOut(FCount()) // Result: 5 QOut(LEN(FieldSym(0))) // Result: 0 QOut(LEN(FieldSym(40))) // Result: 0
This example uses FieldSym() to list the name and type of each field in CUSTOMER.DBF:
USE customer NEW FOR nField := 1 UPTO FCount() QOut(PadR(FieldSym(nField), 10),; VALTYPE(&(FieldSym(nField)))) NEXT
This example accesses fields in unselected work areas using aliased expressions:
USE sales NEW USE customer NEW USE invoices NEW QOut(Sales->FieldSym(1)) // Result: Salenum QOut(Customer->FieldSym(1)) // Result: Custnum

fieldwblock.summary: Return a set-get code block for a field, specified as a string, in a specified work area.
fieldwblock.param: The work area number where the field resides.
fieldwblock.returns: A runtime code block (implemented as an object) that, when evaluated, sets (assigns) or gets (retrieves) the value of <cFieldName> in the work area designated by <dwWorkArea>. If <cFieldName> does not exist in the specified work area, FieldWBlock() returns NULL_OBJECT.
fieldwblock.remarks: FieldWBlock() builds a code block. When evaluated with the Evaluate() function, the code block first selects the designated <dwWorkArea>. If an argument was passed, the code block then assigns the value of the argument to <cFieldName>. If no argument was passed, the code block retrieves the value of <cFieldName>. The original work area is then reselected before the code block returns control. Note that the specified field variable does not have to exist when the code block is created but must exist before the code block is executed.

fieldwblocksym.summary: Return a set-get code block for a field, specified as a symbol, in a specified work area.
fieldwblocksym.param: The work area number where the field resides.
fieldwblocksym.returns: A runtime code block (implemented as an object) that, when evaluated, sets (assigns) or gets (retrieves) the value of <symFieldName> in the work area designated by <dwWorkArea>. If <symFieldName> does not exist in the specified work area, FieldWBlockSym() returns NULL_OBJECT.
fieldwblocksym.remarks: FieldWBlockSym() builds a code block. When evaluated with the Evaluate() function, the code block first selects the designated <dwWorkArea>. If an argument was passed, the code block then assigns the value of the argument to <symFieldName>. If no argument was passed, the code block retrieves the value of <symFieldName>. The original work area is then reselected before the code block returns control. Note that the specified field variable does not have to exist when the code block is created but must exist before the code block is executed.

file.summary: Determine if any file matches a given file specification.
file.param: The file specification for the search. Besides a file name, this specification can include an optional drive, directory, and extension. The file name and extension can include the standard wildcard characters (* and ?). If you do not specify a drive and directory, this function searches only the SetDefault() and SetPath() settings. Note also that File() does not recognize hidden or system files in its search.If <cFileSpec> is longer than 127 characters and has no path VO searches in the current directory only
file.returns: TRUE if any file matches the <cFileSpec> pattern; otherwise, FALSE.
file.example:
This example illustrates how File() attempts to find files:
? File("sales.dbf") // FALSE ? File("\apps\dbf\sales.dbf") // TRUE SetPath("\apps\dbf") ? File("sales.dbf") // TRUE SetPath("") SetDefault("\apps\dbf\") ? File("sales.dbf") // TRUE ? File("*.dbf") // TRUE

floatformat.summary: Set the display format for a floating point numeric.
floatformat.param: The desired length of the display of <fValue>, including decimal digits, decimal point, and sign. A value of -1 means that only significant digits to the left of the decimal point will be displayed (any left padding will be suppressed).

The desired number of decimal digits in the display of <fValue>. A value of -1 means that only significant digits to the right of the decimal point will be displayed (any right padding will be suppressed).
floatformat.remarks: FloatFormat() is used to format floating point numbers. Note that FloatFormat() affects only the display format of numbers and not the actual numeric precision of calculations.
floatformat.example:
These examples use FloatFormat() to display the same number using three different formats. Note the number of leading spaces in each result:
? FloatFormat(1234.546, 12,2) // 1234.54 ? FloatFormat(1234.546, -1,4) // 1234.5460 ? Floatformat(1234.546, 12,-1) // 1234.546

flock.summary: Lock an opened and shared database file.
flock.returns: TRUE if the lock succeeded; otherwise, FALSE.
flock.remarks:
If a database file is opened in shared mode, you must obtain a file lock before attempting any operation that updates the database file with a scope or a condition. For each invocation of FLock(), there is one attempt to lock the database file (and other related files, such as index and memo files), and the result is returned as a logical value. A file lock fails if another process currently has a file or record lock for the same database file. If FLock() is successful, the file lock is locked and other processes are prevented from making updates until the lock is released. FLock() provides a shared lock, allowing other users read-only access to the locked file while allowing only the current process to modify it. A file lock remains in effect until you close the database, explicitly unlock it (with DBUnlock(), for example), or attempt another file or record lock (with RLock() or DBRLock()).
This feature is useful since FLock() does not automatically attempt a file lock for related files. Refer to "Concurrency Control" in the Programmer's Guide for more information on file locking.
flock.example:
This example uses FLock() for a batch update of prices in INVENTORY.DBF:
USE inventory SHARED NEW IF Inventory->FLock() REPLACE ALL Inventory->Price WITH ; Inventory->Price * 1.1 ELSE QOut("File not available") ENDIF
This example attempts a file lock in an unselected work area:
USE sales NEW USE customer NEW IF !Sales->FLock() QOut("Sales is in use") ENDIF

floor.summary: Round a number down to the next lowest integer.
floor.returns: The nearest integer that is less than or equal to <nNum>.
floor.remarks: Floor() rounds a negative value with a fractional portion down to the preceding integer and returns the integer portion of a positive number.
floor.example:
This example uses Floor() on a positive and a negative number:
? Floor(1.6) // 1 ? Floor(-1.6) // -2 (since -2 < -1)

fname.summary: Return the name of the file found by FFCount(), FFirst(), or FNext().
fname.example:
This example uses FName() to return the names of files matching *.TXT:
? FFirst("*.txt", FC_NORMAL) ? FName() // Return first file matched ? FNext() // Find next file matching *.txt ? FName() // Return second file matched

fnext.summary: Find the next file that matches the file previously found by FFirst().
fnext.returns: TRUE if another file was found; otherwise, FALSE.
fnext.remarks: FNext() finds the next file that matches the original FFirst() or FFCount() search. In other words, FFirst() gets the first matching file and FNext() finds subsequent matching files. When FNext() returns FALSE, there are no more files left to match. FFCount() returns the number of matches. FAttrib(), FDate(), FName(), FSize(), and FTime() return the attribute, date stamp, name, size, and time stamp of the current matching file, respectively.
fnext.example:
This example uses FFirst() and FNext() to get all visible files matching "C:\DOCS\*.TXT":
IF FFirst("c:\docs\*.txt", FC_NORMAL) ? FName() // Return first file matched DO WHILE FNext() // Find next match ? FName() // Return second file matched ENDDO ENDIF

fopen.param:
The file name, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. SetDefault() and SetPath() settings are ignored; the Windows default is used unless you specify a drive and directory as part of the file name. No extension is assumed.
This function sets NetErr() in case of a concurrency control conflict.

The DOS open mode, which determines the accessibility of the file. The open mode is composed of elements from the two types of modes: Access mode + Sharing mode. Specifying an access mode constant indicates how the opened file is to be accessed; the sharing mode determines how other processes can access the file.
Available open and sharing mode constants are listed below:
Access Modes Operation
FO_READ Open for reading (default)
FO_READWRITE Open for reading or writing
FO_WRITE Open for writing
Sharing Modes Operation
FO_COMPAT Compatibility mode (default)
FO_DENYNONE Allow others to read or write
FO_DENYREAD Prevent others from reading
FO_DENYWRITE Prevent others from writing
FO_EXCLUSIVE Exclusive use
FO_SHARED Same as FO_DENYNONE
The default open mode is non-sharable and read-only. If just the access mode is used, the file is opened as non-sharable.
fopen.returns: The file handle of the opened file in the range of 0 to 32,767. This value is similar to an alias in the database system and is required to identify the open file to other file functions. It is, therefore, important to assign the return value to a variable for later use, as in the example below. If an error occurs, FOpen() returns F_ERROR. FError() can be used to determine the specific error.
fopen.remarks: FOpen() is a low-level file function that opens an existing file for reading and writing, depending on the <kMode> argument. Note that in order for two processes to use the same file simultaneously, both files should be opened in FO_SHARED sharing mode. Whenever there is an error, FError() can be used to determine the specific error. For example, if the file does not exist, FOpen() returns F_ERROR and FError() returns 2 to indicate that the file was not found.
fopen.example:
This example uses FOpen() to open a file with sharable read/write status and displays an error message if the open fails:
ptrHandle := FOpen("temp.txt") IF ptrHandle = F_ERROR ? DOSErrString(FError()) ENDIF
This example uses FOpen() to open a file with an optional retry if FOpen() fails:
FUNCTION NetOpen(cFile AS STRING,; wMode AS DWORD, wSeconds AS DWORD); AS LOGIC PASCAL LOCAL lForever AS LOGIC // Retry forever if wSeconds is zero lForever := (wSeconds = 0) DO WHILE (lForever .OR. wSeconds > 0) IF FOpen(cFile, wMode) != F_ERROR RETURN TRUE // Open succeeds ENDIF InKey(1) // Wait one second wSeconds -= 1 ENDDO RETURN FALSE // Open fails

fopen2.summary: Open a file, specifying two strongly-typed arguments.
fopen2.param:
The file name, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. SetDefault() and SetPath() settings are ignored; the Windows default is used unless you specify a drive and directory as part of the file name. No extension is assumed.
This function sets NetErr() in case of a concurrency control conflict.
This argument is the same as <kMode> used with FOpen(). See FOpen() for details.
fopen2.returns: The file handle of the opened file in the range of 0 to 32,767. If an error occurs, FOpen2() returns F_ERROR. FError() can be used to determine the specific error.
fopen2.remarks: Note that in order for two processes to use the same file simultaneously, both files should be opened in FO_SHARED sharing mode.
fopen2.example:
This example uses FOpen2() to open a file with sharable read/write status and displays an error message if the open fails:
ptrHandle := FOpen2("temp.txt",; FO_READWRITE + FO_SHARED) IF ptrHandle = F_ERROR ? DOSErrString(FError()) ENDIF

found.summary: Determine if the previous search operation succeeded.
found.returns: TRUE if the last search was successful; otherwise, FALSE. Found() will also return FALSE if there is no database open in the work area.
found.remarks: Found() determines whether a search operation, such as DBSeek(), DBLocate(), DBContinue(), or DBSetRelation(), succeeded. When any of these commands are executed, Found() is set to TRUE if there is a match; otherwise, it is set to FALSE. If the search command is LOCATE or CONTINUE, a match is the next record meeting the scope and condition. If the search command is FIND, SEEK or SET RELATION, a match is the first key in the controlling order that equals the search argument. If the key value equals the search argument, Found() is TRUE; otherwise, it is FALSE. The value of Found() is retained until another record movement command is executed. Unless the command is another search command, Found() is automatically set to FALSE. You can also use DBSetFound() to manually set this flag. Each work area has a Found() value. This means that if one work area has a relation set to a child work area, querying Found() in the child returns TRUE if there is a match.
found.example:
This example illustrates the behavior of Found() after a record movement command:
USE sales INDEX sales SEEK "1000" QOut(Found()) // Result: FALSE SEEK "100" QOut(Found()) // Result: TRUE SKIP QOut(Found()) // Result: FALSE
This example tests a Found() value in an unselected work area using an aliased expression:
USE sales INDEX sales NEW USE customer INDEX customer NEW SET RELATION TO CustNum INTO sales SEEK "Smith" QOut(Found(), Sales->Found())
This code fragment processes all CUSTOMER records with the key value "Smith" using Found() to determine when the key value changes:
USE customer INDEX customer NEW SEEK "Smith" DO WHILE Found() . . <Statements> . SKIP LOCATE REST WHILE Name == "Smith" ENDDO

fparamcount.summary: Return the number of local arguments that a function with the CLIPPER calling convention is expecting.
fparamcount.param: The symbol of the function to examine. The function must use the CLIPPER calling convention.
fparamcount.remarks: Only arguments that are declared within the parentheses of the function are counted. Therefore, arguments that are declared with the PARAMETERS statement do not count.
fparamcount.example:
This example uses FParamCount() with PCount() to determine the number of missing arguments:
Missing("hi") FUNCTION Missing(uOne, uTwo, uThree) ? FParamCount(#Missing) - PCount(),; "Missing arguments" // 2 Missing arguments

fpathname.summary: Return the name and path of the file that was used by FXOpen() or File().
fpathname.returns: The complete name, including path, of the file that was last used by either FXOpen() or File(). Note that the system might also use FXOpen() or File() internally.
fpathname.example:
This example uses FPathName() after calling File() or FXOpen():
SetDefault("\vo") ? File("*.exe") ? FPathName() // C:\VO\EXISTS.EXE ? File("d:\backup\notexist.txt") ? FPathName() // D:\BACKUP\NOTEXIST.TXT SetDefault("c:\backup") File("exists.txt") // c:\backup\exists.txt ? FPathName() SetDefault("c:\vo\data") FXOpen("exists.txt", FO_READ,"") ? FPathName() // C:\VO\DATA\EXISTS.TXT FXOpen("exists.txt", FO_READ, "c:\junk") ? FPathName() // C:\JUNK\EXISTS.TXT

fputs.summary: Write a string, a carriage-return character, and a linefeed character to an open file.
fputs.param: The handle of the file to write to.
The number of bytes in <cBuffer> to write, beginning at the current file pointer position. If <nBytes> is not specified, the value of SLen(<cBuffer>) is used.
fputs.returns: The number of bytes written. If the value returned is equal to <nBytes> + 2, the operation was successful. If the return value is less than <nBytes> + 2 or 0, this means that the length of <cBuffer> was less than <nBytes>, or the disk is full, or another error has occurred.
fputs.remarks: FPuts() is a low-level file function that writes data to an open file from a string buffer. You can either write all or a portion of the buffer contents. Writing begins at the current file position, and the function returns the actual number of bytes written. This function is assumed to handle raw binary data and is not dependent upon the status of SetAnsi(). FWriteText() and FWrite4(), on the other hand, are dependent upon SetAnsi().
fputs.example:
This example uses FPuts() to write lines starting at the beginning of a file. The carriage-return/linefeed pair increase the return value by 2:
ptrHandle := FOpen2("c:\data\sales", FO_READWRITE) ? FPuts(ptrHandle, "Line1") // 7 ? FPuts(ptrHandle, "Line1", 2) // 4

fputs3.summary: Write a string, a carriage-return character, and a linefeed character to an open file, specifying three strongly-typed arguments.
fputs3.param: The handle of the file to write to.
The number of bytes in <cBuffer> to write, beginning at the current file pointer position.
fputs3.returns: The number of bytes written. If the value returned is equal to <dwBytes> + 2, the operation was successful. If the return value is less than <dwBytes> + 2 or 0, this means that the length of <cBuffer> was less than <dwBytes>, or the disk is full, or another error has occurred.
fputs3.remarks: This function is assumed to handle raw binary data and is not dependent upon the status of SetAnsi(). FWriteText() and FWrite4(), on the other hand, are dependent upon SetAnsi().
fputs3.example:
This example uses FPuts3() to write 5 bytes. The carriage-return/linefeed pair increase the return value by 2:
ptrHandle := FOpen2("c:\data\sales", FO_READWRITE) ? FPuts3(ptrHandle, "Line1", 5) // 7

frac.summary: Return the fractional portion of a number.
frac.param: The number whose fractional portion you want to return.
frac.remarks: A number may contain a fractional portion following its integer portion. This function returns only the fractional portion.
frac.example:
This example uses Frac() to implement the logic of a vending machine or a change machine:
FUNCTION GiveChange(fMoney AS FLOAT) AS VOID PASCAL LOCAL fChange AS FLOAT ? "Dollars: $", Integer(fMoney) fChange := Frac(fMoney) // While there is a cent left DO WHILE fChange >= 0.01 // Must check low amounts first: DO CASE CASE fChange < 0.05 ? "Pay a cent" fChange -= 0.01 CASE fChange < 0.10 ? "Pay a nickel (5 cents)" fChange -= 0.05 CASE fChange < 0.25 ? "Pay a dime (10 cents)" fChange -= 0.10 CASE fChange < 0.5 ? "Pay a quarter (25 cents)" fChange -= 0.25 OTHERWISE ? "Pay half a dollar" fChange -= 0.50 ENDCASE ENDDO

fread.summary: Read characters from a file into a buffer variable that is passed by reference.
fread.param: The handle of the file to read from.

A variable used to store data read from the specified file. If the length of <cBufferVar> is less than <dwBytes>, a new string whose length is the minimum of <dwBytes> and the remaining bytes in the file is allocated. <cBufferVar> must be passed by reference and, therefore, must be prefaced by the pass-by-reference operator (@).
The number of bytes to read into the buffer.
fread.returns: The number of bytes successfully read. A return value less than <dwBytes> or 0 indicates end-of-file or some other read error. FError() can be used to determine the specific error.
fread.remarks: FRead() reads from the file starting at the current DOS file pointer position, advancing the file pointer by the number of bytes read. All characters are read, including control, null, and high-order (above Chr(127)) characters. FRead() is similar in some respects to both FReadStr() and FSeek(). FReadStr() reads a specified number of bytes from a file up to the next null (Chr(0)) character. FSeek() moves the file pointer without reading. This function is assumed to handle raw binary data and is not dependent upon the status of SetAnsi(). FReadText() and FRead4(), on the other hand, are dependent upon SetAnsi().
fread.example:
This example uses FRead() after successfully opening a file to read 128 bytes into a buffer area:
DEFINE F_BLOCK := 128 ... cBuffer := Space(F_BLOCK) ptrHandle := FOpen2("temp.txt", FO_READ) IF FError() != 0 ? DOSErrString(FError()) ELSE IF FRead(ptrHandle, @cBuffer, F_BLOCK) <> F_BLOCK ? DOSErrString(FError()) ENDIF FClose(ptrHandle) ENDIF

fread3.summary: Read characters from a file into an allocated buffer.
fread3.param: The handle of the file to read from.
Pointer to an allocated buffer used to store data read from the specified file. The length of this variable must be greater than or equal to <dwBytes>.
The number of bytes to read into the buffer.
fread3.returns: The number of bytes successfully read. A return value less than <dwBytes> or 0 indicates end-of-file or some other read error. FError() can be used to determine the specific error.
fread3.remarks: FRead3() is the same as FRead(), except that the name of the buffer variable is a pointer and is not passed by reference. See FRead() for details. This function is assumed to handle raw binary data and is not dependent upon the status of SetAnsi(). FReadText() and FRead4(), on the other hand, are dependent upon SetAnsi().
fread3.example:
This example uses FRead3() after successfully opening a file to read 128 bytes into a buffer area:
DEFINE F_BLOCK := 128 Function Start() LOCAL cBuffer AS PTR cBuffer := MemAlloc(F_BLOCK) IF cBuffer = NULL PTR RETURN FALSE ENDIF ptrHandle := FOpen2("temp.txt", FO_READ) IF ptrHandle = F_ERROR ? DOSErrString(FError()) RETURN FALSE ELSE IF FRead3(ptrHandle, cBuffer, F_BLOCK) <> F_BLOCK ? DOSErrString(FError()) RETURN FALSE ENDIF FClose(ptrHandle) ENDIF MemFree(cBuffer) RETURN TRUE

fread4.summary: Read characters from a file into an allocated buffer.
fread4.param: The handle of the file to read from.
Pointer to an allocated buffer used to store data read from the specified file. The length of this variable must be greater than or equal to <dwBytes>.
The number of bytes to read into the buffer.
If FALSE an OEM to ANSI conversion is made.
fread4.returns: The number of bytes successfully read. A return value less than <dwBytes> or 0 indicates end-of-file or some other read error. FError() can be used to determine the specific error.
fread4.remarks: FRead4() is the same as FRead3(), except that it provides you with the option of doing an OEM to ANSI conversion.
fread4.example:
This example uses FRead4() after successfully opening a file to read 128 bytes into a buffer area:
DEFINE F_BLOCK := 128 Function Start() LOCAL cBuffer AS PTR cBuffer := MemAlloc(F_BLOCK) IF cBuffer = NULL PTR RETURN FALSE ENDIF ptrHandle := FOpen2("temp.txt", FO_READ) IF ptrHandle = F_ERROR ? DOSErrString(FError()) RETURN FALSE ELSE IF FRead4(ptrHandle, cBuffer, F_BLOCK, FALSE) != F_BLOCK ? DOSErrString(FError()) RETURN FALSE ENDIF FClose(ptrHandle) ENDIF MemFree(cBuffer) RETURN TRUE

freadline.summary: Read a line from an open file.
freadline.param: The handle of the file to read from.

The maximum number of characters to read per line. FReadLine() will read until a hard carriage return (Chr(13)) is reached, end-of-file is encountered, or <nMax> characters are read. The default value for <nMax> is 256.
freadline.returns: The line read. When the end-of-file is reached, FReadLine() returns a NULL_STRING and FError() is set to 257.
freadline.remarks: This function is the same as FGets(). Both functions are assumed to handle raw binary data and are not dependent upon the status of SetAnsi(). FReadText() and FRead4(), on the other hand, are dependent upon SetAnsi().
freadline.example:
This example uses FReadLine() to read an entire file without specifying a value for <nMax>:
ptrHandle := FOpen2("docs.txt", FO_READ) IF ptrHandle != F_ERROR DO WHILE !FEOF(ptrHandle) ? FReadLine(ptrHandle) ENDDO ENDIF FClose(ptrHandle)
The following example provides a utility that displays and counts all occurrences of a string within a file:
FUNCTION Grep(cSearch, cFile AS STRING) ; AS DWORD PASCAL LOCAL handle AS PTR LOCAL Count AS DWORD LOCAL Line AS STRING Line := " " handle := FOpen2(file, FO_READ) cSearch := Upper(cSearch) DO WHILE !FEOF(handle) line := Upper(FReadLine(handle)) IF InStr(cSearch, line) ? line Count += 1 ENDIF ENDDO RETURN Count

freadline2.summary: Read a line from an open file, specifying two strongly-typed arguments.
freadline2.param: The handle of the file to read from.

The maximum number of characters to read per line. FReadLine2() will read until a hard carriage return (Chr(13)) is reached, end-of-file is encountered, or <dwMax> characters are read. The default value for <dwMax> is 256.
freadline2.returns: The line read. When the end-of-file is reached while attempting to read, FReadLine2() returns a NULL_STRING and FError() is set to 257.
freadline2.remarks: This function is the same as FGets2(). Both functions are assumed to handle raw binary data and are not dependent upon the status of SetAnsi(). FReadText() and FRead4(), on the other hand, are dependent upon SetAnsi().
freadline2.example:
This example uses FReadLine2() to read an entire file with a maximum of 80 characters per line:
hF := FOpen2("docs.txt", FO_READ) IF hF != F_ERROR DO WHILE !FEOF(hF) ? FReadLine2(hF, 80) ENDDO ENDIF FClose(hF)

freadstr.param: The handle of the file to read from.

The number of bytes to read, beginning at the current DOS file pointer position. Characters are read up to <dwBytes> or until end-of-file is encountered. The file pointer is then moved forward <dwBytes>. If <dwBytes> is greater than the number of bytes from the pointer position to the end of the file, the file pointer is positioned at the last byte in the file.
freadstr.returns: A string. A NULL_STRING indicates an error or end-of-file. If end-of-file is reached while reading, FError() is set to 257.
freadstr.example:
This example displays the ASCII values of the first 16 bytes of a text file:
ptrHandle := FOpen2("new.txt", FC_NORMAL) IF ptrHandle = F_ERROR ? DOSErrString(FError()) ELSE cString := FReadStr(ptrHandle, 16) ? cString FClose(ptrHandle) ENDIF

freadtext.summary: Read characters from a file into a buffer variable that is passed by reference.
freadtext.param: The handle of the file to read from.

A variable used to store data read from the specified file. If the length of <cBufferVar> is less than <dwBytes>, a new string whose length is the minimum of <dwBytes> and the remaining bytes in the file is allocated. <cBufferVar> must be passed by reference and, therefore, must be prefaced by the pass-by-reference operator (@).
The number of bytes to read into the buffer.
freadtext.returns: The number of bytes successfully read. A return value less than <dwBytes> or 0 indicates end-of-file or some other read error. FError() can be used to determine the specific error.
freadtext.remarks: FReadText() is the same as FRead() except that an OEM to ANSI conversion is made if SetAnsi() is FALSE.
freadtext.example:
This example uses FRead() after successfully opening a file to read 128 bytes into a buffer area:
DEFINE F_BLOCK := 128 ... cBuffer := Space(F_BLOCK) ptrHandle := FOpen("temp.txt") IF FError() != 0 ? DOSErrString(FError()) ELSE IF FReadText(ptrHandle, @cBuffer, F_BLOCK) <> F_BLOCK ? DOSErrString(FError()) ENDIF FClose(ptrHandle) ENDIF

freadtext3.summary: Read characters from a file into an allocated buffer, with possible OEM to ANSI conversion, based on the current SetAnsi() setting.
freadtext3.param: The handle of the file to read from.
Pointer to an allocated buffer used to store data read from the specified file. The length of this variable must be greater than or equal to <dwBytes>.
The number of bytes to read into the buffer.
freadtext3.returns: The number of bytes successfully read. A return value less than <dwBytes> or 0 indicates end-of-file or some other read error. FError() can be used to determine the specific error.
freadtext3.remarks: FReadText3() is the same as FRead3(), except that an OEM to ANSI conversion is made when SetAnsi() is FALSE.
freadtext3.example:
This example uses FReadText3() after successfully opening a file to read 128 bytes into a buffer area:
DEFINE F_BLOCK := 128 Function Start() LOCAL cBuffer AS PTR cBuffer := MemAlloc(F_BLOCK) IF cBuffer = NULL PTR RETURN FALSE ENDIF ptrHandle := FOpen("temp.txt") IF ptrHandle = F_ERROR ? DOSErrString(FError()) RETURN FALSE ELSE IF FReadText3(ptrHandle, cBuffer, F_BLOCK) <> F_BLOCK ? DOSErrString(FError()) RETURN FALSE ENDIF FClose(ptrHandle) ENDIF MemFree(cBuffer) RETURN TRUE

freestaticobject.summary: To free objects that have been created using the CreateInstanceStatic( ) function.
freestaticobject.remarks:
Previously you would have had code like this –
o := CreateInstanceStatic(#MyClass) ….. MemFree(PTR(_CAST, o))
However, this code did not release the memory. The code that you should be using is this
o := CreateInstanceStatic(#MyClass) ….. FreeStaticObject(o)

frename.summary: Change the name of a file.
frename.param: The original file name, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. SetDefault() and SetPath() settings are ignored; the Windows default is used unless you specify a drive and directory as part of the file name. No extension is assumed.

The new file name, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. SetDefault() and SetPath() settings are ignored; the Windows default is used unless you specify a drive and directory as part of the file name. No extension is assumed. If the source directory is different from the target directory, the file moves to the target directory. If <cNewFile> exists or is currently open, FRename() fails and returns FALSE.
frename.returns: TRUE if the operation succeeds; otherwise, FALSE. In the case of a failure, FError() can be used to determine the specific error. Warning! Files must be closed before renaming. Attempting to rename an open file will produce unpredictable results. When a database file is renamed, the associated memo file, if any, must also be renamed. Failure to do so can compromise the integrity of your databases.
frename.example:
This example demonstrates a file rename:
IF !FRename("oldfile.txt", "newfile.txt") ? DOSErrString(FError()) ENDIF

frewind.summary: Set the file pointer at the top of an open file.
frewind.param: The handle of the open file.
frewind.remarks: FRewind() sets the file pointer to the beginning of a file. It is the same as issuing an FSeek() to go to the top-of-file.
frewind.example:
This example uses FRewind() to go back to the top-of-file:
hF := Fopen2("c:\vo.txt", FO_READ) FSeek(hF, 10, FS_SET) // Move by 10 bytes FRewind(hF) // Move back to the top

fseek.summary: Set the file pointer to a new position.
fseek.param: The handle of the open file.

The number of bytes to move the file pointer, from the position defined by <nOrigin>. It can be a positive or negative number. A positive number moves the pointer forward in the file, and a negative number moves the pointer backward. If <nOrigin> is the end-of-file, <nOffset> must be 0 or negative.

One of the following constants indicating the starting location of the file pointer, telling where to start searching the file:
Constant Seeks From
FS_END End-of-file
FS_RELATIVE Current pointer position
FS_SET Beginning-of-file (default)
fseek.returns: The new position of the file pointer, relative to the beginning of the file (position 0). (The original position of the file pointer does not matter.)
fseek.remarks: FSeek() is a low-level file function that moves the file pointer forward or backward in an open file without actually reading the contents of the specified file. The file pointer cannot be moved beyond the beginning or end-of-file boundaries.
fseek.example:
This example uses FSeek() to determine the length of a file by seeking from the end-of-file. Then, the file pointer is reset to the beginning-of-file:
// Open the file read-only IF (ptrHandle := FOpen2("temp.txt", FO_READ)) != F_ERROR // Get length of the file nLength := FSeek(ptrHandle, 0, FS_END) // Reset file position to beginning-of-file FSeek(ptrHandle, 0) FClose(ptrHandle) ELSE ? DOSErrString(FError()) ENDIF
This example positions the file pointer at the last byte in a file:
FUNCTION FileBottom(ptrHandle) AS LONGINT RETURN (FSeek(ptrHandle, 0, FS_END))
This example positions the file pointer at the first byte in a file (same as the Rewind() function):
FUNCTION FileTop(ptrHandle) AS LONGINT RETURN (FSeek(ptrHandle, 0))

fseek3.summary: Set the file pointer to a new position, specifying three strongly-typed arguments.
fseek3.param: The handle of the open file.

The number of bytes to move the file pointer from the position defined by <dwOrigin>. It can be a positive or negative number. A positive number moves the pointer forward in the file, and a negative number moves the pointer backward.
The same as <nOrigin> with FSeek(), except required. See FSeek() for details.
fseek3.returns: The new position of the file pointer, relative to the beginning of the file (position 0). (The original position of the file pointer does not matter.)
fseek3.example:
This example uses the third argument to report the current position of the file pointer in a specified file (same as FTell()):
FUNCTION FilePos(ptrHandle) AS LONGINT RETURN(FSeek3(ptrHandle, 0, FS_RELATIVE))

fsize.summary: Return the size of the file found by FFCount(), FFirst(), or FNext().
fsize.example:
This example uses FSize() to see the size of files named DOCS*.DOC:
? FFirst("docs*.doc", FC_NORMAL) ? FSize() // Size of the first file matched ? FNext() // Find next file with docs*.doc ? FSize() // Size of the next file matched

ftell.summary: Return the current position of the file pointer.
ftell.param: The handle of the file to examine.
ftell.returns: The current position of the file pointer, relative to the beginning of the file.
ftell.remarks: FTell() gets the current file position. This corresponds to the current physical byte offset for files opened in binary mode.
ftell.example:
This example uses FTell() to reflect the file pointer position before and after an FWrite() and an FSeek():
hF := FOpen2("myfile.txt", FO_READWRITE) IF hF != F_ERROR ? FTell(hF) // 0 FWrite3(hF, "Hello", 5) ? FTell(hF) // 5 FSeek3(hF, 10, FS_SET) ? FTell(hF) // 10 ELSE ? "Open failed" ENDIF

ftime.summary: Return the time stamp of the file found by FFCount(), FFirst(), or FNext().
ftime.example:
This example uses FTime() to find out what time the files were last updated:
// Find the first file matching *.txt ? FFirst("*.txt", FC_NORMAL) // TRUE ? FTime() // 13:18:26 // Get the next file matching *.txt ? FNext() // TRUE ? FTime() // 17:53:06

fwrite.summary: Write a string to an open file.
fwrite.param: The handle of the file to write to.
The number of bytes in <cBuffer> to write, beginning at the current file pointer position. If omitted, the entire contents of <cBuffer> is written.
fwrite.returns: The number of bytes written. If the value returned is equal to <nBytes>, the operation was successful. If the return value is less than <nBytes> or 0, this means that the length of <cBuffer> is less than <nBytes>, or the disk is full, or another error has occurred. FError() can be used to determine the specific error. When a disk full error occurs, FError() is set to 256. FWrite() and FWrite3 are assumed to handle raw binary data and are not dependent upon the status of SetAnsi(). FWriteText() and FWrite4(), on the other hand, are dependent upon SetAnsi().
fwrite.example:
This example copies the contents of one file to another:
DEFINE F_BLOCK := 512 ... cBuffer := Space(F_BLOCK) nInfile := FOpen2("temp.txt", FO_READ) nOutfile := FCreate("newfile.txt", FC_NORMAL) lDone := FALSE DO WHILE !lDone nBytesRead := FRead(nInfile, @cBuffer,; F_BLOCK) IF FWrite(nOutfile, cBuffer) < SLen(cBuffer) ? DOSErrString(FError()) lDone := TRUE ELSE lDone := (nBytesRead = 0) ENDIF ENDDO FClose(nInfile) FClose(nOutfile)

fwrite3.summary: Write the contents of a buffer to an open file.
fwrite3.param: The handle of the file to write to.
A pointer to the buffer to write.
The number of bytes in <ptrBuffer> to write, beginning at the current file pointer position.
fwrite3.returns: The number of bytes written. If the value returned is equal to <dwBytes>, the operation was successful. If the return value is less than <dwBytes> or 0, this means that the length of <ptrBuffer> is less than <dwBytes>, or the disk is full, or another error has occurred. FError() can be used to determine the specific error.
fwrite3.remarks: FWrite3() is a strongly-typed version of FWrite(). Moreover, the second argument in FWrite3() is a pointer to a buffer, instead of a string. See FWrite() for details.
fwrite3.example:
This example writes the contents of a PSZ to a file:.
LOCAL pszBuff AS PSZ LOCAL ptrHandle AS PTR pszBuff := "hello" // psz converted data ptrHandle := FOpen2("temp.bin", FO_READWRITE) IF ptrHandle != F_ERROR FWrite3(ptrHandle, pszBuff, PszLen(pszBuff) ENDIF

fwrite4.summary: Write the contents of a buffer to an open file, with an ANSI to OEM conversion option.
fwrite4.param: The handle of the file to write to.
A pointer to the buffer to write
The number of bytes in <ptrBuffer> to write, beginning at the current file pointer position.
If FALSE , an ANSI to OEM conversion is made.
fwrite4.returns: The number of bytes written. If the value returned is equal to <dwBytes>, the operation was successful. If the return value is less than <dwBytes> or 0, this means that the length of <ptrBuffer> is less than <dwBytes>, or the disk is full, or another error has occurred. FError() can be used to determine the specific error.
fwrite4.remarks: FWrite4() is the same as FWrite3() except that it provides the option of doing an ANSI to OEM conversion.
fwrite4.example:
This example writes the contents of a PSZ to a file while performing an ANSI to OEM conversion:
LOCAL pszBuff AS PSZ LOCAL ptrHandle AS PTR pszBuff := "hello" // psz converted data ptrHandle := FOpen2("temp.bin", FO_READWRITE) IF ptrHandle != F_ERROR FWrite4(ptrHandle, pszBuff,; PszLen(pszBuff), FALSE) ENDIF

fwriteline.summary: Write a string, a carriage-return character, and a linefeed character to an open file.
fwriteline.param: The handle of the file to write to.
The number of bytes in <cBuffer> to write, beginning at the current file pointer position. If <nBytes> is not specified, the value of SLen(<cBuffer>) is used.
fwriteline.returns: The number of bytes written. If the value returned is equal to <nBytes> + 2, the operation was successful. If the return value is less than <nBytes> + 2 or 0, this means that the length of <cBuffer> was less than <nBytes>, or the disk is full, or another error has occurred.
fwriteline.remarks: FWriteLine() is a low-level file function that writes data to an open file from a string buffer. You can either write all or a portion of the buffer contents. Writing begins at the current file position, and the function returns the actual number of bytes written. This function is assumed to handle raw binary data and is not dependent upon the status of SetAnsi(). FWriteText() and FWrite4(), on the other hand, are dependent upon SetAnsi().
fwriteline.example:
This example uses FWriteLine() to write lines starting at the beginning of a file. The carriage-return/linefeed pair increase the return value by 2:
hF := FOpen2("c:\data\sales", FO_READWRITE) IF hF != F_ERROR ? FWriteLine(hF, "Line1") // 7 ? FWriteLine(hF, "Line1", 2) // 4 ENDIF

fwriteline3.summary: Write a string, a carriage-return character, and a linefeed character to an open file, specifying two strongly-typed arguments.
fwriteline3.param: The handle of the file to write to.
The number of bytes in <cBuffer> to write, beginning at the current file pointer position.
fwriteline3.returns: The number of bytes written. If the value returned is equal to <dwBytes> + 2, the operation was successful. If the return value is less than <dwBytes> + 2 or 0, this means that the length of <cBuffer> was less than <dwBytes>, or the disk is full, or another error has occurred.
fwriteline3.remarks: This function is assumed to handle raw binary data and is not dependent upon the status of SetAnsi(). FWriteText() and FWrite4(), on the other hand, are dependent upon SetAnsi().
fwriteline3.example:
This example uses FWriteLine3() to write 5 bytes. The carriage-return/linefeed pair increase the return value by 2:
hF := FOpen2("c:\data\sales", FO_READWRITE) IF hF != F_ERROR ? FWriteLine3(hF, "Line1", 5) // 7 ENDIF

fwritetext.summary: Write a string to an open file, with SetAnsi() dependency.
fwritetext.param: The handle of the file to write to.
The number of bytes in <cBuffer> to write, beginning at the current file pointer position. If omitted, the entire contents of <cBuffer> is written.
fwritetext.returns: The number of bytes written. If the value returned is equal to <nBytes>, the operation was successful. If the return value is less than <nBytes> or 0, this means that the length of <cBuffer> is less than <nBytes>, or the disk is full, or another error has occurred. FError() can be used to determine the specific error.
fwritetext.remarks: FWriteText() is the same as FWrite() except that an ANSI to OEM conversion is made if SetAnsi() is FALSE.
fwritetext.example:
This example copies the contents of one file to another.
DEFINE F_BLOCK := 512 ... cBuffer := Space(F_BLOCK) // turn on OEM <=> ANSI conversions SetAnsi(FALSE) nInfile := FOpen2("temp.txt", FO_READ) nOutfile := FCreate("newfile.txt", FC_NORMAL) lDone := FALSE DO WHILE !lDone nBytesRead := FReadText(nInfile, @cBuffer, F_BLOCK) IF FWriteText(nOutfile, cBuffer) < SLen(cBuffer) ? DOSErrString(FError()) lDone := TRUE ELSE lDone := (nBytesRead = 0) ENDIF ENDDO FClose(nInfile) FClose(nOutfile)

fwritetext3.summary: Write the contents of a buffer to an open file, with SetAnsi() dependency.
fwritetext3.param: The handle of the file to write to.
A pointer to the buffer to write.
The number of bytes in <ptrBuffer> to write, beginning at the current file pointer position.
fwritetext3.returns: The number of bytes written. If the value returned is equal to <dwBytes>, the operation was successful. If the return value is less than <dwBytes> or 0, this means that the length of <ptrBuffer> is less than <dwBytes>, or the disk is full, or another error has occurred. FError() can be used to determine the specific error.
fwritetext3.remarks: FWriteText3() is the same as FWrite3() except that an ANSI to OEM conversion is made if SetAnsi() is FALSE.
fwritetext3.example:
This example writes the contents of a PSZ to a file.
LOCAL pszBuff AS PSZ LOCAL ptrHandle AS PTR pszBuff := "hello" // psz converted data ptrHandle := FOpen2("temp.bin", FO_READWRITE) IF ptrHandle != F_ERROR FWriteText3(ptrHandle, pszBuff, PszLen(pszBuff)) ENDIF

fxopen.param: The name of the file to open, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. When <dwMode> contains FXO_WILD, <cFileName> may contain wildcard characters.
The DOS open mode, indicating how the opened file is to be accessed. You may specify one or more of these constants by adding them together or using the _Or() operator:
Description
Open for read only.
Open for write.
Open for read and write.
Open the file with compatibility mode, allowing multiple tasks or work stations to open the file.
Open exclusively, preventing any other program from opening the file.
Open file and deny other programs write access to the file.
Open file and deny other programs read access to the file.
Open file without denying read or write access to other programs.
Fills internal file structure that contains file information resulting from opening the file.
Delete the file (note that file must be closed when deleted).
Compare time and date of an internal file structure with time and date of the file.
Direct Windows to search in directories.
Used for Cancel button in a dialog box.
Create a new file or truncate an existing file to a length of zero.
Display a dialog box if the file does not exist.
Open and then close the file, thus performing an existence test.
Open the file using internal reopen information.
Allow wildcard characters in the file name.

If <cFileName> is specified without an explicit drive and directory indicating where to find the file, this argument allows you to supply a list of additional paths to search in case the file is not found in the default directory or search path (see SetDefault() and SetPath() for standard file searching rules). To omit the argument, specify NULL_STRING.
Note:This argument is not meaningful and should be omitted if you are creating a file.
fxopen.returns: The file handle of the opened file in the range of 0 to 32,767. This value is similar to an alias in the database system and is required to identify the open file to other file functions. It is, therefore, important to assign the return value to a variable for later use, as in the example below. If an error occurs, FXOpen() returns F_ERROR. FError() can be used to determine the specific error. For example, if the file does not exist, FXOpen() returns F_ERROR and FError() returns 2 to indicate that the file was not found. In case of a concurrency conflict, FXOpen() sets NetErr() to TRUE. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.

getamext.summary: Returns a string representing the morning extension for time strings in 12-hour format.
getamext.remarks: Time strings formatted using the 12-hour time format have an extension to specify if the time is in the morning or the evening. GetAMExt() returns the current setting for the extension identifying morning time strings (that is, those between 12:00:00 midnight and just before 12:00:00 noon). A typical extension for morning time strings is "AM", which is how the function derives its name. The initial default for the morning extension is affected by SetInternational(), which you can refer to for more information. Use SetAMExt() to change the value of this setting.
getamext.example:
This example turns on the SetInternational() flag, causing the time string extensions to be determined by International settings in the Windows Control Panel:
SetInternational(#Windows) ? GetAMExt() // Return value varies between systems ? GetPMExt() // Typically, AM and PM are displayed

getapplocaleid.summary: Gets the locale ID that the runtime uses for comparing strings when running in Windows collation mode (SetCollation(#Windows)).

getappobject.summary: Return the global App object for this application.
getappobject.example:
The following example terminates a dialog based application: METHOD CancelButton() CLASS OrderDialog
SELF:EndDialog() GetAppObject():Quit()

getcurpath.summary: Get the current X# search path for opening file.
getcurpath.example: This example uses GetCurPath() to specify the directory where a file is to be processed: FCreate2(GetCurPath() + "newfile.txt", FC_NORMAL)

getdateformat.returns: The default date format supplied with X# or a customized date format defined via the SetDateFormat() or SetDateCountry() functions.
getdateformat.example:
This example returns the default date format:
FUNCTION Start() QOut(GetDateFormat()) // Result: MM/DD/YY

getdefault.summary: Return the X# default drive and directory.
getdefault.example:
This example uses GetDefault() to display the default drive:
FUNCTION Start ? GetDefault() // NULL_STRING SetDefault("c:\vo\prg") ? GetDefault() // c:\vo\prg\ RETURN TRUE

getdefaultdir.remarks: Return the current SetDefaultDir() setting. The string ends with a trailing "\".
getdefaultdir.example:
This example uses GetDefaultDir() to display the location of the error log file:
FUNCTION Start() ? GetDefaultDir() // NULL_STRING SetDefaultDir("c:\vo\prg") ? GetDefaultDir() // c:\vo\prg

getdllmajorversion.summary: Return the major version number of a DLL
getdllmajorversion.param: The name of the DLL whose version you want to read
getdllmajorversion.remarks:
Return the current major Version number of a DLL
The DLL must contain a function called DllGetVersion which fills in a _WINDLLVERSIONINFO structure. This convention for determining DLL version is followed by Windows DLLs such as Shell32.DLL

getdoserror.summary: Return the DOS error code from any application.
getdoserror.remarks: The value of GetDOSError() is an extended DOS error code which is never cleared. The application which sets this error code need not be the current application or even a X# application. By contrast, on every DOS call in a X# application, the value of DOSError() is set to the current DOS error if there was an error or is cleared to 0 if there was no error. For a complete list of DOS error codes and accompanying descriptions, see Appendix A.
getdoserror.example:
In this example, DOSError() indicates that the last DOS call in the current application did not generate an error. By contrast, GetDOSError() indicates that a DOS error occurred in the system previously:
? DOSError() // 0 ? GetDOSError() // 2

getenv.summary: Retrieve the contents of a DOS environment variable.
getenv.param: The name of the environment variable whose contents you want to retrieve. (Note that GetEnv() is not case-sensitive.)
getenv.returns: The contents of the specified environment variable. If the variable cannot be found, GetEnv() returns a NULL_STRING.
getenv.remarks:
GetEnv() lets you retrieve information from the DOS environment into an application program. Typically, this is configuration information — including path names — that describe the location of files (database, index, label, or reports). Note: Instead of using environment variables for configuring your application, you may want to consider using registry settings. See the "X# Registry Entries" appendix in the IDE User Guide for more information.
Empty return value: If you are certain that an environment variable exists and yet GetEnv() always returns a NULL_STRING, be sure there are no spaces between the environment variable name and the first character of the string assigned to it in the DOS SET command.
getenv.example:
This example retrieves the current DOS path setting, making it the current X# path:
cPath := GetEnv("PATH") SET PATH TO (cPath)
This example uses environment variables to configure the specific locations of files. When you set up a system, define environment variables that contain the location of various file types, like this:
C>SET LOC_DBF=<DatabaseFilePath> C>SET LOC_NTX=<IndexFilePath> C>SET LOC_RPT=<ReportFilePath>
In the configuration section of your application program, assign the contents of the environment variables to variables. Then when you access a file, preface the reference with the path, as follows:
cDdfDirectory := GetEnv("LOC_DBF") USE (cDdfDirectory + "invoices.dbf")

getfattr.param:
One or more of the following constants or strings:
Character Constant Description
A FC_ARCHIVED Archived
D FA_DIRECTORY Directory
H FC_HIDDEN Hidden
NULL_STRING FC_NORMAL Read/write
R FC_READONLY Read-only
S FC_SYSTEM System
V FA_VOLUME Search for the DOS volume label and exclude all other files
To specify more than one constant, you can either add attributes together, as in FC_SYSTEM + FC_HIDDEN, or use the _Or() operator, as in _Or(FC_SYSTEM, FC_HIDDEN). To specify more than one string, simply concatenate them, as in "SH."
getfattr.returns: A number that represents the file attribute specified. This number could represent two or more file attributes added together.
getfattr.example:
This example uses GetFAttr() to return file attributes as a number:
? GetFAttr(FA_DIRECTORY) // 16 ? GetFAttr(FC_ARCHIVED + FC_READONLY) // 33 ? GetFAttr("AR") // 33 // Below GetFAttr() converts a string // to the required numeric format ? FFirst("*.txt", GetFAttr("H"))

getfmask.summary: Prepare a file specification for wildcard searching.
getfmask.param: The name of a drive and/or directory and/or file.
getfmask.returns: If <cString> ends with ":" or "\", the modified <cString> +"*.*" is returned; otherwise <cString> is returned.
getfmask.remarks: If <cString> ends with ":" or "\", indicating that <cString> is a drive or directory, "*.*" is added. This enables searching through all files in the drive or directory specified.
getfmask.example:
This example uses GetFMask() to add a wild-card search to the arguments passed to Dir() and File().
LOCAL cOrigin AS STRING LOCAL cSearch AS STRING cOrigin := "c:" cSearch := GetFMask(cOrigin) ? cSearch // c:*.* Dir(cSearch) File(cSearch)

getfocusedobject.summary: Return the object corresponding to the control or window that currently has input focus.
getfocusedobject.returns: The window or control object that currently has input focus.
getfocusedobject.example:
This example causes a beep if the object that currently has input focus is a MultiLineEdit control:
oObj := GetFocusedObject() IF oObj != NULL_OBJECT .AND. IsInstanceOf(oControl, #MultiLineEdit) MessageBeep(MB_ICONASTERISK) ENDIF

getfolderpath.summary: Return a folder path as a string.
getfolderpath.param: A constent or an integer that represents the folder you require the path of.
:= 0x0038 // %windir%\Resources\, For theme and other windows resources.
:= 0x0039 // %windir%\Resources\<LangID>, for theme and other windows specific resources.
TRUE to create nominated folder, FALSE to retrieve
Only needed in special cases. See SHGetFolderPath API func.
Only needed in special cases. See SHGetFolderPath API func.
getfolderpath.returns:
The path to the requested folder as a string.
This requires IE4 (Shell 4.71) or later.

getnatdll.summary: Get the current DLL for nation-dependent operations and messages.
getnatdll.returns: The name of the current nation-dependent DLL.
getnatdll.remarks: The default library for nation-dependent operations is VO28NAT.DLL, but you can change it using SetNatDLL(). GetNatDLL() returns the current setting for the nation-dependent DLL.
getnatdll.example:
This example shows the difference in the return value of GetNatDLL() before and after a call to SetNatDLL():
? GetNatDLL() // VO28NAT.DLL ? SetNatDLL("GERMAN.DLL") // .T. ? GetNatDLL() // GERMAN.DLL

getnatdllhandle.summary: Retrieve the DLL handle for the currently loaded NationDLL
getnatdllhandle.returns: PTR of the current loaded DLL
getnatdllhandle.remarks: This function gives you access to the currently loaded Nation DLL. You can use this to retrieve language strings from the DLL.

getobjectbyhandle.summary: Return the object associated with a given window handle.
getobjectbyhandle.returns: The Window or Control object associated with the given window handle.
getobjectbyhandle.example:
This example gets the object associated with the control that currently has focus:
FUNCTION GetFocusedObject() AS OBJECT LOCAL oCtrl AS OBJECT oCtrl := GetObjectByHandle(GetFocus()) IF IsInstanceOf(oCtrl, #Control) RETURN oCtrl ELSE RETURN NULL_OBJECT ENDIF

getpmext.summary: Returns a string representing the evening extension for time strings in 12-hour format.
getpmext.remarks: Time strings formatted using the 12-hour time format have an extension to specify if the time is in the morning or the evening. GetPMExt() returns the current setting for the extension identifying evening time strings (that is, those between 12:00:00 noon and just before 12:00:00 midnight). A typical extension for evening time strings is "PM", which is how the function derives its name. The initial default for the evening extension is affected by SetInternational(), which you can refer to for more information. Use SetPMExt() to change the value of this setting. Note: If SetInternational(#Windows) is in effect, the evening extension is also displayed as part of the 24-hour time format. This is a Windows standard that is not specific to X#.
getpmext.example:
This example turns on the SetInternational() flag, causing the time string extensions to be determined by International settings in the Windows Control Panel:
SetInternational(#Windows) ? GetAMExt() // Return value varies between systems ? GetPMExt() // Typically, AM and PM are displayed

getshellmajorversion.summary: Return the major version number of a DLL
getshellmajorversion.remarks: Returns the major version number of the Windows Shell, SHELL32.DLL.

getstoragenames.summary: Fills up the passed array with the names of the storages in the OLEObject storage file.
getstoragenames.param: The name of the storage file.
getstoragenames.example:
The following example is from the OLE Container application in \CAVOxx\SAMPLES\OLE\CONT:
METHOD FileLoad() CLASS ContainerShell LOCAL oOle AS DraggableOleObject LOCAL oOD AS OpenDialog LOCAL aStgNames AS ARRAY LOCAL i AS INT LOCAL oCont AS Container (oOD := OpenDialog{SELF, "*.CDF"}):Show() aStgNames := {} IF (!EMPTY(oOD:FileName) .and. GetStorageNames(oOD:FileName, aStgNames)) oCont := SELF:FileNew() oCont:Caption := oOD:FileName IF (oCont != NULL_OBJECT) FOR i:=1 TO ALen(aStgNames) oOle := DraggableOleObject{oCont} IF (oOle:ImportFromStorage(oOD:Filename, aStgNames[i])) oCont:SetupOLEObject(oOle, NIL, TRUE) ELSE oOle:Destroy() ENDIF NEXT ENDIF ENDIF
OLE Library

getsystemmessage.summary: Convert a system error code to a text message.
getsystemmessage.param: A DWord system error code. This is usually the result of GetLastError().
getsystemmessage.returns: The system message associated with the error code passed in.

getthemeappproperties.summary: Retrieves the property flags that control how visual styles are applied in the current application
getthemeappproperties.returns: STAP_ALLOW_NONCLIENT Specifies that the nonclient areas of application windows have visual styles applied. STAP_ALLOW_CONTROLS Specifies that controls in application windows have visual styles applied. STAP_ALLOW_WEBCONTENT Specifies that all web content displayed in an application is rendered using visual styles.

gettickcountlow.summary: Get the number of 1/10000 seconds that have elapsed since Windows was started.
gettickcountlow.returns: The number of 1/10000 seconds (milliseconds/10) that have elapsed since Windows was last started.
gettickcountlow.remarks: Because of the range of a DWORD, after 5 days there will be a numeric overflow.

gettimesep.summary: Return the current separation character used in time strings.
gettimesep.returns: The ASCII value of the current time separator (the character being used to separate hours, minutes and seconds in time strings). Since the default time separator is a colon (:), GetTimeSep() returns 58 by default. Note that you can use the Chr() function to convert this return value to a character.
gettimesep.example:
This example uses GetTimeSep() to display the current time separator:
? TIME() // 08:31:53 ? GetTimeSep() // 58 ? CHR(GetTimeSep()) // : SetTimeSep(ASC("*")) // Set time separator to * ? TIME() // 08*31*56 ? GetTimeSep() // 42 ? CHR(GetTimeSep()) // *

hardcr.summary: Replace all soft carriage returns (Chr(141)) in a string with hard carriage returns (Chr(13)).
hardcr.remarks: Soft carriage returns are added by MemoEdit() when lines wrap. X# console commands, like REPORT and LABEL FORM, do not automatically convert soft carriage returns to hard carriage returns; therefore, in order to display long strings and memo fields containing soft carriage returns, you must convert them.
hardcr.example:
This examples uses HardCR() to display a memo field that has been formatted with the automatic word wrapping of MemoEdit():
USE sales NEW ? HARDCR(sales->Notes)
This example formats a string:
? HARDCR(_Chr(141) + _Chr(10)) // Result: _Chr(13) + _Chr(10)

header.summary: Return the length of the database file header.
header.returns: The number of bytes in the header of the database file. If no database file is in use, Header() returns a 0.
header.remarks: Header() is used with LastRec(), RecSize(), and DiskSpace() to create procedures for backing up files.
header.example:
This example determines the header size of the SALES.DBF:
USE sales NEW QOut(Header()) // Result: 258
This example defines a pseudofunction, DBFSize(), that uses Header() with RecSize() and LastRec() to calculate the size of the current database file in bytes: define DBFSize() ((RecSize() * LastRec()) + Header() + 1) Later you can use DBFSize() as you would any function:
USE sales NEW USE customer NEW QOut(DBFSize()) QOut(Sales->DBFSize())

hibyte.summary: Return the high-order (leftmost) byte in a number.
hibyte.param: The number whose high-order byte you want to get.
hibyte.remarks: Related data can be stored in the high-order and low-order words of a variable. Therefore, instead of creating and returning a 2-element array, it may be more efficient to return a word whose 2 bytes contain separate information.
hibyte.example:
This example applies HiByte() and LoByte() to a binary number. It also displays the high-order and low-order portions of the binary number as 2 separate numbers:
bHi := HiByte(0b0000000011111111) bLow := LoByte(0b0000000011111111) // High-order bits ? 0b00000000 // 0 ? bHi // 0 // Low-order bits ? 0b11111111 // 255 ? bLow // 255

hiword.summary: Return the high-order (leftmost) word in a number.
hiword.param: The number whose high-order word you want to get.
hiword.remarks: Related data can be stored in the high-order and low-order words of a variable. Therefore, instead of creating and returning a 2-element array, it may be more efficient to return a double word whose 2 words contain separate information. Also, many Windows API functions receive data in a LONGINT argument. Usually the high-order and low-order words of this argument contain different information about a window and its messages. HiWord() can be used to extract the high-order word of this argument.

i2bin.summary: Convert a short integer to a string containing a 16-bit signed integer.
i2bin.param: The value to convert. Decimal digits are truncated.
i2bin.remarks: I2Bin() is a conversion function that converts a short integer to a 2-byte string. Typical applications include reading foreign file types in their native format and then saving, reading, decrypting, and transmitting numeric data in their compressed binary form instead of in strings. Its inverse is Bin2I().

incollect.summary: Check whether the application is in a garbage collection phase.
incollect.returns: TRUE if the application is collecting garbage; otherwise, FALSE.
incollect.remarks: Inside Axit() methods and within routines that are registered to be called at the time of garbage collection, InCollect() might be TRUE. In such cases, you should avoid altering dynamic objects or call UnregisterAxit() to terminate the registration of Axit() methods or garbage collection routines.
incollect.example:
This example checks whether the application is in garbage collection before clearing out a string and calling UnregisterAxit():
Method AXIT() CLASS CaptainCautious IF !InCollect() cInstanceVar := "" UnregisterAxit(SELF)
ENDIF RETURN NIL

indexext.summary: Return the default index file extension for a work area as defined by its RDD.
indexext.returns: A string indicating the default index file extension for a work area as defined by its RDD.
indexext.remarks: This function is provided for compatibility only. The recommended function for obtaining the default index file extension is DBOrderInfo(DBOI_INDEXEXT).

indexhplock.summary: Return and optionally change the setting that determines whether to use the High Performance (HP) locking schema for newly created .NTX files.
indexhplock.param: TRUE uses the HP locking schema. FALSE uses the standard locking schema as defined by NewIndexLock(). The initial default is FALSE, which can be changed using the HPLock entry (1 means TRUE and 0 means FALSE) in the X# section of WIN.INI.
indexhplock.returns: If <lNewSetting> is not specified, IndexHPLock() returns the current setting. If <lNewSetting> is specified, the previous setting is returned.
indexhplock.remarks: By default, this function sets the index locking schema for the current work area. It can be made to operate on an unselected work area by specifying it within an aliased expression. Thus, you can set a separate flag for each work area. You cannot, however, use index files with different locking schema in the same work area. This setting affects only newly created index files. It has no effect on existing files, in which locking schema is determined by information stored in the file's header record. Note: This function applies only if you are using the DBFNTX RDD. Important! If your application must share data with an Xbase product, either simultaneously or at different times, do not set IndexHPLock(TRUE) or include HPLock=1 in the X# settings in WIN.INI. Doing so will make your .NTX files incompatible with these products.
indexhplock.example:
This example illustrates the status of IndexHPLock() after several calls to the function:
? IndexHPLock() // FALSE (initial setting) ? IndexHPLock(TRUE) // FALSE (previous setting) ? IndexHPLock() // TRUE (current setting)

indexkey.summary: Return the key expression of a specified order.
indexkey.param: The position of the order in the order list of the work area. A value of 0 specifies the controlling order, without regard to its actual position in the list.
indexkey.returns: The key expression of the specified order. If there is no corresponding order or if no database file is open, IndexKey() returns a NULL_STRING.
indexkey.remarks: This function is provided for compatibility only. The recommended function for obtaining the key expression of an order is DBOrderInfo(DBOI_EXPRESSION,, <nPosition>).

indexord.summary: Return the position of the controlling order within the order list.
indexord.returns: The position of the controlling order. A value of 0 indicates either that no database file is open or that there is no controlling order and records are being accessed in natural order.
indexord.remarks: This function is provided for compatibility only. The recommended function for obtaining the position of the controlling order is DBOrderInfo(DBOI_NUMBER).

inlist.summary: Indicate whether the first expression in a series is repeated later in the series.
inlist.param: A list of expressions separated by commas. The first expression can be any data type. All other expressions should be the same data type as the first expression. If the other expressions are not the same type as the first expression, a runtime error indicates a data type mismatch.
inlist.returns: TRUE if the first expression matches any of the other listed expressions; otherwise, FALSE.
inlist.remarks: InList() determines whether an expression is found in a series of expressions. The first expression is compared to each of the other expressions until either a match is found or the entire list has been traversed. For exact matching, use InListExact().
inlist.example:
This examples use InList() to indicate whether the first expression in each series is repeated later in the series:
? InList("b", "a", "b", "c") // TRUE ? InList("d", "a", "b", "c") // FALSE nJack := 11 nQueen := 12 nKing := 13 nAce := 14 ? InList(nJack, nQueen, nKing, nAce, nKing) // FALSE ? InList(nJack, nAce, nJack, nJack, nQueen) // TRUE

inlistexact.summary: Indicate whether the first expression in a series is repeated in the exact same form later in the series.
inlistexact.param: A list of expressions separated by commas. The first expression can be any data type. All other expressions should be the same data type as the first expression. If the other expressions are not the same type as the first expression, a runtime error indicates a data type mismatch.
inlistexact.returns: TRUE if the first expression matches any of the other listed expressions; otherwise, FALSE.
inlistexact.remarks: InListExact() is the same as InList() except that == is used for matching instead of =. See the "Operators and Expressions" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on how these operators work.
inlistexact.example:
This example compares InList() and InListExact() when the left operand in a comparison is longer than the right operand of a comparison:
? InList("longer", "long") // TRUE ? InList("long ", "long") // TRUE ? InListExact("longer", "long") // FALSE ? InListExact("long ", "long") // FALSE
This example compares InList() and InListExact() when the right operand in a comparison is longer than the left operand of a comparison:
? InList("long", "longer") // FALSE ? InList("long", "long ") // FALSE ? InListExact("long", "longer") // FALSE ? InListExact("long", "long ") // FALSE

instr.summary: Indicate whether a substring is contained in a string.
instr.param: The string in which to search.
instr.returns: TRUE if the substring was found; otherwise, FALSE.
instr.remarks: InStr() is a strongly typed version of the $ operator. See "Operators and Expressions" in the Programmer's Guide for information on the $ operator.
instr.example:
This example uses InStr() to indicate if a specific substring is part of a longer string:
LOCAL cSearch AS STRING LOCAL cTarget AS STRING cSearch := "Bend" cTarget := "Indian Bend Road" IF InStr(cSearch, cTarget) ? "Found It" END

integer.summary: Truncate or floor a number with decimal digits to a whole number.
integer.param: The number to truncate or floor.
integer.returns: The whole number to the left of the decimal point. Since both <uValue> and the return value are data type USUAL, you are not limited to the size of an integer.
integer.remarks:
Integer() converts a numeric value to an integer by taking the floor of the number. Note – this is not the same as truncation except for positive integers — it is not rounding. Integer() is useful in operations where the decimal portion of a number is not needed. See "Operators and Expressions" in the Programmer's Guide for information on type casting. Note that a loss of precision on floating numbers might be significant. For example, you might not know that a number is internally represented as 0.99999999999999999, because, when that number is displayed with QOut() or passed to the Str() function, internal rounding returns a value of 1.0. When a number like that is passed to the Integer() function, however, its decimal portion is truncated and a value of zero is returned. If this is not what you had intended, you can use Round(<nValue>, 0) instead of Integer().
Integer() is the same as the Int() function in CA-Clipper, but INT is a reserved word in X#. Under X#, Int() is a conversion operator. With numbers that are not greater than a short integer, it yields the same results as Integer() and maintains compatibility with CA-Clipper.
integer.example:
These examples demonstrate the results of various invocations of the Integer() function:
? Integer(100.00) // 100 ? Integer(.5) // 0 ? Integer(-100.75) // -100 ? Integer(-1.2) // -1

isaccess.summary: Check whether a particular access method can be sent to an object.
isaccess.returns:
TRUE if the specified access method is defined for the class of the specified object; otherwise, FALSE.
This example checks if x and y of CLASS MyClass are true instance variables or if they are overridden by an access:
CLASS MyClass EXPORT x ACCESS y CLASS MyClass FUNCTION Start() LOCAL o AS MyClass o := MyClass{} ?IsAccess(o,#x) // FALSE ?IsAccess(o,#y) // TRUE

isalnum.summary: Determine if the leftmost character in a string is alphanumeric.
isalnum.returns: TRUE if the first character in <pszString> is either alphabetic or numeric; FALSE if the string begins with any character other than a number or letter.
isalnum.remarks: This function is nation-dependent. In the US version, for example, an alphanumeric character is a number from '0' to '9' or an uppercase or lowercase English letter from A to Z.
isalnum.example:
These examples demonstrate various results of IsAlNum():
? IsAlNum("AbcDe") // TRUE ? IsAlNum("aBcDE") // TRUE ? IsAlNum("1BCde") // TRUE ? IsAlNum(".Steve") // FALSE

isalpha.summary: Determine if the leftmost character in a string is alphabetic.
isalpha.returns: TRUE if the first character in <pszString> is alphabetic; FALSE if the string begins with a digit or any other non-alphabetic character.
isalpha.remarks: This function is nation-dependent. In the US version, for example, an alphabetic character is any uppercase or lowercase English letter from A to Z.
isalpha.example:
These examples demonstrate various results of IsAlpha():
? IsAlpha("Carl") // TRUE ? IsAlpha("aBcDE") // TRUE ? IsAlpha("1BCde") // TRUE ? IsAlpha("..Flemming") // FALSE

isappthemed.summary: Return the theme setting for the current application.
isappthemed.returns: Reports whether the current application's user interface displays using visual styles. A visual style can be turned off in Control Panel, so that an application can support visual styles but not have a visual style applied at a given time.

isarray.summary: Determine if a value is an array.
isarray.returns: TRUE if the value is an array; otherwise, FALSE.
isarray.example:
This example uses IsArray() to determine a course of action:
DO CASE CASE IsArray(uValue) AEval(uValue, cbBlock) CASE IsString(uValue) SEval(uValue, cbBlock) OTHERWISE Eval(cbBlock) ENDCASE

isassign.summary: Check whether a particular assign method can be sent to an object.
isassign.returns:
TRUE if the specified assign method is defined for the class of the specified object; otherwise, FALSE.
This example checks if x and y of CLASS MyClass are true instance variables or if they are overridden by an assign:
CLASS MyClass EXPORT x ASSIGN y(a) CLASS MyClass FUNCTION Start() LOCAL o AS MyClass o := MyClass{} ?IsAssign(o,#x) // FALSE ?IsAssign(o,#y) // TRUE

isbdigit.summary: Determine if the leftmost character in a string is a binary digit (0 or 1).
isbdigit.returns: TRUE if the first character of the string is 0 or 1; otherwise, FALSE.
isbdigit.example:
These examples demonstrate various results of IsBDigit():
? IsBDigit("AbcDe") // FALSE ? IsBDigit("1abcd") // TRUE ? IsBDigit("012345") // TRUE ? IsBDigit("21345") // FALSE

isclass.param: The symbol of the class to examine.
isclass.returns: TRUE if the class exists; otherwise, FALSE.
isclass.example:
This example shows that IsClass() returns TRUE for a declared class name:
