CLASS Cars // Declare a class named Cars ? IsClass(#Cars) // TRUE
This example uses IsClass() to decide how to manipulate colors:
LOCAL uColor AS USUAL IF IsClass(#CustomPalette) uColor := CustomPalette{} ELSE uColor := SetColor() ENDIF

isclassof.summary: Determine if one class is a subclass of another class.
isclassof.param: The symbol of the class to examine.
The symbol of the superclass to examine.
isclassof.returns: TRUE if <symClassName> inherits from <symSuperClassName>; otherwise, FALSE.
isclassof.example:
The following example shows the result of IsClassOf() when queried:
CLASS A CLASS B INHERIT A CLASS C FUNCTION CheckClasses() ? IsClassOf(#B, #A) // TRUE ? IsClassOf(#B, #C) // FALSE ? IsClassOf(#C, #A) // FALSE

iscodeblock.summary: Determine if a value is a code block.
iscodeblock.returns: TRUE if the value is a code block; otherwise, FALSE.
iscodeblock.remarks: IsCodeBlock() identifies both runtime and compile-time code blocks as code blocks. UsualType(), on the other hand, identifies runtime code blocks as objects.
iscodeblock.example:
This example uses IsCodeBlock() and UsualType() on a runtime code block:
LOCAL cbRunTime // Create code block at runtime cbRunTime := &("{||TRUE}") ? UsualType(cbRunTime) // OBJECT ? IsCodeBlock(cbRunTime) // TRUE
This example uses IsCodeBlock() and UsualType() on a compile-time code block:
LOCAL cbCompileTime // Code block known at compile-time cbCompileTime := {||TRUE} ? UsualType(cbCompileTime) // CODEBLOCK ? IsCodeBlock(cbCompileTime) // TRUE

isdate.summary: Determine if a value is a DATE.
isdate.returns: TRUE if the value is a DATE data type; otherwise, FALSE.
isdate.example:
This example uses IsDate() to determine whether any data conversion is needed:
IF IsString(uValue) uValue := CToD(uValue) ELSEIF !IsDate(uValue) uValue := Today() ENDIF

isdigit.summary: Determine if the leftmost character in a string is a digit (that is, a numeric digit between 0 and 9).
isdigit.returns: TRUE if the first character of the string is a number from 0 to 9; otherwise; FALSE.
isdigit.remarks: IsDigit() is useful when you need to know if the current string is a number before converting it to a numeric value with the Val() function.
isdigit.example:
These examples demonstrate various results of IsDigit():
? IsDigit("AbcDe") // FALSE ? IsDigit("1abcd") // TRUE ? IsDigit(".12345") // FALSE

isdynptr.summary: Check to see if a value is in dynamic memory.
isdynptr.param: A pointer to the object you want to check.
isdynptr.returns: TRUE if a value is in dynamic memory; otherwise, FALSE.
isdynptr.remarks: IsDynPtr() determines whether a value is in dynamic memory. Literal objects, such as strings and floats, are in static memory. Objects copied through DynToOldSpace() are also in static memory. It is possible that both IsDynPtr() and IsOldSpace() return FALSE for a given pointer.
isdynptr.example:
This example uses IsDynPtr() on a literal string, which is static: ? IsDynPtr(Ptr(_CAST, "hello")) // FALSE This example uses IsDynPtr() on a string that is created through the + operator and is dynamic: ? IsDynPtr(Ptr(_CAST, "hello" + "world")) // TRUE This example uses IsDynPtr() to show the effect of DynToOldSpace() on a value:
FUNCTION IsDynamic() LOCAL cDynTool cDynTool := Time() // Dynamic ? IsDynPtr(Ptr(_CAST, cDynTool)) // TRUE cDynTool := DynToOldSpace(cDynTool) // Copy it to static memory ? IsDynPtr(Ptr(_CAST, cDynTool)) // FALSE

isfloat.summary: Determine if a value is a FLOAT.
isfloat.returns: TRUE if the value is the FLOAT data type; otherwise, FALSE.
isfloat.example:
This example uses IsFloat() to determine how to format numeric data for display:
IF IsFloat(uValue) nDecimal := 2 ELSE nDecimal := 0 ENDIF ? Str(uValue, 10, nDecimal)

isinstanceof.summary: Determine if an object is an instance of a class.
isinstanceof.param: A symbolic representation of the class.
isinstanceof.returns: TRUE if <oObject> is an instance of <symClassName>; otherwise, FALSE.
isinstanceof.remarks: An instance of an inherited class is also an instance of the original (super) class. However, an instance of a super class is not an instance of any of its inherited classes. IsInstanceOf() is similar to CheckInstanceOf() except that it does not generate an error message if the specified object is not an instance of the specified class.
isinstanceof.example:
These examples illustrates IsInstanceOf() on inherited classes:
CLASS Employee EXPORT name, age METHOD Init(tName, tAge) CLASS Employee name := tName age := tAge CLASS Programmer INHERIT Employee CLASS Assembler INHERIT Programmer FUNCTION CheckArgument() LOCAL x, y AS OBJECT x := Employee{"John", "25"} y := Assembler{"Bill", "30"} ? IsInstanceOf(x, #Employee) // TRUE ? IsInstanceOf(x, #Programmer) // FALSE ? IsInstanceOf(x, #Assembler) // FALSE ? IsInstanceOf(y, #Employee) // TRUE ? IsInstanceOf(y, #Programmer) // TRUE ? IsInstanceOf(y, #Assembler) // TRUE

isinstanceofusual.summary: Determine if an object inside a USUAL is an instance of a class.
isinstanceofusual.param: A USUAL type containing the object to check for.
A symbolic representation of the class.
isinstanceofusual.returns: TRUE if <uObject> is an instance of <symClassName>; otherwise, FALSE.
isinstanceofusual.remarks: IsInstanceOfUsual() is used to determine whether the polymorphic value <uObject> belongs to a class whose symbol is <symClassName>. An instance of an inherited class is also an instance of the super class. However, an instance of a super class is not an instance of any of its inherited classes. IsInstanceOfUsual() is the same as the following: UsualType(<uO>) = OBJECT .AND. IsInstanceOf(<uO>, <symClassName>). Thus, it should be used instead of IsInstanceOf() in situations where it is not known whether a variable is an object. IsInstanceOfUsual()() is also similar to CheckInstanceOf() except that it does not generate an error message if the specified object is not an instance of the specified class.
isinstanceofusual.example:
This example uses IsInstanceOfUsual() to check whether a USUAL variable is an object of a specific class:
CLASS Cars EXPORT Wheels LOCAL uMercedes uMercedes := Cars{} ? IsInstanceOfUsual(uMercedes, #Cars) // TRUE

iskanji.summary: Determine if the first character of a string is a kanji character.
iskanji.returns: TRUE if the first character in <cMBTarget> is a kanji character; otherwise, FALSE.

islogic.summary: Determine if a value is a logical.
islogic.returns: TRUE if the value is the LOGIC data type; otherwise, FALSE.
islogic.example:
This example uses IsLogic() to display the possible results of a survey:
IF IsLogic(uValue) IF uValue ? "Responded Yes" ELSE ? "Responded No" ENDIF ELSEIF IsNil(uValue) ? "Did not respond" ELSE ? "Other response or transmission error" ENDIF

islong.summary: Determine if a value is a LONGINT.
islong.returns: TRUE if the value is the LONGINT data type; otherwise, FALSE.
islong.example:
This example uses IsLong() to determine the appropriate conversion function:
IF IsLong(uValue) cTransmit := L2Bin(uValue) ELSEIF IsFloat(uValue) cTransmit := F2Bin(uValue) ENDIF

islower.summary: Determine if the leftmost character in a string is a lowercase letter.
islower.returns: TRUE if the first character of the string is a lowercase letter; otherwise, FALSE.
islower.remarks: IsLower() is the inverse of IsUpper(), which determines whether a character begins with an uppercase character. Both IsLower() and IsUpper() relate to the Lower() and Upper() functions, which actually convert lowercase characters to uppercase, and vice versa. This function is nation-dependent.
islower.example:
These examples demonstrate various results of IsLower():
? IsLower("aBcDe") // TRUE ? IsLower("AbcDe") // FALSE ? IsLower("1abcd") // FALSE ? IsLower("abcd") // TRUE

ismethod.summary: Check whether a particular method can be sent to an object.
ismethod.param: The method name, specified without parentheses.
ismethod.returns: TRUE if the specified method is defined for the class of the specified object; otherwise, FALSE.
ismethod.example:
This example uses IsMethod() to check whether an object is capable of making sounds:
CLASS Animal EXPORT sound, weight METHOD Init(s, w) CLASS Animal sound := s weight := w METHOD Speaks CLASS Animal QOut(sound) CLASS Programmer EXPORT language METHOD Init(lang) CLASS Programmer language := lang METHOD Speaks CLASS Programmer QOut(language) QOut("Hello World") QOut(Chr(7)) Function Start() LOCAL dog AS Animal LOCAL hacker AS Programmer dog := Animal{"Bark Bark!", 50} hacker := Programmer{"VO"} IF IsMethod(dog, #Speaks) dog:Speaks() // Says Bark Bark ENDIF IF IsMethod(hacker, #Speaks) // Says VO, Hello World, rings a bell hacker:Speaks() ENDIF

ismethodclass.summary: Check whether a particular method can be sent to a class.
ismethodclass.param: The method name, specified without parentheses.
ismethodclass.returns: TRUE if the specified method is defined for the class of the specified object; otherwise, FALSE.
ismethodclass.example:
This example uses IsMethodClass() to check whether a class is capable of making sounds:
CLASS Animal EXPORT sound, weight METHOD Init(s, w) CLASS Animal sound := s weight := w METHOD Speaks CLASS Animal QOut(sound) CLASS Programmer EXPORT language METHOD Init(lang) CLASS Programmer language := lang METHOD Speaks CLASS Programmer QOut(language) QOut("Hello World") QOut(Chr(7)) Function Start() LOCAL dog AS Animal LOCAL hacker AS Programmer dog := Animal{"Bark Bark!", 50} hacker := Programmer{"VO"} IF IsMethodClass(#Animal, #Speaks) dog:Speaks() // Says Bark Bark ENDIF IF IsMethodClass(#Programmer, #Speaks) hacker:Speaks() // Says VO // Says Hello World // Rings a bell ENDIF

ismethodusual.summary: Check whether a particular method can be sent to an object inside a USUAL.
ismethodusual.param: The method name, specified without parentheses.
ismethodusual.returns: TRUE if the specified method is defined for the class of the specified object; otherwise, FALSE.
ismethodusual.remarks: IsMethodUsual() is used to determine whether the polymorphic value <uObject> is an object that has a method <symMethod>. IsMethodUsual() is the same as the following: UsualType(<uObject>) = OBJECT .AND. IsMethod(<uObject>, <symMethod>). Thus it should be used instead of IsMethod() in situations where it is not known whether a variable is an object.
ismethodusual.example:
This example uses IsMethodUsual() to check whether a particular method can be sent. If there is an object and a particular method for it exists, it issues the method; otherwise, it calls a function:
IF IsMethodUsual(uO, #GoTop) uO:GoTop() ELSE MyGoTop() ENDIF

isnil.summary: Determine if a value is NIL.
isnil.returns: TRUE if the value is NIL; otherwise, FALSE.
isnil.example:
This example uses IsNil() to determine whether to query users for a file name:
FUNCTION GetFile(cFile) IF IsNil(cFile) ? "Input missing file name" ENDIF

isnumeric.summary: Determine if a value is a numeric.
isnumeric.returns: TRUE if the value is a numeric; otherwise, FALSE.
isnumeric.remarks: IsNumeric() is equivalent to UsualType(<uValue> = LONG .OR. UsualType(<uValue> = FLOAT.
isnumeric.example:
This example uses IsNumeric() to determine the formatting to be used:
IF IsNumeric(uValue) ? Str3(uValue, 7, 2) ELSE ? uValue ENDIF

isobject.summary: Determine if a value is an object.
isobject.returns: TRUE if the value is an object; otherwise, FALSE.
isobject.example:
This example uses IsObject() to check whether a correct argument was passed:
FUNCTION OOpsCheck(uObject) AS LOGIC LOCAL lSuccess AS LOGIC LOCAL aObject AS ARRAY lSuccess := IsObject(uObject) IF lSuccess // Display object contents aObject := Object2Array(uObject) FOR i := UPTO ALen(aObject) QOut(aObject[i]) NEXT ELSE ? "Object is required" ENDIF RETURN lSuccess

isoldspace.summary: Check to see if a dynamic object is static.
isoldspace.param: The object (string, float, class object, or array) you want to check.
isoldspace.returns: TRUE if <uValue> is static; otherwise, FALSE.
isoldspace.remarks: IsOldSpace() determines whether a value is static, either because it is a literal string or because it was copied with one of the DynToOldSpace() functions.
isoldspace.example:
This example uses IsOldSpace() both on a literal static and on a static created through DynToOldSpace():
Function Start() LOCAL cLiteral LOCAL cDynTool cLiteral := "Hello" cDynTool := Time() ? IsOldSpace(cLiteral) // TRUE (static) ? IsOldSpace(cDynTool) // FALSE (not static) cDynTool := DynToOldSpace(cDynTool) // Make it static ? IsOldSpace(cDynTool) // TRUE (static now)

isoldspacearray.summary: Check to see if a typed dynamic object is static.
isoldspacearray.param: The array you want to check.
isoldspacearray.returns: TRUE if <aValue> is static; otherwise, FALSE.
isoldspacearray.remarks: IsOldSpaceArray() is the same as IsOldSpace() except that it is strongly typed. For more information, see IsOldSpace().
isoldspacearray.example:
This example uses IsOldSpaceArray():
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL aDyn AS ARRAY LOCAL aOldSpace AS ARRAY
aDyn := {1,2,3} aOldSpace := DynToOldSpaceArray(aDyn) ? IsOldSpaceArray(aDyn) // FALSE ? IsOldSpaceArray(aOldSpace) // TRUE

isoldspacefloat.summary: Check to see if a typed dynamic object is static.
isoldspacefloat.param: The floating point number you want to check.
isoldspacefloat.returns: TRUE if <fValue> is static; otherwise, FALSE.
isoldspacefloat.remarks: IsOldSpaceFloat() is the same as IsOldSpace() except that it is strongly typed. For more information, see IsOldSpace().
isoldspacefloat.example:
This example uses IsOldSpaceFloat():
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL fDyn AS FLOAT LOCAL fOldSpace AS FLOAT
fDyn := 2.71828 fOldSpace := DynToOldSpaceFloat(fDyn) ? IsOldSpaceFloat(aDyn) // FALSE ? IsOldSpaceFloat(fOldSpace) // TRUE

isoldspaceobject.summary: Check to see if a typed dynamic object is static.
isoldspaceobject.param: The class object you want to check.
isoldspaceobject.returns: TRUE if <oValue> is static; otherwise, FALSE.
isoldspaceobject.remarks: IsOldSpaceObject() is the same as IsOldSpace() except that it is strongly typed. For more information, see IsOldSpace().
isoldspaceobject.example:
This example uses IsOldSpaceObject():
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL oDyn AS MyClass LOCAL oOldSpace AS MyClass
oDyn := MyClass{} oOldSpace := DynToOldSpaceObject(oDyn) ? IsOldSpaceObject(oDyn) // FALSE ? IsOldSpaceObject(oOldSpace) // TRUE

isoldspacestring.summary: Check to see if a typed dynamic object is static.
isoldspacestring.param: The string you want to check.
isoldspacestring.returns: TRUE if <cValue> is static; otherwise, FALSE.
isoldspacestring.remarks: IsOldSpaceString() is the same as IsOldSpace() except that it is strongly typed. For more information, see IsOldSpace().
isoldspacestring.example:
This example uses IsOldSpaceString():
Function Start() LOCAL cLiteral AS STRING LOCAL cDynTool AS STRING cLiteral := "Hello" cDynTool := Time() ? IsOldSpaceString(cLiteral) // TRUE (static) ? IsOldSpaceString(cDynTool) // FALSE (not static) cDynTool := DynToOldSpaceString(cDynTool) // Make it static ? IsOldSpaceString(cDynTool) // TRUE

isptr.summary: Determine if a value is a pointer.
isptr.returns: TRUE if the value is a pointer; otherwise, FALSE.
isptr.example:
This example uses IsPtr() to check whether a conversion to a pointer is needed:
IF !IsPtr(uValue) uValue := Ptr(_CAST, uValue) ENDIF

isspace.summary: Determine if the leftmost character in a string is a blank (that is, Chr(9) through Chr(13) or Chr(32)).
isspace.returns: TRUE if the first character is blank; otherwise, FALSE.
isspace.example:
These examples illustrate IsSpace() applied to various values:
LOCAL cString2Examine AS STRING cString2Examine := Chr(9) + "Hello" ? IsSpace(Substr(cString2Examine, 1, 1)) // TRUE ? IsSpace(Substr(cString2Examine, 2, 1)) // TRUE ? IsSpace(Substr(cString2Examine, 3, 1)) // FALSE

isstring.summary: Determine if a value is a string.
isstring.returns: TRUE if the value is a string; otherwise, FALSE.
isstring.example:
This example uses IsString() to determine whether to query users for a file name:
FUNCTION TBDemo(cFile) IF !IsString(cFile) cFile := Space(12) ? "Input correct file name" ENDIF

issymbol.summary: Determine if a value is a symbol.
issymbol.returns: TRUE if the value is a symbol; otherwise, FALSE.
issymbol.example:
This example uses IsSymbol() to check whether a variable contains a symbol:
IF IsSymbol(uValue) .AND.; uValue != NULL_SYMBOL ? "Symbol is" + Symbol2String(uValue) ENDIF

isthemeenabled.summary:
NOTE: For Windows XP or later only.
Determine if visual theme support is enabled.
isthemeenabled.returns: TRUE if visual theme support is enabled; otherwise, FALSE.

isupper.summary: Determine if the leftmost character in a string is uppercase.
isupper.returns: TRUE if the first character is an uppercase letter; otherwise, FALSE.
isupper.remarks: IsUpper() is the inverse of IsLower(). Both IsUpper() and IsLower() relate to the Upper() and Lower() functions, which actually convert uppercase characters to lowercase, and vice versa. This function is nation-dependent.
isupper.example:
These examples illustrate IsUpper() applied to various values:
? IsUpper("AbCdE") // TRUE ? IsUpper("aBCdE") // FALSE ? IsUpper("$abcd") // FALSE ? IsUpper("8ABCD") // FALSE

isvoobject.summary: Determine if the given object is a valid VO Object.
isvoobject.returns: TRUE if the object is a valid VO object; otherwise, FALSE.
isvoobject.remarks: IsVoObject() can be used to test any object for the following - It does NOT check -

isvostring.summary: Determine if the given string is a valid VO string.
isvostring.returns: TRUE if the string is a valid VO string; otherwise, FALSE.
isvostring.remarks: IsVoString() can be used to test any string for the following -

isxdigit.summary: Determine if the leftmost character in a string is a hex character (that is, digits from 1 through 9 and letters from A through F).
isxdigit.returns: TRUE if the first character is hex; otherwise, FALSE.
isxdigit.example:
These examples illustrate IsXDigit() applied to various values:
? IsXDigit("3FDE") // TRUE ? IsXDigit("hjku") // FALSE

ivarget.summary: Return the contents of an exported instance variable.
ivarget.param: The object containing the exported instance variable.
The exported instance variable to get.
ivarget.remarks: IVarGet() returns the contents of an exported instance variable. The symbol of this instance variable can be stored inside <symInstanceVar> at runtime. Therefore, the instance variable does not have to be known at compile-time. The class operator (:) also returns the contents of an exported instance variable, but the instance variable must be known at compile-time.
ivarget.example:
This example uses IVarGet() to retrieve the contents of an exported instance variable. Note that the contents of cTrick cannot be retrieved via IVarGet() since it is an INSTANCE variable.
CLASS GetVars EXPORT cName INSTANCE cTrick METHOD Init CLASS GetVars cName := "Eve" cTrick := "Apple" FUNCTION Start() LOCAL oVars AS OBJECT oVars := GetVars{} ? IVarGet(oVars, #cName) // Eve

ivargetinfo.summary: Get information about how a particular instance variable (or access method) was declared.
ivargetinfo.param: The object containing the instance variable.
The instance variable that you want information about.
ivargetinfo.returns: A numeric value that can be interpreted as follows: wIvarInfo Description 0 Not found 1 INSTANCE declaration 2 EXPORT declaration 3 ACCESS declaration Note: PROTECT and HIDDEN variables cannot be tested with this function.
ivargetinfo.remarks: IVarGetInfo() tests for an instance variable or access method of a given name and returns a numeric value indicating how (or if) the variable was declared.
ivargetinfo.example:
This example illustrates the various return values for IVarGetInfo():
CLASS A INSTANCE x EXPORT y ACCESS z CLASS A FUNCTION Start() LOCAL o AS A o := a{} ? IVarGetInfo(o,#x) // 1 ? IVarGetInfo(o,#y) // 2 ? IVarGetInfo(o,#z) // 3 ? IVarGetInfo(o,#none) // 0

ivargetself.summary: Return the contents of an instance variable.
ivargetself.param: The object containing the instance variable.
ivargetself.remarks: IVarGetSelf() returns the contents of a specific EXPORT or INSTANCE variable. The scope throughout the function call is SELF.
ivargetself.example:
This example uses IVarGetSelf() to retrieve the contents of both EXPORT and INSTANCE variables:
CLASS GetVars EXPORT cName INSTANCE cPhone PROTECT cID HIDDEN cPassWord METHOD Init CLASS GetVars cName := "Adam" cPhone := "4460" FUNCTION Start() LOCAL oVars AS OBJECT oVars := GetVars{} ? IVarGetSelf(oVars, #cName) // Adam ? IVarGetSelf(oVars, #cPhone) // 4460

ivarlist.summary: Store all instance variables of an object into an array.
ivarlist.param: The object containing the instance variable to store.
ivarlist.returns: An array of symbols containing the name of all instance variables and access methods of <oObject>.
ivarlist.remarks: This conversion can offer you additional flexibility in manipulating data and can allow you to utilize powerful array functions, such as AEval() and AScan(). The scope throughout the function call is SELF.
ivarlist.example:
This example uses IVarList() to store INSTANCE and EXPORT instance variables into an array. It then prints the stored instance variables. (Note that the password is not stored in the array because it is a protected instance variable.)
CLASS Person EXPORT name INSTANCE grade PROTECT password METHOD Init(tname, tgrade, tpassword) CLASS Person name := tname grade := tgrade password := tpassword FUNCTION MakeArray() AS VOID LOCAL x AS OBJECT LOCAL a AS ARRAY x := Person{"Randal", "A", "123"} a := IVarList(x) // Print them FOR i := UPTO ALen(a) QOut(a[i]) NEXT // NAME // GRADE

ivarlistclass.summary: Store all instance variables of a class into an array.
ivarlistclass.param: The class containing the instance variable to store.
ivarlistclass.returns: An array of symbols containing the name of all instance variables and access methods of <symClass>.
ivarlistclass.remarks: This conversion can offer you additional flexibility in manipulating data and can allow you to utilize powerful array functions, such as AEval() and AScan(). The scope throughout the function call is SELF. Note that this function does not store PROTECT or HIDDEN instance variables.
ivarlistclass.example:
This example uses IVarListClass() to store INSTANCE and EXPORT instance variables into an array. It then prints the stored instance variables. (Note that the password is not stored in the array because it is a protected instance variable.)
CLASS Person EXPORT name INSTANCE grade PROTECT password METHOD Init(tname, tgrade, tpassword) CLASS Person name := tname grade := tgrade password := tpassword FUNCTION MakeArray() AS VOID LOCAL a AS ARRAY a := IVarListClass(#Person) // Print them FOR i := UPTO ALen(aObject) QOut(a[i]) NEXT // NAME // GRADE

ivarput.summary: Assign a value to an exported instance variable.
ivarput.param: The object containing the exported instance variable.
The exported instance variable to assign a value to.
The value to assign to the exported instance variable.
ivarput.remarks: Instead of modifying an instance variable through the := or = operators, IVarPut() provides a way to practice encapsulated object-oriented programming by safeguarding against accidental modification to an instance variable.
ivarput.example:
This example uses IVarPut() to assign a value to an exported instance variable.
CLASS GetVars EXPORT cName INSTANCE cPhone FUNCTION Start() LOCAL oVars AS OBJECT oVars := GetVars{} ? IVarPut(oVars, #cName, "VO") // VO

ivarputinfo.summary: Get information about how a particular instance variable (or assign method) was declared.
ivarputinfo.param: The object containing the instance variable.
The instance variable that you want information about.
ivarputinfo.returns: A numeric value that can be interpreted as follows: wIvarInfo Description 0 Not found 1 INSTANCE declaration 2 EXPORT declaration 3 ASSIGN declaration Note: PROTECT and HIDDEN variables cannot be tested with this function.
ivarputinfo.remarks: IVarPutInfo() tests for an instance variable or assign method of a given name and returns a numeric value indicating how (or if) the variable was declared.
ivarputinfo.example:
This example illustrates the various return values for IVarPutInfo():
CLASS A INSTANCE x EXPORT y ASSIGN z(value) CLASS A z := value RETURN value
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL o AS A o := a{} ? IVarPutInfo(o,#x) // 1 ? IVarPutInfo(o,#y) // 2 ? IVarPutInfo(o,#z) // 3 ? IVarPutInfo(o,#none) // 0

ivarputself.summary: Assign a value to an instance variable.
ivarputself.param: The object containing the instance variable.
The instance variable to assign a value to.
The value to assign to the instance variable.
ivarputself.remarks: IVarPutSelf() assigns a value to a specific EXPORT or INSTANCE variable.
ivarputself.example:
This example uses IVarPut() to assign a value to both EXPORT and INSTANCE variables.
CLASS GetVars EXPORT cName INSTANCE cPhone PROTECT cID HIDDEN cPassWord FUNCTION Start() LOCAL oVars AS OBJECT oVars := GetVars{} ? IVarPutSelf(oVars, #cName, "Adam") // Adam ? IVarPutSelf(oVars, #cPhone, "4460") // 4460

l2bin.summary: Convert a long integer to a string containing a 32-bit signed integer.
l2bin.param: The value to convert. Decimal digits are truncated.
l2bin.remarks: L2Bin() is a conversion function that converts a long integer into a 4-byte string. Typical applications include reading foreign file types in their native format and then saving, reading, decrypting, and transmitting numeric data in their compressed binary form instead of in strings. Its inverse is Bin2L().
l2bin.example:
This example creates a new binary file, then writes a series of numbers to the files using L2Bin() to convert the numeric value to 32-bit binary form:
LOCAL nNumber, ptrHandle ptrHandle := FCreate("MyFile", FC_NORMAL) FOR nNumber := 1 UPTO 100 FWrite3(ptrHandle, L2BIN(nNumber), 4) NEXT FClose(ptrHandle)

labeljump.summary: Branch out of a BEGIN SEQUENCE...END construct.
labeljump.param: The value passed to the RECOVER clause. Note that <uValue> is not optional; however, NIL can be specified if there is no break value.
labeljump.returns: The same value as its argument. Traditionally, this is an object of the Error class. The return value is passed to the RECOVER USING clause.
labeljump.remarks: LabelJump() is identical in functionality to both _Break() and the BREAK statement. LabelJump(), LabelPop(), and LabelPush() provide functional forms of the BEGIN SEQUENCE...END construct.
labeljump.example:
This example shows a simple error handling code which goes to the line after the RECOVER:
FUNCTION GoToLine() AS VOID LOCAL e AS USUAL // Value passed to RECOVER BEGIN SEQUENCE ? "You see this" LabelJump("Hello") ? "But not this. This line never executes!" RECOVER USING e ? "I was forced to jump to here" ? e // Hello END SEQUENCE
This example installs an error handler through ErrorBlock(). The installed error handler calls up LabelJump(), which in turn goes to the RECOVER line. The error is invoked when an attempt is made to open a non-existing file. The error object (ErrorInfo) is passed to RECOVER and is printed out:
FUNCTION LabelTest() AS VOID LOCAL cbSblock AS USUAL LOCAL ErrorInfo AS USUAL cbSblock := ErrorBlock({|x| LabelJump(x)}) BEGIN SEQUENCE // File does not exist so an error is invoked USE noexist ?? "Never execute this if an error " + ; ? "occurred on the previous line" RECOVER USING ErrorInfo // ErrorInfo contains the error object ? "An error has occurred" ?? "Operating system error code is:" ? ErrorInfo:OSCode END // Restore the old error handler ErrorBlock(cbSblock)

labelpop.remarks: LabelPop() is the functional form of END SEQUENCE and must be issued after a LabelPush() or a BEGIN SEQUENCE has been issued. The number of calls to LabelPop() should equal the number of calls to LabelPush(). LabelJump(), LabelPop(), and LabelPush() provide functional forms of the BEGIN SEQUENCE...END construct.

labelpush.param: A pointer to a jump target label. Note that X# does not provide you with labels inside a function. A label can only be obtained from a low-level programming language, such as C or Assembler.
labelpush.remarks: LabelPush() is the functional form of BEGIN SEQUENCE. It is used internally by the X# compiler to implement BEGIN SEQUENCE. LabelPush() is only useful if you can obtain a label in your code. LabelJump(), LabelPop(), and LabelPush() provide functional forms of the BEGIN SEQUENCE...END construct.

lastrec.summary: Return the number of the last record in a database file.
lastrec.returns: The number of physical records in a database file. Filtering or deleted settings have no effect on the return value. LastRec() returns 0 if there is no database file in use.
lastrec.example:
This example illustrates the relationship between LastRec(), RecCount(), and COUNT:
USE sales NEW QOut(LastRec(), RecCount()) // Result: 84 84 SET FILTER TO Salesman = "1001" COUNT TO nRecords QOut(nRecords, LastRec()) // Result: 14 84
This example uses an aliased expression to access the number of records in a open database file in an unselected work area:
USE sales NEW USE customer NEW QOut(LastRec(), Sales->LastRec())

left.summary: Extract a substring beginning with the first character in a string.
left.param: The string from which to extract characters.
The number of characters to extract.
left.returns: The leftmost <dwCount> characters of <cString>. If <dwCount> is negative or 0, Left() returns a NULL_STRING. If <dwCount> is larger than the length of the string, Left() returns the entire string.
left.remarks: Left() is the same as Substr(<cString>, 1, <wCount>). Left(), Right(), and Substr() are often used with both the At() and RAt() functions to locate the first and/or the last position of a substring before extracting it.
left.example:
This example extracts the first three characters from the left of the target string: ? LEFT("ABCDEF", 3) // ABC This example extracts a substring from the beginning of a string up to the first occurrence of a comma:
LOCAL cName := "James, William" AS STRING ? LEFT(cName, AT(",", cName)) // James

len.summary: Return the length of a string or an array.
len.param: The string or array to measure. In a string, each byte counts as 1, including an embedded null character (Chr(0)). A NULL_STRING counts as 0. In an array, each element counts as 1.

remarks.note: ALen(), PszLen() and SLen() are the strongly typed versions of Len().

len.example:
These examples demonstrate Len() with various arguments:
? LEN("string of characters") // 20 ? LEN(NULL_STRING) // 0 ? LEN(CHR(0)) // 1 LOCAL aTest[10] ? LEN(aTest) // 10 ? LEN(ArrayNew(5)) // 5

lennum.summary: Return the number of characters in a number, including digits, decimal point, and sign.
lennum.param: The number you want the length of.
lennum.remarks: LenNum() returns the number of bytes a number will occupy when converted to a string.
lennum.example:
This example uses LenNum() on various numbers:
? LenNum(1234) // 4 ? LenNum(1234.56) // 7 ? LenNum(1234.5678) // 9 ? LenNum(-1234.5678) // 10

loadresstring.summary: Look up an identifier in a string table and returns its corresponding string.
loadresstring.param: The default string to return if <nStringID> cannot be found in the designated string table. Omitting this value is the same as specifying NULL_STRING.
The unique integer identifier that you want to look up. This value is defined when you declare the string table via RESOURCE...STRINGTABLE statement.

The module containing the string table in which to perform the lookup. This argument can be specified either as a string, in which case it will be the name of a .DLL or .EXE file, or a WORD that identifies the module via its handle. If not specified, LoadResString() assumes the string table resides in the module that is currently executing.
Important! The module that you specify here is not automatically loaded by the LoadResString() function. Therefore, prior to calling LoadResString(), you must either directly reference the module (for example, by calling one of its functions), or load the module manually using the Windows API function LoadLibrary().
loadresstring.remarks: The LoadResString() function allows you to easily read information from a string table in your X# application. String tables are defined via the RESOURCE statement using the STRINGTABLE keyword and are compiled, like all resource entities, by the Windows resource compiler. In a X# application, you can declare as many string table resource entities as you like; however, when the application is built, all of these are combined into a single string table, allowing only one table in each executable file or DLL. This means that within an application and across its library search path, string identifiers in string table resource declarations must be unique. Note, however, that another module (such as a DLL) referenced by an application can also have a string table, which is why LoadResString() allows you to specify which module to reference. Identifiers need only be unique within a module (that is, an .EXE or .DLL file).
loadresstring.example:
This example illustrates a technique for looking up an object's HyperLabel:Caption property using a string table. Using this technique facilitates internationalization of an application by isolating the natural language portion of the application that needs to be translated into a string table:
oDCMyControl:HyperLabel := HyperLabel{#MyControl, ; LoadResString("&File", MyFileString, MyLanguage),,} DEFINE MyFileString := 100 GLOBAL MyLanguage AS STRING METHOD Start() CLASS App ... IF ... // it's French MyLanguage := "MYFRENCH.DLL" ELSEIF ... // it's German MyLanguage := "MYGERMAN.DLL" ENDIF
RETURN NULL_STRING The code for the MYFRENCH DLL string table would be as follows:
DEFINE MyFileString := 100 RESOURCE French STRINGTABLE BEGIN MyFileString, "&Fichier" ... END
The code for the MYGERMAN DLL string table would be as follows:
DEFINE MyFileString := 100 RESOURCE German STRINGTABLE BEGIN MyFileString, "&Datei" ... END

lobyte.summary: Return the low-order (rightmost) byte in a number.
lobyte.param: The number whose low-order byte you want to get.
lobyte.remarks: Related data can be stored in the high-order and low-order words of a variable. Therefore, instead of creating and returning a 2-element array, it may be more efficient to return a word whose 2 bytes contain separate information.
lobyte.example:
The Windows API function GetVersion() returns the DOS version in the high-order WORD and the Windows version in the low-order WORD. Moreover, the DOS major number is in the high-order byte of its WORD, the DOS minor number is in the low-order bytes of its WORD, the Windows major number is in the low-order byte of its WORD, and the Windows minor number is in the high-order byte of its WORD:
LOCAL dwVersion AS DWORD LOCAL wDOS, wWindows AS DWORD LOCAL bDOSMinor, bDOSMajor AS BYTE LOCAL bWindowsMajor, bWindowsMinor AS BYTE dwVersions := GetVersion() wDOS := HiWord(dwVersions) bDOSMajor := HiByte(wDOS) bDOSMinor := LoByte(wDOS) wWindows := LoWord(dwVersions) bWindowsMinor := HiByte(wWindows) bWindowsMajor := LoByte(wWindows) ? "The DOS major and minor numbers are",; bDOSMajor, bDOSMinor // The DOS major and minor numbers are 5 0 ? "The Windows major and minor numbers are",; bWindowsMajor, bWindowsMinor // The Windows major and minor numbers are 3 10

log.summary: Calculate the natural logarithm of a numeric value.
log.param: A number greater than 0 to convert to its natural logarithm.
log.returns: The natural logarithm of <nValue>. If <nValue> is less than or equal to 0, Log() generates a numeric overflow.
log.remarks: The Log() function returns x in the following equation: e^x = y where e is the base of the natural logarithm (approximately 2.7183) and y is the numeric expression used as the Log() argument (that is, Log(y) = x). Due to mathematical rounding, the values returned by Log() and Exp() may not agree exactly (that is, Exp(Log(n)) may not always equal n). Log() is the inverse of Exp().
log.example:
These examples demonstrate various results of Log():
? Log(10) // 2.30 ? Log(10 * 2) // 3.00 ? Exp(Log(1)) // 1.00 ? Log(2.71) // 1.00
This example is a function that returns the base 10 logarithm:
FUNCTION MyLog10(nNumber) IF nNumber > 0 RETURN Log(nNumber)/Log(10) ELSE RETURN 0 ENDIF

log10.summary: Calculate the common logarithm of a numeric value.
log10.param: A number greater than 0 to convert to its common logarithm.
log10.returns: The common logarithm of <nValue>. If <nValue> is less than or equal to 0, Log10() generates a run-time error.
log10.remarks: Log10() is the inverse of the power (to the base 10) operator (** or ^). The common logarithm has a base of 10. The Log10() function returns x in the following equation: 10^x = y where y is the numeric expression used as the Log10() argument (that is, Log10(y) = x). Due to mathematical rounding, the values returned by Log10() and the power operator (** or ^) may not agree exactly (that is, 10^(Log10(n)) may not always equal n).

logic2bin.summary: Convert a logical value to a string containing an 8-bit logical value.
logic2bin.remarks: Logic2Bin() is a conversion function that converts a logical data type into a 1-byte string. Typical applications include saving data in their native format, data decryption, and transmitting logical data in their binary form. Its inverse is Bin2Logic().
logic2bin.example:
This example creates a new binary file, then writes a logical value in a binary form:
LOCAL ptrHandle AS PTR ptrHandle := FCreate("MyFile", FC_NORMAL) FWrite3(ptrHandle, Logic2Bin(TRUE), 1) FClose(ptrHandle)

longjmp.summary: Restore the stack environment and return control to the point immediately following the corresponding SetJmp() call.
longjmp.param: A structure in which the environment was stored by a prior call to SetJmp().
The value that appears to be returned by an earlier call to SetJmp(). It should not be a 0. If it is a 0, LongJmp() substitutes 1.
longjmp.remarks: LongJmp() restores the stack environment saved earlier by a call to SetJmp() and then jumps to the return address for SetJmp(). Execution resumes at the point immediately following SetJmp(), so it seems as though <siValue> was just returned from SetJmp(). SetJmp() and LongJmp() provide you with a mechanism to go to a particular line of code. They are typically used to simulate a "return to master" command or to branch out to error recovery code. SetJmp() must be called prior to LongJmp(). Then, LongJmp() must be called before the routine in which you called SetJmp() returns.
longjmp.example:
This example shows how LongJmp() and SetJmp() work together to save and restore the stack environment:
STATIC GLOBAL strucMark IS _JMP_BUF FUNCTION Start() LOCAL siJMPRetVal AS SHORTINT siJMPRetVal := SetJmp(@strucMark) IF siJMPRetVal <>0 ? "LongJmp() was here with", siJMPRetVal RETURN FALSE ENDIF IF .NOT. File("voerror.log") LongJmp(@strucMark, 1) ENDIF SubFunc() RETURN TRUE FUNCTION SubFunc() LOCAL cLog AS STRING cLog := MemoRead("voerror.log") IF SLen(cLog) = MAX_ALLOC LongJmp(@strucMark, 2) ENDIF RETURN 0

lower.summary: Convert the uppercase and mixed case characters in a string to lowercase.
lower.param: The string to convert to lowercase.
lower.returns: <cString> with all alphabetic characters converted to lowercase. All other characters remain the same as in the original string.
lower.remarks: Lower() is related to Upper(), which converts lowercase and mixed case strings to uppercase. Lower() is also related to IsLower() and IsUpper(), which determine whether a string begins with a lower or uppercase letter. Lower() is generally used to format strings for display purposes. It can, however, be used to normalize strings for case-independent comparison or indexing purposes. This function is nation-dependent.
lower.example:
These examples demonstrate various results of Lower():
? Lower("1234 CHARS = ") // 1234 chars = LOCAL cString AS STRING cString := "DATA" ? Lower(cString) // data ? cString // DATA

lowera.summary: Convert the uppercase and mixed case characters in a string to lowercase, changing the contents of the argument as well as the return value.
lowera.param: The string to convert to lowercase.
lowera.returns: <cString> with all alphabetic characters converted to lowercase. All other characters remain the same as in the original string.
lowera.remarks:
LowerA() is the same as Lower(), except that LowerA() converts both the characters in the original string and the characters in the return value to lowercase. See Lower() for more information.
You may change more than one variable at the same time (see example below).
lowera.example:
This example shows how LowerA() converts both the original string and the return value to lowercase. Compare the results to the results in the Lower() example:
LOCAL cString AS STRING cString := "DATA" ? LowerA(cString) // data ? cString // DATA
This example shows how you may change more than one variable at the same time:
a := "I Change" b := a LowerA(b) ? b // "i change" ? a // "i change"

loword.summary: Return the low-order (rightmost) word in a number.
loword.param: The number whose low-order word you want to get.
loword.remarks: Related data can be stored in the high-order and low-order words of a variable. Therefore, instead of creating and returning a 2-element array, it may be more efficient to return a double word whose 2 words contain separate information. Also, many Windows API functions receive data in a LONGINT argument. Usually the high-order and low-order words of this argument contain different information about a window and its messages. LoWord() can be used to extract the low-order word of this argument.
loword.example: This example uses LoWord() and HiWord() to determine the coordinates of a pixel. It assumes that liParam was passed to a Windows callback function: CRTSetPixel(LoWord(liParam), HiWord(liParam), 0L)

ltoc.summary: Convert a logical value to a string.
ltoc.remarks: LToC() is useful in forming combined indexes.
ltoc.example: This example uses LToC() to write the return value of a logical function to a text file: FWriteText(ptrHandle, LToC(Deleted()), 1) This example uses LToC() to form a combined string expression: ? LToC(_FIELD->lRegister) + _FIELD->cName

ltrim.summary: Remove leading spaces from a string.
ltrim.returns: <cString> with the leading spaces removed. If <cString> is a NULL_STRING or all spaces, LTrim() returns a NULL_STRING.
ltrim.remarks: LTrim() is used to format strings that have leading spaces, for example, numbers that have been converted to strings using Str(). LTrim() is related to RTrim(), which removes trailing spaces, and AllTrim(), which removes both leading and trailing spaces. The inverse of AllTrim(), LTrim(), and RTrim() are the PadC(), PadR(), and PadL() functions, which center, right-justify, and left-justify strings by padding them with fill characters.
ltrim.example:
These examples illustrate LTrim() used with several other functions:
nNumber = 18 ? Str(nNumber) // 18 ? SLen(Str(nNumber)) // 10 ? LTrim(Str(nNumber)) // 18 ? NTrim(nNumber) // 18 ? SLen(LTrim(Str(nNumber))) // 2

lupdate.summary: Return the date a database file was last modified and closed.
lupdate.returns: The date of last change. If there is no database file in use, LUpdate() returns a NULL_DATE.
lupdate.example:
This example demonstrates that the modification date of a database file is not changed until the database file is closed:
QOut(TODAY()) // Result: 09/01/90 USE sales NEW QOut(LUpdate()) // Result: 08/31/90 APPEND BLANK QOut(LUpdate()) // Result: 08/31/90 DBCloseAll() USE sales NEW QOut(LUpdate()) // Result: 09/01/90
This example uses an aliased expression to return the last modification date of a database file in an unselected work area:
USE sales NEW USE customer NEW QOut(LUpdate(), Sales->LUpdate())

makedword.summary: Create a DWORD from two words
makedword.param: The number you want to have in the Low word of the Dword
The number you want to have in the High word of the Dword

makelong.summary: Create a long from two words
makelong.param: The number you want to have in the Low word of the Long
The number you want to have in the High word of the Long

makeshort.summary: Create a Short from two bytes
makeshort.param: The number you want to have in the Low byte of the Short
The number you want to have in the High byte of the Short

makeword.summary: Create a Short from two bytes
makeword.param: The number you want to have in the Low byte of the Word
The number you want to have in the High byte of the Word

massign.summary: Perform an assignment to a variable whose name is stored in a specified string.
massign.param: The string containing the variable name you want to assign <uValue> to.
massign.remarks: MAssign() is the functional equivalent of using the macro operator (&) to perform an assignment.
massign.example:
The following example uses the MAssign() function to perform assignments:
MEMVAR iValue LOCAL cVar AS STRING cVar := "iValue" MAssign(cVar, 5) // Same a &cVar := 5 ? iValue // Result: 5

max.param: The second value to compare. This must be of the same type as <uValue1> except that numerics of different types are allowed.
max.returns: The larger of the 2 arguments. The value returned is the same type as the larger argument.
max.remarks: The inverse of Max() is Min(), which returns the smaller of 2 expressions.
max.example:
In these examples Max() returns the larger of 2 numbers:
? MAX(99, 100) // 100 ? MAX(100, 99) // 100
In these examples Max() compares date values:
? TODAY() // 05/27/93 ? MAX(TODAY(), TODAY() + 1) // 05/28/93

maxatom.summary: Determine the number of symbols in the atom table.
maxatom.returns: MaxAtom() returns the highest symbol value, which tells you the total number of atoms used in the entire system. Each time a symbol is added to the atom table, the number of available spaces is decreased by 1, and the value of MaxAtom() increases by 1. Note that the return value depends on the specific circumstances in your application. For example, if you are executing your application dynamically from within the IDE, the return value will be different from the value you get when you run the executable version of the application.
maxatom.remarks: MaxAtom() returns the same value as Memory(MaxAtom).
maxatom.example:
This example uses MaxAtom() to print the highest system value (note that actual results will vary):
? MaxAtom() // 5346 ? SysAddAtom("First") // First ? MaxAtom() // 5347 ? SysAddAtom("Second") // Second ? MaxAtom() // 5348 ? Memory(MaxAtom) // 5348

mballtrim.summary: Remove leading and trailing spaces — including double-byte spaces — from a string.
mballtrim.returns: A trimmed string, with leading and trailing spaces removed.
mballtrim.remarks: This function is identical in functionality to AllTrim() except that it handles strings containing double-byte characters.

mbat.summary: Return the position of the first occurrence of a substring within a string — both the substring and the string can contain double-byte characters.
mbat.param: The string in which to search. (To start at a specific offset, use MBAt3().)
mbat.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cMBSearch> within <cMBTarget>. If <cMBSearch> is not found, MBAt() returns zero.
mbat.remarks: This function is like At() except that it handles strings containing double-byte characters.

mbat2.summary: Return the position of the first occurrence of a substring within a string — both the substring and the string can contain double-byte characters.
mbat2.param: The substring for which to search.
The string in which to search. (To start at a specific offset, use MBAt3().)
mbat2.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cMBSearch> within <cMBTarget>. If <cMBSearch> is not found, MBAt2() returns zero.
mbat2.remarks: This function is like MBAt() except that it returns a WORD.

mbat3.summary: Return the position of the first occurrence of a substring within a string, starting at a specific position — both the substring and the string can contain double-byte characters.
mbat3.param: The string in which to search.
The position in the string at which to start searching. A value of zero corresponds to the first byte.
mbat3.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cMBSearch> within <cMBTarget>. If <cMBSearch> is not found, MBAt3() returns zero.
mbat3.remarks: This function is the same as MBAt(), except that you can specify an offset that tells where to start searching.

mbatc.summary: Return the position of the first occurrence of a sub string within a string, without regard for case — both the substring and the string can contain double-byte characters.
mbatc.param: The string in which to search.
mbatc.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cMBSearch> within <cMBTarget>. If <cMBSearch> is not found, MBAtC() returns zero.
mbatc.remarks: This function is like AtC() except that it handles strings containing double-byte characters.

mbatc2.summary: Return the position of the first occurrence of a substring within a string, without regard for case — both the substring and the string can contain double-byte characters.
mbatc2.param: The substring for which to search.
The string in which to search.
mbatc2.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cMBSearch> within <cMBTarget>. If <cMBSearch> is not found, MBAtC2() returns zero.
mbatc2.remarks: This function is like MBAtC() except that it returns a WORD.

mbatline.summary: Return the line number of the first occurrence of a substring within a multiple line string — both the substring and the string can contain double-byte characters.
mbatline.param: The string in which to search.
mbatline.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cMBSearch> within <cMBTarget>. If <cMBSearch> is not found, MBAtLine() returns zero.
mbatline.remarks: This function is like AtLine() except that it handles strings containing double-byte characters.

mbatline2.summary: Return the line number of the first occurrence of a substring within a multiple line string — both the substring and the string can contain double-byte characters.
mbatline2.param: The substring for which to search.
The string in which to search.
mbatline2.returns: The position of the first occurrence of <cMBSearch> within <cMBTarget>. If <cMBSearch> is not found, MBAtLine2() returns zero.
mbatline2.remarks: This function is like MBAtLine() except that it returns a WORD.

mbleft.summary: Return a substring beginning with the first character of a string containing double-byte characters.
mbleft.param: The string from which to extract characters.
The number of characters to extract.
mbleft.returns: The leftmost <wCount> characters of <cMBString> — each double-byte character counts as one character. If <wCount> is zero, MBLeft() returns a NULL_STRING. If <wCount> is larger than the length of the string, MBLeft() returns the entire string.
mbleft.remarks: This function is like Left() except that it handles strings containing double-byte characters.

mblen.summary: Return the length of a string containing double-byte characters or an array.
mblen.param: The string or array to measure. In a string, each single-byte character counts as one, including an embedded null character (Chr(0)). Double-byte characters also count as one. A NULL_STRING counts as zero. In an array, each element counts as one.
mblen.returns: The length of <uMBValue> in which each double-byte character counts as one character.
mblen.remarks: This function is like Len() except that it handles strings containing double-byte characters.

mbltrim.summary: Remove leading spaces — including double-byte spaces — from a string.
mbltrim.returns: <cMBString> with the leading spaces removed. If <cMBString> is a NULL_STRING or all spaces, MBLTrim() returns a NULL_STRING.
mbltrim.remarks: This function is like LTrim() except that it handles strings containing double-byte characters.

mbrat.summary: Return the position of the last occurrence of a substring within a string — both the substring and the string can contain double-byte characters.
mbrat.param: The substring for which to search.
The string in which to search. (To start at a specific offset, use MBRAt3().)
mbrat.returns: The position of <cMBSearch> within <cMBTarget>. If <cMBSearch> is not found, MBRAt() returns zero.
mbrat.remarks: This function is like RAt() except that it handles strings containing double-byte characters.

mbrat2.summary: Return the position of the last occurrence of a substring within a string — both the substring and the string can contain double-byte characters.
mbrat2.param: The substring for which to search.
The string in which to search. (To start at a specific offset, use MBRAt3().)
mbrat2.returns: The position of <cMBSearch> within <cMBTarget>. If <cMBSearch> is not found, MBRAt2() returns zero.
mbrat2.remarks: This function is like MBRAt() except that it returns a DWORD.

mbrat3.summary: Return the position of the last occurrence of a substring within a string, starting at a specific position — both the substring and the string can contain double-byte characters.
mbrat3.param: The substring for which to search.
The string in which to search.
The position in the string at which to start searching. A value of zero specifies the first byte.
mbrat3.returns: The position of <cMBSearch> within <cMBTarget>. If <cMBSearch> is not found, MBRAt3() returns zero.
mbrat3.remarks: This function is like MBRAt(), except that you can specify an offset that tells where to start searching.

mbright.summary: Return a substring beginning with the last character of a string containing double-byte characters.
mbright.param: The string from which to extract characters.
The number of characters to extract.
mbright.returns: The rightmost <wCount> characters of <cMBString> — each double-byte character counts as one character. If <wCount> is zero, MBRight() returns a NULL_STRING. If <wCount> is larger than the length of the string, MBRight() returns <cMBString>.
mbright.remarks: This function is like Right() except that it handles strings containing double-byte characters.

mbrtrim.summary: Remove trailing spaces — including double-byte spaces — from a string.
mbrtrim.returns: <cMBString> with the trailing spaces removed. If <cMBString> is a NULL_STRING or all spaces, MBRTrim() returns a NULL_STRING.
mbrtrim.remarks: This function is like RTrim() except that it handles strings containing double-byte characters.

mbslen.summary: Return the length of a strongly typed string containing double-byte characters.
mbslen.returns: The length of <cMBString> in which each double-byte character counts as one character. If the string is a NULL_STRING, MBSLen() returns zero.
mbslen.remarks: This function is like SLen() except that it handles strings containing double-byte characters.

mbstuff.summary: Insert a string into another string, optionally deleting a specified number of characters from the original string — both strings can contain double-byte characters.
mbstuff.param: The string into which characters are inserted and deleted.
The position in <cMBTarget> where the insertion/deletion occurs.
The number of characters to delete — each double-byte character counts as one character.
mbstuff.returns: <cMBTarget> with the specified characters deleted and <cMBInsert> inserted.
mbstuff.remarks: This function is like Stuff() except that it handles strings containing double-byte characters.

mbsubstr.summary: Extract a substring from a string — both the substring and the string can contain double-byte characters.
mbsubstr.param: The string from which to extract a substring.

The starting position in <cMBTarget>. If <nStart> is positive, it is relative to the leftmost character in <cMBTarget>. If <nStart> is negative, it is relative to the rightmost character in <cMBTarget>.

The number of characters to extract — double-byte characters count as one character. If omitted, the substring begins at <nStart> and continues to the end of the string. If <nCount> is greater than the number of characters from <nStart> to the end of <cMBTarget>, the extra is ignored.
mbsubstr.returns: The substring. If the substring is not present, or if you specify <nStart> as zero, MBSubstr() returns a NULL_STRING.
mbsubstr.remarks: This function is like Substr() except that it handles strings containing double-byte characters.

mbsubstr2.summary: Extract a substring from a string, using strong typing and only two arguments — both the substring and the string can contain double-byte characters.
mbsubstr2.param: The string from which to extract a substring.
The starting position relative to the leftmost character in <cMBTarget>.
mbsubstr2.returns: The substring. If the substring is not present, or if you specify <wStart> as zero, MBSubstr2() returns a NULL_STRING.
mbsubstr2.remarks: MBSubstr2() is a typed version of MBSubstr(). The third argument of MBSubstr() which counts the number of characters is not allowed. Instead, this function starts at the specified location and extracts to the end of the string. Also, because <wStart> cannot be negative, MBSubstr2() cannot extract a substring relative to the rightmost character of <cMBTarget> as can MBSubstr().

mbsubstr3.summary: Extract a substring from a string, using strong typing and three required arguments — both the substring and the string can contain double-byte characters.
mbsubstr3.param: The string from which to extract a substring.
The starting position relative to the leftmost character in <cMBTarget>.

The number of characters to extract — double-byte characters count as one character. If <wCount> is greater than the number of characters from <wStart> to the end of <cMBTarget>, the extra is ignored.
mbsubstr3.returns: The substring. If the substring is not present, or if you specify <wStart> as zero, MBSubstr3() returns a NULL_STRING.
mbsubstr3.remarks: MBSubstr3() is a typed version of MBSubstr() in which all three arguments are required. Because <wStart> cannot be negative, MBSubstr3() cannot extract a substring relative to the rightmost character of <cMBTarget> as can MBSubstr().

mbtrim.summary: Remove trailing spaces — including double-byte spaces — from a string.
mbtrim.returns: <cMBString> with the trailing spaces removed. If <cMBString> is a NULL_STRING or all spaces, MBTrim() returns a NULL_STRING.
mbtrim.remarks: This function is like Trim() except that it handles strings containing double-byte characters.

mcompile.returns: The string in a macro-compiled form.
mcompile.remarks: MCompile() allows you to use the macro compiler to compile a string and store the compiled results for later execution. Instead of invoking the macro compiler each time an expression is evaluated, you could speed up your application by compiling an expression only once and executing the compiled form as often as desired.
mcompile.example:
This examples show typical uses of MCompile():
LOCAL cComp AS STRING cComp := MCompile("2+3") ? MExec(cComp) // 5 nResult := MExec(cComp) // Assigning ? MExec(cComp) = 5 // Comparing Two := 2 // Private variable cComp := MCompile("Two+3") ? MExec(cComp) // 5

mcshort.summary: Return and optionally change the setting that determines whether logical shortcutting is used in macro expression evaluation.
mcshort.param: TRUE turns logical shortcutting on. FALSE turns it off. The initial default is TRUE.
mcshort.returns: If <lNewSetting> is not specified, MCShort() returns the current setting. If <lNewSetting> is specified, the previous setting is returned.
mcshort.remarks: When MCShort() is set to its initial default of TRUE, X# uses a shortcut to speed up the evaluation of the logical .AND. and .OR. operators in macro expressions. For .AND., the second operand is not evaluated if the first operand evaluates to FALSE. For .OR., the second operand is not evaluated if the first operand evaluates to TRUE. Note: X# always uses this shortcut for non-macro expressions — there is no function to control this behavior.
mcshort.example:
The following examples demonstrates the difference in macro expression evaluation with MCShort() set to TRUE and FALSE:
FUNCTION MacroTest() Yes := FALSE x := "Yes .AND. No" ? &x // FALSE, variable No is never evaluated MCShort(FALSE) ? &x // Runtime error because variable No // is not defined

mem2string.summary: Extract a substring of a certain size from the left of a buffer.
mem2string.param: Pointer to the buffer from which to extract the substring.
The number of bytes, from the left, to extract from <ptrSource>.
mem2string.returns: A substring of the specified number of bytes.

remarks.note: Contrary to normal PSZs, strings are not static and may be collected by the garbage collector. Therefore, if you supply a string as an argument to a function, like Mem2String, which directly or indirectly allocates dynamic memory, you may run into trouble. For example, in Mem2String(Time(), 5), Time() may cause problems. But Mem2String("hi there", 5) will not cause problems since literal strings are not collected.

mem2string.example:
This example uses Mem2String() to get the three leftmost characters of a PSZ:
LOCAL pszSource AS PSZ pszSource := "ABCDEF" ? Mem2String(pszSource, 3) // ABC

memalloc.summary: Allocate a static memory buffer of a specified size.
memalloc.param: The number of bytes to allocate.
memalloc.returns: A pointer to the allocated space if there is sufficient memory available; otherwise, it returns a NULL_PTR. You should always check the return value for a successful allocation.
memalloc.remarks:
MemAlloc() allocates a memory buffer of at least <wBytes>. The allocated memory is defined to be static so it is not moved by the garbage collector. Since memory is allocated in increments of 32 bytes, some extra space may be allocated. For example, a request for even 1 byte will allocate 32 bytes. Space allocated by MemAlloc() is freed by MemFree().
This function allows the direct manipulation of a memory location and should be used with extreme care.
memalloc.example:
This example uses MemAlloc() to see whether a specified block is available:
FUNCTION IsAvailable(wRequest AS DWORD) AS LOGIC LOCAL ptrBuff AS PTR LOCAL lAvailable AS LOGIC ptrBuff := MemAlloc(wRequest) IF ptrBuff = NULL_PTR ? "Memory allocation has failed" lAvailable := FALSE ELSE lAvailable := TRUE MemFree(ptrBuff) ENDIF RETURN lAvailable

mematspecial.summary: Get the location of the first special console character in a buffer.
mematspecial.param: The number of bytes in <ptrBuffer> to check.
mematspecial.returns: The location of the first special console character within the specified portion of <ptrBuffer>. If a special console character does not exist, MemAtSpecial() returns 0.
mematspecial.remarks: Special console characters are characters with ASCII values less than or equal to 13, which can require special handling when displayed on the screen. Moreover, a terminal driver can assign special meaning to them, such as ringing the bell when a Chr(7) is specified.
mematspecial.example:
This example uses MemAtSpecial() iteratively to detect all special console characters in a string:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL s := "AB" + _Chr(10) + "CD" + _Chr(7) + ; "EF" + _Chr(13) + "GH" AS STRING LOCAL wAt AS DWORD DO WHILE SLen(s) > 0 wAt := MemAtSpecial(Ptr(_CAST, s), SLen(s)) IF wAt > 0 ? "Special char with ASCII code of:",; Asc(Substr3(s, wAt, 1)), "was detected" // Query the rest of the string // (from wAt+1 and on) s := Substr(s, wAt+1) ELSE s := "" ENDIF ENDDO

membyte.summary: Get a pointer to a byte in a memory buffer.
membyte.param: A pointer to the memory buffer to examine.
The number of bytes in <ptrBuffer> to examine.
membyte.returns: A pointer to the first occurrence of <bChar> within the first <dwCount> bytes of <ptrBuffer>. If <bChar> is not matched, MemChr() returns a NULL_PTR.
membyte.example:
This example uses MemByte() on a PSZ:
FUNCTION FindChar() LOCAL pszC1 := "ABCDEF" AS PSZ ? MemByte(pszC1, ASC("A"), 6) // 3F37:2788 ? MemByte(pszC1, ASC("B"), 6) // 3F37:2789 ? MemByte(pszC1, ASC("B"), 1) // 0000:0000 // NULL_PTR: ASC("B") is not in the // first "1" characters of the PSZ
This example uses MemByte() on an allocated block:
FUNCTION FindChar2() LOCAL ptrBuff := MemAlloc(10) AS PTR IF ptrBuff != NULL_PTR // Write 68 to first 10 MemSet(ptrBuff, 68, 10) // Overwrite first 5 with 67 MemSet(ptrBuff, 67, 5) ? MemByte(ptrBuff, 68, 10) // 3CA7:07DD ? MemByte(ptrBuff, 67, 10) // 3CA7:07D8 ENDIF MemFree(ptrBuff)

memcalloc.summary: Allocate static memory buffers of a specified size.
memcalloc.param: The number of items to allocate memory for.
The number of bytes to allocate for each item.
memcalloc.returns: A pointer to the allocated space if there is sufficient memory available; otherwise, a NULL_PTR. You should always check the return value from MemCAlloc() for a successful allocation.
memcalloc.remarks:
MemCAlloc() is useful in allocating space for several items at one time. The allocated memory is defined to be static so that it is not moved by the garbage collector. Space allocated by MemCAlloc() is freed by MemFree().
This function allows the direct manipulation of a memory location and should be used with extreme care.
memcalloc.example:
This example uses MemCAlloc() to allocate space for ten long integers:
LOCAL ptrLongs AS PTR ptrLongs := MemCAlloc(10, 4)
Instead of hard-coding 4 for the size of a long integer, we could have issued: ptrLongs := MemCAlloc(10, _SizeOf(LONG)) This next example uses MemCAlloc() to allocate space for five instances of a defined structure:
STRUCTURE StatInfo MEMBER wAverageHit AS DWORD MEMBER wMaxHit AS DWORD MEMBER wMinHit AS DWORD FUNCTION MemCAlloc2() AS VOID LOCAL ptrStruct AS PTR ptrStruct := MemCAlloc(5, _SizeOf(StatInfo)) IF ptrStruct = NULL_PTR ? "Allocation failed" ELSE MemFree(ptrStruct) ENDIF

memcheckptr.summary: Check the validity of a pointer to a memory buffer.
memcheckptr.param: The number of bytes to check.
memcheckptr.returns: TRUE if it is a valid dynamically allocated memory pointer; otherwise, FALSE.
memcheckptr.remarks: MemCheckPtr() can safeguard you against invalid wild pointers or null pointers whose use can bring adverse results.
memcheckptr.example:
This example uses MemCheckPtr():
ptrV := MemAlloc(100) ? MemCheckPtr(ptrV, 100) // TRUE

memchr.summary: Get a pointer to a matching character value in a memory buffer.
memchr.param: A pointer to the memory buffer to examine.
Word representation of the character to match.
The number of characters in <ptrBuffer> to examine.
memchr.returns: A pointer to the first occurrence of <dwChar> within the first <dwCount> characters of <ptrBuffer>. If <dwChar> is not matched, MemChr() returns a NULL_PTR.
memchr.example:
This example uses MemChr() on a PSZ:
FUNCTION FindChar() AS VOID LOCAL pszC1 := "ABCDEF" AS PSZ ? MemChr(pszC1, ASC("A"), 6) // A pointer ? MemChr(pszC1, ASC("B"), 6) // A pointer ? MemChr(pszC1, ASC("B"), 1) // NULL_PTR: ASC("B") is not in the // first "1" characters of the PSZ
This next example uses MemChr() on an allocated block:
FUNCTION FindChar2() AS VOID LOCAL ptrBuff := MemAlloc(10) AS PTR IF ptrBuff != NULL_PTR // Write 68 to first 10 MemSet(ptrBuff, 68, 10) // Overwrite first 5 with 67 MemSet(ptrBuff, 67, 5) ? MemChr(ptrBuff, 68, 10) //3CEF:07DD ? MemChr(ptrBuff, 67, 10) //3CEF:07D8 ENDIF

memclear.summary: Fill a memory buffer with null characters.
memclear.param: A pointer to the memory buffer to fill.
The number of bytes to fill.
memclear.returns: A pointer to the filled memory buffer.
memclear.remarks:
MemClear() sets the first <dwCount> bytes of the memory buffer pointed to by <ptrValue> to the ASCII CHR(0) character.
This function allows the direct manipulation of a memory location and should be used with extreme care.
memclear.example:
This example clears out the contents of an allocated block:
LOCAL ptrBuff AS PTR ptrBuff := MemAlloc(10) MemClear(ptrBuff, 10)

memcomp.summary: Compare bytes in two memory buffers.
memcomp.param: A pointer to the first memory buffer.
A pointer to the second memory buffer.
The number of bytes to compare.
memcomp.returns: -1, 0, or 1 if the first <dwCount> bytes of <ptrFirst> are less than, equal to, or greater than the first <dwCount> bytes of <ptrSecond>, respectively.

remarks.code: MemComp() compares the ANSI values of the first <dwCount> bytes in each memory buffer. Note that some characters (such as ä can have a greater ANSI value but a lower OEM value than other characters (such as ). The system only uses the ANSI set.

memcomp.example:
This examples use MemComp():
FUNCTION Compare() LOCAL pszC1 := "abc" AS PSZ LOCAL pszC2 := "abcd" AS PSZ LOCAL pszChar1 := "ä" AS PSZ LOCAL pszChar2 := "ß" AS PSZ ? MemComp(pszC1, pszC2, 4) // -1 ? MemComp(pszC2, pszC1, 4) // 1 // The ANSI value of "ä" is greater than "ß" // although its OEM value is less. ? MemComp(pszChar1, pszChar2) // 1

memcopy.summary: Copy one memory buffer to another.
memcopy.param: A pointer to the destination memory buffer.
A pointer to the source string to copy.
The number of bytes to copy.
memcopy.returns: A pointer to the destination memory buffer.
memcopy.remarks:
MemCopy() copies the specified number of bytes from the source memory buffer to the destination memory buffer. If portions of memory occupied by the source string overlap with portions in the destination, the overlapping region is overwritten. Use MemMove() to copy overlapping regions before they are overwritten.
This function allows the direct manipulation of a memory location and should be used with extreme care.
memcopy.example:
This example uses MemCopy():
LOCAL pszDest := "Hi there" AS PSZ LOCAL pszSrc := "***" AS PSZ MemCopy(pszDest, pszSrc, 3) ? pszDest // ***there

memcopystring.summary: Copy one memory buffer to another and fill any remaining spaces with blanks.
memcopystring.param: A pointer to the destination memory buffer.
The number of bytes to copy.
memcopystring.remarks:
MemCopyString() copies the specified number of bytes from the source memory buffer to the destination memory buffer. If portions of memory occupied by the source string overlap with portions in the destination, the overlapping region is overwritten. If the number of bytes in the source memory buffer is less than <dwCount>, the rest of the destination memory buffer is filled with blanks. Use MemMove() to copy overlapping regions before they are overwritten.
This function allows the direct manipulation of a memory location and should be used with extreme care.
memcopystring.example:
This example uses MemCopyString():
LOCAL pszDest := "Hi there" AS PSZ LOCAL pszSrc := "***" AS PSZ MemCopyString(pszDest, pszSrc, 5) ? pszDest // "*** ere"

memdword.summary: Get a pointer to a matching double word in a memory buffer.
memdword.param: A pointer to the memory buffer to examine.
The double word value to match.
The number of double words in <ptrBuffer> to examine.
memdword.returns: A pointer to the first occurrence of <dwValue> within the first <dwCount> characters of <ptrBuffer>. If <dwValue> is not matched, MemDWord() returns a NULL_PTR.
memdword.example:
This example uses MemDWord() on a PSZ:
FUNCTION FindDWord() AS VOID LOCAL pszC := "ABCDEFGHIJ" AS PSZ ? MemDWord(pszC, Bin2DW("EFGH"), 2) // A pointer ? MemDWord(pszC, Bin2DW("EFGH"), 1) // Pattern not found in the first DWord of pszC // 0000:0000

memfree.param: A pointer to a previously allocated memory buffer. If an invalid pointer is specified, a message box informs you of the failed attempt.
memfree.remarks:
MemFree() is a memory function used to free up memory allocated by MemAlloc(). The number of bytes freed is the number of bytes that were previously allocated by MemAlloc().
This function allows the direct manipulation of a memory location and should be used with extreme care.
memfree.example:
This example uses MemFree() to deallocate a newly allocated block:
LOCAL ptrBuff AS PTR ptrBuff := MemAlloc(128) IF ptrBuff = NULL_PTR ? "Allocation failed" ELSE MemFree(ptrBuff) ENDIF

memgrpalloc.summary: Allocate a new memory buffer in a group.
memgrpalloc.param: The group to which the newly allocated memory buffer will belong. This group should have already been opened by MemGrpOpen().
The number of bytes to allocate.
memgrpalloc.returns: A pointer to the newly allocated space if there is sufficient memory available; otherwise, a NULL_PTR is returned. You should always check the return value for a successful allocation.
memgrpalloc.remarks:
MemGrpAlloc() allocates a memory buffer of at least <wBytes>. Since memory is allocated in increments of 32 bytes, some extra space may be allocated. For example, a request for even 1 byte will allocate 32 bytes. Space allocated by MemGrpAlloc() is freed by MemGrpClose().
This function allows the direct manipulation of a memory location and should be used with extreme care.
memgrpalloc.example:
This example uses MemGrpAlloc():
Function Start() LOCAL ptrCurrent AS PTR LOCAL wGroup AS DWORD LOCAL lRet AS LOGIC wGroup := MemGrpOpen() // Need to have a // group ready first IF wGroup != 0 ptrCurrent := MemGrpAlloc(wGroup, 100) MemGrpClose(wGroup) lRet := FALSE ELSE lRet := TRUE ENDIF RETURN lRet

memgrpclose.param: The group you want to close. If an invalid group is specified, a message box informs you of the failed attempt to close an invalid group.
memgrpclose.remarks:
After a call to MemGrpClose(), any memory held by the group is subject to garbage collection, and <wGroup> ceases to exist as a valid group handle.
This function allows the direct manipulation of a memory location and should be used with extreme care.
memgrpclose.example:
This example uses MemGrpClose() to close two different groups.
w1 := MemGrpOpen() // 1 IF w1 != 0 ? MemGrpClose(w1) // TRUE ENDIF IF w2 != 0 w2 := MemGrpOpen() // 1 (Same handle is reused) ENDIF MemGrpClose(w2) // TRUE

memgrpopen.summary: Open up a new memory group.
memgrpopen.returns: If successful, the handle of the new group; otherwise, 0. You should always check for a valid group handle.
memgrpopen.remarks:
MemGrpOpen() opens up a new memory group. In conjunction with MemGrpAlloc(), MemGrpOpen() allows you to group or organize dynamically allocated memory buffers.
This function allows the direct manipulation of a memory location and should be used with extreme care.
memgrpopen.example:
This example uses MemGrpOpen() and checks for a valid group number:
wGrp := MemGrpOpen() IF wGrp = 0 ? "Unsuccessful - invalid handle" ELSE ? "New valid handle", wGrp ENDIF

memint.summary: Get a pointer to a matching integer in a memory buffer.
memint.param: A pointer to the memory buffer to examine.
The number of integers in <ptrBuffer> to examine.
memint.returns: A pointer to the first occurrence of <iValue> within the first <dwCount> integers of <ptrBuffer>. If <iValue> is not matched, MemInt() returns a NULL_PTR.
memint.example:
This example uses MemInt() on a PSZ:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL ptrI := "ABCDEFGHIJ" AS PSZ ? MemInt(ptrI, Bin2I("EFGH"), 2) // A pointer ? MemInt(ptrI, Bin2I("EFGH"), 1) // Not found in the first integer of ptrI 0000:0000

memlines.summary: Count the number of lines in a string or memo field.
memlines.param: The string in which to count.
memlines.returns: The number of lines in <cString>, depending on the <nLineLength>, the <nTabSize>, and whether word wrapping is on or off.
memlines.remarks: MemLines() is used with MemoLine() to print strings and memo fields based on the number of characters per line. In the basic operation, use MemLines() to return the number of lines in the string or memo field. Then, using MemoLine() to extract each line, loop through the memo field until there are no lines left.
memlines.example:
This example displays the contents of each Notes memo field in the SALES.DBF file, 1 line at a time:
USE sales NEW nLineLength = 65 DO WHILE !EOF() nLines = MemLines(Sales->Notes) FOR nCurrLine = 1 UPTO nLines ? MemoLine(Sales->Notes, nLineLength,; nCurrLine) NEXT SKIP ? ENDDO

memlong.summary: Get a pointer to a matching long integer in a memory buffer.
memlong.param: A pointer to the memory buffer to examine.
The long integer value to match.
The number of long integers in <ptrBuffer> to examine.
memlong.returns: A pointer to the first occurrence of <liValue> within the first <dwCount> long integers of <ptrBuffer>. If <liValue> is not matched, MemLong() returns a NULL_PTR.
memlong.example:
This example uses MemLong() on a PSZ:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL ptrLI := "ABCDEFGHIJ" AS PSZ ? MemLong(ptrLI, Bin2L("EFGH", 2)) // A pointer ? MemLong(ptrLI, Bin2L("EFGH", 1)) // Not found in the first long integer of ptrLI // 0000:0000

memmove.summary: Move one memory buffer to another.
memmove.param: A pointer to the destination memory buffer.
A pointer to the source memory buffer.
The number of bytes to copy.
memmove.returns: A pointer to the destination memory buffer.
memmove.remarks:
MemMove() copies the specified number of bytes from the source memory buffer to the destination memory buffer. If portions of the source buffer overlap with portions of the destination buffer, the overlapping region is copied and kept for the duration of the operation before it is overwritten.
This function allows the direct manipulation of a memory location and should be used with extreme care.
memmove.example:
This example uses MemMove():
LOCAL pszDest := "Hi there" AS PSZ LOCAL pszSrc := "***" AS PSZ MemMove(pszDest, pszSrc, 3) ? pszDest // ***there

memoline.summary: Extract a line of text from a string.
memoline.param: The string from which to extract a line of text.
The number of characters per line. This can be a value between 4 and 254. The default is 79.
The line number to extract. The default is 1.

The number of characters to insert when the user presses Tab. If <nTabSize> is not specified, 4 spaces are inserted. If <nTabSize> is greater than or equal to <nLineLength>, the tab size is automatically converted to <nLineLength> minus 1.
TRUE toggles word wrap on; FALSE toggles it off. The default is TRUE.
memoline.returns: The line of text specified by <nLineNumber> in <cString>. If the line has fewer characters than the indicated length, the return value is padded with blanks. If the line number is greater than the total number of lines in <cString>, MemoLine() returns a NULL_STRING. If <lWrap> is TRUE and the indicated line length breaks the line in the middle of a word, that word is not included as part of the return value but shows up at the beginning of the next line extracted with MemoLine(). If <lWrap> is FALSE, MemoLine() returns only the number of characters specified by the line length. The next line extracted by MemoLine() begins with the character following the next hard carriage return, and all intervening characters are not processed.
memoline.remarks: MemoLine() is a memo function used with MLCount() to extract lines of text from strings and memo fields, based on the number of characters per line. It is the most basic facility provided by X# to display memo fields and long strings. The basic method of operation is to determine the number of lines in the string using MLCount() and specifying the same number of characters per line, tab size, and wrapping behavior as you intend to use with MemoLine(). Using this value as the upper boundary of a FOR...NEXT, each line of the string can be extracted with MemoLine() and processed with any combination of output commands and functions required.
memoline.example:
This example demonstrates the general method for displaying memo fields and long strings using the combination of MLCount() and MemoLine():
