LOCAL nLineLength := 40, nTabSize := 3, lWrap := TRUE LOCAL nLines, nCurrentLine USE customer INDEX custname NEW nLines := MLCount(CustNotes, nLineLength, nTabSize, lWrap) SET PRINTER ON FOR nCurrentLine := 1 UPTO nLines ? MemoLine(CustNotes, nLineLength, nCurrentLine, nTabSize, lWrap) NEXT SET PRINTER OFF

memoread.summary: Return the contents of a text file as a string.
memoread.param: The name of the text file to read from disk, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. SetDefault() and SetPath() settings are ignored; the Windows default is used unless you specify a drive and directory as part of the file name. No extension is assumed.
memoread.returns: The contents of the file. The maximum file size that can be read is MAX_ALLOC bytes — the maximum size of a string. If <cFileName> does not exist, MemoRead() returns a NULL_STRING. If it exists, this function attempts to open the file in shared mode and, if successful, it proceeds. If access is denied because, for example, another process has exclusive use of the file, MemoRead() returns a NULL_STRING and NetErr() is set to TRUE.
memoread.remarks: MemoRead() reads a disk file into memory, where it can be manipulated as a string or assigned to a memo field. MemoRead() is used with MemoEdit() and MemoWrit() to edit an imported disk file; then write it back to disk. This function does an automatic OEM to ANSI conversion when SetAnsi() is FALSE.
memoread.example:
This example uses MemoRead() to assign the contents of a text file to the Notes memo field and to a character variable:
REPLACE Notes WITH MemoRead("temp.txt") cString = MemoRead("temp.txt")
This example defines a function that edits a disk file:
FUNCTION Editor(cFile) LOCAL cString AS STRING If(cString := MemoRead(cFile)) = NULL_STRING ? "Error reading " + cFile RETURN FALSE ELSE MemoWrit(cFile, MemoEdit(cString)) RETURN TRUE ENDIF

memory.param: One of the following constants, indicating the type of memory information about which you want to report (note that each constant begins with the prefix MEMORY_ as illustrated in the example below):
Size of activation stack table in bytes (maximum is 64)
Size of private var table in bytes (maximum is 64)
Size of public var table in bytes (maximum is 64)
Size of SEQUENCE table in bytes (maximum is 64) (see LABEL...())
Size of stack segment of application
Calls the Windows API GlobalMemoryStatus() function, returning MemoryStatus.dwTotalPhys
Calls the Windows API GlobalMemoryStatus() function, returning MemoryStatus.dwAvailPhys
Calls the Windows API GlobalMemoryStatus() function, returning MemoryStatus.dwMemoryLoad
memory.example:
This example uses Memory() to query various memory states:
? Memory(MEMORY_SYSTEM_FREE) ? Memory(MEMORY_SYSTEM_MAX) ? Memory(MEMORY_DYNINFOFREE) ? Memory(MEMORY_DYNINFOMAX)

memotran.summary: Replace carriage-return/linefeeds with a character that can be displayed.
memotran.param: The string that contains the carriage-return/linefeed.
The character to replace a hard carriage-return/linefeed pair with. The default is a semicolon (;).
The character to replace a soft carriage-return/linefeed pair with. The default is a space.
memotran.returns: A copy of <cString> with the specified carriage-return/linefeed pairs replaced.
memotran.remarks: Carriage-return/linefeed characters are end-of-line formatting indicators placed in the string by MemoEdit(): Soft carriage returns (Chr(141)) are inserted when a line longer than the width of the MemoEdit() window wraps. Hard carriage returns (Chr(13)) are inserted when the user explicitly presses Enter. MemoTran() is particularly useful when displaying a memo field in a report form that does not wrap when a soft carriage return is encountered. MemoTran() resolves this by converting soft carriage returns to spaces.
memotran.example: This example strips all end-of-line characters from a memo field: REPLACE _FIELD->Notes WITH MemoTran(_FIELD->Notes)

memowrit.summary: Write a string to a disk file.
memowrit.param:
The name of the target disk file, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. SetDefault() and SetPath() settings are ignored; the Windows default is used unless you specify a drive and directory as part of the file name. No extension is assumed.
If <cFileName> does not exist, it is created. If it exists, this function attempts to open the file in exclusive mode and, if successful, the file is overwritten without warning or error. If access is denied because, for example, another process is using the file, MemoWrit() returns FALSE and NetErr() is set to TRUE.
memowrit.returns: TRUE if the writing operation is successful; otherwise, FALSE.
memowrit.remarks:
MemoWrit() is generally used with MemoRead() to load text files into memory, where they can be edited, displayed, and written back to disk. You can also use MemoWrit() as a quick way of exporting a memo field to a text file.
Some characters, such as "ß," have different ANSI and OEM codes. When writing such characters from Windows to a file, you may need to issue the Ansi2Oem() function. Conversely, when reading the file back to Windows, you may need to issue an Oem2Ansi() function. To circumvent such problems, MemoWrit() automatically does an ANSI to OEM conversion when SetAnsi() is FALSE.
memowrit.example:
This example uses MemoWrit() to save the contents of a field to a text file:
USE Sales IF MemoWrit("votmp.txt", Sales->Notes) ? "Saved" ELSE ? "Error while writing cliptmp.txt" BREAK ENDIF

memset.summary: Fill a memory buffer with a specified character.
memset.param: A pointer to the memory buffer to fill.
The code for the character, as a number from 0 to 255.
The number of bytes to fill.
memset.returns: A pointer to the filled memory buffer.
memset.remarks:
MemSet() sets the first <wCount> characters of the memory buffer pointed to by <ptrBuffer> to a specified character.
This function allows the direct manipulation of a memory location and should be used with extreme care.
memset.example:
This example uses MemSet() to fill up all characters of an allocated buffer with "A":
FUNCTION MemReplicate() AS VOID LOCAL ptrC AS PTR ptrC := MemAlloc(10) ptrC := MemSet(ptrC, Asc("A"),10) ? ptrC // AAAAAAAAAA MemFree(ptrC)
This example uses MemSet() to change all characters of a PSZ to "Z":
FUNCTION PszQ() LOCAL pszS := "ABC" AS PSZ // Asc("Z") = 90 MemSet(pszS, 90,3) ? pszS // ZZZ

memshort.summary: Get a pointer to a matching short integer in a memory buffer.
memshort.param: A pointer to the memory buffer to examine.
The short integer value to match.
The number of short integers in <ptrBuffer> to examine.
memshort.returns: A pointer to the first occurrence of <siValue> within the first <dwCount> short integers of <ptrBuffer>. If <siValue> is not matched, MemShort() returns a NULL_PTR.

memtotal.summary: Report the total number of bytes used by other memory manager functions.
memtotal.returns: The total memory consumed by memory manager functions. This value is rounded or accurate within 4 KB increments.
memtotal.example:
This example uses MemTotal() before and after allocating a memory buffer through a MemAllocSeg() function:
? MemTotal() w := MemAllocSeg(100) ? MemTotal() // Larger value than first call

memvarblock.summary: Return a set-get code block for a given memory variable.
memvarblock.param: The name of the variable referred to by the set-get block.
memvarblock.returns: A runtime code block (implemented as an object) that, when evaluated, sets (assigns) or gets (retrieves) the value of <cMemvarName>. If <cMemvarName> does not exist, MemVarBlock() returns a NULL_OBJECT.
memvarblock.remarks:
The code block created by MemVarBlock() has two operations, depending on whether an argument is passed to the code block when it is evaluated: If the code block is evaluated with an argument, it assigns the value of the argument to <cMemvarName>. If the code block is evaluated without an argument, it retrieves the value of <cMemvarName>.
MemVarBlock() creates set-get blocks only for variables whose names are known at runtime. MemVarBlock(), therefore, cannot be used to create set-get blocks for local or static variables. The same restriction applies to creating blocks using the macro operator (&).

memvarblocksym.summary: Obtain a set-get code block for a given memory variable.
memvarblocksym.param: A symbol representing the variable name whose set-get block you want to obtain.
memvarblocksym.returns: A runtime code block (implemented as an object) that, when evaluated, sets (assigns) or gets (retrieves) the value of <cMemvarName>. If <cMemvarName> does not exist, MemVarBlockSym() returns a NULL_OBJECT.
memvarblocksym.remarks:
The code block created by MemVarBlockSym() has two operations depending on whether an argument is passed to the code block when it is evaluated. If the code block is evaluated with an argument, it assigns the value of the argument to <cMemvarName>. If the code block is evaluated without an argument, it retrieves the value of <cMemvarName>.
MemVarBlockSym() creates set-get blocks only for variables whose names are known at runtime. MemVarBlockSym(), therefore, cannot be used to create set-get blocks for local or static variables. The same restriction applies to creating blocks using the macro operator (&).

memvarget.summary: Return the contents of a memory variable.
memvarget.param: The name of the memory variable.
memvarget.remarks: MemVarGet() is used instead of a macro when the name of the variable is in a string.
memvarget.example:
This example uses MemVarGet() to retrieve the contents of a memory variable:
cPrivate := "hi" cHasName := "cPrivate" // Instead of ? &cHasName, use this: ? MemVarGet(cHasName) // hi

memvarput.summary: Assign a value to a memory variable of a given name.
memvarput.param: The name of the variable you want to create.
The value to assign to the variable.
memvarput.remarks:
If a memory variable called <cVarName> does not exits, a memory variable called <cVarName> is created. Therefore, MemVarPut(), like VarPut() can be used to create undeclared memory variables. It should be used instead of a macro.
This function allows the direct manipulation of a memory location and should be used with extreme care.
memvarput.example:
This example uses MemVarPut() to create a memory variable:
LOCAL cHasName AS STRING cHasName := "cPrivate" // Instead of &cHasName := "new", use this: MemVarPut(cHasName, "new") ? cPrivate // new
This example shows that the newly created variable is a MEMVAR:
MemVarPut("cVar", "hi") ? _MEMVAR->cVar // hi

memwalk.summary: Walk through the memory system, checking for validity.
memwalk.example:
This example uses MemWalk() after allocating and deallocating memory with other memory manager functions:
p := MemAlloc(100) MemFree(p) ? MemWalk()

memword.summary: Get a pointer to a matching word in a memory buffer.
memword.param: A pointer to the memory buffer to examine.
The number of words in <ptrBuffer> to examine.
memword.returns: A pointer to the first occurrence of <dwValue> within the first <dwCount> words of <ptrBuffer>. If <dwValue> is not matched, MemWord() returns a NULL_PTR.
memword.example:
This example uses MemWord() on a PSZ:
Function Start() LOCAL ptrW := "ABCDEFGHIJ" AS PSZ ? MemWord(ptrW, Bin2W("CD"), 3) // A pointer ? MemWord(ptrW, Bin2W("CD"), 1) // Not found in the first word of ptrW // 0000:0000

methodlist.summary: Create a class list in the form of an array for the specified object.
methodlist.param: The object whose methods you want to list.
methodlist.returns: An array of symbols containing the name of all methods defined for <symObject>.
methodlist.remarks: This function creates a list of all methods defined for the specified object. The resulting method list array does not include ACCESS or ASSIGN methods.
methodlist.example:
This example uses MethodList() to store a method list for an object of the Person class, then displays the resulting array. Note how the ACCESS method is ignored.
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL oPerson AS Person oPerson := Person{"Susan", 5, "Cue") AEval(MethodList(oPerson),{|x| QOut(x)}) // Result is: // INIT // SHOWGRADE CLASS Person EXPORT name INSTANCE grade PROTECT password METHOD Init(tname, tgrade, tpassword) CLASS Person name := tname grade := tgrade password := tpassword METHOD ShowGrade() CLASS Person ? grade ACCESS Grade() CLASS Person RETURN grade

methodlistclass.summary: Create a class list in the form of an array for the specified class.
methodlistclass.param: The class whose methods you want to list.
methodlistclass.returns: An array of symbols containing the name of all methods declared for <symClass>.
methodlistclass.remarks: This function creates a list of all methods defined for the specified class. The resulting method list array does not include ACCESS or ASSIGN methods.
methodlistclass.example:
This example uses MethodListClass() to store a method list for the Person class, then displays the resulting array. Note how the ACCESS method is ignored.
FUNCTION Start() AEval(MethodListClass(#Person),{|x| QOut(x)}) // Result is: // INIT // SHOWGRADE CLASS Person EXPORT name INSTANCE grade PROTECT password METHOD Init(tname, tgrade, tpassword) CLASS Person name := tname grade := tgrade password := tpassword METHOD ShowGrade() CLASS Person ? grade ACCESS Grade() CLASS Person RETURN grade

mexec.returns: The value of the compiled expression.
mexec.remarks: MExec() evaluates an expression that was previously macro-compiled. Instead of invoking the macro compiler each time an expression is evaluated, you could speed up your application by compiling an expression only once and executing the compiled result as often as desired.
mexec.example:
These examples show typical uses of MExec():
LOCAL cComp := MCompile("2+3-1") AS STRING LOCAL cExpr AS STRING ? MExec(cComp) // 4 cPrivate := 2 cExpr := "3+cPrivate-1" // cPrivate is a PRIVATE variable cComp := MCompile(cExpr) ? MExec(cComp) // 4 ? MExec(cComp) + 1 // 5

min.param: The second value to compare. This must be of the same type as <uValue1> except that numerics of different types are allowed.
min.returns: The smaller of the 2 arguments. The value returned is the same type as the smaller argument.
min.remarks: The inverse of Min() is Max(), which returns the larger of 2 expressions.
min.example:
In these examples Min() returns the smaller of 2 numbers:
? MIN(99, 100) // 99 ? MIN(100, 99) // 99
In these examples Min() compares date values:
? TODAY() // 05/27/93 ? MIN(TODAY(), TODAY() + 30) // 05/27/93

mlcount.summary: Count the number of lines in a string.
mlcount.param: The number of characters per line, ranging from 4 to 254. The default line length is 79.

The number of characters to insert when the user presses the tab key. The default value is 4. If <nTabSize> is greater than or equal to <nLineLength>, the tab size is automatically converted to <nLineLength> minus 1.
Controls whether words wrap to the next line: TRUE if they wrap; FALSE if they do not. The default is TRUE.
mlcount.returns: The number of lines in <cString>, depending on the <nLineLength>, the <nTabSize>, and whether word wrapping is on or off.
mlcount.remarks: MLCount() is a memo function used with MemoLine() to print strings and memo fields based on the number of characters per line. In the basic operation, use MLCount() to return the number of lines in the string. Then, using MemoLine() to extract each line, loop through the string until there are no lines left. If <lWrap> is TRUE and an end of line position breaks a word, it is word-wrapped to the next line and the next line begins with that word. If <lWrap> is FALSE, MLCount() counts the number of characters specified by <nLineLength> as the current line. The next line begins with the character following the next hard or soft carriage return. Intervening characters are ignored.
mlcount.example:
This example displays the contents of each Notes memo field in the SALES database file, 1 line at a time:
USE sales NEW nLineLength = 65 DO WHILE !EOF() nLines = MLCount(Sales->Notes, nLineLength) FOR nCurrLine = 1 UPTO nLines ? MemoLine(Sales->Notes, nLineLength, nCurrLine) NEXT SKIP ? ENDDO

mlcount1.summary: Count the number of lines in a string.
mlcount1.remarks: MLCount1() is similar to MLCount() except that MLCount1() has only one argument and that argument is strongly typed. See MLCount() for more information.

mlctopos.summary: Return the position of a character in a formatted string.
mlctopos.param: The length of each line after <cText> is formatted.
The line number in the formatted text, starting from the top at 1.
The column number in the formatted text, starting from the left at 0.
The number of characters to insert when the user presses Tab. If <nTabSize> is not specified, 4 spaces are inserted.
The word-wrap flag. The default is TRUE.
mlctopos.returns: The byte position of the character within <cText>, counting from 1.
mlctopos.remarks: MLCToPos() determines the character position that corresponds to a particular line and column within formatted text. Note that the line number is 1-relative, and the column number is 0-relative. This is compatible with MemoEdit(). The return value is 1-relative, making it suitable for use in Substr() or other string functions. MLCToPos() is used with MPosToLC() to create search routines or other text processing for MemoEdit().
mlctopos.example:
This example gives the current position of the character that will appear in line 3, column 0 when <cText> is formatted with a line length of 5 characters:
cText := "Note the side on which the bread" + "is buttered." ? MLCToPos(cText, 5, 3, 0) // Result: 10

mline.summary: Extract a line of text from a string, specifying an optional offset argument.
mline.param: The string that contains the line of text.

The position from which to extract characters. An offset of 0 corresponds to the first byte in <cString>. This is the default. Alternatively, <nOffset> may be passed by reference (preceded by an @) in which case, after the function call, it will contain the size of the returned line.
mline.returns: The specified line. If the specified line does not exist, the return value is a NULL_STRING. A new line begins when a hard-carriage return is encountered.
mline.example:
This example uses MLine(), to extract the first line that is past offset 10 (the 11th character). ? MLine(Customer->Memos, 1, 10) This example applies MLine() to a string that has two lines:
? MLine(Space(30)+Chr(13)+Space(40), 1) // Returns the first line (Space(30))
This example passes <nOffset> by reference:
nOffset := 0 ? MLine(Space(30)+Chr(13)+Space(40), 1, @nOffset) // Space(30) ? nOffset // 30

mline3.summary: Extract a line of text from a string, specifying a required offset argument.
mline3.param: The string that contains the line of text.
<ptrN> must be a DWORD variable that is passed by reference. At the end of the function call, <ptrN> will contain the offset of the last character of the returned line (cLineString).
mline3.returns: The specified line. If the specified line does not exist, the return value is NULL_STRING and <ptrN> contains a 0.
mline3.remarks: MLine3() is similar to MLine(), except that all three arguments are required and it stores the offset of the last returned character with respect to the beginning of <cString>. See MLine() for more information.
mline3.example:
This example displays the content and the size of all lines in a character or memo field:
LOCAL dwOffset AS DWORD LOCAL dwLines AS DWORD LOCAL i AS DWORD dwLines := MemLines(_FIELD->Mail) FOR i := 1 UPTO dwLines // Extract lines sequentially ? MLine3(_FIELD->Mail, i, @dwOffset) ? dwOffset // Length of line NEXT

mlpos.summary: Determine the position of a line in a string.
mlpos.param: The length of each line after <cText> is formatted.
The line number in the formatted text, starting from the top at 1.
The number of characters to insert when the user presses Tab. If <nTabSize> is not specified, 4 spaces are inserted.
The word-wrap flag. The default is TRUE.
mlpos.returns: The character position of <wLine> in <cString>. If <wLine> is greater than the number of lines in <cString>, MLPos() returns the length of <cString>.
mlpos.example:
This example uses MLPos() to find the position of a specific line, given a line length of 40:
LOCAL cString AS STRING LOCAL wLine AS DWORD LOCAL wPosition AS DWORD cString = MemoRead("temp.txt") nLineLength = 40 wLine = 5 wPosition = MLPos(cString, nLineLength, wLine) ? Substr(cString, wPosition, 12)

mlpos2.summary: Determine the position of a line in a string.
mlpos2.returns: The character position of <dwLine> in <cString>. If <dwLine> is greater than the number of lines in <cString>, MLPos2() returns the length of <cString>.
mlpos2.remarks: MLPos2() is similar to MLPos() except that MLPos2() has only two arguments and those arguments are strongly typed. See MLPos() for more information.

mod.summary: Return the remainder of one number divided by another number.
mod.param: The dividend of the division operation.
The divisor of the division operation.
mod.returns: A number representing the remainder of <nDividend> divided by <nDivisor>.
mod.remarks:
Mod() is not implemented using the X# modulus operator (%). Note that there are differences between the Mod() function and the modulus operator, which are described in the following table: Dividend Divisor Modulus Operator Mod() function 3 0 Error 3 3 -2 1 -1 -3 2 -1 1 -3 0 Error -3 -1 3 -1 2 -2 3 -2 1 2 -3 2 -1 1 -3 1 -2
In dBASE III PLUS, a 0 divisor returns the dividend for every value of the dividend. In versions of CA-Clipper prior to Summer '87, a 0 divisor returned 0 for all dividends. In X#, by contrast, the modulus of any dividend using a 0 divisor causes a runtime error.

month.summary: Extract the number of the month from a date.
month.returns: A number from 0 to 12. Specifying a NULL_DATE returns 0.
month.remarks: Month() is a date conversion function that is useful when you require a numeric month value during calculations for such things as periodic reports. Month() is a member of a group of functions that return components of a date value as numbers. The group includes Day() and Year() to return the day and year values as numerics. CMonth() is a related function that allows you to return the name of the month from a date value.
month.example:
These examples return the month of the system date:
? Today() // 09/01/90 ? Month(Today()) // 9 // Advance by 1 month: ? Month(Today()) + 1 // 10
This example uses month along with Day() and Year():
?"We are", Year(Today()), "years, ",; Month(Today()), "months, and", Day(Today()),; "days into our history!"
This example shows the result when a NULL_DATE is passed: ? Month(NULL_DATE) // 0

mparamcount.summary: Return the number of arguments that a method is expecting.
mparamcount.param: The symbol of the class containing the method to examine.
The method name, specified without parentheses.
mparamcount.example:
This example uses MParamCount() to get the number of arguments that the Area method in class Rectangle is expecting. Furthermore, the example sets up a Geometry class with an IdentifyObject() method that uses MParamCount() to collect information about different objects:
CLASS Rectangle METHOD Area(x, y) CLASS Rectangle RETURN x*y CLASS Geometry METHOD IdentifyObject(symObject, symMethod); CLASS Geometry RETURN MParamCount(symObject, symMethod) Function Start() LOCAL oShapes AS OBJECT ? MParamCount(#Rectangle, #Area) // 2 oShapes := Geometry{} ? "It is a "+NTrim(oShapes:IdentifyObject; (#Rectangle, #Area))+ " dimensional object" // It is a 2 dimensional object RETURN TRUE

mpostolc.summary: Return the line and column position of a character in a formatted string.
mpostolc.param: The length of each line after <cText> is formatted.
The byte position within the formatted text, counting from 1.
The number of characters to insert when the user presses Tab. If <nTabSize> is not specified, 4 spaces are inserted.
The word-wrap flag. The default is TRUE.
mpostolc.returns: An array containing the line and column numbers for the character at the specified position.
mpostolc.remarks: MPosToLC() identifies the formatted line and column that correspond to a particular character position within <cText>. Note that the line number returned is 1-relative, and the column number is 0-relative. This is compatible with MemoEdit(). <nPos> is 1-relative, which is compatible with At(), RAt(), and other string functions. MPosToLC() is used with MLCToPos() to create search routines or other text processing for MemoEdit().

neterr.param: Sets the value returned by NetErr() to either TRUE or FALSE. Setting NetErr() allows the runtime error handler to control the way certain concurrency control errors are handled.
neterr.returns: TRUE if a concurrency conflict occurs or if programmatically set to TRUE via the <lNewError> argument; otherwise, FALSE. The initial value is FALSE.
neterr.remarks: NetErr() is a global flag set by certain operations that is used to test for concurrency control conflicts in the following situations: Operation Attempted NetErr() is TRUE Append a blank record with APPEND BLANK or DBAppend() If another process has a file lock in place or a record lock of LastRec() + 1 (with, for example, a simultaneous append blank operation) File open in either shared or exclusive mode (with, for example, USE or DBUseArea()) If another process has exclusive use of the file File open in exclusive mode (with, for example, USE...EXCLUSIVE or DBUseArea() with <lShared> set to FALSE) If another process has the file open, in either shared or exclusive mode Internally, these situations result in a runtime error, invoking the installed error handler. The source code for the default error handler, defined in the ERRORSYS.PRG file located in your X# \SAMPLES directory, does not display an error message in these cases, allowing your application to continue. NetErr() is generally applied in a program by testing one of these operations. If the function returns FALSE, you can perform the next operation. Otherwise, you must handle the error either by retrying the operation or by terminating it with a BREAK or RETURN. For more information, refer to "Concurrency Control" in the Programmer's Guide.
neterr.example:
This example demonstrates typical usage of NetErr(). If the USE succeeds, the index files are opened and processing continues. If the USE fails, a message is displayed, and control returns to the nearest BEGIN SEQUENCE construct:
USE customer SHARED NEW IF !NetErr() SET INDEX TO custnum, custorders, custzip ELSE ? "File is in use by another" ENDIF

netname.returns: The workstation ID as a string up to 15 characters in length. If the workstation ID was never set or the application is not operating under Microsoft LAN Manager, it returns a NULL_STRING.
netname.example: This example demonstrates the NetName() result when a workstation is started as a network node with a station identifier of "STATION 1": ? NetName() // Result: STATION 1 This example demonstrates the NetName() result when a workstation is started as a stand-alone unit: ? NetName() // Result: NULL_STRING

newindexlock.summary: Return and optionally change the setting that determines whether to use the new locking offset of -1 (0xFFFFFFFF) for .NTX files.
newindexlock.param:
TRUE uses the new locking offset. FALSE uses a locking offset of 1 billion bytes.
The initial default is FALSE.
newindexlock.returns: If <lNewSetting> is not specified, NewIndexLock() returns the current setting. If <lNewSetting> is specified, the previous setting is returned.
newindexlock.remarks: By default, this function sets the index locking offset for the current work area. It can be made to operate on an unselected work area by specifying it within an aliased expression. Thus, you can set a separate flag for each work area. You cannot, however, use index files with different locking offsets in the same work area. This setting affects only newly created index files. It has no effect on existing files, in which locking offset is determined by information stored in the file's header record. Note: This function may not be implemented for RDDs other than DBFNTX. Index files created with NewIndexLock(FALSE) in effect have a built-in limitation which limits the size of the database files to 1 GB. If you do not require compatibility with Xbase applications, you can use NewIndexLock(TRUE) to implement a less restrictive locking offset that does not limit the file size in any way. Important! If your application must share data with an Xbase product, either simultaneously or at different times, do not set NewIndexLock(TRUE) unless this can also be done in the other applications as well. Doing so will make your .NTX files incompatible with these products.
newindexlock.example:
This example illustrates the status of NewIndexLock() after several calls to the function:
? NewIndexLock() // FALSE (initial setting) ? NewIndexLock(TRUE) // FALSE (previous setting) ? NewIndexLock() // TRUE (current setting)

newlocks.summary: Return the setting that determines whether to use the new locking offset of -1 (0xFFFFFFFF) for .NTX files. Note: NewLocks() is a compatibility function and therefore not recommended. It is superseded by the NewIndexLock() function, which allows you to change and retrieve the setting. Refer to NewIndexLock() for more information.
newlocks.returns: A logical value indicating the current status of NewIndexLock().

nomethod.returns: A NULL_SYMBOL is returned if such a method does not exist.
nomethod.remarks: You can declare a method called NoMethod() for any class which is executed any time a method is invoked that is not defined for that class. This way you can trap a bad method call before it generates a runtime error. The NoMethod() function can be called from the NoMethod() method to determine the name of the missing method.

ntocdow.summary: Convert the number that identifies a day into the name of the day.
ntocdow.returns: The name of the day that corresponds to <dwDayNum>, where Sunday is 1, Monday is 2, and so on.
ntocdow.example:
This example shows how NToCDoW() works in English:
? NToCDoW(1) // "Sunday" ? NToCDoW(4) // "Wednesday" ? NToCDoW(7) // "Saturday" ? NToCDoW(8) // NULL_STRING

ntocmonth.summary: Convert the number that identifies a month into the name of the month.
ntocmonth.returns: The name of the month that corresponds to <dwMonthNum>, where January is 1, February is 2, and so on through December, which is 12.
ntocmonth.example:
This example shows how NToCMonth() works in English:
? NToCMonth(1) // "January" ? NToCMonth(2) // "February" ? NToCMonth(12) // "December" ? NToCMonth(14) // NULL_STRING

ntrim.summary: Convert a numeric expression to a left-trimmed string.
ntrim.param: The expression to convert to a string.
ntrim.remarks: NTrim() returns the same value as LTrim(Str(<nNum>)). Thus, any conversion rules that apply to the Str() function also apply to the NTrim() function.
ntrim.example:
This example compares the output of NTrim() to that of Str():
? NTrim(234) // "234" ? LTrim(Str(234)) // "234" ? Str(234) // " 234"

nversion.summary: Identify a character set by its nation driver.
nversion.example: This example uses NVersion() to identify a nation driver: ? NVersion() // US ASCII

object2array.summary: Convert the values of an object's instance variables to an array.
object2array.param: The object containing the instance variable to convert.
object2array.returns: An array containing the contents of all instance variables of <oObject>.
object2array.remarks: This conversion can offer you additional flexibility in manipulating data and can allow you to utilize powerful array functions, such as AEval() and AScan(). The scope throughout the function call is SELF.
object2array.example:
This example uses Object2Array() to store INSTANCE and EXPORT instance variables into an array. It then prints the stored instance variables. (Note that the password is not stored in the array because it is a protected instance variable.)
CLASS Person EXPORT name INSTANCE grade PROTECT password METHOD Init(tname, tgrade, tpassword) CLASS Person name := tname grade := tgrade password := tpassword FUNCTION Start() LOCAL x AS OBJECT LOCAL a AS ARRAY LOCAL i AS SHORT x := Person{"Randal", "A", "123"} a := Object2Array(x) // Print them FOR i := 1 UPTO ALen(a) QOut(a[i]) NEXT // Randal // A

occurs.summary: Return the number of times a substring occurs in a string.
occurs.param: The substring for which to search.
The string in which to search. (To specify an offset, use Occurs3()).
occurs.returns: The number of times that <cSearch> appears in <cTarget>.
occurs.example:
This example shows typical use of Occurs():
LOCAL cSearch AS STRING LOCAL cTarget AS STRING cSearch := "any" cTarget := "Anything goes anyway anytime." ? Occurs(cSearch, cTarget) // 2 ? Occurs("any","ANY any") // 1

occurs2.summary: Return the number of times a substring occurs in a string.
occurs2.param: The substring for which to search.
The string in which to search. (To specify an offset, use Occurs3()).
occurs2.returns: The number of times that <cSearch> appears in <cTarget>.
occurs2.remarks: Occurs2() is the same as Occurs() except Occurs2() returns a WORD. See Occurs() for more information.

occurs3.summary: Return the number of times a substring occurs in a string, starting at a specified position.
occurs3.param: The string in which to search.
The position in the string at which to start searching. A value of zero (0) specifies the first byte.
occurs3.returns: The number of times that <cSearch> appears in <cTarget>.
occurs3.remarks: Occurs3() is the same as Occurs(), except that you can specify an offset that tells where to start searching. See Occurs() for more information.
occurs3.example:
This example show typical use of Occurs3():
LOCAL cSearch AS STRING LOCAL cTarget AS STRING cSearch := "any" cTarget := "Anything goes anyway anytime." ? Occurs3(cSearch,cTarget,18) // 1

oem2ansi.summary: Convert a string of OEM characters to ANSI characters.
oem2ansi.param: A source string of OEM characters.
oem2ansi.returns: A converted string of ANSI characters.
oem2ansi.remarks: Oem2Ansi() converts the individual characters in the source string to matching characters from the ANSI character set. This may need to be done because certain symbols, such as ß, have different code values in the ANSI and OEM character sets. Therefore, when using Windows to read or display DOS string data or file names, it is often necessary to translate characters from OEM to ANSI. Note that most X# for Clipper applications automatically perform an OEM to ANSI conversion when SetAnsi() is FALSE. Some, however, such as FRead(), that assume they are working with binary data, do not do such a conversion.

oem2ansia.summary: Convert a string of OEM characters to ANSI characters, changing the contents of the argument as well as the return value.
oem2ansia.param: A source string of OEM characters.
oem2ansia.returns: A converted string of ANSI characters.
oem2ansia.remarks: Oem2AnsiA() is the same as Oem2Ansi(), except that Oem2AnsiA() also replaces the contents of the original string with OEM characters.
oem2ansia.example:
This example uses Oem2AnsiA() to change the contents of a variable by translating each character from OEM to ANSI:
LOCAL cString AS STRING cString := "ßá" Oem2AnsiA(cString)

oem2ansibuff.summary: Convert a specified number of OEM characters in a source buffer to a buffer of corresponding, if any, ANSI characters.
oem2ansibuff.param: A pointer to the buffer that will contain the converted string.
A pointer to the buffer that contains the string to convert.
The number of characters to convert.
oem2ansibuff.returns: A pointer to the buffer that contains the converted string.
oem2ansibuff.remarks:
Oem2AnsiBuff() is the same as Oem2Ansi, except that the resulting pointer is stored in the buffer pointed to by <pszTarget>. Also, the <dwCount> argument lets you specify the number of characters to be converted.
You are responsible for allocating space for the buffer pointed to by <pszTarget>. Using an unallocated buffer pointer can have adverse results.
oem2ansibuff.example:
This example does a conversion from OEM to ANSI. Note that the source string is also used as the target string:
LOCAL cStr := "ßá" Oem2AnsiBuff(Ptr(_CAST, cStr),; Ptr(_CAST, cStr), sLen(cStr))

oldspacefree.summary: Free up static memory created by DynToOldSpace().
oldspacefree.param: The static object that occupies the memory to be freed.
oldspacefree.remarks:
Static memory is not touched by the garbage collector. Therefore OldSpaceFree() is used to wipe out objects that have been copied to static memory via DynToOldSpace().
IIf you have created several items (objects, strings, floats etc) and moved them into OldSpace, then moved an object to OldSpace memory that has references to these other items, OldSpaceFree() will clear these items as well as the item named in uStatic. For this reason, it is important that you clear the items from the lowest item up to the highest item in a linked list. Clearing the highest item first will give a runtime error when you try to clear a lower item using OldSpaceFree(). For example –
LOCAL cDynStatic AS STRING LOCAL oStatic AS MyObject cDynStatic := Space(100) cDynStatic := DynToOldSpace(cDynStatic) oStatic := MyObject{cDynStatic} oStatic := DynToOldSpace(oStatic) OldSpaceFree(oStatic) OldSpaceFree(cDynStatic)
In this code an error would occur on the last line because freeing the object on the line before it would have already freed the string. This should make it clear that you would need to free the string first and then the object that referenced it.
oldspacefree.example:
This example first uses DynToOldSpace() to copy a dynamic object to static memory and then uses OldSpaceFree() to free up the static memory:
LOCAL cDynStatic AS STRING cDynStatic := Space(100) cDynStatic := DynToOldSpace(cDynStatic) OldSpaceFree(cDynStatic)

oledatetimeasdate.summary: Change the return values of OLE date values to VO date values.
oledatetimeasdate.param: The new setting. FALSE allows the return values to be instances of the OleDateTime class, TRUE forces all OLE DateTime values to be VO dates . The default is FALSE
oledatetimeasdate.remarks: An OLE date is actually a DateTime combination, often known as a timestamp in SQL databases. This combination of DateTime can not be stored in a DBF Date field and is not recognised by the Date FieldSpec as being a valid date. When an OLE date field is returned it is an instance of the OleDateTime class and the values can be extracted from this. The alternative is to use the OleDateTimeAsDate(TRUE) function which will convert all of the returned dates into the standard VO format.

ooptree.summary: Return a multidimensional array of all object-oriented programming symbols that constitute the class.
ooptree.param: The object whose class symbols you want to retrieve.
ooptree.returns: Each class occupies an array consisting of the class name, a subarray of instance variables, and a subarray of methods.
ooptree.remarks: OOPTree() retrieves the names of ancestors (super classes), instance data, and methods in the class definition tree.
ooptree.example:
This example uses OOPTree():
CLASS Thing_1 EXPORT x1 METHOD Init() CLASS Thing_1 x1 := 1 METHOD Meth_1() CLASS Thing_1 METHOD Meth_1x() CLASS Thing_1 CLASS Thing_2 INHERIT Thing_1 EXPORT x2 METHOD Meth_2 CLASS Thing_2 METHOD Meth_2x CLASS Thing_2 CLASS Thing_3 INHERIT Thing_2 EXPORT x3 METHOD Meth_3 CLASS Thing_3 METHOD Meth_3x CLASS Thing_3 Function Start() LOCAL o AS OBJECT, aTree AS ARRAY o := Thing_3{} aTree := OOPTree(o)
The array, aTree, contains the following information:
/*************************** Thing-1 x1 Meth_1x Meth_1 Init Thing-2 x2 x1 Meth_2x Meth_2 Meth_1x Meth_1 Init Thing-3 x2 x1 x3 Meth_3x Meth_3 Meth_2x Meth_2 Meth_1x Meth_1 Init ***************************/

ooptreeclass.summary: Return a multidimensional array of all object-oriented programming symbols that constitute the class of an object.
ooptreeclass.param: The class name whose class symbols you want to retrieve.
ooptreeclass.returns: Each class occupies an array consisting of the class name, a subarray of instance variables, and a subarray of methods.
ooptreeclass.remarks: OOPTreeClass() retrieves the names of ancestors (super classes), instance data, and methods in the class definition tree.
ooptreeclass.example:
This example uses OOPTreeClass():
CLASS Thing_1 EXPORT x1 METHOD Init() CLASS Thing_1 x1 := 1 METHOD Meth_1() CLASS Thing_1 METHOD Meth_1x() CLASS Thing_1 CLASS Thing_2 INHERIT Thing_1 EXPORT x2 METHOD Meth_2 CLASS Thing_2 METHOD Meth_2x CLASS Thing_2 CLASS Thing_3 INHERIT Thing_2 EXPORT x3 METHOD Meth_3 CLASS Thing_3 METHOD Meth_3x CLASS Thing_3 Function Start() LOCAL aTree AS ARRAY aTree := OOPTreeClass(#Thing_3)
The array, aTree, contains the following information:
/*************************** Thing-1 x1 Meth_1x Meth_1 Init Thing-2 x2 x1 Meth_2x Meth_2 Meth_1x Meth_1 Init Thing-3 x2 x1 x3 Meth_3x Meth_3 Meth_2x Meth_2 Meth_1x Meth_1 Init ***************************/

ordbagext.summary: Return the default index file extension for a work area as defined by its RDD.
ordbagext.returns: A string indicating the default index file extension for a work area as defined by its RDD.

remarks.note: You can also obtain the default index file extension using DBOrderInfo(DBOI_INDEXEXT).

ordbagname.summary: Return the index file name of a specific order.
ordbagname.param: The name of the order whose index file name you want to obtain or a number representing its position in the order list. Using the order name is the preferred method since the position may be difficult to determine using multiple-order index files. Invalid values are ignored.
ordbagname.returns: The name of the index file containing the order.

remarks.note: You can also obtain the index file name using DBOrderInfo(DBOI_INDEXNAME, <cOrder>).

ordcondset.summary: Set the condition and scope for an order.
ordcondset.param: A string that specifies the for condition for the order. This string is returned by DBOrderInfo(DBOI_CONDITION, [<cIndexFile>], <cOrder>). If you do not need this information, you can specify a NULL_STRING.

> This condition (not <cForCondition>) is the one that is actually used to create the order. Unlike the while condition and other scoping information, the for condition is stored as part of the index file and is used when updating or rebuilding the order with DBReindex(). Any limitations on the for condition are determined by the RDD (see the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide for information about RDD limitations.)
A value of TRUE specifies a scope of all records. Use FALSE if you want to indicate other record scoping conditions (that is, <nNext>, <nRecord>, or <lRest>). The default is FALSE.

A code block that is evaluated at intervals specified by <nInterval>. This is useful in producing a status bar or odometer that monitors the ordering progress. The return value of <cbEval> must be a logical value. If <cbEval> returns FALSE, indexing halts. The default is NIL.

A numeric expression that determines the number of times <cbEval> is evaluated. This argument offers a performance enhancement by evaluating the condition at intervals instead of for every record processed. To step through every record, you can specify a value of 0. The default is 0.

The starting record number. To start at the beginning of the file, specify a value of 0. The default is 0.
You define the scope using one of these three, mutually exclusive arguments (use 0 or FALSE for the others). The default is all records. Record scoping information is used only to create the order. It is not stored in the index file and not used for index updates and reindexing purposes.
The number of records to process, starting at <nStart>. Specify 0 to ignore this argument.
A single record number to process. Specify 0 to ignore this argument.
TRUE processes only records from <nStart> to the end of the file. FALSE processes all records.
Specifies whether the keyed pairs be sorted in decreasing or increasing order of value. TRUE results in descending order. FALSE results in ascending order. The default is FALSE.

Specifies whether open orders should remain open while the new order is being created. TRUE specifies that they should remain open. FALSE specifies that all open orders should be closed. The default is FALSE.

Specifies whether only records in the controlling order — and within the current range as specified by OrdSetScope() — will be included in this order. TRUE specifies that the controlling order and range should be used to limit the scope of the newly created order. FALSE specifies that all records in the database file are included in the order. The default is FALSE.

Specifies whether the new order will be a custom built order (for RDDs that this feature). TRUE specifies that a custom built order will be created. A custom built order is initially empty, giving you complete control over order maintenance. The system does not automatically add and delete keys from a custom built order. Instead, you explicitly add and delete keys using OrdKeyAdd() and OrdKeyDel(). FALSE specifies a standard, system-maintained order. The default is FALSE.
Specifies whether the FOR condition will be optimized (for RDDs that support this feature). TRUE optimizes the FOR condition, and FALSE does not. The default is FALSE.
ordcondset.remarks: This function is identical to DBSetOrderCondition(), which you can refer to for more information.

ordcreate.summary: Create or replace an order in an index file.
ordcreate.remarks: Except for the order of the arguments, this function is identical to DBCreateOrder(), which you can refer to for more information.

orddescend.summary: Return and optionally change the descending flag of an order.
orddescend.param:
The name of the order or a number representing its position in the order list. Using the order name is the preferred method since the position may be difficult to determine using multiple-order index files. If omitted or NIL, the controlling order is assumed.
Specifying an invalid value will raise a runtime error.

The name of an index file, including an optional drive and directory (no extension should be specified). Use this argument with <cOrder> to remove ambiguity when there are two or more orders with the same name in different index files.
If <cIndexFile> is not open by the current process, a runtime error is raised.
TRUE dynamically turns on the descending flag for the order, resulting in descending order. FALSE dynamically turns the flag off, resulting in ascending order.
orddescend.returns: If <lNewDescend> is not specified, OrdDescend() returns the current setting. If <lNewDescend> is specified, the previous setting is returned.
orddescend.remarks: OrdDescend() changes the ascending/descending flag at runtime only — it does not change the descending flag stored in the actual index file.

orddestroy.summary: Remove an order from an open index file.
orddestroy.param: The name of the order or a number representing its position in the order list. Using the order name is the preferred method since the position may be difficult to determine using multiple-order index files. Invalid values are ignored.

The name of an index file, including an optional drive and directory (no extension should be specified). Use this argument with <cOrder> to remove ambiguity when there are two or more orders with the same name in different index files.
If <cIndexFile> is not open by the current process, a runtime error is raised. The default is NULL_STRING.
orddestroy.remarks: This function is identical to DBDeleteOrder(), which you can refer to for more information.

ordfor.summary: Return the for condition of an order.
ordfor.param: The name of the order whose for condition you want to obtain or a number representing its position in the order list. Using the order name is the preferred method since the position may be difficult to determine using multiple-order index files. Invalid values are ignored.

The name of an index file, including an optional drive and directory (no extension should be specified). Use this argument with <cOrder> to remove ambiguity when there are two or more orders with the same name in different index files.
If <cIndexFile> is not open by the current process, a runtime error is raised.
ordfor.returns: A string representing the for condition of the specified order. If the order was not created with a for condition, the return value will be a NULL_STRING. If the RDD does not support the for condition, it can either return a NULL_STRING or cause an error, depending on the RDD. See the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide for details about a particular RDD.

remarks.note: You can also obtain the for condition using of an order DBOrderInfo(DBOI_CONDITION, [<cIndexFile>], <cOrder>).

ordisunique.summary: Return the status of the unique flag for a given order.
ordisunique.param:
The name of the order or a number representing its position in the order list. Using the order name is the preferred method since the position may be difficult to determine using multiple-order index files. If omitted or NIL, the controlling order is assumed.
Specifying an invalid order will raise a runtime error.

The name of an index file, including an optional drive and directory (no extension should be specified). Use this argument with <cOrder> to remove ambiguity when there are two or more orders with the same name in different index files.
If <cIndexFile> is not open by the current process, a runtime error is raised.
ordisunique.returns: The status of the indicated order's unique flag as a logical value.
ordisunique.example:
This example shows the return value of OrdIsUnique() using various orders:
USE customer VIA "DBFCDX" INDEX ON LastName TAG Last UNIQUE INDEX ON FirstName TAG First INDEX ON AGE TO j:\test\tmp\age UNIQUE SET ORDER TO last ? OrdIsUnique() // Result: TRUE, for last ? OrdIsUnique("First") // Result: FALSE ? OrdIsUnique("Age") // Result: TRUE

ordkey.summary: Return the key expression of an order.
ordkey.param: The name of the order whose key expression you want to obtain or a number representing its position in the order list. Using the order name is the preferred method since the position may be difficult to determine using multiple-order index files. Invalid values are ignored.

The name of an index file, including an optional drive and directory (no extension should be specified). Use this argument with <cOrder> to remove ambiguity when there are two or more orders with the same name in different index files.
If <cIndexFile> is not open by the current process, a runtime error is raised.
ordkey.returns: A string representing the key expression of the specified order.

remarks.note: You can also obtain the key expression of an order using DBOrderInfo(DBOI_EXPRESSION, [<cIndexFile>], <cOrder>).

ordkeyadd.summary: Add a key to a custom built order.
ordkeyadd.param:
The name of the order or a number representing its position in the order list. Using the order name is the preferred method since the position may be difficult to determine using multiple-order index files. If omitted or NIL, the controlling order is assumed.
Specifying an invalid order, such as one that is not custom built, will raise a runtime error.

The name of an index file, including an optional drive and directory (no extension should be specified). Use this argument with <cOrder> to remove ambiguity when there are two or more orders with the same name in different index files.
If <cIndexFile> is not open by the current process, a runtime error is raised.

A specific key value that you want to add for the current record. The data type must match that of the order. If not specified, the order's key expression is evaluated for the current record and added to the order.
ordkeyadd.returns:
TRUE if successful; otherwise FALSE.
From the standard RDDs only the DBFCDX RDD supports Custom Indexes. This RDD does NOT support the use of the <uKeyValue> parameter. It always uses the Key Expression to calculate the Key Values to insert.
ordkeyadd.remarks: A custom built order is one that is not automatically maintained by the DBFCDX driver. You can determine if an order is custom built using DBOrderInfo(DBOI_CUSTOM, ...). When you create such an order, it is initially empty. You must manually add and delete keys using OrdKeyAdd() and OrdKeyDel(). OrdKeyAdd() evaluates the key expression (or <uKeyValue>, if specified), then adds the key for the current record to the order. If the order has a for condition, the key will be added only if that condition is met, and then, only if it falls within the current scoping range. Note: RDDs may allow you to add several keys for the same record with consecutive calls to OrdKeyAdd(). OrdKeyAdd() will fail if: The record pointer is positioned on an invalid record (i.e., at EOF()) The specified order is not custom built The specified order does not exist No order was specified and there is no controlling order
ordkeyadd.example:
This example creates a custom index and adds every fiftieth record to it:
USE customer VIA "DBFCDX" // Create custom built order that is initially empty INDEX ON LastName TO Last CUSTOM // Add every 50th record FOR n := 1 UPTO RecCount() STEP 50 GOTO n OrdKeyAdd() NEXT

ordkeycount.summary: Return the number of keys in an order.
ordkeycount.param:
The name of the order or a number representing its position in the order list. Using the order name is the preferred method since the position may be difficult to determine using multiple-order index files. If omitted or NIL, the controlling order is assumed.
Specifying an invalid order will raise a runtime error.

The name of an index file, including an optional drive and directory (no extension should be specified). Use this argument with <cOrder> to remove ambiguity when there are two or more orders with the same name in different index files.
If <cIndexFile> is not open by the current process, a runtime error is raised.
ordkeycount.remarks:
OrdKeyCount() counts the keys in the specified order and returns the result as a numeric value. If the order is not conditional and no scope has been set for it, OrdKeyCount() is identical to RecCount(), returning the number of records in the database file. However, for a conditional order, there may be fewer keys than there are records, since some records may not meet the order's for condition or may not fall inside the scope specified by OrdScope() — in counting the keys, OrdKeyCount() respects the currently defined scope and for condition.
If there is no order in operation, the return value will be 0 and not the value of RecCount().
ordkeycount.example:
This example demonstrates using OrdKeyCount() with various orders.
USE customer // Assume 1000 total records, // 500 less than thirty years old, and // 895 making less than 50,000 ? RecCount() // Result: 1000 ? OrdKeyCount() // Result: 0 INDEX ON Age TO Age INDEX ON First TO First FOR Age < 30 INDEX ON Last TO Last FOR Salary < 50000 // Age is the controlling order SET INDEX TO Age, First, Last ? RecCount() // Result: 1000 ? OrdKeyCount() // Result: 1000 ? OrdKeyCount("First") // Result: 500 ? OrdKeyCount(3) // Result: 895

ordkeydel.summary: Delete a key from a custom built order.
ordkeydel.param:
The name of the order or a number representing its position in the order list. Using the order name is the preferred method since the position may be difficult to determine using multiple-order index files. If omitted or NIL, the controlling order is assumed.
Specifying an invalid order, such as one that is not custom built, will raise a runtime error.

The name of an index file, including an optional drive and directory (no extension should be specified). Use this argument with <cOrder> to remove ambiguity when there are two or more orders with the same name in different index files.
If <cIndexFile> is not open by the current process, a runtime error is raised.
ordkeydel.remarks: A custom built order is one that is not automatically maintained by the DBFCDX driver. You can determine if an order is custom built using DBOrderInfo(DBOI_CUSTOM, ...). When you create such an order, it is initially empty. You must manually add and delete keys using OrdKeyAdd() and OrdKeyDel(). OrdKeyDel() will fail if: The record pointer is positioned on an invalid record (for example, EOF() returns TRUE or the record pointer is positioned on a record that falls outside the orders' scope or for condition) The specified order is not custom built The specified order does not exist No order was specified and there is no controlling order
ordkeydel.example:
This example creates a custom index, adds every fiftieth record to it, and deletes every hundredth record:
USE customer VIA "DBFCDX" // Create custom built order that is initially empty INDEX ON LastName TO Last CUSTOM // Add every 50th record FOR n := 1 UPTO RecCount() STEP 50 GOTO n OrdKeyAdd() NEXT // Remove every 100th record FOR n := 1 UPTO RecCount() STEP 100 GOTO n OrdKeyDel() NEXT

ordkeygoto.summary: Move to a record specified by its logical record number in the controlling order.
ordkeygoto.param: The logical record number. If the value specified does not satisfy the scope or for condition for the order, the record pointer is positioned at the end-of-file.
ordkeygoto.remarks: OrdKeyGoTo() is the complement to OrdKeyNo(). OrdKeyNo() returns the logical record number (i.e., its position in the controlling order) of the current record, and OrdKeyGoTo() moves the record pointer to the specified logical record. Tip: This function can be useful when displaying scroll bars. If the user clicks on a certain position on the scroll bar, you can move to the corresponding record by calling OrdKeyGoTo().

ordkeyno.summary: Get the logical record number of the current record.
ordkeyno.param:
The name of the order or a number representing its position in the order list. Using the order name is the preferred method since the position may be difficult to determine using multiple-order index files. If omitted or NIL, the controlling order is assumed.
Specifying an invalid order will raise a runtime error.

The name of an index file, including an optional drive and directory (no extension should be specified). Use this argument with <cOrder> to remove ambiguity when there are two or more orders with the same name in different index files.
If <cIndexFile> is not open by the current process, a runtime error is raised.
ordkeyno.returns: The relative position of the current record in the specified order, as a numeric value. OrdKeyNo() respects the scope and for condition of the order by returning zero if the record pointer is positioned on an invalid record or if EOF() is TRUE.
ordkeyno.remarks: OrdKeyNo() returns the logical record number of a key in an order. This in contrast to the physical record number (returned using the RecNo() function), which is the relative position of the record in the physical database file. Tip: This function can be useful for displaying scroll bars and messages such as "Record 9 of 123" when viewing records in a browser.
ordkeyno.example:
This example shows the difference between physical and logical record number:
USE customer // Assuming 1000 records SET INDEX TO first // Make records in first order ? OrdKeyNo() // Result: 1 DBSkip(10) ? OrdKeyNo() // Result: 11 ? RECNO() // Result: Unknown DBGoBottom() ? OrdKeyNo() // Result: 1000 ? RECNO() // Result: Unknown

ordkeyval.summary: Get the key value of the current record from the controlling order.
ordkeyval.returns: The current record's key value. The data type of the return value is the same as the that of the key expression used to create the order. Use ValType() or UsualType() to determine the data type. OrdKeyVal() returns NIL if: The is no controlling order The record pointer is at the end-of-file (EOF() returns TRUE) There is no key defined for this record (for example, you have positioned the record pointer to a record that does not meet the order's for condition or that lies outside of its specified scope)
ordkeyval.remarks: The key value is retrieved from the controlling order, not the database file. This makes the retrieval faster because no time is spent reading in the actual record. Tip: OrdKeyVal() is fast, but if you are going to use the value more than once, it is faster to store the result in a local variable. Then use the local variable rather than calling OrdKeyVal() repeatedly for the same record.
ordkeyval.example:
This example displays the values for all keys in an order without ever reading the individual records into memory:
FUNCTION DisplayKeys() LOCAL cKey, cFirst, cLast
USE customer // Assuming both LastName and FirstName are // 20 characters INDEX ON LastName + FirstName TO lastfir
DO WHILE !Customer->EOF() cKey := Customer->OrdKeyVal() // Get key // value cLast := LEFT(cKey, 20) // Get last // name cFirst := RIGHT(cKey, 20) // Get first // name ? cLast, cFirst Customer->DBSkip() ENDDO
CLOSE

ordlistadd.summary: Open an index file and add specified orders to the order list in a work area.
ordlistadd.param:
The name of the index file to open, including an optional drive, directory, and extension for each. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules. The default extension is determined by the RDD and can be obtained using DBOrderInfo(DBOI_INDEXEXT). See the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide for details on a particular RDD.
If <cIndexFile> does not exist, a runtime error is raised. If it exists and is not already open by the current process, this function attempts to open the file in the same mode as the corresponding database file. If access is denied because, for example, another process is using the file and this one is asking for exclusive use, NetErr() is set to TRUE. Otherwise, the file open is successful.
Concurrency conflicts with index files are rare since they should be used with only one database file. If a concurrency problem arises, it will normally be when you attempt to open the database file. Refer to the "Concurrency Control" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on resolving concurrency conflicts.

The name of a specific order to add. If not specified, all orders in the index file are added to the order list. Invalid values are ignored.
Important! Using this argument can be dangerous, because the orders in <cIndexFile> that are not added to the order list will not be kept up to date with changes made to the database file.
ordlistadd.remarks: Except for its ability to select orders from the index file, it is functionally equivalent to DBSetIndex(), which you can refer to for more information.

ordlistclear.summary: Remove orders from the order list in a work area and close associated index files.
ordlistclear.remarks: Except for the order of the arguments, this function is identical to DBClearIndex(), which you can refer to for more information.

ordlistrebuild.summary: Rebuild all orders in the order list of a work area.
ordlistrebuild.remarks: This function is identical to DBReindex(), which you can refer to for more information.

ordname.summary: Return the name of an order in the order list of a work area.
ordname.param: The name of the order whose name you want to obtain or a number representing its position in the order list. Using the position is the preferred method since it is the name you want to obtain. Invalid values are ignored.

The name of an index file, including an optional drive and directory (no extension should be specified). Use this argument with <cOrder> to remove ambiguity when there are two or more orders with the same name in different index files.
If <cIndexFile> is not open by the current process, a runtime error is raised.
ordname.returns: The name of the specified order.

remarks.note: You can also obtain the name of an order using DBOrderInfo(DBOI_NAME, [<cIndexFile>], <cOrder>).

ordnumber.summary: Return the position of an order in the order list of a work area.
ordnumber.param: The name of the order whose position you want to obtain or a number representing its position in the order list. Using the order name is the preferred method since it is the position you want to obtain. Invalid values are ignored.

The name of an index file, including an optional drive and directory (no extension should be specified). Use this argument with <cOrder> to remove ambiguity when there are two or more orders with the same name in different index files.
If <cIndexFile> is not open by the current process, a runtime error is raised.
ordnumber.returns: A numeric value that is equal to the position of the specified order in the order list.

remarks.note: You can also obtain the position of an order using DBOrderInfo(DBOI_NUMBER, [<cIndexFile>], <cOrder>).

ordscope.summary: Set or clear the boundaries for scoping key values in the controlling order.
ordscope.param: A number specifying the top (TOPSCOPE) or bottom (BOTTOMSCOPE) boundary.

The top or bottom range of key values that will be included in the controlling order's current scope. <uNewValue> can be an expression that matches the data type of the key expression in the controlling order or a code block that returns the correct data type.
Omitting <uNewValue> or specifying it as NIL has the special effect of resetting the specified scope to its original default. The default top range is the first logical record in the controlling order, and the default bottom range is the last logical record.
ordscope.returns: If <uNewValue> is not specified, OrdScope() returns and clears the current setting. If <uNewValue> is specified, the function sets it and the previous setting is returned.
ordscope.remarks: The range of values specified using OrdScope() is inclusive. In other words, the keys included in the scope will be greater than or equal the top boundary and less than or equal to the bottom boundary. Note: To return current settings without changing them, call the DBOrderInfo() function, using the DBOI_SCOPETOP and DBOI_SCOPEBOTTOM constants.

ordsetfocus.summary: Set the controlling order for a work area.
ordsetfocus.remarks: This function is similar to DBSetOrder(), which you can refer to for more information.

ordsetrelation.summary: Relate a specified work area to the current work area.
ordsetrelation.param: The number of the child work area or the alias of the child work area.
A code block that expresses the relational expression in executable form.

An optional string value that expresses the relational expression in textual form. If <cKey> is supplied, it must be equivalent to <cbKey>. If <cKey> is omitted, DBRelation() returns a NULL_STRING for the relation.
ordsetrelation.remarks: OrdSetRelation() relates the work area specified by <nArea> or <cAlias> (the child work area) to the current work area (the parent work area). Any existing relations remain active. Relating work areas synchronizes the child work area with the parent work area. This is achieved by automatically repositioning the child work area whenever the parent work area moves to a new record. If there is a controlling order in the child work area, moving the parent work area causes an automatic seek operation in the child work area; the seek key is based on the expression specified by <cbKey> and/or <cKey>. If the child work area has no controlling order, moving the parent work area causes an automatic "go to" in the child work area; the record number for the "go to" is based on the expression specified by <cbKey> and/or <cKey>. OrdSetRelation() is identical to DBSetRelation() (and the SET RELATION...SCOPED command), but it also sets up a scope on the order in the child work area. This means that whenever you select the child work area, only the records related to the current parent record will be visible. This allows straightforward handling of one-to-many relationships and is particularly useful when displaying the related data in a sub-data window. Refer to DBSetRelation() for additional information.
ordsetrelation.example:
This example displays each invoice with its related line items:
USE lineitem NEW VIA "DBFCDX" SET ORDER TO TAG InvNo USE invoice NEW VIA "DBFCDX" // Set a selective relation from Invoice into LineItem OrdSetRelation("LineItem", {|| Invoice->InvNo}, "Invoice->InvNo") GO TOP DO WHILE !EOF() ? InvNo, InvDate // Display invoice fields SELECT LineItem // Only records for current invoice # are visible LIST " ", PartNo, Qty, Price SELECT Invoice // On to next invoice SKIP ENDDO

ordskipunique.summary: Move the record pointer to the next or previous unique key in the controlling order.
ordskipunique.param: Specifies whether the function will skip to the next or previous key. Omitting this value or specifying it as 1 skips to the next unique key. Specifying a negative value skips to the previous key.
ordskipunique.remarks: OrdSkipUnique() allows you to make a non-unique order look like a unique order. Each time you use OrdSkipUnique(), you are moved to the next (or previous) unique key, exactly as if you were skipping through a unique order. This function eliminates the problems associated with maintaining a unique order, while providing you with fast access to unique keys.
ordskipunique.example:
This examples uses OrdSkipUnique() to build an array of unique last names beginning with the letter "J:"
FUNCTION LastUnique() LOCAL aLast[0] SET INDEX TO last // Use the last name order ? OrdIsUnique() // Result: FALSE SET SCOPE TO "J" // Only look at the J's GO TOP DO WHILE !EOF() // Add all the unique J AADD(aLast, Last) // last names to aLast OrdSkipUnique() ENDDO SET SCOPE TO // Clear the scope RETURN aLast // Return array of // unique J names

os.returns: OS() returns the name of the disk operating system under which the current workstation is operating, followed by the version number.
os.remarks: Without the parameter the functions returns "Windows 2000...." for W2K, WXP and Windows Server 2003 so as to maintain backward compatability. With the parameter, the content and type is unimportant, it returns the correct OS name, such as "Windows XP...." or "Windows 2003 Server...." if a more acurate answer is required.
os.example: This example uses OS() to report the operating system the current workstation is running under: ? OS() // DOS 6.00, Windows 3.10

pad.summary: Pad character, numeric, and date values with fill characters on the right.
pad.param: A character, numeric, or date value to pad with a fill character.
The length of the string to return.
The character with which to pad <uValue>. The default is a space character.
pad.returns: A string containing <uValue> and padded with <cFillChar> to a total length of <nLength>. If the length of <uValue> exceeds <nLength>, Pad() truncates cPaddedString to <nLength>.
pad.remarks: Pad() displays variable-length strings within a fixed-length area. It can be used, for example, to ensure alignment with consecutive ?? commands. Another use is to display text to a fixed-width screen area, ensuring that previous text is completely overwritten. Pad() is the inverse of Trim(), which trims trailing space from strings.

padc.summary: Pad character, numeric, and date values with fill characters on both the right and left.
padc.param: A character, numeric, or date value to pad with a fill character.
The length of the string to return.
The character with which to pad <uValue>. The default is a space character.
padc.returns: A string containing <uValue> and padded with <cFillChar> to a total length of <nLength>. If the length of <uValue> exceeds <nLength>, Pad() truncates cPaddedString to <nLength>.
padc.remarks: PadC is the same as Pad() except that PadC() centers <uValue> within <nLength> and adds fill characters on both the left and right sides. For more information, see Pad(). PadC() is the inverse of AllTrim(), which trims both leading and trailing space from strings.

padl.summary: Pad character, numeric, and date values with fill characters on the left.
padl.param: A character, numeric, or date value to pad with a fill character.
The length of the string to return.
The character with which to pad <uValue>. The default is a space character.
padl.returns: A string containing <uValue> and padded with <cFillChar> to a total length of <nLength>. If the length of <uValue> exceeds <nLength>, Pad() truncates cPaddedString to <nLength>.
padl.remarks: PadL is the same as Pad() except that PadL() adds fill characters on the left. For more information, see Pad(). PadL() is the inverse of LTrim(), which trims leading space from strings.

padr.summary: Pad character, numeric, and date values with fill characters on the right.
padr.param: A character, numeric, or date value to pad with a fill character.
The length of the string to return.
The character with which to pad <uValue>h. The default is a space character.
padr.returns: A string containing <uValue> and padded with <cFillChar> to a total length of <nLength>. If the length of <uValue> exceeds <nLength>, PadR() truncates cPaddedString to <nLength>.
padr.remarks: PadR() is the same as Pad(). For more information, see Pad().

palettergb.summary: Get a particular color from a user-defined palette.
palettergb.param: The amount of red in the color, as a number from 0 to 255.
The amount of green in the color, as a number from 0 to 255.
The amount of blue in the color, as a number from 0 to 255.
palettergb.returns: The number of the color described, relative to the numbers of the other colors in the palette. If the color described does not have a number in the palette, the next closest number is returned.
palettergb.remarks: PaletteRGB() can be used only with devices that support palettes that can be created by Windows programmers. See the Windows API PaletteRGB() function for more information on palettes.
palettergb.example:
This example uses PaletteRGB() to create a brush with a red color. CreateSolidBrush() and SelectObject() are defined in the Win32 API library:
hBr := CreateSolidBrush(PaletteRGB(255, 0, 0)) SelectObject(hdc, hBr) // Select the created brush into the current DC

pause.summary: Display a system modal dialog box to pause the current application.
pause.returns: A handle for the dialog box.
pause.remarks: Pause() opens a system modal dialog box, displaying the current module, entity, and line number and a "Waiting..." message. The dialog box has two buttons: Ignore and Abort. Pressing Ignore will continue application execution, and pressing Abort will abort the application.

pclone.remarks: PClone() is similar to SClone() and ACloneShallow() but PClone() accepts a polymorphic argument.
pclone.example:
This example uses PClone() to duplicate polymorphic arguments that were passed to a function:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL u1 LOCAL u2 LOCAL u3 u1 := 1 u2 := TRUE u3 := {||TRUE} CloneThem(@u1, @u2, @u3) RETURN TRUE FUNCTION CloneThem(u1, u2, u3) AS VOID LOCAL u1Clone, u2Clone, u3Clone u1Clone := PClone(u1) u2Clone := PClone(u2) u3Clone := PClone(u3) // Change the originals u1 := 0 u2 :=FALSE u3 := {||FALSE} ? u1, u2, u3 // 0 FALSE {||FALSE} // Clone copies remain unchanged ? u1Clone, u2Clone, u3Clone // 1 TRUE {||TRUE}

pcount.summary: Return the position of the last argument in the list of arguments passed when a procedure or function is invoked.
pcount.returns: The position of the last argument passed. If no arguments are passed, PCount() returns 0.
pcount.remarks: PCount() is useful for determining whether arguments were left off the end of a list of arguments. Arguments that were left off the middle of a list of arguments cannot be detected by this function. There are, however, other ways to detect them: Skipped arguments are uninitialized and, therefore, return NIL when accessed. Therefore, you can determine if a argument did not receive a value by testing it for NIL. To check arguments for NIL, use the IsNil() function. You can set the default value of skipped arguments with the Default() function. You can enforce correct data types by using EnforceType() or EnforceNumeric(). For more information on passing arguments, refer to "Functions and Procedures" in the Programmer's Guide.
pcount.example:
This example is a function that opens a database file and uses PCount() to determine whether the calling procedure passed the name of the database file to open. If the name was not passed, OpenFile() asks for the name:
FUNCTION OpenFile(cFile) IF PCount() = 0 ACCEPT "File to use: " TO cFile ENDIF USE (cFile) RETURN (NetErr())

pow.summary: Raise the first argument to the numeric power specified by the second argument.
pow.param: The power to which to raise the base number.
pow.example: This example uses Pow() to raise 2 to the 3rd power: ? Pow(2,3) // 8.00

procfile.summary: Return the name of the activated module.
procfile.param: Specifies which activation to query. A value of 0 refers to the current activation, a value of 1 refers to the previous activation, and so on. The default value is 0.
procfile.returns: For the current activation, ProcFile() returns the name of the current module. For a previous activation, ProcFile() returns the name of the module that invoked the current module.
procfile.remarks: ProcFile() queries the X# activation stack to determine the name of the currently executing module. ProcFile() is used with ProcLine() and ProcName() to report debugging information. Not every function call sets up the activation stack. A function invokes the activation stack if in it you have used PRIVATE or PUBLIC variables or issued a SET PROCNAME ON command.
procfile.example:
This example presents a function that you can call during the debugging phase of program development to display the names of the current and previously activated modules:
// In Module1: FUNCTION Start() MyFunction() // In Module2: FUNCTION MyFunction() AS VOID ? ProcFile() // Module2 (current) ? ProcFile(1) // Module1 (previous)

procline.summary: Return the source line number of the last line executed in an activated entity.
procline.param: Specifies which activation to query. 0 refers to the current activation, 1 refers to the previous activation, and so on. The default value is 0.
procline.returns: For the current activation, ProcLine() returns the number of the current line. For a previous activation, ProcLine() returns the number of the line that invoked the procedure, function, or method in which ProcLine() is invoked. Since X# is not file-based, the line number is relative to the beginning of the activated entity and not relative to the beginning of the source file containing the entity. A line can include a comment, a blank line, a user defined command, or a continued line. A multistatement line is counted as a single line.
procline.remarks: ProcLine() queries the X# activation stack to determine the last line executed in a currently executing procedure, function, or method. ProcLine() is used with ProcFile() and ProcName() to report debugging information. ProcLine() and ProcName() are controlled by two options on the Application menu: 1. Application Compiler Options displays a list of CA-Clipper compatibility options, one of which is PROCNAME/PROCLINE: If PROCNAME/PROCLINE is selected, these functions will compile and run accurately. If PROCNAME/PROCLINE is not selected, these functions will compile and run but may not produce accurate results. 2. Application Properties displays a Debug option. If this option is selected, these functions will produce accurate results even if PROCNAME/PROCLINE is not selected. The SET PROCLINE command overrides these compiler options and application settings on an entity level. See the SET PROCLINE entry for more information.
