STATIC GLOBAL strucMark IS _JMP_BUF FUNCTION Start() LOCAL siJMPRetVal AS SHORTINT siJMPRetVal :=SetJmp(@strucMark) ? siJMPRetVal IF siJMPRetVal <>0 ? "LongJmp() got me here", siJMPRetVal RETURN FALSE ENDIF LongJmp(@strucMark, 1)| ? "You will never see this on the screen." RETURN TRUE
Here is another example where a LongJmp() is issued if a an error is detected:
STATIC GLOBAL strucMark IS _JMP_BUF FUNCTION Start() LOCAL siJMPRetVal AS SHORTINT siJMPRetVal := SetJmp(@strucMark) IF siJMPRetVal <>0 ? "LongJmp() was here with", siJMPRetVal RETURN FALSE ENDIF IF .NOT. FILE("voerror.log") LongJmp(@strucMark, 1) ENDIF SUBFUNC() RETURN TRUE FUNCTION Subfunc LOCAL cLog AS STRING cLog := MEMOREAD("voerror.log") IF SLen(cLog) =MAX_ALLOC LongJmp(@strucMark, 2) ENDIF RETURN 0

setkidstacksize.param: The required size of the KID stack memory in bytes.
setkidstacksize.returns: The existing size of KID stack in Bytes.
setkidstacksize.remarks: Allows the size of the KID stack to be programmatically changed. Note: that this function was introduced in version 2.7 of X#. In previous versions this functionality was achieved using registry settings on each machine. Note : For safety you can only increase the amount of memory. You should set this at the beginning of your application. The default value is 0x2000.

setmath.summary: Return and optionally change the setting that determines the internal operational characteristics of the underlying floating-point system.
setmath.param: One of the following values, indicating the type of math processor to be used:
A 387 math coprocessor is in use.
At least a 486 with a built-in math coprocessor is in use.
setmath.returns: If <nNewSetting> is not specified, SetMath() returns the current setting. If <nNewSetting> is specified, the previous setting is returned.
setmath.example:
This example uses SetMath() to check the current setting against a value of 486:
IF SetMath() != 486 ? "Not a 486 unit" ENDIF

setmaxdynsize.summary: Set the maximum amount of dynamic memory for the main thread.
setmaxdynsize.param: The required size of the dynamic memory in bytes.
setmaxdynsize.returns: The existing size of MaxDynSpace in Bytes.
setmaxdynsize.remarks: When an application starts, the maximum dynamic memory is set to 16Mb. SetMaxDynSize( ) allows you to increase this for the main thread of larger applications. Note: that this function was introduced in version 2.7 of X#. In previous versions this functionality was achieved using registry settings on each machine. Note : For safety you can only increase the amount of memory. You should set this at the beginning of your application. The default value is 0x1000000.

setmaxregisteredaxit.summary: Set the maximum number of Axit methods that can be registered.
setmaxregisteredaxit.param:
The required number of Axit methods that can be registered.
Note that if this is not a multiple of 32 it is rounded up to the nearest multiple of 32.
setmaxregisteredaxit.returns: The existing number of Axit's that could be registered.
setmaxregisteredaxit.remarks: Allows the setting of the maximum number of Axit's that can be registered to be programmatically changed. Note: that this function was introduced in version 2.7 of X#. In previous versions this functionality was achieved using registry settings on each machine. Note : For safety you can only increase the amount of memory. You should set this at the beginning of your application. The default value is 16000.

setmaxregisteredkids.summary: Set the maximum number of KID's that can be registered.
setmaxregisteredkids.param: The required number of KID's that can be registered.
setmaxregisteredkids.returns: The existing number of KID's that could be registered.
setmaxregisteredkids.remarks: Allows the setting of the maximum number of registered KID's to be programmatically changed. Note: that this function was introduced in version 2.7 of X#. In previous versions this functionality was achieved using registry settings on each machine. Note : For safety you can only increase the amount of memory. You should set this at the beginning of your application. The default value is 10000.

setmaxthreaddynsize.summary: Set the maximum amount of dynamic memory for the new thread.
setmaxthreaddynsize.param: The required size of the dynamic memory in bytes.
setmaxthreaddynsize.returns: The existing size of MaxDynSpace of this thread in Bytes.
setmaxthreaddynsize.remarks: When an application starts a thread, the maximum dynamic memory is set to 16Mb. SetMaxThreadDynSize( ) allows you to increase this for the NEW thread when memory intensive operations will be performed in that thread. Note: that this function was introduced in version 2.7 of X#. In previous versions this functionality was achieved using registry settings on each machine. Note : For safety you can only increase the amount of memory. Existing threads will not be influenced by this setting. The default value is 0x1000000.

setnatdll.summary: Activate a new DLL for nation-dependent operations and messages.
setnatdll.param: The name of the new DLL to use.
setnatdll.remarks: The default library for nation-dependent operations is VO28NAT.DLL. SetNatDLL() disables the default DLL and loads the specified DLL <cNewDLL> which is active until the next call to SetNatDLL().
setnatdll.example:
This example sets DLL CAVONT20.GER for nation-dependent operations:
? GetNatDLL() // VO28NAT.DLL ? SetNatDLL("GERMAN.DLL") // .T. ? GetNatDLL() // GERMAN.DLL

setpath.summary: Change the setting that determines the X# search path for opening files.
setpath.param:
The paths X# uses when searching for a file not found in the default directory. A path is a pointer to a directory. It consists of an optional drive letter and colon, followed by a list of directories from the root to the desired directory separated by backslash (\) characters. A path list is the sequence of paths to search, each separated by a comma or semicolon.
If omitted, the path list is released so that X# searches only the default directory. (Use GetCurPath() to get the current setting.)
setpath.remarks: SetPath() allows commands and functions that open database and associated files to find and open existing files in another drive and/or directory. It does this by specifying a path list to search if a referenced file cannot be found in the default directory. When you attempt to access a file without specifying its path, X# first searches the default drive and directory. The default drive and directory are established by Windows when your application is loaded, or, during execution, by the SetDefault() function. If the file is not found, X# then searches each path in the specified path list until the first occurrence of the file is found. To create new files in another drive or directory, use SetDefault() or explicitly declare the path when specifying the new file name. Note: Certain commands and functions that open files do not respect the SetPath() setting. These cases are noted explicitly in the documentation for those commands and functions.
setpath.example: This example sets two paths for opening files: SetPath("a:\inventory;b:\vendors") This example configures a path setting at runtime by passing a DOS environment variable to a program, retrieving its value with GetEnv(), then setting the path with this value. For example, in DOS: SET VO_PATH = c:\apps\data;c:\apps\progs Later in the configuration section of your application program: SetPath(GetEnv("VO_PATH"))

setpmext.summary: Set the evening extension for time strings in 12-hour format.
setpmext.param: The extension to be used for time strings that occur in the evening hours. This string can be up to eight characters in length — additional characters are ignored.
setpmext.remarks: Time strings formatted using the 12-hour time format have an extension to specify if the time is in the morning or the evening. SetPMExt() allows you to programmatically set the extension identifying evening time strings (that is, those between 12:00:00 noon and just before 12:00:00 midnight). A typical extension for evening time strings is "PM", which is how the function derives its name. The initial default for the evening extension is affected by SetInternational(), which you can refer to for more information. Use GetPMExt() to retrieve the current value of this setting. Note: If SetInternational(#Windows) is in effect, the evening extension is also displayed as part of the 24-hour time format. This is a Windows standard that is not specific to X#.
setpmext.example:
This example turns on the 12-hour time format and displays a time string using two different extensions:
SetAMPM(TRUE) SetPMExt(" pm") ? TString(47000) // 01:03:20 pm SetAMExt(" evening") ? TString(47000) // 01:03:20 evening

setpos.summary: Move the cursor to a new position on the terminal window.
setpos.param: The new row position of the cursor
The new column position of the cursor
setpos.remarks: SetPos() moves the cursor to the specified location, and updates Row() and Col() with the new cursor position.
setpos.example:
This example shows the relationship between the DevPos() function and the @...SAY command:
SetPos(10, 10) ? Qout("Hello there")

setrtregint.summary: Save a numeric value to the Registry.
setrtregint.param: The subkey under which you want to add the number.
The key under which you want to add the number.
The key value you want to add to the Registry.
setrtregint.remarks: SetRTRegInt() can be used to save runtime settings into the Registry. The value will be saved as <cKey> = <dwKeyValue> under the following key: HKEY_CURRENT_USER \\Software \\ComputerAssociates \\X# Applications \\<cSubkey> and optionally under HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE \\Software \\ComputerAssociates \\X# Applications \\<cSubkey> If <cSubkey> is empty (NULL_STRING), the Registry entry will be saved without a subkey under: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE \\Software \\ComputerAssociates \\X# Applications SetRtRegInt() only writes to HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE if the key already exists (and ignores write errors). It always writes to HKEY_CURRENT_USER as well. The return value reflects the result of the write operation to HKEY_CURRENT_USER
setrtregint.example:
This example adds the entry LOCK_RETRIES = 10 to the Registry under the subkey SSA:
SetRTRegInt("SSA", "LOCK_RETRIES", 10") ... nRetries := QueryRTRegInt("SSA", "LOCK_RETRIES") DO WHILE nRetries > 0 IF RLock() EXIT ENDIF nRetries-- ENDDO IF nRetries = 0 // Error message ENDIF ...

setrtregstring.summary: Save a string value to the Registry.
setrtregstring.param: The subkey under which you want to add the string.
The key under which you want to add the string.
The key value you want to add to the Registry.
setrtregstring.remarks: SetRTRegString() can be used to save runtime settings into the Registry. The value will be saved as <cKey> = <dwKeyValue> under the following key: HKEY_CURRENT_USER \\Software \\ComputerAssociates \\X# Applications \\<cSubkey> and optionally under HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE \\Software \\ComputerAssociates \\X# Applications \\<cSubkey> If <cSubkey> is empty (NULL_STRING), the Registry entry will be saved without a subkey under: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE \\Software \\ComputerAssociates \\X# Applications SetRTRegString() only writes to HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE if the key already exists (and ignores write errors). It always writes to HKEY_CURRENT_USER as well. The return value reflects the result of the write operation to HKEY_CURRENT_USER
setrtregstring.example:
This example adds the entry APP_DIR = \SSA\ to the Registry under the subkey SSA:
SetRTRegString("SSA", "APP_DIR", "\SSA\") ... cDbf:=QueryRTRegString("SSA","APP_DIR") + "test.dbf" USE (cDbf) ...

setscience.summary: Return and optionally change the setting that displays numbers in scientific notation.
setscience.param: TRUE turns scientific notation on; specifying FALSE turns it off. The initial default is FALSE.
setscience.returns: If <lNewSetting> is not specified, SetScience() returns the current setting. If <lNewSetting> is specified, the previous setting is returned.
setscience.remarks: SetScience() is an environment function that allows you to display numbers in scientific notation. Any number can be shown in scientific notation where a number is represented by a mantissa (its whole digits) multiplied by 10 raised to the power of an exponent.
setscience.example:
This example uses SetScience() to show numbers in scientific notation:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL lSNSetting AS LOGIC lSNSetting := SetScience(TRUE) ? 1234567890 ? 12345.678 SetScience(lSNSetting)

setsoftseek.summary: Return and optionally change the setting that determines whether a seek operation will find a close match when no exact match is found.
setsoftseek.param:
TRUE moves the record pointer to the next record with a higher key after a failed order search; FALSE moves the record point to the end of the file after a failed order search.
The initial default is FALSE.
setsoftseek.returns: If <lNewSetting> is not specified, SetSoftSeek() returns the current setting. If <lNewSetting> is specified, the previous setting is returned.
setsoftseek.remarks: SetSoftSeek() enables relative seeking, a method of searching an order and returning a record even if there is no match for a specified key. When TRUE is specified and a match for a seek operation (for example, the SEEK command or DBSeek() function) is not found, the record pointer is set to the next logical record with a higher key value than the seek argument. Records not visible (because of DBSetFilter(), SetDeleted(), or a conditional controlling order) are skipped when searching for the next higher key value. If there is no record with a higher key value, the record pointer is positioned at LastRec() + 1, EOF() returns TRUE, and Found() returns FALSE. Found() returns TRUE only if the record is actually found. It never returns TRUE for a relative find. When FALSE is specified and a seek operation is unsuccessful, the record pointer is positioned at LastRec() + 1, EOF() returns TRUE, and Found() returns FALSE.
setsoftseek.example:
This example starts relative seeking at the beginning of a routine and stops it at the end of the routine:
LOCAL lSSSetting AS LOGIC lSSSetting := SetSoftSeek(TRUE) SEEK UPPER("CarlM") ? Found() // FALSE ? EOF() // FALSE ? cName // CarlT SetSoftSeek(lSSSetting)

setthousandsep.summary: Return and optionally change the setting that determines the thousands separation character to be used in numeric-to-string conversion functions.
setthousandsep.param: An ASCII code representing the new thousands separator. The initial default depends on SetInternational(), which you can refer to for more information.
setthousandsep.returns: If <nNewSetting> is not specified, SetThousandSep() returns the current setting. If <nNewSetting> is specified, the previous setting is returned.
setthousandsep.remarks: Normally, numeric values are displayed without thousands separators, unless you explicitly specify the number using pictured output. Pictured output is achieved using a picture clause, which can be defined with the @...SAY...GET command, the Transform() function, or the FieldSpec:Picture property. Note: The comma character used in your source code to represent the thousands separator in picture clauses is unaffected by this setting, just as the period used to represent the decimal separator is unaffected by SetDecimalSep(). Therefore, your source code will not change based on these settings, as illustrated in the example below.

settimesep.summary: Change the setting that determines the separation character to be used in time strings.
settimesep.param: The ASCII code for a character to be used as the time string separator (for example, periods or dashes). The initial default is a colon (:), which is ASCII code 58. (Use GetTimeSep() to get the current setting.)
settimesep.example:
This example changes the way times are displayed from 24:00:00 to 24.00.00:
FUNCTION Start() SetTimeSep(Asc(".")) QOut(Time()) // 24.00.00

setunique.summary: Return and optionally change the setting that determines whether to include unique record keys in an order.
setunique.param: TRUE creates orders with unique records only; FALSE creates orders with all records, even if their keys are the same. The initial default is FALSE.
setunique.returns: If <lNewSetting> is not specified, SetUnique() returns the current setting. If <lNewSetting> is specified, the previous setting is returned.
setunique.remarks: SetUnique() is a database function that controls whether orders are created with uniqueness as an attribute. When TRUE is specified, new orders are created including only unique keys. This is the same as creating an order with the INDEX...UNIQUE command. The manner in which nonunique keys are handled in a unique order is determined by the RDD. The standard behavior in most DBF-based RDDs is to include a record reference to a particular key value only once. Thus, if, during the creation or update of a unique order, two or more records are encountered with the same key value, only the first record is included in the order. When the unique order is updated, reindexed, or packed, only unique records are maintained, without regard to the current SetUnique() value. Changing key values in a unique order has important implications. First, if a unique key is changed to the value of a key already in the order, the changed record is lost from the order. Second, if there is more than one instance of a key value in a database file, changing the visible key value does not bring forward another record with the same key until the order is rebuilt. When FALSE is specified, orders are created with all records. Subsequent updates to the database files add all key values to the order independent of the current UNIQUE setting. Note that keys from deleted records are also included in the index, and may hide keys from non-deleted records.
setunique.example:
This example sets one routine to create orders with only records that have unique keys:
LOCAL lUniqueSetting AS LOGIC lUniqueSetting := SetUnique(TRUE) MyFunc() SetUnique(lUniqueSetting)

setwipedynspace.param:
The logical value for setting WipeDynSpace on and off.
TRUE turns it on, FALSE turns it off.
Note that changing this setting will be enforced the next time the garbage collecter activates.
setwipedynspace.remarks: Allows the changing of the garbage collectors WipeDynSpace setting. The change made using this function will be enforced the next time the garbage collector is activated. Note: that this function was introduced in version 2.7 of X#. In previous versions this functionality was achieved using registry settings on each machine.

seval.summary: Execute a code block for each of the individual characters in a string.
seval.param: The code block to execute for each character encountered.
The starting character. A negative value starts from the end. The default value is 1 if <nCount> is positive and the length of <cString> if <nCount> is negative.
The number of characters to process from <nStart>. A negative value steps downward. The default is all characters to the end of the string.
seval.returns: A string of characters that have been processed by the code block.
seval.remarks: SEval() is a character function that evaluates a code block once for each character in a string, passing the ASCII value and the character index as arguments. The return value of the code block is ignored. All characters in <cString> are processed unless either the <nStart> or the <nCount> argument is specified. Refer to "Code Blocks" in the Programmer's Guide for more information on code blocks.
seval.example:
This example uses SEval() to extract the street number from a string containing the complete street address:
LOCAL cStreetNumber AS STRING LOCAL cAddress AS STRING cStreetNumber := NULL_STRING cAddress := "1209 West Golden Lane" SEval(cAddress, ; {|c| cStreetNumber += ; If(IsDigit(Chr(c)), Chr(c), NULL_STRING)}) ? cStreetNumber // 1209

sevala.summary: Execute a code block for each of the individual characters in a string, changing the contents of the argument as well as the return value.
sevala.param: The code block to execute for each character encountered.
The starting character. A negative value starts from the end. The default value is 1 if <nCount> is positive and the length of <cString> if <nCount> is negative.
The number of characters to process from <iStart>. A negative value steps downward. The default is all characters to the end of the string.
sevala.returns: A string of characters that have been processed by the code block.
sevala.remarks: SEvalA() is identical to SEval() in that they both evaluate a code block once for each character of a string, passing the ASCII value and the character index as arguments. The only difference is that, while SEval() ignores the return value of the code block, SEvalA() assigns the return value to the original string. See SEval() for details.
sevala.example:
This example uses SEvalA() to change part of a string to uppercase:
LOCAL cString cString := "He was doa." ? SEvalA(cString,; {|cChar| Asc(Upper(Chr(cCha-r)))}, 8, 3) // "He was DOA." ? cString // "He was DOA."

shellautocomplete.summary: Allow the user to select from the autosuggest list by pressing the TAB key
shellautocomplete.param: Ignore the registry default and force the autoappend feature off. This flag must be used in combination with one or more of the SHACF_FILESYS* or SHACF_URL* flags.

Ignore the registry value and force the autoappend feature on. The completed string will be displayed in the edit box with the added characters highlighted. This flag must be used in combination with one or more of the SHACF_FILESYS* or SHACF_URL* flags.
Ignore the registry default and force the autosuggest feature off. This flag must be used in combination with one or more of the SHACF_FILESYS* or SHACF_URL* flags.

Ignore the registry value and force the autosuggest feature on. A selection of possible completed strings will be displayed as a drop-down list, below the edit box. This flag must be used in combination with one or more of the SHACF_FILESYS* or SHACF_URL* flags.
The default setting, equivalent to SHACF_FILESYSTEM | SHACF_URLALL. SHACF_DEFAULT cannot be combined with any other flags.
Include the URLs in the users History and Recently Used lists. Equivalent to
Include the URLs in the user's History list.
Include the URLs in the user's Recently Used list.

Allow the user to select from the autosuggest list by pressing the TAB key. If this flag is not set, pressing the TAB key will shift focus to the next control and close the autosuggest list. If SHACF_USETAB is set, pressing the TAB key will select the first item in the list. Pressing TAB again will select the next item in the list, and so on. When the user reaches the end of the list, the next TAB key press will cycle the focus back to the edit control. This flag must be used in combination with one or more of the SHACF_FILESYS* or SHACF_URL* flags.

remarks.note: This will require version 5.0 or later of the shlwapi.dll The supported operating systems are Windows 2000, Windows NT 4.0 with Internet Explorer 5, Windows 98, Windows 95 with Internet Explorer 5 This will require the inclusion of the OLE library or a call to CoInitialize(NULL) for AutoComplete. CoInitialize will make a call to CoUninit later.

showbitmap.summary: Display a bitmap in a window or control.
showbitmap.param: Handle of the window or control in which you want to display the bitmap.
Caption for the window or control.
showbitmap.remarks: This function allows you to display a bitmap in a window or a control.

sin.summary: Calculate the sine of a number.
sin.returns: The sine of the specified angle.
sin.example: This example uses Sin() to calculate the sine of 2.7: ? Sin(2.7) // 0.43 This example finds the sine of a 60 degree angle. The first step is to convert 60 degrees to radians. This is done by dividing the angle by 180/PI: ? Sin(60/(180/PI)) // 0.87

slen.summary: Return the length of a strongly typed string.
slen.returns: The length of a string. If the string is a NULL_STRING, SLen() returns 0.
slen.remarks: SLen() is a typed version of Len(). See Len() for a complete description.
slen.example:
This example shows how to use strong typing to determine the length of a string:
LOCAL cName AS STRING cName := "William Shakespeare" ? SLen(cName) // 19

soundex.summary: Convert a string to Soundex form.
soundex.returns: A 4-digit string starting with an alphabetic character and ending with three digits.
soundex.remarks: Soundex() is a character function that indexes and searches for sound-alike or phonetic matches. It is used in applications where the precise spelling of character keys is not known or where there is a high probability of misspelled names. Misspelling is common in real-time transaction systems where the data entry operator is receiving information over the telephone. Soundex() works by bringing sound-alikes together under the same key value. Note, however, the soundex method is not absolute. Keys that are quite different can result in the same soundex value.
soundex.example:
This example builds an order using Soundex() to create the key values. It then searches for a value found in the Salesman field:
USE sales INDEX ON Soundex(Salesman) TO salesman SEEK Soundex("Smith") ? Found(), salesman // TRUE Smith
Here, a search is made for the same key as above but with a different spelling:
SEEK Soundex("Smythe") ? Found(), salesman // TRUE Smith

space.param: The number of spaces to return, up to a maximum of MAX_ALLOC byes. If <dwSize> is 0, Space() returns a NULL_STRING.
space.remarks: Space() is similar to Buffer() but uses an initialization character of " ". If an initialization character is not needed, Buffer() is more efficient. Space() is also the same as Replicate(" ", <dwCount>).

splitpath.summary: Break a path name into its components.
splitpath.param: The drive letter followed by a colon. <pszDrive> must contain 2 bytes, plus 1 byte for the terminating _Chr(0) character.

The directories, including the trailing slash. Forward slashes and backslashes both may be present in <pszFile>. Forward slashes (/) are converted to backslashes (\). <pszDir> must contain 255 bytes, plus 1 byte for the terminating _Chr(0) character.
The file name, without the extension. <pszFile> must contain 255 bytes, plus 1 byte for the terminating _Chr(0) character.
The extension, including the leading period. <pszExt> must contain 7 bytes, plus 1 byte for the terminating _Chr(0) character.
splitpath.remarks: SplitPath() breaks a path name into its components and stores the result in the supplied arguments. The supplied arguments must have enough space to hold the maximum possible size of the broken components. If any of the components is missing in the path name, the corresponding argument is truncated to a 0 length.
splitpath.example:
This example breaks a full path name into its four components:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL cDrive, cDir, cFile, cExt AS STRING MySplitPath("c:\develop\myprg\hello.prg", ; @cDrive, @cDir, @cFile, @cExt) ? cDrive // C: ? cDir // \DEVELOP\MYPRG ? cFile // HELLO ? cExt // .PRG FUNCTION MySplitPath(cPath AS STRING, ; cDrive REF STRING, ; cDir REF STRING, ; cFile REF STRING, ; cExt REF STRING) LOCAL pszPath, pszDrive, pszDir AS PSZ LOCAL pszFile, pszExt AS PSZ LOCAL cb pszPath := MemAlloc(cb := SLen(cPath) + 1) MemCopy(pszPath, PTR(_CAST, cPath), cb) pszDrive := MemAlloc(2+1) pszDir := MemAlloc(255+1) pszFile := MemAlloc(255+1) pszExt := MemAlloc(7+1) SplitPath(cPath, pszDrive, pszDir, ; pszFile, pszExt) cDrive := Psz2String(pszDrive) cDir := Psz2String(pszDir) cFile := Psz2String(pszFile) cExt := Psz2String(pszExt) MemFree(pszDrive) MemFree(pszDir) MemFree(pszFile) MemFree(pszExt) RETURN
This example shows that the supplied argument is truncated to 0 length if its corresponding component is missing in the path name:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL cDrive, cDir, cFile, cExt AS STRING MySplitPath("c:\develop\myprg\hello", ; @cDrive, @cDir, @cFile, @cExt) ? cDrive // C: ? cDir // \DEVELOP\MYPRG ? cFile // HELLO ? SLen(cExt) // 0

sqlconnecterrormsg.summary: Return and optionally change the setting that determines whether to display connection error messages.
sqlconnecterrormsg.param: TRUE enables the connection error message; FALSE disables the connection error message. The initial default is TRUE.
sqlconnecterrormsg.returns: If <lNewSetting> is not specified, SQLConnectErrorMsg() returns the current setting. If <lNewSetting> is specified, the previous setting is returned.
sqlconnecterrormsg.remarks: If SQLConnectErrorMsg() is set to FALSE, connection error messages are not displayed. If SQLConnectErrorMsg() is set to TRUE, which is the default, a connection error message is displayed in a message box.

sqldropmyconnection.param: The user id that was used to connect to the source.
The password that was used to connect to the source.
sqldropmyconnection.returns: TRUE if a connection is found; otherwise FALSE.
sqldropmyconnection.remarks: If a connection is found, the use count is decremented by 1. When the use count is 1, the source is disconnected.
sqldropmyconnection.example:
The following example connects to WATCOM; then ends the connection:
FUNCTION TestConnect() LOCAL oConn AS SQLConnection oConn := SQLGetMyConnection("sample", "dba", "sql") ? "SRC=",oConn:DataSource ? "UID=",oConn:UserID ? "PWD=",oConn:Password SQLDropMyConnection("sample", "dba", "sql")

sqlgetdatasources.summary: Identify the available ODBC data sources.
sqlgetdatasources.returns: An array of strings identifying the available ODBC data sources. If no sources are available, SQLGetDataSources() returns a NULL_ARRAY.

sqlgetmyconnection.summary: Connect to the ODBC source specified.
sqlgetmyconnection.param: The user ID that will be used to connect to the source.
The password that will be used to connect to the source.
sqlgetmyconnection.returns: If a connection to the source is found, it is returned as an SQLConnection object. If a connection is not found, one is created and returned as an object.
sqlgetmyconnection.remarks: SQLGetMyConnection is used in the code generated from the SQL editor. It allows a connection to be shared among multiple servers in the same task.
sqlgetmyconnection.example:
The following example connects to WATCOM; then ends the connection:
FUNCTION TestConnect() LOCAL oConn AS SQLConnection oConn := SQLGetMyConnection("sample", "dba", "sql") ? "SRC=",oConn:DataSource ? "UID=",oConn:UserID ? "PWD=",oConn:Password SQLDropMyConnection("sample", "dba", "sql")

sqlopenconnection.summary: Connect to a list of ODBC sources.
sqlopenconnection.remarks: SQLOpenConnection() displays a dialog box listing all of the sources that have been installed and prompts you to select one.

sqlsetconnection.summary: Return and optionally change the default SQL connection.
sqlsetconnection.param: The default SQL connection that will be used by any function or class that requires a connection.
sqlsetconnection.returns: If <oNewSetting> is not specified, SQLSetConnection() returns the current setting. If <oNewSetting> is specified, the new setting is returned.
sqlsetconnection.remarks: If <oNewSetting> is not specified and there is no previous or default connection, SQLSetConnection() calls SQLOpenConnection(), sets that connection as the default, and returns it.

sqlsetstmtconcurrency.summary: Return and optionally change the default concurrency mode for SQLSelect objects
sqlsetstmtconcurrency.param: The default concurrency strategy that will be used by new SqlSelect objects
sqlsetstmtconcurrency.returns: If <nNewSetting> is not specified, SQLSetStmtConcurrency() returns the current setting. If <nNewSetting> is specified, the new setting is returned.
sqlsetstmtconcurrency.remarks: The concurrency mode for SQLSelect objects is used to determine if rows have been changed by other connections. The possible values are: Constant Description SQL_CONCUR_READ_ONLY Cursor is read-only. No updates are allowed SQL_CONCUR_LOCK Cursor uses the lowest level of locking sufficient to ensure that the row can be updated SQL_CONCUR_ROWVER Cursor uses optimistic concurrency control, comparing row versions such as SQLBase ROWID or Sybase TIMESTAMP SQL_CONCUR_VALUES Cursor uses optimistic concurrency control, comparing values The default value used by X# is SQL_CONCUR_ROWVER

sqlsetstmtcursortype.summary: Return and optionally change the default cursor type used by for SQLSelect objects
sqlsetstmtcursortype.param: The default concurrency strategy that will be used by new SqlSelect objects
sqlsetstmtcursortype.returns: If <nNewSetting> is not specified, SQLSetStmtCursorType() returns the current setting. If <nNewSetting> is specified, the new setting is returned.
sqlsetstmtcursortype.remarks: The concurrency mode for SQLSelect objects is used to determine if rows have been changed by other connections. The possible values are: Constant Description SQL_CURSOR_FORWARD_ONLY The cursor only scrolls forward SQL_CURSOR_KEYSET_DRIVEN The driver saves and uses the keys for the number of rows specified in the SQL_ATTR_KEYSET_SIZE statement attribute SQL_CURSOR_DYNAMIC The driver saves and uses only the keys for the rows in the rowset. SQL_CURSOR_STATIC The data in the result set is static The default value used by X# is SQL_CURSOR_KEYSET_DRIVEN

sqlsetstmtsimulatecursor.summary: Return and optionally change the default cursor simulation mode used by for SQLSelect objects
sqlsetstmtsimulatecursor.param: The default cursor simulation mode that will be used by new SqlSelect objects
sqlsetstmtsimulatecursor.returns: If <nNewSetting> is not specified, SQLSetStmtSimulateCursor() returns the current setting. If <nNewSetting> is specified, the new setting is returned.
sqlsetstmtsimulatecursor.remarks: The cursor simulation mode for SQLSelect objects is used to determine if rows have been changed by other connections. The possible values are: Constant Description SQL_SC_NON_UNIQUE The driver does not guarantee that simulated positioned update or delete statements will affect only one row; it is the application's responsibility to do so. If a statement affects more than one row, SQLExecute, SQLExecDirect, or SQLSetPos returns SQLSTATE 01001 (Cursor operation conflict). SQL_SC_TRY_UNIQUE The driver attempts to guarantee that simulated positioned update or delete statements affect only one row. The driver always executes such statements, even if they might affect more than one row, such as when there is no unique key. If a statement affects more than one row, SQLExecute, SQLExecDirect, or SQLSetPos returns SQLSTATE 01001 (Cursor operation conflict). SQL_SC_UNIQUE The driver guarantees that simulated positioned update or delete statements affect only one row. If the driver cannot guarantee this for a given statement, SQLExecDirect or SQLPrepare returns an error The default value used by X# is SQL_SC_TRY_UNIQUE

sqrt.summary: Return the square root of a positive number.
sqrt.param: A positive number to take the square root of. A negative <nNumber> returns 0.
sqrt.returns: The number of decimal places displayed is determined solely by SetDecimal() regardless of SetFixed().
sqrt.remarks: SqRt() can be used anywhere in a numeric calculation to compute a square root (for example, in an expression that calculates standard deviation).
sqrt.example:
These examples show various results of SqRt():
SetDecimal(5) ? SQRT(2) // 1.41421 ? SQRT(4) // 2.00000 ? SQRT(4) ^ 2 // 4.00000 ? SQRT(2) ^ 2 // 2.00000

stod.summary: Convert an ANSI date string to date format.
stod.param: A date in the ANSI format yyyymmdd. The century digits must be specified. If <cDate> contains more than the eight characters required for the date, the extra characters are ignored.
stod.returns: A date in the current SetDateFormat() or SET DATE format. If <cDate> is not a valid ANSI date, a NULL_DATE is returned.
stod.remarks: SToD() is a date function that converts an ANSI date created by the DToS() function back into the standard date format.
stod.example:
This example displays the ANSI date in default date format:
? SToD("19981028") // 10/28/98 ? SToD("981028") // NULL_DATE ? SToD("19981028extra") // 10/28/98

str.summary: Convert a numeric expression to a string.
str.param: The numeric expression to convert to a string.

The length of the string to return, including decimal digits, decimal point, and sign.
A value of -1 specifies that any right padding is suppressed. However, decimal places are still returned as specified in <nDecimals>.
If <nLength> is not specified, SetDigit() and SetDigitFixed() determine the number of digits that are returned.

The number of decimal places in the return value. A value of -1 specifies that only the significant digits to the right of the decimal point are returned (see example below). The number of whole digits in the return value, however, are still determined by the <nLength> argument.
If <nDecimals> is not specified, SetDecimal() and SetFixed() determine the number of decimals that are returned.
The representation of the decimal point is determined by the current setting of SetDecimalSep().
str.returns: A string, with these exceptions: If <nNumber> is an expression that yields a numeric overflow, a runtime error is generated that could be handled by the currently installed error handler. Either "+INF" or "-INF", which represent the biggest possible float number, is returned by the error handler. If <nLength> is less than the number of whole number digits in <nNumber>, the result will be in scientific notation. If the result of scientific notation does not fit, a series of asterisk is returned. Rounding is determined as follows: If <nLength> is less than the number of decimal digits required for the decimal portion of the returned string, the return value is rounded to the available number of decimal places. If <nLength> is specified, but <nDecimals> is omitted (no decimal places), the return value is rounded to an integer. If <nLength> and <nDecimals> are not specified, they are taken out of the internal float format inside the FLOAT, or out of SetDigit() if the internal digit number is 0. If SetFixed() or SetDigitFixed() is TRUE, these values are overridden by the values of SetDecimal() or SetDigit(). If SetScience() is TRUE, the return will be in scientific notation. Moreover, If SetDigit() specifies a number that is less than the number of whole number digits in <nNumber> and SetDigitFixed() is set to TRUE, the result is in scientific notation. But if scientific notation does not fit, the result is a series of asterisks.
str.remarks: Str() is commonly used to concatenate numbers to strings. Thus, it is useful for creating codes for items, such as part numbers, from numbers and for creating order keys that combine numeric and character data. Str() is like Transform(), which formats numbers as strings using a mask instead of length and decimal specifications. The inverse of Str() is Val() which converts numbers formatted as strings to numeric values.
str.example:
These examples demonstrate the range of values returned by Str(), depending on the arguments specified:
nNumber := 123.45 ? Str(nNumber) // 123.45 ? Str(nNumber, 4) // 123. ? Str(nNumber, 2) // ** ? Str(nNumber * 10, 7, 2) // 1234.50 ? Str(nNumber * 10, 12, 4) // 1234.5000 ? Str(nNumber, 10, 1) // 123.5 ? Str(123.45, -1) // 123.45 ? Str(123.45, -1, 2) // 123.45 ? Str(0.45000, 12, -1) // 0.45000
Often two numbers display the same results, but internally they have two different values stored in them. Thus an equality test will fail (return FALSE) unless you round each side. Here is an example:
? nNum // displays identical to MyFunction() below ? MyFunction() // displays identical to nNum above // but internally they are not equal ? nNum = MyFunction() // FALSE // after rounding they are equal ? Round(nNum, 0) == Round(MyFunction(), 0) // TRUE // a Val(Str()) is also rounding ? Val(Str(nNum)) = Val(Str(MyFunction())) // TRUE
Setting SetFloatDelta() to a higher value than before has the same effect:
SetFloatDelta(0.1) ? nNum == MyFunction() // TRUE
This functions returns a string of all asterisks when the Decimals parameter is > 0 and the Decimals parameter is > Length-2. Also a string of all asterisks is returned when the number does NOT fit into the allocated space. Example:
? Str(9,6,6) => "******" ? Str(9,6,5) => "******" ? Str(9,6,4) => "9.0000" ? Str(9,6,3) => " 9.000" ? Str(10,6,6) => "******" ? Str(10,6,5) => "******" ? Str(10,6,4) => "******" ? Str(10,6,3) => "10.000"
This example uses Str() to create an order with a compound key of order numbers and customer names:
USE customer NEW INDEX ON Str(NumOrders, 9) + Custname TO custord

str1.summary: Convert a numeric expression to a string.
str1.remarks: Str1() is a typed version of the Str() numeric function. See Str() for a detailed description.
str1.example:
This example shows how to use Str1() to convert a number to a string:
LOCAL fNumber AS FLOAT fNumber := 123.45 ? Str1(fNumber) // 123.45

str2.summary: Convert a numeric expression to a string of a specified length.
str2.param: The length of the string to return, including decimal digits, decimal point, and sign. If <siLength> is not long enough to hold the entire number, the result will be in scientific notation.
str2.remarks: Str2() is a typed version of the Str() numeric function where both arguments are mandatory. See Str() for a detailed description.
str2.example:
These examples show how to use Str2() to change a number to a string:
LOCAL fNumber AS FLOAT fNumber := 123.45 ? Str2(fNumber, 4) // 123. ? Str2(fNumber, 2) // **

str3.summary: Convert a numeric expression to a string of specific length and decimal places.
str3.param: The length of the string to return, including decimal digits, decimal point, and sign. If <dwLength> is not long enough to hold the entire number, the result will be in scientific notation.
The number of decimal places to return.
str3.remarks: Str3() is a typed version of the Str() numeric function where all three arguments are mandatory. See Str() for a detailed description.
str3.example:
These examples show how to use Str3() to change a number to a string:
LOCAL fNumber AS FLOAT fNumber := 123.45 ? Str3(fNumber, 10, 1) // 123.5 ? Str3(fNumber * 10, 7, 2) // 1234.50 ? Str3(fNumber * 10, 12, 4) // 1234.5000
This functions returns a string of all asterisks when the Decimals parameter is > 0 and the Decimals parameter is > Length-2. Also a string of all asterisks is returned when the number does NOT fit into the allocated space. Example:
? Str(9,6,6) => "******" ? Str(9,6,5) => "******" ? Str(9,6,4) => "9.0000" ? Str(9,6,3) => " 9.000" ? Str(10,6,6) => "******" ? Str(10,6,5) => "******" ? Str(10,6,4) => "******" ? Str(10,6,3) => "10.000"

stretchbitmap.summary: Display a bitmap stretched or shrunk to fit a window or control.
stretchbitmap.param: Handle of the window or control in which you want to display the bitmap.
Caption for the window or control.
stretchbitmap.remarks: This function allows you to stretch or shrink a bitmap to fit the current window or control size, and then displays that bitmap.

strevaluate.summary: Allows text substitution in strings entered at runtime.
strevaluate.param: A string containing one or more macro variables to expand.
strevaluate.returns: The new string, after all macro substitutions have taken place.
strevaluate.example:
This example demonstrates StrEvaluate() on a string entered at runtime that contains a macro variable:
MEMVAR cOne LOCAL cTwo AS STRING cOne := "world" ACCEPT "Enter a macro string " TO cTwo // If you type "Hello &cOne" (without quotes) ? cTwo // Result: "Hello &cOne" ? StrEvaluate(cTwo) // Result: "Hello world"

strfloat.summary: Convert a float expression to a PSZ.
strfloat.param: The length of the string to return, including decimal digits, decimal point, and sign. If <dwLength> is not long enough to hold the entire number, the result will be in scientific notation.
The number of decimal places to return.
strfloat.remarks: StrFloat() is a typed version of the Str() numeric function, except that SetDecimalSep() is ignored. See Str() for a detailed description.
strfloat.example:
These examples demonstrate the range of values returned by StrFloat(), depending on the arguments specified:
LOCAL fNumber AS FLOAT fNumber := 123.45 ? StrFloat(fNumber * 10, 7, 2) // 1234.50 ? StrFloat(fNumber * 10, 12, 4) // 1234.5000 ? StrFloat(fNumber, 10, 1) // 1234.5

string2atom.summary: Convert a string to a symbol.
string2atom.returns: A symbol which is added to the atom table if it is not already there.
string2atom.remarks: String2Atom() and its counterpart Symbol2String() allow you to manipulate symbols to a more desirable or convenient form.
string2atom.example:
This example uses String2Atom() to assign the contents of a string to a symbol:
LOCAL cMyName AS STRING LOCAL symMyName AS SYMBOL cMyName := "Josie" symMyName : = String2Atom(cMyName) ? symMyName // Josie
This example shows the differences between String2Atom() and String2Symbol(), which yields the symbol in uppercase:
? String2Atom("Hello") = String2Symbol("Hello") // FALSE ? String2Atom("HELLO") = String2Symbol("Hello") // TRUE

string2psz.summary: Convert a strongly typed string to a null-terminated string.
string2psz.returns: A non-zero PSZ if successful; otherwise, NULL_PSZ.
string2psz.remarks: String2Psz() is useful for many Windows or DLL functions that require a PSZ in their argument list. It checks whether <cString> is a NULL_STRING. If this is the case, String2Psz() returns a static pointer to a byte containing 0x00. Otherwise, it allocates a buffer within static memory, copies the string content to it, and returns the pointer to this buffer. The pointer becomes a hidden local variable. If the appropriate function or method, which called String2Psz(), goes out of scope, the allocated buffer will be freed up automatically. Furthermore, the pointer is no longer valid. Warning! Do not use String2Psz() to initialize global variables!
string2psz.example:
The following example uses the Win32 API function GetDriveType(). It shows three different ways to create the required PSZ argument:
LOCAL cDrive AS STRING LOCAL nType AS INT cDrive := Upper(CurDrive()) + ":" // Version 1: Slow, copy of cDrive created nType := GetDriveType( String2Psz(cDrive) ) // Version 2: Better, no copy of cDrive created nType := GetDriveType( Cast2Psz(cDrive) ) // Version 3: Best performance, no function call at all // But: No check for NULL_STRING nType := GetDriveType( PSZ(_CAST, cDrive) ) DO CASE CASE nType = DRIVE_REMOTE ? cDrive + " is a network drive" CASE nType = DRIVE_CDROM ? cDrive + " is a CD-ROM" CASE nType = DRIVE_REMOVABLE ? cDrive + " is a floppy or zip drive" CASE nType = DRIVE_FIXED ? cDrive + " is a fixed drive" CASE nType = DRIVE_RAMDISK ? cDrive + " is a RAM disk" ENDCASE

string2symbol.summary: Convert a string to an uppercase symbol.
string2symbol.returns: The symbol in uppercase. This symbol is added to the atom table if it is not already there.
string2symbol.remarks: String2Symbol() changes the argument to uppercase before converting it. It is the same as using a literal symbol.
string2symbol.example:
This example uses String2Symbol() to assign the contents of a string to a symbol:
LOCAL cMyName AS STRING LOCAL symMyName AS SYMBOL cMyName := "Josie" symMyName : = String2Symbol(cMyName) ? symMyName // JOSIE
This example shows the similarities between String2Symbol() and the # sign which identifies a symbol:
? String2Symbol("Hello") = #Hello // TRUE ? String2Symbol("HELLO") = #Hello // TRUE
This example shows the differences between String2Symbol() and String2Atom(), which does not change the case:
? String2Atom("Hello") = String2Symbol("Hello") // FALSE ? String2Atom("HELLO") = String2Symbol("Hello") // TRUE

stringalloc.summary: Copy a string to a newly allocated block of memory and return a PSZ to the memory.
stringalloc.returns: A pointer to the newly allocated string.
stringalloc.remarks: StringAlloc() makes a copy of a string. The new copy is a PSZ and points to a different address from the original string. The newly allocated string is a static object which will not be moved by the garbage collector. Note that storage allocated by StringAlloc() must be removed by MemFree().
stringalloc.example:
This example displays the storage addresses of two variables:
LOCAL pszString AS PSZ LOCAL cString AS STRING cString := "CAVO2x tree" pszString := StringAlloc(cString) ? @cString ? @pszString // Has different storage address than cString MemFree(pszString)

strint.summary: Convert an integer expression to a PSZ.
strint.param: The length of the string to return, including decimal digits, decimal point, and sign. If <dwLength> is not long enough to hold the entire number, the result will be in scientific notation.
The number of decimal places to return.
strint.remarks: StrInt() is a typed version of the Str() numeric function, except that SetDecimalSep() is ignored. See Str() for a detailed description.
strint.example:
These examples demonstrate the range of values returned by StrInt(), depending on the arguments specified:
LOCAL iNumber AS INT iNumber := 123 ? StrInt(iNumber,10, 0) // 123 ? StrInt(iNumber, 4, 0) // 123 ? StrInt(iNumber, 2, 0) // **

strlong.summary: Convert a long integer expression to a PSZ.
strlong.param: The long integer expression to convert.
The length of the string to return, including decimal digits, decimal point, and sign. If <dwLength> is not long enough to hold the entire number, the result will be in scientific notation.
The number of decimal places to return.
strlong.remarks: StrLong() is a typed version of the Str() numeric function, except that SetDecimalSep() is ignored. See Str() for a detailed description.
strlong.example:
These examples demonstrate the range of values returned by StrLong(), depending on the arguments specified:
LOCAL liNumber AS LONGINT liNumber := 12345L ? StrLong(liNumber, 5, 0) // "12345" ? StrLong(liNumber, 4, 0) // "****" ? StrLong(liNumber, 2, 10) // "**" ? StrLong(liNumber * 10, 7, 2) // "****.**" ? StrLong(liNumber * 10, 12, 4) // " 123450.0000" ? StrLong(liNumber, 10, 1) // " 12345.0"

strtran.summary: Search and replace characters within a string.
strtran.param: The string in which to search.

The substring for which to search. All occurrences of <uSearch> are replaced unless <uStart> or <uCount> is specified. Note that StrTran() replaces substrings and, therefore, does not account for whole words.
The substring with which to replace <cSearch>. If this argument is not specified, <cSearch> is replaced with a NULL_STRING.
The first occurrence to replace. If this argument is omitted or 0, the default is 1.
The number of occurrences to replace. If this argument is not specified, the default is all.
strtran.returns: A new string with the specified occurrences of <uSearch> replaced by <uReplace>.
strtran.example:
This example uses StrTran() to convert a postmodern analog to a famous quotation:
cString := "To compute or not to compute?" ? StrTran(cString, "compute", "be") // To be or not to be?

strzero.summary: Convert a numeric expression to a string and pad it with leading zeroes instead of blanks.
strzero.param: The numeric expression to convert to a string.
The length of the string to return, including zeroes, decimal digits, decimal point, and sign.
The number of decimal places in the return value.
strzero.remarks: StrZero() is useful in displaying numbers, creating codes such as part numbers from numeric values, and creating order keys that combine numeric and character data. StrZero() is similar to the Str() function except that the padding character is a zero ("0") instead of a blank. For more information, see the Str() function.
strzero.example: This example uses StrZero() to convert a 3-digit number to a 5-character string: ? StrZero(987, 5, 0) // "00987"

stuff.summary: Delete and insert characters in a string.
stuff.param: The string into which characters are inserted and deleted.
The position in <cTarget> where the insertion/deletion occurs.
The number of characters to delete.
stuff.returns: <cTarget> with the specified characters deleted and <cInsert> inserted.
stuff.remarks: Stuff() first deletes characters from <cTarget>, then inserts characters into the resulting string to form the return string. Stuff() can perform the following six operations: Insert: If <dwDelete> is 0, no characters are removed from <cTarget>. <cInsert> is then inserted at <dwStart>, and the entire string is returned. For example, Stuff("My dog has fleas.", 12, 0, "no ") returns "My dog has no fleas." Replace: If <cInsert> is the same length as <dwDelete>, <cInsert> replaces characters beginning at <dwStart>. The same number of characters are deleted as are inserted, and the resulting string is the same length as the original. For example, Stuff("My dog has fleas.", 12, 5, "bones") returns "My dog has bones." Delete: If <cInsert> is a NULL_STRING, the number of characters specified by <dwDelete> are removed from <cTarget>, and the string is returned without any added characters. For example, Stuff("My dog has fleas.", 1, 3, NULL_STRING) returns "dog has fleas." Replace and insert: If <cInsert> is longer than <dwDelete>, all characters from <dwStart> up to <dwDelete> are replaced and the rest of <cInsert> is inserted. Since more characters are inserted than are deleted, the resulting string is always longer than the original. For example, Stuff("My dog has fleas.", 8, 3, "does not have") returns "My dog does not have fleas." Replace and delete: If the length of <cInsert> is less than <dwDelete>, more characters are deleted than inserted. The resulting string, therefore, is shorter than the original. For example, Stuff("My dog has fleas.", 8, 3, "is") returns "My dog is fleas." Replace and delete rest: If <dwDelete> is greater than or equal to the number of characters remaining in <cTarget> beginning with <dwStart>, all remaining characters are deleted before <cInsert> is inserted. For example, Stuff("My dog has fleas.", 8, 10, "is.") returns "My dog is."

substr.summary: Extract a substring from a string.
substr.param: The string from which to extract a substring.

The starting position in <cTarget>. If <wStart> is positive, it is relative to the leftmost character in <cTarget>. If <nStart> is negative, it is relative to the rightmost character in <cTarget>. If <nStart> is zero, a NULL_STRING is returned.

The number of characters to extract. If omitted, the substring begins at <nStart> and continues to the end of the string. If <nCount> is greater than the number of characters from <nStart> to the end of <cTarget>, the extra is ignored.
substr.returns: The substring. If the substring is not present, a NULL_STRING is returned.
substr.remarks: Substr() is related to the Left() and Right() functions, which extract substrings beginning with leftmost and rightmost characters in <cTarget>, respectively. The Substr(), Right(), and Left() functions are often used with both the At() and RAt() functions to locate either the first and/or the last position of a substring before extracting it. They are also used to display or print only a portion of a string.
substr.example:
These examples extract the first and last name from a variable:
cName := "Biff Styvesent" ? Substr(cName, 1, 4) // Biff ? Substr(cName, 6) // Styvesent ? Substr(cName, SLen(cName) + 2) // Null string ? Substr(cName, -9) // Styvesent ? Substr(cName, -9, 3) // Sty
This example uses Substr() with At() and RAt() to create a function to extract a file name from a file specification:
? FileBase("c:\prg\myfile.obj") // myfile.obj FUNCTION FileBase(cFile) LOCAL nPos AS DWORD IF (nPos := RAt("\", cFile)) != 0 cFile := Substr(cFile, nPos + 1) ELSEIF (nPos := At(":", cFile)) != 0 cFile := Substr(cFile, nPos + 1) ENDIF RETURN cFile

substr2.summary: Extract a substring from a string, using strong typing and only two arguments.
substr2.param: The string from which to extract a substring.
The starting position in <cTarget>. Since this argument is a WORD, it cannot be negative.
substr2.returns: The substring. If the substring is not found, a NULL_STRING is returned.
substr2.remarks: Substr2() is a typed version of Substr(). See Substr() for details.
substr2.example:
These examples extract part of a name:
LOCAL cName AS STRING cName := "Biff Styvesent" ? Substr2(cName, 6) // Styvesent ? Substr2(cName, SLen(cName) + 2) // null string
This example uses Substr2() with At() and RAt() to create a function to extract a file name from a file specification:
? FileBase("c:\prg\myfile.obj") // myfile.obj FUNCTION FileBase(cFile) LOCAL nPos AS DWORD IF (nPos := RAt("\", cFile)) != 0 cFile := Substr2(cFile, nPos + 1) ELSEIF (nPos := At(":", cFile)) != 0 cFile := Substr2(cFile, nPos + 1) ENDIF RETURN cFile

substr3.summary: Extract a substring from a string, using strong typing and three required arguments.
substr3.param: The string from which to extract a substring.
The starting position in <cTarget>. Since this argument is a WORD, it cannot be negative.

The number of characters to extract. If omitted, the substring begins at <dwStart> and continues to the end of the string. If <dwLen> is greater than the number of characters from <dwStart> to the end of <cTarget>, the extra is ignored.
substr3.returns: The substring. If the substring is not found, it returns a NULL_STRING.
substr3.remarks: Substr3() is a typed version of Substr() and requires three arguments. See Substr() for details.
substr3.example:
These examples extract the first and last name from a variable:
LOCAL cName AS STRING cName := "Biff Styvesent" ? Substr3(cName, 1, 4) // Biff ? Substr3(cName, 6, 9) // Styvesent ? Substr3(cName, 6, 3) // Sty ? Substr3(cName, SLen(cName) + 2, 5) // null string

swapbyte.summary: Exchange the right and left halves of a byte.
swapbyte.param: The byte whose nibbles you want to swap.
swapbyte.returns: The byte value with swapped nibbles.
swapbyte.remarks: SwapByte() swaps the right nibble of a byte with the left nibble of a byte and returns the result. (A nibble is 4 bits, which is half of a byte.)
swapbyte.example: This example uses SwapByte() on the character "A". The ASCII value of "A" is 65. Thus, its binary representation is 0100 0001. Swapping it gives 0001 0100. Therefore, an ASCII value of 20 is returned. ? SwapByte(Asc("A"))

swapdword.summary: Exchange the right and left halves of a double word.
swapdword.param: The double word value whose words you want to swap.
swapdword.remarks: SwapDWord() swaps the right half of a double word with the left half of a double word and returns the result. The sign may not be preserved during the swap.
swapdword.example:
This example uses SwapDWord():
bHex := 0x23CACE ? SwapDWord(bHex) // returns 3402498083

swapint.summary: Exchange the right and left halves of an integer.
swapint.param: The integer whose bytes you want to swap.
swapint.remarks: SwapInt() swaps the right half of an integer with the left half of an integer and returns the result. The sign may not be preserved during the swap.

swaplong.summary: Exchange the right and left halves of a long integer.
swaplong.param: The long integer whose words you want to swap.
swaplong.remarks: SwapLong() swaps the right half of a long integer with the left half of a long integer and returns the result. The sign may not be preserved after the swap.

swapshort.summary: Exchange the right and left halves of a short integer.
swapshort.param: The short integer whose bytes you want to swap.
swapshort.remarks: SwapShort() swaps the right half of a short integer with the left half of a short integer and returns the result. The sign may not be preserved after the swap.

swapword.summary: Exchange the right and left halves of a word.
swapword.param: The word whose bytes you want to swap.
swapword.remarks: SwapWord() swaps the right half of a word with the left half of a word and returns the result.
swapword.example:
This example uses SwapWord():
aHex := 0xAB00 ? SwapWord(aHex) // returns 171

symbol2string.summary: Convert a symbol to a string.
symbol2string.remarks: The operations available for symbols are limited due to their storage mechanism — you can only compare them and manipulate their functions. Using Symbol2String() to convert symbols to strings gives them access to all of the string operations.
symbol2string.example:
This example uses Symbol2String() to convert a symbol to a string so it can be used in string comparisons. Since the symbol is a literal symbol, the scanner converts it to uppercase:
LOCAL cMyName AS STRING LOCAL symMemoName AS SYMBOL cMyName := Symbol2String(#symMemoName) ? cMyName // Result: SYMMEMONAME IF "MEMO" $ cMyName ? "Symbol name contains the string MEMO" ENDIF

sysaddatom.summary: Convert a null-terminated string to a symbol and add it to the atom table.
sysaddatom.param: A pointer to the null-terminated string to convert.
sysaddatom.returns: A symbol which is added to the atom table if it is not already there.

remarks.note: Although literal symbols are converted to uppercase letters, symbols created using SysAddAtom() are not; SysAddAtom() preserves the casing of letters as specified in the function argument. SysAddAtomUpperA(), on the other hand, converts its argument to uppercase and creates the resulting symbol in uppercase, the same way a literal symbol does.

sysaddatom.example:
This example uses SysAddAtom() to convert names to symbols and illustrates how the return value from MaxAtom() increases by one as each string is converted, thus adding to the number of symbols currently in use: (The last conversion does not add to the number of symbols because "Charly" was added to the symbol table earlier).
SysAddAtom("Vera") // Convert Vera ? MaxAtom() // 7531 SysAddAtom("Charly") // Convert Charly ? MaxAtom() // 7532 SysAddAtom("Odile") // Convert Odile ? MaxAtom() // 7533 SysAddAtom("Charly") // Convert Charly ? MaxAtom() // Still 7533

sysaddatomuppera.summary: Convert a null-terminated string to an uppercase symbol and add it to the atom table.
sysaddatomuppera.returns: An uppercase symbol which is added to the atom table if it is not already there.
sysaddatomuppera.remarks: SysAddAtomUpperA() converts its argument to uppercase and creates the resulting symbol in uppercase, the same way a literal symbol does. SysAddAtom(), on the other hand, preserves the casing of letters as specified in the function argument.
sysaddatomuppera.example:
This example uses SysAddAtomUpperA:
LOCAL pszC := "Hello" AS PSZ ? SysAddAtomUpperA(pszC) // HELLO ? pszC // "HELLO"

sysfindatom.summary: Determine whether a symbol is in the atom table.
sysfindatom.param: The string that corresponds to the symbol you are checking on.
sysfindatom.returns: If found, the symbol value corresponding to the string is returned. If not found, a symbol value corresponding to a non-existing symbol, WORD(_CAST,65535), is returned.
sysfindatom.example:
This example uses SysFindAtom() and type casting to determine whether the string "Charly" exists:
IF Word(_CAST, SysFindAtom("Charly")) ; = Word(_CAST, 65535) ? "Charly was not found" ELSE ? "Charly was found" ENDIF

sysgetatomname.summary: Convert a symbol to a null-terminated string.
sysgetatomname.example:
This example uses SysGetAtomName() to convert a symbol to a string:
symC := SysAddAtom("Chuck") ? SysGetAtomName(symC) // "Chuck"

sysobject.summary: Install a system-wide object that receives all messages being sent to other data types.
sysobject.param: The object to be installed. <oSys> can be a NULL_OBJECT, in which case the system object mechanism is disabled.
sysobject.returns: <oSys> or, if <oSys> is not specified, the currently installed object.
sysobject.remarks: SysObject() serves as the default object for Send(). Therefore, if the first argument of Send() is not specified, SysObject() is used in its place.
sysobject.example:
This example defines QQOut() and AsString() methods and then applies them to normal X# expressions:
CLASS SysClass // Define a customized QQOut() method METHOD QQOut(x) CLASS SysClass // Still could use the normal QQOut(): QQOut("This", x) // Define a customized AsString() Method AsString(x) CLASS SysClass LOCAL wType AS DWORD // no OBJECT, no ARRAY, if not called directly wType := USUALTYPE(x) DO CASE CASE wType =DATE RETURN "Date is: " + DTOC(x) CASE wType =STRING RETURN "String is: " + x CASE wType =SYMBOL RETURN "Symbol is: " + SYMBOL2STRING(x) OTHERWISE // Use the normal AsString() RETURN AsString(x) ENDCASE Function Start() SysObject(SysClass{}) // Invoke the AsString() method // This is like using SysClass:AsString(Today()) ? Today():AsString() // Date is: 11/19/98 ? 1:AsString() // 1 ? #HELLO:AsString() // Symbol is: HELLO ? "HELLO":AsString() // String is: HELLO // Invoke the QQOut() method "Thing":QQOut() // This Thing {1, 2, 3}:QQOut() // This 1This 2This 3

tan.summary: Calculate the tangent of a number.
tan.returns: The tangent of the specified angle.
tan.example: This example uses Tan() to calculate the tangent of 1.38 radians: ? Tan(1.38) // 5.18 This example shows that the tangent is equal to the sine over the cosine: ? Sin(1.38)/Cos(1.38) // 5.18

time.summary: Return the system time in a format determined by various international settings.
time.returns: The format of the return value is dependent on several functions, including SetAMPM(), SetAMExt(), SetPMExt(), and SetInternational(), which you can refer to for more information.
time.remarks: Time() returns the system time. Time() is related to Seconds(), which returns the integer value representing the number of seconds since midnight.
time.example:
These examples show the results of Time() under various circumstances:
SetInternational(#Windows) // Assuming 12-hour time with "AM" and "PM"extensions // and colon separator set in Control Panel ? Time() // 02:37:17 PM SetInternational(#Clipper) ? Time() // 14:37:19 SetAMPM(TRUE) // 12-hour format SetPMExt(" pm") ? Time() // 02:37:21 pm

time24.summary: Return the system time in 24-hour format.
time24.returns: The system time in the form hh:mm:ss, where hh is hours in 24-hour format, mm is minutes, and ss is seconds.
time24.remarks: Time24() does not depend on any other setting to determine its output format. Instead, it returns the system time. Time() is related to Seconds(), which returns the integer value representing the number of seconds since midnight.
time24.example:
These examples show the results of Time24() used with Substr() to extract the hour, minutes, and seconds:
? Time24() // 10:37:17 ? Substr3(Time24(), 1, 2) // 10 ? Substr3(Time24(), 4, 2) // 37 ? Substr3(Time24(), 7, 2) // 17

today.summary: Return the system date as a date value.
today.remarks:
Today() provides a means of initializing memory variables to the current date, comparing other date values to the current date, and performing date arithmetic relative to the current date. The display format for dates is controlled by SetDateFormat() and the SET DATE command. The default format is mm/dd/yy.
Today() is the same as the Date() function in CA-Clipper, but DATE is a reserved word in X#.
today.example:
These examples show Today() used in various ways:
? Today() // 09/09/98 ? Today() + 30 // 10/09/98 ? Today() - 30 // 08/10/98 dDate := Today() ? CMonth(dDate) // September

tohira.summary: Convert single-byte and double-byte katakana characters in a string to their double-byte hiragana equivalents.

tojnum.summary: Convert the single-byte and double-byte numbers in a string to double-byte kanji numbers.
tojnum.param: The string of numbers to convert.

tokata.summary: Convert single-byte katakana and double-byte hiragana characters in a string to their double-byte katakana equivalents.

tone.summary: Sound a speaker tone for a specified frequency and duration. Note: Tone() is a compatibility function and is no longer recommended. It is superseded by the Windows API MessageBeep(), SndPlaySound(), and the MCI family of functions. MessageBeep() is defined in the System Library, whereas the other functions are defined in the Win32 API library. In order to use these functions, you must include the Win32 API library in your application's search path.
tone.param: The frequency of the tone to sound.

The duration of the tone measured in increments of 1/18 of a second. For example, an <wDuration> value of 18 represents one second.
For both arguments, noninteger values are truncated — not rounded — to their integer portion.
tone.remarks: Tone() is a sound function that indicates various program states to the user. These can be error states, boundary conditions, or the end of a time-consuming process. For example, an error state would sound an error tone before alerting the user with a message or interactive dialog box. A boundary condition might indicate that the user is attempting to cursor past the top or bottom of a column in a TBrowse object. A batch process also might indicate its completion with a sound to alert the user, in case the user has turned away from the screen. Tone() works by sounding the speaker at the specified frequency for the specified duration. The duration is measured in increments of 1/18 of a second. The frequency is measured in hertz (cycles per second). Frequencies of less than 20 are inaudible. The table below shows the frequencies of standard musical notes. Note: Tone() works only on IBM PC and 100% compatible computers. Pitch Frequency Pitch Frequency C 130.80 mid C 261.70 C# 138.60 C# 277.20 D 146.80 D 293.70 D# 155.60 D# 311.10 E 164.80 E 329.60 F 174.60 F 349.20 F# 185.00 F# 370.00 G 196.00 G 392.00 G# 207.70 G# 415.30 A 220.00 A 440.00 A# 233.10 A# 466.20 B 246.90 B 493.90 C 523.30
tone.example:
This example is a beep function that indicates that a batch operation has completed:
FUNCTION DoneBeep() Tone(300, 1) Tone(100, 1) Tone(300, 1) Tone(100, 1)
This example is a tone sequence that indicates invalid keystrokes or boundary conditions:
FUNCTION ErrorBeep() Tone(100, 3)

toword.summary: Convert a number to a word.
toword.param: The number to convert to a word, specified in the range of plus or minus 32,767, inclusive.
toword.remarks:
ToWord() can be used in situations where a word is preferred or required, such as when passing arguments to a DLL function.
ToWord() is the same as the Word() function in CA-Clipper, but WORD is a reserved word in X#. Under X#, Word() is a conversion operator. With numbers that are not greater than a WORD type number, it yields the same results as ToWord() and maintains compatibility with CA-Clipper.
toword.example:
This example uses ToWord() as an argument to a function which expects a short integer:
LOCAL n := 30000 AS USUAL CProc(ToWord(n)) FUNCTION CProc(siV AS SHORTINT) ? siV

transform.summary: Convert any value into a formatted string.
transform.param: The value to format. This expression can be any valid X# data type except array, code block, object, and NIL.
A string of picture and template characters that describes the format of the returned string.
transform.returns: A formatted string as defined by <cSayPicture>.
transform.remarks: Transform() is a conversion function that formats character, date, logical, and numeric values according to a specified picture string that includes a combination of picture function and template strings. Transform() formats data for output to the screen or the printer in the same manner as the PICTURE clause of the @...SAY command. To convert the transformed string back to its original value, use Unformat(). Function string: A picture function string specifies formatting rules that apply to the Transform() return value as a whole, rather than to particular character positions within <uValue>. The function string consists of the @ character, followed by one or more additional characters, each of which has a particular meaning (see table below). If a function string is present, the @ character must be the leftmost character of the picture string, and the function string must not contain spaces. A function string can be specified alone or with a template string. If both are present, the function string must precede the template string, and the two must be separated by a single space. Function Action B Displays numbers left-justified C Displays CR after positive numbers D Displays date in SET DATE format E Displays date in British format R Nontemplate characters are inserted X Displays DB after negative numbers Z Displays zeros as blanks ( Encloses negative numbers in parentheses ! Converts alphabetic characters to uppercase Template string: A picture template string specifies formatting rules on a character by character basis. The template string consists of a series of characters, some of which have special meanings (see table below). Each position in the template string corresponds to a position in the value of the <uValue> argument. Because Transform() uses a template, it can insert formatting characters such commas, dollar signs, and parentheses. Characters in the template string that have no assigned meanings are copied literally into the return value. If the @R picture function is used, these characters are inserted between characters of the return value; otherwise, they overwrite the corresponding characters of the return value. A template string can be specified alone or with a function string. If both are present, the function string must precede the template string, and the two must be separated by a single space. Template Action A,N,X,9,# Displays digits for any data type L Displays logicals as "T" or "F" Y Displays logicals as "Y" or "N" ! Converts an alphabetic character to uppercase $ Displays a dollar sign in place of a leading space in a numeric * Displays an asterisk in place of a leading space in a numeric . Specifies a decimal point position , Specifies a comma position
transform.example: This example formats a number into a currency format using a template: ? Transform(123456, "$999,999") // Result: $123,456 This example formats a string using a function: ? Transform("to upper", "@!") // Result: TO UPPER

trim.summary: Remove trailing spaces from a string.
trim.returns: <cString> with the trailing spaces removed. If <cString> is a NULL_STRING or all spaces, Trim() returns a NULL_STRING.
trim.remarks: Trim() is used to format strings by deleting trailing spaces while concatenating strings. This is typically the case with database fields which are stored in fixed-width format. For example, you can use Trim() to concatenate first and last name fields to form a name string. Trim() is related to LTrim(), which removes leading spaces, and AllTrim(), which removes both leading and trailing spaces. The inverse of AllTrim(), LTrim(), and Trim() are the PadC(), PadR(), and PadL() functions, which center, right-justify, or left-justify strings by padding them with fill characters.
trim.example:
This is a function in which Trim() formats city, state, and zip code fields for labels or form letters:
FUNCTION CityState(cCity, cState, cZip) RETURN Trim(cCity) + ", " ; + Trim(cState) + " " + cZip
To complete the example the function, CityState(), displays a record from CUSTOMER.DBF:
USE customer INDEX custname NEW SEEK "Kate" ? CityState(City, State, ZipCode) // Athens, GA 10066

tstring.summary: Convert a specified number of seconds to a time string.
tstring.param: The number of seconds to convert.
tstring.returns: The format of the return value is dependent on several functions, including SetAMPM(), SetAMExt(), SetPMExt(), and SetInternational(), which you can refer to for more information. If <nSeconds> is greater than 86,400 (the number of seconds in one day), the number of seconds past the whole number of days is returned (see the second example below).
tstring.remarks: TString() converts a specified number of seconds to a time string. Days() is a related function that is particularly useful when <nSeconds> is greater than 86,400, since it returns the number of full days in a given number of seconds.
tstring.example:
This example uses TString() on a number less than 86,400. The initial settings define a 12-hour time format with " AM" and " PM" as the morning and evening extensions:
SetAMPM(TRUE) SetAMExt(" AM") SetPMExt(" PM") ? TString(6400) // 01:46:40 AM
This example passes 303,600 to TString(). Since 303,600 seconds is equal to 3 days, 11 hours, and 20 minutes, TString() only returns the time past the whole 3 days. The initial settings define a 24-hour format with no morning or evening extension:
SetAMPM(FALSE) SetAMExt(NULL_STRING) SetPMExt(NULL_STRING) ? TString(303600) // 12:20:00 ? Days(303600) // 3

type.summary: Determine the data type of an expression represented as a string.
type.param: A string that contains an expression whose type is to be determined. It cannot contain undeclared variables or functions that are not intended for used with macros If <cString> does not exist, "U" is returned.
type.returns: One of the following characters: Returns Meaning A Array B Block C String D Date L Logical M Memo N Numeric O Object U NIL, local, or static UE Error syntactical UI Error indeterminate
type.remarks:
Type() uses the macro operator (&) to determine the argument's data type; therefore, you cannot use it to determine the data type of undeclared variables or functions that are not intended for used with macros. Use UsualType() for these expressions.
Array references: References to private and public arrays return "A." References to array elements return the type of the element. If(): To return the appropriate data type for an If() expression, Type() evaluates the condition then returns the type of the evaluated path. If either the If() condition or the evaluated path are invalid, Type() returns "UE." Testing parameters: Type() can only test the validity of parameters received using the PARAMETERS statement. Testing a parameter declared as part of a FUNCTION or PROCEDURE declaration always returns "U." because local parameters do not have a symbol in the symbol table. To determine whether an argument was skipped or left off the end of the argument list, compare it to NIL or use IsNil().
type.example:
These examples demonstrate various results from invocations of Type():
? Type('Substr("Hi There", 4, 5)') // C ? Type("UdF()") // UI ? Type('If(TRUE, "true", 12)') // C PROCEDURE NilParameters() PARAMETERS cParam1, nParam2, uParam3 IF cParam1 = NIL ? "First parameter was not passed" cParam1 := "Default value" ENDIF IF Type("nParam2") = "U" ? "Second parameter was not passed" ENDIF IF IsNil(uParam3) ? "Third parameter was not passed" ENDIF . . <Statements> .
This example shows the difference between Type(), ValType(), UsualType(), and UsualVal(). Note that Type() macro-expands the contents of the string before evaluating it, whereas UsualType() does not:
num := 10 // Undeclared variable ? Type("num + num") // N ? ValType(num + num) // N ? UsualType("num + num") // 7 (stands for STRING) ? UsualVal(num + num) // 20

unformat.summary: Convert a transformed string back to its original value.
unformat.param: The picture string used when the original value was converted.
The data type of the original value. This can be any valid X# data type except array, code block, object, and NIL.
unformat.remarks:
Unformat() is the inverse of Transform(). It uses the picture string to convert back to its original value a value that was converted into a formatted string with the Transform() function. It is useful for converting data that was entered from a single-line edit which included picture characters.
