If the Transform() function overwrote characters in the original value, the overwritten characters are lost and the characters that overwrote them appear in their place. Also, any characters or numbers that were truncated are not restored.

unregisteraxit.summary: Terminate the registration of an object that has been registered with RegisterAxit().
unregisteraxit.param: The object that you want to stop registering.
unregisteraxit.remarks: When the garbage collector calls the Axit() method, it automatically terminates registration of the object after the Axit() method is complete, so UnregisterAxit() is only necessary if you directly or explicitly call the Axit() method in your application. Before calling UnregisterAxit() make sure that InCollect() is FALSE.
unregisteraxit.example:
This example calls UnregisterAxit() after checking for InCollect():
IF !InCollect() UnregisterAxit() ENDIF

unregisterkid.summary: Remove the registration of an object that was registered to the garbage collector.
unregisterkid.param: A pointer to the object you want to unregister.
unregisterkid.remarks: UnregisterKid() unregisters an object that was previously registered for update after garbage collection via the RegisterKid() function. The pointer to the dynamic object once again becomes subject to the garbage collector and could become invalid after a garbage collection.
unregisterkid.example:
This example uses UnregisterKid():
STRUCTURE StrucMyStrings MEMBER DIM aStr[10] AS PTR Function Start() LOCAL wI AS DWORD LOCAL strucMyArray AS StrucMyStrings strucMyArray ; := MemCAlloc(_SizeOf(StrucMyStrings), 1) RegisterKid(strucMyArray, 10, FALSE) FOR wI := 1 UPTO 10 strucMyArray.aStr[wI] := Ptr(_CAST, STR(wI)) NEXT CollectForced() // Force a garbage collection UnregisterKid(strucMyArray) // Collection is complete: unregister objects // Objects have survived after a collection: FOR wI := 1 UPTO 10 MessageBox(0, strucMyArray.aStr[wI], ; AsPsz(wI), 0) NEXT MemFree(strucMyArray) // Don't forget to free the allocated memory when you're done

unregisteroleautomati.summary: Remove the registration of a X# object that was registered previously as an active automation server object.
unregisteroleautomati.param: The object registered as an automation server.
unregisteroleautomati.returns: TRUE, if the operation was successful; otherwise, FALSE.
unregisteroleautomati.remarks: UnRegisterOLEAutomationObject() unregisters a X# object that was previously registered by a call to RegisterOLEAutomationObject(). Note: If you use the AutoServer base class or the Automated property in the GUI classes, you do not have to call this function explicitly. See Creating OLE Servers in Visual Obects in the "How To" section of the online help for further details.

upper.summary: Convert the lowercase and mixed case characters in a string to uppercase.
upper.param: The string to convert to uppercase.
upper.returns: <cString> with all alphabetical characters converted to uppercase. All other characters remain the same as in the original string.
upper.remarks: Upper() is related to Lower(), which converts uppercase and mixed case strings to lowercase. Upper() is also related to IsUpper() and IsLower(), which determine whether a string begins with an uppercase or lowercase letter. Upper() is generally used to format strings for display purposes. It can, however, be used to normalize strings for case-independent comparison or indexing purposes. Upper() and UpperA() are nation-dependent.

uppera.summary: Convert the lowercase and mixed case characters in a string to uppercase, changing the contents of the argument as well as the return value.
uppera.param: The string to convert to uppercase.
uppera.returns: <cString> with all alphabetical characters converted to uppercase. All other characters remain the same as in the original string.
uppera.remarks:
UpperA() is similar to Upper() except that it changes the contents of the argument as well as the return value. See Upper() for details.
You may change more than one variable at the same time (see example below).
uppera.example:
These examples illustrate the effects of UpperA(). Compare them to the results of the Upper() example:
LOCAL cName AS STRING cName := "noLi1" ? UpperA(cName) // NOLI1 ? cName // NOLI1
This example shows how you may change more than one variable at the same time:
a:= "i Change" b:= a UpperA(b) ? b // "I Change" ? a // "I Change"

used.summary: Determine whether a database file is open.
used.returns: TRUE if there is a database file in use; otherwise, FALSE.
used.remarks: Used() determines whether there is a database file in use in a work area.
used.example:
This example determines whether a database file is in use in the current work area:
USE customer NEW QOut(Used()) // Result: TRUE CLOSE QOut(Used()) // Result: FALSE

usualtype.summary: Determine the data type of an expression.
usualtype.param: The expression whose data type you want to return.
usualtype.returns: The data type of <uValue>. The return values have the following meanings: Returns Meaning ARRAY Array CODEBLOCK Code block DATE Date FLOAT Float, Real4, Real8 LOGIC Logical value LONGINT Byte, Word, DWord, ShortInt, Int, LongInt OBJECT Object or runtime code block (see example below) VOID NIL PTR Pointer STRING String, PSZ SYMBOL Symbol If <uValue> is passed by reference, 128 is automatically added to the return value (see the last example).
usualtype.remarks: UsualType() does not macro expand strings. UsualType() is faster and provides more detailed information than the old ValType() function.
usualtype.example:
This example displays different results, depending on the type of the variable:
xType := USUALTYPE(xVar) DO CASE CASE xType =STRING ? "String" CASE xType =LONGINT ? "LongInt" CASE xType =DATE ? "Date" OTHERWISE ? "One of the many others" ENDCASE
These examples show the numeric return values for several data types:
? UsualType(1) = LONGINT // TRUE ? UsualType("D. Lyon") = STRING // TRUE ? UsualType(NIL) = 0 // TRUE ? UsualType({"An Array"}) = ARRAY // TRUE ? UsualType(block) = CODEBLOCK // TRUE
This example shows the difference between Type(), ValType(), UsualType(), and UsualVal(). Note that Type() macro-expands the contents of the string before evaluating it, whereas UsualType() does not:
num := 10 // Undeclared variable ? Type("num + num") // N ? ValType(num + num) // N ? UsualType("num + num") // 7 (stands for STRING) ? UsualVal(num + num) // 20
This example shows the differences between the UsualType() of a compile-time code block and a runtime code block:
// Hard-coded code block is visible at compile // time: LOCAL cb := {||"Compile time"} LOCAL ob // The code block is within quotes so the compiler // is not aware of it at compile time: ob := Evaluate("{||'Run time'}") ? UsualType(cb) // CODEBLOCK ? UsualType(ob) // OBJECT
This example shows how 128 is added to the return value when a value is passed by reference:
FUNCTION PassRef() LOCAL v AS STRING v := NULL_STRING AtFront(@v) FUNCTION AtFront(pv) // @STRING ? UsualType(@pv) // 7 + 128 = 135

usualval.summary: Access contents of an address, whether it is passed by reference or not.
usualval.param: An expression of any type. This can be referenced or preceded with the @ sign.
usualval.returns: The actual content of <uValue>, whether it was referenced or not.
usualval.remarks: UsualVal() can be used to retrieve the contents of an argument that is passed by reference or preceded by the @ sign.
usualval.example:
This example shows how UsualVal() retrieves the content of an argument that is passed by reference: ? UsualVal(@Var) = Var // TRUE This example shows how UsualVal() retrieves the content of an argument that is not passed by reference: ? UsualVal(Var) = Var // TRUE This example shows the difference between Type(), ValType(), UsualType(), and UsualVal(). Note that Type() macro-expands the contents of the string before evaluating it, whereas ValType() does not:
num := 10 // Undeclared variable ? Type("num + num") // N ? ValType(num + num) // N ? UsualType("num + num") // 7(stands for STRING) // Argument was not referenced below ? UsualVal(num + num) // 20

val.summary: Convert a string containing a numeric value to a numeric data type.
val.param: The string to convert. <cNumber> can be in any of the compiler-supported base formats, such as binary, decimal, hex, or scientific. When in scientific format, a decimal point is necessary to identify the base "E". So Val("1E+1") equals 1 but Val("1.0E+1") equals 10.0. Moreover, "+INF" and "-INF" (both must be in uppercase) represent +infinity and -infinity.
val.remarks: If <cNumber> is a valid numeric expression, Val() processes it all. However, if <cNumber> is not entirely a valid numeric expression but does contain decimal numerics, Val() evaluates it until it reaches a second decimal point, the first non-numeric character, or the end of the expression. Leading spaces are always ignored. All variables containing a FLOAT type have internal picture information (like a template) relating to digits and decimals (see FloatFormat()). For data base fields of type FLOAT, such picture information resides in the database header structure and is obtainable by FieldVal(). With the Val() function and with literal floats (that is, hard-coded in source code and thus known at compile-time), the number of decimals is derived from the hard-coded decimal portion and the number of digits is taken from the SetDigit() or SET DIGIT setting. Str() and Transform() are closely related to Val() since each converts numeric values to strings.
val.example:
This example compares the results when SetFixed() is TRUE and when it is FALSE:
FUNCTION Start() SetDecimal(3) SetFixed(FALSE) ? Val("12.1234") // 12.1234 SetFixed(TRUE) ? Val("12.1234") // 12.123 RETURN TRUE
These examples illustrates Val() with SetFixed() set to TRUE and SetDecimal() set to 2:
SetDecimal(2) SetFixed(TRUE) ? Val("12.1234") // 12.12 ? Val("12.1256") // 12.13 ? Val("12A12") // 12.00 ? Val("A1212") // 0.00 ? Val(Space(1)) // 0.00 ? Val(" 12.12") // 12.12 ? Val("12 .12") // 12.00
This example applies Val() on a hexadecimal string: ? Val("0xFF") // 255

valtype.summary: Determine the data type of an expression. Note: ValType() is a compatibility function and is no longer recommended. UsualType() and IsNumeric() work faster and provide more information.
valtype.param: The expression whose data type you want to return. If the argument does not exist, an "undefined error" occurs.
valtype.returns: One of the following characters, which represent the data type of <uValue>: Characters Meaning A Array B Code block C String, PSZ D Date L Logic N LongInt, ShortInt, Byte, Word, Dword, Real4, Real8, Float, Numeric O Object U NIL # Symbol - PTR If <uValue> is passed by reference, the return value will be preceded by an @ sign (see the second example).
valtype.remarks: ValType() is similar to Type(), but differs by actually evaluating the specified argument and determining the type of the return value. For this reason, you can determine the type of local and static variables and functions. Type(), by contrast, uses the macro operator (&) to evaluate the type of its argument.
valtype.example:
This example shows the difference between Type(), ValType(), UsualType(), and UsualVal(). Note that Type() macro-expands the contents of the string before evaluating it, whereas ValType() does not:
num := 10 // Undeclared variable ? Type("num + num") // N ? ValType(num + num) // N ? UsualType("num + num") // 7 (stands for STRING) ? UsualVal(num + num) // 20
This example shows how @ is added to the return value when a value is passed by reference:
FUNCTION PassRef() LOCAL v AS STRING AtFront(@v) FUNCTION AtFront(pv) ? ValType(@pv) // @C

varget.summary: Return the contents of a field or a memory variable.
varget.param: The name of the field or memory variable.
varget.remarks: VarGet() is used instead of a macro when the name of the field or memory variable is in a string.
varget.example:
This example uses VarGet() to retrieve the contents of a field:
LOCAL cFieldName := "Address" USE Customer // Instead of ? &cFieldName, use this: ? VarGet(cFieldName) // 101 5th Street

varput.summary: Assign a value to a field or a memory variable of a given name.
varput.param: The name of the variable you want to create.
The value to assign to the variable.
varput.remarks: If a field or memory variable called <cVarName> does not exist, a memory variable called <cVarName> is created. Therefore, VarPut(), like MemVarPut(), can be used to create undeclared memory variables. It should be used instead of a macro.
varput.example:
This example uses VarPut() to store a value into a database field:
LOCAL cFieldName cFieldName := "Address" VarPut(cFieldName, "Hollywood, Room 222")
This example uses VarPut() to create a memory variable:
LOCAL cHasName cHasName := "cPrivate" // Instead of &cHasName := "new", use this: VarPut(cHasName, "new") ? cPrivate // new
This example shows that the newly created variable is a MEMVAR:
VarPut("cVar", "hi") ? _MEMVAR->cVar // hi

verifythemestate.summary: Verifies the current theme state and sets the ThemeEnabled flag
verifythemestate.returns: The function returns the current value of the ThemeEnabled flag like the function IsThemeEnabled()

version.summary: Returns the version of X# you are using.

vodbalias.summary: Return the alias of a specified work area as a string.
vodbalias.returns: If there is no database file in use, VODBAlias() returns a NULL_STRING.
vodbalias.remarks: VODBAlias() is like Alias() but is strongly typed. See Alias() for more information and an example.

vodbaliassym.summary: Return the alias of a specified work area as a symbol.
vodbaliassym.returns: The alias of the specified work area as a symbol. If there is no database file in use for the specified work area, VODBAlias() returns a NULL_SYMBOL.
vodbaliassym.example:
This example opens a file, issues the VODBGetSelect() function to determine the current work area number, and then gets the symbol associated with the work area:
USE file1 NEW ALIAS test1 nAlias := VODBGetSelect() sAlias := VODBAliasSym(nAlias) ? sAlias // Returns: test1

vodbappend.param: TRUE clears all pending record locks, then appends the next record. FALSE maintains all pending record locks, adding new records to the end of the lock list.
vodbappend.remarks: VODBAppend() is like DBAppend() but is strongly typed. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBAppend() for more information and examples.

vodbbof.returns: TRUE after an attempt to skip backward beyond the first logical record in a database file or if the current database file contains no records; otherwise, FALSE. If there is no database file open in the current work area, VODBBOF() returns TRUE.
vodbbof.remarks: VODBBOF() is the same as BOF(). See BOF() for more information and examples.

vodbclearfilter.remarks: VODBClearFilter() is the same as DBClearFilter(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBClearFilter() for more information and an example.

vodbclearlocate.summary: Clear a locate condition by deleting the locate code block.
vodbclearlocate.remarks:
VODBClearLocate() clears the locate condition by deleting the locate code block.
A locate condition can be set by DBLocate(), VODBLocate(), VODBSetLocate(), or the LOCATE command. Note that this function does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs.

vodbclearrelation.remarks: VODBClearRelation() is the same as DBClearRelation(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBClearRelation() for more information and an example.

vodbcloseall.summary: Close all files in all work areas.
vodbcloseall.remarks: VODBCloseAll() is the same as DBCloseAll(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBCloseAll() for more information.
vodbcloseall.example:
The following example closes all work areas:
LOCAL rddList AS _RDDLIST ... aRdds := {"CAVODBF", "DBFNTX"} n := ALen(aRdds) rddList := MemAlloc( (_SizeOf(DWORD)) + (n * _SizeOf(SYMBOL)) ) rddList.uiRddCount := n FOR i := 1 TO n rddList.atomRddName[i] := SysAddAtomUpperA(aRdds[i]) NEXT VODBUseArea(TRUE, rddList, "sales", "sales", TRUE, FALSE) VODBOrdListAdd("Last", NIL) VODBUseArea(TRUE, rddList, "customer", "", TRUE, FALSE) MemFree(rddList) cLast := customer->last IF (Sales->(VODBSeek(cLast))) IF Sales->(Deleted()) IF RLock() Sales->(VODBRecall()) ? "Record deleted: ", sales; (Deleted()) ENDIF ENDIF ELSE ? "Not found" ENDIF VODBCloseAll() // Close all work areas

vodbclosearea.summary: Close all files in a work area.
vodbclosearea.remarks: VODBCloseArea() is the same as DBCloseArea(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBCloseArea() for more information.
vodbclosearea.example:
The following example closes a file via an alias reference:
LOCAL rddList AS _RDDLIST ... aRdds := {"CAVODBF", "DBFNTX"} n := ALen(aRdds) rddList := MemAlloc( (_SizeOf(DWORD)) + (n * _SizeOf(SYMBOL)) ) rddList.uiRddCount := n FOR i := 1 TO n rddList.atomRddName[i] := SysAddAtomUpperA(aRdds[i]) NEXT cLast := "Winston" VODBUseArea(TRUE, rddList, "sales", "sales", TRUE, FALSE) VODBOrdListAdd("Last", NIL) MemFree(rddList) IF (VODBSeek(cLast)) IF Deleted() .AND. RLock() VODBRecall() ? "Record deleted: ", Deleted() ENDIF ELSE ? "Not found" ENDIF VODBCloseArea()

vodbcommit.summary: Flush pending updates in one work area.
vodbcommit.remarks: VODBCommit() is the same as DBCommit(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBCommit() for more information and an example.

vodbcommitall.summary: Flush pending updates in all work areas.
vodbcommitall.remarks: VODBCommitAll() is the same as DBCommitAll(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBCommitAll() for more information.
vodbcommitall.example:
The following example writes all pending updates to disk:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL rddList AS _RDDLIST aRdds := {"CAVODBF", "DBFNTX"} n := ALen(aRdds) rddList := MemAlloc( (_SizeOf(DWORD)) + (n * _SizeOf(SYMBOL)) ) rddList.uiRddCount := n FOR i := 1 TO n rddList.atomRddName[i] := SysAddAtomUpperA(aRdds[i]) NEXT cLast := "Winston" VODBUseArea(TRUE, rddList, "sales", "sales", TRUE, FALSE) VODBOrdListAdd("SaleFNam", NIL) VODBOrdListAdd("SaleLNam", NIL) VODBUseArea(TRUE, rddList, "colls", "colls", TRUE, FALSE) VODBOrdListAdd("CollFNam", NIL) VODBOrdListAdd("CollLNam", NIL) MemFree(rddList) DBSelectArea("sales") // Select "sales" workarea IF (Sales->(VODBSeek(cLast))) IF Sales->(Deleted()) .AND. sales(RLock()) Sales->(VODBRecall()) ? "Deleted record has been recalled." ENDIF ELSE ? "Not found" ENDIF // Processing done, write updates to disk and // close files VODBCommitAll() VODBCloseAll() RETURN TRUE

vodbcontinue.remarks: VODBContinue() is the same as DBContinue(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBContinue() for more information and an example.

vodbdelete.summary: Mark the current record for deletion.
vodbdelete.remarks: VODBDelete() is the same as DBDelete(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBDelete() for more information and an example.

vodbdeleted.summary: Return the deleted status of the current record.
vodbdeleted.returns: TRUE if the current record is marked for deletion; otherwise, FALSE. If there is no database file in use in the current work area, VODBDeleted() returns FALSE.
vodbdeleted.remarks: VODBDeleted() is the same as Deleted(). See Deleted() for more information and examples.

vodbeof.returns: TRUE when an attempt is made to move the record pointer beyond the last logical record in a database file or if the current database file contains no records; otherwise, FALSE. If there is no database file open in the current work area, VODBEOF() returns TRUE.
vodbeof.remarks: VODBEOF() is the same as EOF(). See EOF() for more information and examples.

vodbeval.summary: Evaluate a code block for each record that matches a specified scope and/or condition.
vodbeval.param: The code block to execute for each record that matches the scope and conditions.
The number of records to process, starting with the current record.
The number of the record to process.
TRUE processes only records from the current record to end-of-file. FALSE processes all records.
vodbeval.remarks: VODBEval() is like DBEval() but is strongly typed. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBEval() for more information.

vodbfieldget.summary: Retrieve the value of a specified database field.
vodbfieldget.param: The position of the field in the record structure for the current work area.

A pointer to a polymorphic value. This value will receive the requested information if the function is successful and will be unchanged otherwise. If you just want to retrieve information, this value must be NIL before calling the function.
Although other RDDs may expand on this concept, the supplied RDDs (as outlined in the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide) limit using a non-NIL value to a single circumstance in which you can change the information rather than just retrieve it. With the DBS_ALIAS <kInfoType>, you can specify a non-NIL value, allowing you to specify a string that you can subsequently use to access the indicated field.
vodbfieldget.remarks: VODBFieldGet() is like FieldGet() but is strongly typed. See FieldGet() for more information and an example.

vodbfieldinfo.summary: Retrieve field definition information about a field.
vodbfieldinfo.param: Determines what type of information is retrieved.
The position number of the field that you want information on.

A pointer to a polymorphic value. This value will receive the requested information if the function is successful and will be unchanged otherwise. If you just want to retrieve information, this value must be NIL before calling the function.
Although other RDDs may expand on this concept, the supplied RDDs (as outlined in the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide) limit using a non-NIL value to a single circumstance in which you can change the information rather than just retrieve it. With the DBS_ALIAS <kInfoType>, you can specify a non-NIL value, allowing you to specify a string that you can subsequently use to access the indicated field.
A new value to assign to the field attribute.
vodbfieldinfo.remarks: VODBFieldInfo() is the same as DBFieldInfo(), except for the purpose of its third argument and the fact that it returns a logical. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBFieldInfo() for more information.
vodbfieldinfo.example:
The following examples use VODBFieldInfo() to retrieve field information:
FUNCTION ShowFieldInfo(wField AS WORD) AS VOID LOCAL uResult AS USUAL uResult := NIL IF VODBFieldInfo(DBS_NAME, wField, @uResult) ? "FieldName(): ", uResult ELSE DoError() ENDIF IF VODBFieldInfo(DBS_TYPE, wField, @uResult) ? "Field type: ", uResult ELSE DoError() ENDIF IF VODBFieldInfo(DBS_LEN, wField, @uResult) ? "Field length: ", uResult ELSE DoError() ENDIF IF VODBFieldInfo(DBS_DEC, wField, @uResult) ? "Decimals: ", uResult ELSE DoError() ENDIF RETURN STATIC FUNCTION DoError() AS USUAL LOCAL uRetCode AS USUAL LOCAL oError AS USUAL oError := ErrorBuild(@strucErrInfo) oError:FuncSym := #VODBFieldInfo RETURN EVAL(ErrorBlock(), oError)

vodbfieldput.summary: Set the value of a specified database field.
vodbfieldput.param: The position of the field in the current database file.
The value to assign to the field. The data type of this expression must match the data type of the designated field variable.
vodbfieldput.remarks: VODBFieldPut() is like FieldPut() but is strongly typed. See FieldPut() for more information.
vodbfieldput.example:
This example compares VODBFieldPut() to assign a value to the first field of a database:
nField := 1 // Using VODBFieldPut() VODBFieldPut(nField, "MyData") // Set field value // Or: ? FIELDNAME(1) // City (name of the first field) City := "MyData"

vodbfilter.returns: The filter condition defined in the current work area. If no filter has been set, VODBFilter() returns a NULL_STRING.
vodbfilter.remarks: VODBFilter() is the same as DBFilter(). See DBFilter() for more information and an example.

vodbflock.summary: Lock an opened and shared database file.
vodbflock.returns: TRUE if the lock succeeded; otherwise, FALSE.
vodbflock.remarks: VODBFLock() is the same as FLock(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See FLock() for more information and examples.

vodbfound.summary: Determine if the previous search operation succeeded.
vodbfound.returns: TRUE if the last search command was successful; otherwise, FALSE. VODBFound() will also return FALSE if there is no database open in the current work area.
vodbfound.remarks: VODBFound() is the same as Found(). See Found() for more information and examples.

vodbgetselect.remarks: VODBGetSelect() is the same as DBGetSelect(). See DBGetSelect() for more information and an example.

vodbgobottom.summary: Move to the last logical record.
vodbgobottom.remarks: VODBGoBottom() is the same as DBGoBottom(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBGoBottom() for more information.
vodbgobottom.example:
The following example uses VODBGoBottom() to position the record pointer on the last logical record:
cLast := "Winston" DBUseArea(TRUE, "DBFNTX", "sales", "sales", TRUE) VODBOrdListAdd("lastname", NIL, NIL) Sales->(VODBGoBottom()) IF (Sales->Last == "Winston") IF Sales->(RLock()) Sales->(VODBDelete()) ? "Record deleted: ", sales; (VODBDeleted()) ELSE ? "Unable to lock record..." ENDIF END

vodbgoto.summary: Move to a record specified by record number.
vodbgoto.param: The record ID to go to. If <uRecID> does not exist, the work area is positioned to LastRec() + 1, and both VODBEOF() and VODBBOF() return TRUE.
vodbgoto.remarks: VODBGoTo() is like DBGoTo() but is strongly typed. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBGoTo() for more information and an example.

vodbgotop.summary: Move to the first logical record.
vodbgotop.remarks: VODBGoTop() is the same as DBGoTop(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBGoTop() for more information and an example.

vodbinfo.summary: Retrieve information about a work area.
vodbinfo.param: Determines what type of information is retrieved.

A pointer to a polymorphic value. This value will receive the requested information if the function is successful and will be unchanged otherwise. If you just want to retrieve information, this value must be NIL before calling the function.
Using a non-NIL value is not currently supported by any of the supplied RDDs (as outlined in the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide). This feature is reserved for RDDs that allow you to change the information rather than just retrieve it.
vodbinfo.remarks: VODBInfo() is similar to DBInfo(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBInfo() for more information.
vodbinfo.example:
The following examples return work area information:
FUNCTION ShowInfo() AS VOID LOCAL uResult AS USUAL uResult := NIL IF VODBInfo(DBI_GETHEADERSIZE, @uResult) ? "HEADER(): ", uResult ELSE DoError() ENDIF IF VODBInfo(DBI_LASTUPDATE, @uResult) ? "LUpdate(): ", uResult ELSE DoError() ENDIF IF VODBInfo(DBI_GETRECSIZE, @uResult) ? "RecSize(): ", uResult ELSE DoError() ENDIF IF VODBInfo(DBI_FULLPATH, @uResult) ? "PATHNAME: ", uResult ELSE DoError() ENDIF RETURN STATIC FUNCTION DoError() AS USUAL LOCAL uRetCode AS USUAL LOCAL oError AS USUAL oError := ErrorBuild(@strucErrInfo) oError:FuncSym := #VODBInfo RETURN EVAL(ErrorBlock(), oError)

vodblastrec.summary: Return the number of the last record in a database file.
vodblastrec.returns: The number of physical records in a database file. Filtering or deleted settings have no effect on the return value. VODBLastRec() returns 0 if there is no database file in use.
vodblastrec.remarks: VODBLastRec() is the same as LastRec(). See LastRec() for more information and examples.

vodblocate.summary: Search for the first record that matches a specified condition and scope.
vodblocate.param: The number of records to process, starting with the current record. To omit this argument, specify -1.
The number of the record to process. To omit this argument, specify -1.
TRUE processes only records from the current record to end-of-file. FALSE processes all records.
vodblocate.remarks: VODBLocate() is like DBLocate() but is strongly typed. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBLocate() for more information.
vodblocate.example:
The following example locates the first sale in the past 30 days in the city of LA:
USE sales VODBLocate({||City == "LA"}, {||SaleDay > ; TODAY()-30},-1,NIL,FALSE)

vodbordbagext.summary: Return the default index file extension for a work area as defined by the its RDD.
vodbordbagext.remarks: VODBOrdBagExt() is the same as calling DBOrderInfo(DBOI_BAGEXT).

vodbordcondset.summary: Set the condition and scope for an order.
vodbordcondset.param: A pointer to a data structure (_DBORDERCONDINFO) defining the condition and scope information.
vodbordcondset.remarks: VODBOrdCondSet() is the same as DBSetOrderCondition() except that it is strongly typed and the condition information is specified using a data structure rather than individual function arguments. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs.

vodbordcreate.summary: Create or replace an order in an index file.
vodbordcreate.param:
A pointer to a data structure (_DBORDERCONDINFO) defining the condition and scope information.
Note: See DBCreateOrder() for descriptions of the remaining arguments.
vodbordcreate.remarks: VODBOrdCreate() is the same as DBCreateOrder() except that it is strongly typed, the order of the <cIndexFile> and <cOrder> arguments is reversed, and it allows you to specify condition information using a data structure. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs.

vodborddestroy.summary: Remove an order from an open index file.
vodborddestroy.remarks: VODBOrdDestroy() is the same as DBDeleteOrder() except that it is strongly typed and the order of the arguments is reversed. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs.

vodborderinfo.summary: Return information about index files and the orders in them.
vodborderinfo.param: Determines what type of information is retrieved.

The name of an open index file (only the eight-letter file name is needed). Use this argument with <cOrder> to remove ambiguity when there are two or more orders with the same name in different index files. To omit the argument, specify NULL_STRING.
The name of the order about which you want to obtain information or a number representing its position in the order list. To omit the <cOrder> | <nPosition> argument, specify NIL.

A pointer to a polymorphic value. This value will receive the requested information if the function is successful and will be unchanged otherwise. If you just want to retrieve information, this value must be NIL before calling the function.
Using a non-NIL value is not currently supported by any of the supplied RDDs (as outlined in the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide). This feature is reserved for RDDs that allow you to change the information rather than just retrieve it.
vodborderinfo.remarks: VODBOrderInfo() is similar to DBOrderInfo(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBOrderInfo() for more information.
vodborderinfo.example:
The following examples return order access information:
FUNCTION ShowOrderInfo() AS VOID LOCAL uResult AS USUAL uResult := NIL IF VODBOrderInfo(DBOI_EXPRESSION,"",0,@uResult) ? "IndexKey(): ", uResult ELSE DoError() ENDIF // Record number for specified position: uResult := 100 IF VODBOrderInfo(DBOI_RECNO,"",0,@uResult) ? "Record number of position 100: ", uResult ELSE DoError() ENDIF IF VODBOrderInfo(DBOI_FULLPATH,"",0,@uResult) ? "FULLPATH of index file: ", uResult ELSE DoError() ENDIF RETURN STATIC FUNCTION DoError() AS USUAL LOCAL uRetCode AS USUAL LOCAL oError AS USUAL oError := ErrorBuild(@strucErrInfo) oError:FuncSym := #VODBOrderInfo RETURN EVAL(ErrorBlock(), oError)

vodbordlistadd.summary: Open an index file and add specified orders to the order list in a work area.
vodbordlistadd.remarks: VODBOrdListAdd() is the same as DBSetIndex() except that it is strongly typed. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs.

vodbordlistclear.summary: Remove orders from the order list in a work area and close associated index files.
vodbordlistclear.remarks: VODBOrdListClear() is the same as DBClearIndex() except that it is strongly typed and the order of the arguments is reversed. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs.

vodbordlistrebuild.summary: Rebuild all orders in the order list of a work area.
vodbordlistrebuild.remarks: VODBOrdListRebuild() is the same as DBReindex() except that it is strongly typed. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs.

vodbordsetfocus.summary: Set the controlling order for a work area.
vodbordsetfocus.remarks: VODBOrdSetFocus() is similar to DBSetOrder() except that it is strongly typed and the order of the arguments is reversed. Also, the third argument <pszPreviousOrder> points to the old controlling order. See DBSetOrder() for more information and an example.

vodbpack.summary: Remove all records that have been marked for deletion from a database file.
vodbpack.remarks: VODBPack() is the same as DBPack(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBPack() for more information and an example.

vodbrddlist.summary: Get a list of RDDs in use.
vodbrddlist.param:
A structure of type _RDDLIST. _RDDLIST is defined as follows:
MEMBER uiRDDCount AS DWORD
MEMBER DIM atomRDDName[1] AS SYMBOL
You must allocate enough memory for <strucRDDList>. Use MemAlloc() and MemFree() to allocate and deallocate the memory. The memory must be large enough to hold the uiRDDCount member and a DIM array of symbols having RDDCount() elements. Normally, the return of RDDCount() is assigned to uiRDDCount. Since the uiRDDCount member is a WORD, its size is given by _SizeOf(WORD). Moreover, the size of a DIM array of symbols having uiRDDCount (RDDCount()) elements is equal to uiRDDCount * _SizeOf(SYMBOL).
The types of RDDs to include in the list. The types are:
vodbrddlist.returns: TRUE, if successful; otherwise, FALSE. A FALSE return value indicates an error, but this function does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs.
vodbrddlist.example:
The following example lists all the RDDs in use:
FUNCTION QOutRDD() AS VOID PASCAL LOCAL rddList AS _RDDLIST LOCAL si AS SHORTINT LOCAL wCount AS WORD wCount := ; RDDCount(RDT_FULL+RDT_TRANSFER+RDT_HIDDEN) IF wCount > 0 // Allocate memory for one WORD (that is, // RDDlist.uiRDDCount) and // a DIM array of symbols having wCount elements RDDList := MemAlloc((_SizeOf(WORD)) +; (wCount * _SizeOf(SYMBOL))) RDDList.uiRDDCount := wCount IF VODBRDDList(rddList, ; RDT_FULL+RDT_TRANSFER+RDT_HIDDEN) FOR si := 1 UPTO RDDList.uiRDDCount ? RDDList.atomRDDName[si] NEXT ENDIF MemFree(rddList) ENDIF

vodbrddname.remarks: VODBRDDName() is the same as RDDName(). See RDDName() for more information and an example.

vodbrddsetdefault.summary: Return and optionally change the default RDD for the application.
vodbrddsetdefault.param: The name of the RDD that will be used to activate and manage applications when no RDD is explicitly specified. If this RDD is not available to the application, the call has no effect.
vodbrddsetdefault.returns: If <cNewSetting> is not specified, VODBRDDSetDefault() returns the current default RDD. If <cNewSetting> is specified, the previous default RDD is returned.
vodbrddsetdefault.remarks: VODBRDDSetDefault() is like RDDSetDefault() but is strongly typed. See RDDSetDefault() for more information and an example.

vodbrecall.summary: Restore the current record if it is marked for deletion.
vodbrecall.remarks: VODBRecall() is the same as DBRecall(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBRecall() for more information.
vodbrecall.example:
The following example recalls a record if it is deleted and attempts to lock the record if successful:
LOCAL rddList AS _RDDLIST ... aRdds := {"CAVODBF", "DBFNTX"} n := ALen(aRdds) rddList := MemAlloc( (_SizeOf(DWORD)) + (n * _SizeOf(SYMBOL)) ) rddList.uiRddCount := n FOR i := 1 TO n rddList.atomRddName[i] := SysAddAtomUpperA(aRdds[i]) NEXT cLast := "Winston" VODBUseArea(TRUE, rddList, "sales", "sales", TRUE, FALSE) VODBOrdListAdd("LastName", NIL, NIL) MemFree(rddList) IF (Sales->(VODBSeek(cLast))) IF Sales->(VODBDeleted()) IF Sales->(RLock()) Sales->(VODBRecall()) ? "Record recalled" ELSE ? "Unable to lock record..." ENDIF ENDIF ELSE ? "Not found" ENDIF

vodbrecno.returns: The current record number. If the work area contains a database file with 0 records, VODBRecNo() returns 1, BOF() and EOF() both return TRUE, and LastRec() returns 0. If the record pointer is moved past the last record, VODBRecNo() returns LastRec() + 1 and EOF() returns TRUE. If an attempt is made to move before the first record, VODBRecNo() returns the record number of the first logical record in the database file and BOF() returns TRUE. If no database file is open, VODBRecNo() will return a 0.
vodbrecno.remarks: VODBRecNo() is the same as RecNo(). See RecNo() for more information and examples.

vodbrecordinfo.param: Determines what type of information is retrieved..
The ID of the record to retrieve information on. A value of 0L means the current record.

A pointer to a polymorphic value. This value will receive the requested information if the function is successful and will be unchanged otherwise. If you just want to retrieve information, this value must be NIL before calling the function.
Using a non-NIL value is not currently supported by any of the supplied RDDs (as outlined in the "RDD Specifics" appendix in the Programmer's Guide). This feature is reserved for RDDs that allow you to change the information rather than just retrieve it.
vodbrecordinfo.remarks: VODBRecordInfo() is similar to DBRecordInfo(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBRecordInfo() for more information.
vodbrecordinfo.example:
The following examples retrieve record information:
FUNCTION ShowRecordInfo() AS VOID LOCAL uResult AS USUAL uResult := NIL IF VODBRecordInfo(DBRI_LEN,0,@uResult) ? "RecSize(): ", uResult ELSE DoError() ENDIF IF VODBRecordInfo(DBRI_LOCKED,200,@uResult) ? "Locking flag of record 200: ", uResult ELSE DoError() ENDIF RETURN STATIC FUNCTION DoError() AS USUAL LOCAL uRetCode AS USUAL LOCAL oError AS USUAL oError := ErrorBuild(@strucErrInfo) oError:FuncSym := #VODBRecordInfo RETURN EVAL(ErrorBlock(), oError)

vodbrelation.summary: Return the linking expression of a specified relation.
vodbrelation.param: The position of the desired relation in the list of current work area relations. The relations are numbered according to the order in which they were defined with SET RELATION.
The position of the desired relation in the list of current work area relations. The relations are numbered according to the order in which they were defined with SET RELATION.
vodbrelation.returns:
The linking expression defined to <wRelation>. If there is no relation set for <wRelation>, VODBRelation() returns a NULL_STRING.
TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
vodbrelation.remarks: VODBSetRelation() is similar to DBRelation(). See DBRelation() for more information and examples.

vodbrlock.param: The ID of the record to be locked. To omit, specify NIL. This will lock the current record and release all previously locked records.
vodbrlock.returns: TRUE if the record lock is obtained; otherwise, FALSE. An attempt to lock a record in an empty database returns TRUE.
vodbrlock.remarks: VODBRLock() is like DBRLock() but is strongly typed. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBRLock() for more information and examples.

vodbrselect.summary: Return the work area number of a relation.
vodbrselect.param: The position of the desired relation in the list of current work area relations. The relations are numbered according to the order in which they were defined by the relation setting.
vodbrselect.returns: The work area number of the specified relation. If there is no relation set for <wRelation>, VODBRSelect() returns 0.
vodbrselect.remarks: VODBRSelect() is like DBRSelect() but is strongly typed. See DBRSelect() for more information and examples.

vodbseek.summary: Move to the record having the specified key value.
vodbseek.param: A value of any type that specifies the key value associated with the desired record.
Determines how the work area is positioned if the specified key value is not found: TRUE performs a soft seek; FALSE does not.
vodbseek.remarks: VODBSeek() is like DBSeek() but is strongly typed. See DBSeek() for more information.
vodbseek.example:
In this example, VODBSeek() moves the pointer to the record in the database, EMPLOYEE, in which the value in the field cName matches the entered value of cName:
ACCEPT "Employee name: " TO cName IF (Employee->(VODBSeek(cName), FALSE)) Employee->(ViewRecord()) ELSE ? "Not found" END

vodbselect.summary: Select a new work area and retrieve the current work area.
vodbselect.param: The work area number for the new work area.
A variable that is passed by reference and will contain the number of the current work area.
vodbselect.remarks: VODBSelect() is like DBSelect() but is strongly typed. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBSelect() for more information.
vodbselect.example:
This example shows how to save and restore the old environment:
LOCAL wOld AS DWORD VODBSelect(10, @wOld) // Process the work area VODBSelect(wOld, @wOld)

vodbsetfilter.param: A code block that expresses the filter condition in executable form.

A character value that expresses the filter condition in textual form. It must be equivalent to <cbCondition>. To omit, specify a NULL_STRING. <cCondition> is the value returned by the DBFilter() function.
vodbsetfilter.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE. If <cCondition> is omitted, the DBSetFilter() function will return an empty string for the work area.
vodbsetfilter.remarks: VODBSetFilter() is like DBSetFilter() but is strongly typed. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBSetFilter() for more information and an example.

vodbsetfound.param: The new setting for the found flag.
vodbsetfound.remarks: VODBSetFound() is like DBSetFound() but is strongly typed. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBSetFound() for more information and an example.

vodbsetlocate.summary: Specify the code block for a locate condition.
vodbsetlocate.param: If no scope is specified, <cbForCondition> changes the default scope to all records. The code block should contain a logical expression. It corresponds to the first argument of DBLocate() or VODBLocate(). It is valid until it is overwritten by the next VODBSetLocate().
vodbsetlocate.remarks:
VODBSetLocate() allows you to change the locate condition. Once you issue a LOCATE command, DBLocate(), or VODBLocate(), you could continue searching but with a different condition.
Note that this function does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs.
vodbsetlocate.example:
The following example shows how to search on two different and independent criteria:
FUNCTION Locators() AS LOGIC LOCAL cbForCondition, cbWhileCondition, nNext, ; uRecId, lRest USE test cbForCondition := {||Proper(ALLTRIM(Name)) == ; "Charly"} cbWhileCondition := {||TRUE} // Process to EOF nNext := -1 // Scope ALL uRecId := NIL // Leave it at NIL lRest := FALSE // Search from top of file // Search for Charly DBLocate(cbForCondition, cbWhileCondition, ; nNext, uRecId, lRest) ? Found(), RECNO(), Name // Specify a second name; Search for Odile VODBSetLocate({||Proper(ALLTRIM(Name))=="Odile"}) CONTINUE ? Found(), RECNO(), Name DBCloseArea() RETURN Found()

vodbsetrelation.summary: Relate a specified work area to the current work area.
vodbsetrelation.param: The alias of the child work area.
A code block that expresses the relational expression in executable form.
The relational expression in textual form. It must be equivalent to <cbRel>. To omit, specify a NULL_STRING.
vodbsetrelation.remarks: VODBSetRelation() is like DBSetRelation() but is strongly typed. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBSetRelation() for more information and an example.

vodbsetselect.param: The number of the new work area.
vodbsetselect.remarks: VODBSetSelect() is like DBSetSelect() but is strongly typed. See DBSetSelect() for more information and an example.

vodbskip.summary: Move the record pointer relative to the current record.
vodbskip.param: The number of logical records to move, relative to the current record. A positive value means to skip forward, and a negative value means to skip backward.
vodbskip.remarks: VODBSkip() is like DBSkip() but is strongly typed. This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBSkip() for more information and an example.

vodbsymselect.summary: Select a new work area by specifying its alias as a symbol and return the number of the current work area.
vodbsymselect.param: The alias of the work area you want to select.
vodbsymselect.returns: The number of the current work area.
vodbsymselect.remarks: VODBSymSelect() is like DBSymSelect() but is strongly typed. See DBSymSelect() for more information.
vodbsymselect.example:
This example uses VODBSymSelect() to change work areas:
FUNCTION ChangeArea() AS VOID USE test USE address NEW ? Alias() // Address VODBSymSelect(#Test) ? Alias() // Test

vodbunlock.summary: Release all locks for a work area.
vodbunlock.param: The ID of the record to be unlocked. To omit, specify NIL. This unlocks all locked records or the whole file.
vodbunlock.remarks: VODBUnlock() is the same as DBUnlock(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBUnlock() for more information.
vodbunlock.example:
The following example illustrates a basic use of the VODBUnlock() function:
cLast := "Winston" USE sales SHARED NEW VIA "DBFNTX" VODBOrdListAdd("Lastname", NIL, NIL) IF (Sales->(VODBSeek(cLast))) IF Sales->(VODBRLock(NIL)) Sales->(VODBDelete()) ? "Record deleted: ", sales; (VODBDeleted()) Sales->(VODBUnlock(NIL)) ELSE ? "Unable to lock record..." ENDIF ELSE ? "Not found" ENDIF

vodbunlockall.summary: Release all locks for all work areas.
vodbunlockall.remarks: VODBUnlockAll() is the same as DBUnlockAll(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBUnlockAll() for more information.
vodbunlockall.example:
The following example marks a record for deletion if an VODBRLock() attempt is successful, then clears all locks in all work areas:
cLast := "Winston" USE sales SHARED NEW VIA "DBFNTX" VODBOrdListAdd("Salefnam", NIL) VODBOrdListAdd("Salelnam", NIL) USE colls SHARED NEW VIA "DBFNTX" VODBOrdListAdd("Collfnam", NIL) VODBOrdListAdd("Colllnam", NIL) DBSelectArea("sales") // Select "sales" work area IF (colls->(VODBSeek(cLast))) IF colls->(VODBDeleted()) ? "Record deleted: ", colls->; (VODBDeleted()) IF colls->(VODBRLock(NIL)) colls->(VODBRecall()) ? "Record recalled..." ENDIF ENDIF ELSE ? "Not found" VODBUnlockAll() // Remove all locks in ENDIF // all work areas

vodbusearea.param: Specifies whether the file is to be opened in a new work area. TRUE selects the lowest numbered unoccupied work area as the current work area before the use operation. FALSE uses the current work area (if the work area is occupied, it is closed first).

A pointer to a structure (_RDDLIST) that contains a list of RDD names from which the work area gets its functionality. If multiple RDDs (specified with this argument) implement the same function, the function associated with the last RDD in the list takes precedence. This allows you to use RDDs with special capabilities, like encryption or decryption, in different work areas with different database drivers.

The name of the database file to open, including an optional drive, directory, and extension. If the database file has a corresponding memo file, it is also opened. The default extension for database and memo files is determined by the RDD. See SetDefault() and SetPath() for file searching and creation rules.
An identifier name to associate with the work area when <cDataFile> is opened. Duplicate alias names are not allowed within a single application.
TRUE Attempts to open <cDataFile> for shared use. FALSE attempts to open <xcDataFile> for exclusive (non-shared) use, denying all other processes access until the database file is closed.
TRUE attempts to open <cDataFile> with a read-only attribute, prohibiting updates to the work area. FALSE attempts to open <cDataFile> with a read-write attribute, allowing updates.
vodbusearea.remarks: VODBUseArea() is a strongly typed function used to implement DBUseArea(). This function does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBUseArea() for more information.
vodbusearea.example:
This example is a typical use of the VODBUseArea() function:
FUNCTION NtxUse(cDBF AS STRING) AS LOGIC PASCAL LOCAL n,i AS DWORD LOCAL rddList AS _RDDLIST LOCAL aRdds AS ARRAY LOCAL lRet AS LOGIC aRdds := {"CAVODBF", "DBFNTX"} n := ALen(aRdds) rddList := MemAlloc( (_SizeOf(DWORD)) + (n * _SizeOf(SYMBOL)) ) rddList.uiRddCount := n FOR i := 1 TO n rddList.atomRddName[i] := SysAddAtomUpperA(aRdds[i]) NEXT lRet := VODBUseArea(TRUE, rddList, cDBF, "", TRUE, FALSE) MemFree(rddList) RETURN lRet

vodbzap.summary: Remove all records from open files.
vodbzap.remarks: VODBZap() is the same as DBZap(). This function, however, does not call the error handler and will not, therefore, produce a runtime error message or create an error object if it fails. Thus, it may be important to check the return value to determine if the function succeeded. The global structure, StrucErrInfo, will contain needed information regarding any error that occurs. See DBZap() for more information.
vodbzap.example:
This example demonstrates a typical zap operation:
USE sales EXCLUSIVE NEW IF !NetErr() SET INDEX TO sales, branch, salesman IF VODBZap() ? "Zapped OK" ELSE ? "Error detected during zap" ENDIF CLOSE sales ELSE ? "Error detected when opening the file" ENDIF

vosendmessage.summary: Send the specified message to the specified window.
vosendmessage.param: Handle of the window to which the message is being sent.
Windows API message constant representing the message to send to the window.
vosendmessage.returns: LONGINT return value, dependent upon the message sent.
vosendmessage.remarks: This is a garbage collector-safe version of the Windows API SendMessage() function. If a Windows message involves a PSZ as one of the message parameters and you pass a regular string to SendMessage(), there is a potential problem with the X# garbage collection. By using VOSendMessage() for messages involving dynamic X# data types, this problem can be avoided. Note: Refer to the Windows API for further information on the SendMessage() function, messages, parameters and return values.

w2bin.summary: Convert a word to a string containing a 16-bit unsigned integer.
w2bin.param: The value to convert. Decimal values are truncated.
w2bin.remarks: W2Bin() is a conversion function that converts a word into a 2-byte string. Typical applications include reading foreign file types in their native format and then saving, reading, decrypting, and transmitting numeric data in their compressed binary form instead of in strings. Its inverse is Bin2W().
w2bin.example:
This example uses W2Bin() to store the current procedure line to a debugging file:
FUNCTION ErrorLines() AS LOGIC LOCAL nh LOCAL lSuccess := FALSE AS LOGIC nh := FOpen2("data.bin", FO_READWRITE) // Assumes that file debug.bin already exists IF nh != F_ERROR FWrite(nh, W2Bin(ProcLine())) FWrite(nh, W2Bin(ProcLine(1))) FClose(nh) lSuccess := TRUE ELSE ? "An error occurred when opening debug.bin" FError() ENDIF RETURN lSuccess

workdir.summary: Return the currently selected working directory.
workdir.remarks:
The working directory is where the associated .EXE file resides and was executed from. The .EXE file is either CAVO2x.EXE or your linked application's .EXE, as appropriate.
This example uses the WorkDir() function to get the current directory before setting a new one:
LOCAL cWorkDir AS STRING cWorkDir := WorkDir() SetDefault(cWorkDir + "samples\debug")

year.summary: Extract the number of the year from a date.
year.returns: The year of <dDate>, including the century digits, as a 4-digit number. The value returned is not affected by SetDateFormat(), SetCentury(), SET DATE, or SET CENTURY. Specifying a NULL_DATE returns 0.
year.remarks: Year() is a date conversion function that converts a date value to a numeric year value. If the century digits are not specified, the century is determined by the rules of SET EPOCH or SetEpoch(). Year() is a member of a group of functions that return components of a date value as numbers. The group includes Day() and Month(), which return the day and month values as numbers.
year.example:
These examples illustrate Year() using the system date:
? TODAY() // 09/20/90 ? YEAR(TODAY()) // 1990 ? YEAR(TODAY()) + 11 // 2001 ? YEAR(05.15.64) // 1964 SetEpoch(2000) ? YEAR(CTOD("05.15.64")) // 2064
This example creates a function using Year() to format a date value in the form month, day, year:
? Mdy(TODAY()) // September 20, 1990 FUNCTION Mdy(dDate) RETURN CMONTH(dDate) + " " + ; NTrim(DAY(dDate)) ; + "," + STR(YEAR(dDate))

_accept.summary: Take input from the keyboard and assign it to a memory variable.
_accept.param: An optional prompt displayed before the input area.
The variable that will hold input from the keyboard. If there is no variable named <idVar> that is visible to the current routine, a private variable is created.
_accept.remarks: When _Accept is executed, it first performs a carriage return/linefeed, displays the prompt in the terminal window, and begins taking characters from the keyboard at the position immediately following the prompt. Up to 255 characters can be entered. When input reaches the edge of the window, as defined by MaxCol(), the cursor moves to the next line. _Accept supports only two editing keys: Backspace and Enter (Esc is not supported). Backspace deletes the last character typed. Enter confirms entry and is the only key that can terminate an _Accept. If Enter is the only key pressed, _Accept assigns a NULL_STRING to <cVar>.
_accept.example:
This example uses ACCEPT to get keyboard input from the user:
LOCAL cVar AS STRING cVar := _Accept("Enter a value: " ) IF cVar = NULL_STRING ? "User pressed Enter" ELSE ? "User input:", cVar ENDIF
Terminal Lite

_debout32.summary: Write information to the Debug Terminal Program
_debout32.param: PSZ text that gets written to the Debug Terminal Program
_debout32.remarks: _DebOut32() helps when debugging X# applications. It uses the same mechanism as the Operating Systems OutPutDebugString() functions. To see the output you need to run a special program that intercepts this output. You can download such a program from http://www.sysinternals.com

_dyncheck.returns: TRUE means that dynamic memory is not corrupted. FALSE means that dynamic memory is corrupted.
_dyncheck.remarks: This function is useful if you are manipulating dynamic memory directly with functions such as RegisterKid(). It can help you determine where in your application dynamic memory corruption occurred. Care must be taken using this function. Some dynamic memory errors can cause immediate termination of the application due to the nature of the detected error.
_dyncheck.example:
The following example displays a message based on the return value of _DynCheck():
IF _DynCheck() ? "Dynamic memory ok." ELSE ? "Dynamic memory corrupted." ENDIF

_getcmdline.summary: Return a pointer to the command line used to invoke the application.

_getcmdshow.summary: Return a constant specifying how the application window is shown.
_getcmdshow.returns: One of the following constants indicating the status of the window: Constant Meaning SW_HIDE The window is hidden and another window activated SW_MINIMIZE The window is minimized and the top-level window in the system's list is activated SW_RESTORE Window is activated and displayed — if minimized or maximized, Windows restores it to its original size and position (same as SW_SHOWNORMAL). SW_SHOW Window is activated and displayed in its current size and position SW_SHOWMAXIMIZED Window is activated and displayed as maximized SW_SHOWMINIMIZED Window is activated and displayed as an icon SW_SHOWMINNOACTIVE Window is displayed as an icon, leaving the currently active window active SW_SHOWNA Window is displayed in its current state, leaving the currently active window active SW_SHOWNOACTIVATE Window is displayed in its most recent size and position, leaving the currently active window active SW_SHOWNORMAL Window is activated and displayed — if minimized or maximized, Windows restores it to its original size and position (same as SW_RESTORE).

_getfirstparam.summary: Access the first parameter in a variable parameter list.
_getfirstparam.param: The anonymous pointer variable local to the calling function which will serve as an address to the list of variable parameters.
The address of a fixed parameter variable in the parameter list of the calling function.
Specifies the type of the above fixed parameter.
Specifies the type of the actual parameter to be accessed.
_getfirstparam.returns: The value (USUAL) of the type specified for <dwType>.
_getfirstparam.remarks: This special function is used in conjunction with _GetNextParam() for accessing the variable parameters within functions defined to access a variable parameter list.
_getfirstparam.example:
The following example illustrates the implementation of a function accepting a variable number of parameters:
FUNCTION CFunc(dummy:=1 AS INT, dwNumber AS INT, ... ); AS VOID STRICT LOCAL xParam AS USUAL LOCAL i AS DWORD LOCAL pParam AS PTR LOCAL cString AS STRING xParam := _GetFirstParam(@pParam, @dwNumber, INT,; STRING) ? dwNumber ? xParam FOR i := 2 UPTO dwNumber xParam := _GetNextParam(@pParam, STRING) ? xParam NEXT RETURN FUNCTION Start CFunc(,1, "How") CFunc(,2, "How ", "are ") CFunc(,3, "How ", "are ", "you ")

_getinst.summary: Return the instance handle of an application or DLL.
_getinst.remarks: The instance handle is assigned by Windows to the application or DLL and is needed for low-level Windows system programming.

_getnextparam.summary: Access the remaining parameters in a variable parameter list.
_getnextparam.param: Anonymous pointer obtained by a previous call to _GetFirstParam() or _GetNextParam().
Specifies the type of the actual parameter to be accessed.
_getnextparam.returns: The value (USUAL) of the type specified for <dwType>.
_getnextparam.remarks: This special function is used in conjunction with _GetFirstParam() for accessing the variable parameters within functions defined to access a variable parameter list.

_getprevinst.summary:
NOTE: This is not supported in 32 bit applications. The function is kept for backward compatibility, but always returns a NULL_PTR.
Return the previous instance handle of an application or DLL.

remarks.note: For a Windows 3.2 application or DLL, the previous instance handle is always NULL.

_registerexit.summary: Register an exit routine to be called when the current application ends.
_registerexit.param: A pointer to the function or procedure to register as an exit routine.
_registerexit.remarks: The registered routine will be called when the application ends, regardless of whether the termination was normal or the result of an error. A maximum number of 64 routines can be registered as exit routines, but the order of execution cannot be controlled by the application. The exit routines may be executed in any order, regardless of the order in which you register them. Note: The PROCEDURE statement can be used to declare initialization routines.
_registerexit.example:
The following example displays a message box before the current application is terminated:
FUNCTION Start() ... _RegisterExit(@MyExitFunc()) ... FUNCTION MyExitFunc() MessageBox(0, "App over", "Exit", MB_OK)

_voloadlibrary.summary: To safely use a .Dll that was created in X#.
_voloadlibrary.param: The name of a variable expressed as a literal identifier.
_voloadlibrary.remarks: When a .Dll is created in X#, it will almost always call on the runtime library. It is possible that the .Dll you are trying to load will be calling the old version of the runtime (CAVORT20.DLL) into memory and this needs to be avoided. Using _VOLoadLibrary( ) to load the .Dll will allow the system to check to see that the old runtime (CAVORT20.DLL) is not being brought into memory and will generate an error if it is. If the old runtime is detected the runtime will first call the error handler and then terminate the application because having two runtimes in memory would cause all sorts of problems.

_wait.summary: Display a prompt after sending a carriage return/linefeed to the terminal window, then wait for a key to be pressed. Note: WAIT is a compatibility command and is no longer recommended.
_wait.param: An optional prompt displayed before the input area. If omitted, "Press any key to continue..." is displayed. Specify NULL_STRING if you do not want to display a prompt.

The variable that will hold input from the keyboard. If there is no variable named <idVar> that is visible to the current routine, a private variable is created. <idVar> is assigned the keystroke as a string. If an Alt or Ctrl key combination is pressed, WAIT assigns Chr(0) to <idVar>.
Non-alphanumeric values entered by pressing an Alt+key combination assign the specified character. If the character can be displayed, it is echoed to the screen.

uAreaValue.span: Specifies the work area name or number for a table from which the value must be retrieved.

uAreaOperation.span: Specifies the work area name or number for a table on which the operation must be performed.

currentWorkareaParam.span: By default, this function operates on the currently selected work area. It can be made to operate on an unselected work area by specifying it within an aliased expression or by calling the overload that accepts a workarea parameter (a workarea number or alias ).

currentWorkarea.span: By default, this function operates on the currently selected work area. It can be made to operate on an unselected work area by specifying it within an aliased expression

cbwhile.span:
A code block that defines another condition that each record must meet in order to be processed. As soon as a record is encountered that causes the condition to fail, the operation terminates.
If no scope is specified, <cbWhileCondition> changes the default scope to <lRest>.
You define the scope using one of these three, mutually exclusive arguments. The default is all records.

cbfor.span: A code block that defines a condition that each record within the scope must meet in order to be processed.

span.note: The <nNext>, <nRecord>, and <lRest> arguments are mutually exclusive. You should not pass all three of them. And if you pass the <cbWhile> argument then this also controls the scope behavior.
